HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Tender Witness to the Togetherness of People in Want

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
Socially engaged, humanistic photography has a long and densely textured history in the United States, one marked by a constant tension between objectivity and empathy, idea and sentiment, the polemical urge and the personal touch.
The artist Walter Rosenblum, 78, holds a distinguished if still under-valued place in that tradition. In a sense, he was born into it. The child of Romanian Jewish immigrants, he was raised on Manhattan's Lower East Side, at the corner of Clinton and Rivington Streets, during the Depression. He was introduced to photography as a teen-ager at a local Boys Club, and in 1937 he joined the politically progressive Photo League, a largely volunteer organization that sponsored workshops, lectures and classes. 
 There he met two extraordinary figures who became his teachers and his friends. One was Lewis Hine (1874-1940), the sociologist turned photographer who had been using the camera to document the lives of immigrants and workers since 1905. The other was the pioneering modernist Paul Strand (1890-1976).
From each Mr. Rosenblum took different things. Hine's pictures offered a model of photography as a democratic, socially responsive, reformist tool, with quotidian life as its subject. Strand's work, exhilaratingly experimental, suggested the medium's tremendous formal potential. Mr. Rosenblum integrated the example of both artists into the succession of memorable photo essays he created between the 1930's and the 1980's.
A sampling of that work is on view in "Walter Rosenblum, Photographs: A Retrospective Exhibition" at the Godwin-Ternbach Museum at Queens College in Flushing. The show of 70 images, organized by Jerald R. Green, represents small selections from eight of Mr. Rosenblum's major series. But it captures the essence of a life's work, giving a sense both of the consistency of an artist's vision and of how his thoughts about his medium developed over time.
Early on, Mr. Rosenblum produced work of startling maturity. Working under the nurturing eye of Sid Grossman, the director of the Photo League school, he shot his "Pitt Street" series over six months in 1938, when he was only 19. Here he stuck close to a subject he knew intimately: daily life in a tenement neighborhood tucked within the shadow of the Williamsburg Bridge.
These images, about a dozen of which are included in the exhibition, make no effort to disguise the hardships experienced by the blacks, Jews and European Gypsies who made the area their home. But in almost every case the emphasis is on community rather than on misery, on a hard-won emotional amplitude rather than on oppression.
In one picture, neighborhood women with strollers gather to chat outside a rubble-strewn lot; in another, a little girl plays alone on a swing; in a third, Gypsy children sit on a stoop absorbed in a card game. The vignettes are straightforward, but each is warmed by suggestive details. Behind the women a line of immaculate white laundry hangs like a row of guardian angels; the high trajectory of the swinging girl is echoed in the soaring lines of the bridge behind her, and the faces of the children playing cards seem gilded, even in black and white, by late-day sunlight.
A few years later, Mr. Rosenblum was in Europe. As a photographer with the United States Army during World War II, he recorded thelanding in Normandy in 1944, and was the first Allied photographer to enter the concentration camp at Dachau after its liberation. When the war was over he stayed in Europe to work for the Unitarian Service Committee photographing Spanish Civil War refugees living in southern France.
A few of his combat pictures are in the show, but they are outnumbered by images of civilians -- mourners at a military funeral in France, flag-waving crowds on fire escapes at a New York block party, Spanish children in hospitals and camps. In all these photographs, ordinary people are seen reacting, often with unself-conscious stoicism, to the forces shaping their destinies.
Such influences are given a particularly incisive visual embodiment in the "Spanish Refugee" series, which is unique, at least in the Queens College show, for being shot almost entirely indoors. Picture after picture has a shut-in, humid, underground look, with faces and figures seeming to loom out of semidarkness into the camera's eye.
In contrast to these ashen, claustrophobic images, those he produced a few years later of fishing villages in the Gaspe Peninsula in Quebec are buoyant with light and air. Nature is the real subject here, seen in sweeps of sea and sky, and a hardscrabble coastal landscape shared by people and animals.
Yet, despite dramatic differences in atmosphere and subject, the two series have essential elements in common, as seen in a simple comparison. A Spanish woman sitting erect with her grandchild in her lap in a refugee camp in France and an elderly French Canadian widow staring, alert as a bird, straight into the camera, may have lived an ocean apart, but they are both, in the photographer's eye, unassuming cultural emblems of endurance.
Almost a decade later, Mr. Rosenblum worked again outside the United States when, on a sabbatical from his job at Brooklyn College (where taught photography from 1947 to 1986) he traveled to Haiti. He stayed there for 10 months, immersing himself in the spirit of the place, a practice he had followed since the "Pitt Street" series.
The show offers 13 of his 90 some pictures from Haiti. And whether they are shots of a domestic altar in a thatch-roof house, an exhausted woman leaning against a veranda pole or the island landscape, almost preposterously gorgeous with its lush hills and piled-up clouds, the tone is one of restrained, level-eyed observation, never prosaic or overtly poetic but somewhere in between.
The same is true of his several New York City series, among them one made in the neighborhood around 105th Street in East Harlem in 1952 and another in the South Bronx in 1980. A handful of the East Harlem images -- three confident young men posed before a graffiti-covered wall, a child playing hopscotch in the street, a girl smiling shyly from an open window -- are much-exhibited classics. The Bronx pictures, taken nearly 30 years later, are tougher, jumpier, more varied, less lyrical, but every bit as engaged and, like all of this artist's work, determinedly hopeful.
Mr. Rosenblum has said that he chose East Harlem as a subject in the 1950's because he was convinced of the vital role that the growing Latino population would play in the country's future. And he chose to spend time in the South Bronx in 1980 because he felt that its community, then at the nadir of its economic fortunes, was being unjustly blamed for its travails.
That he called upon art as a persuasive means of stating his convictions is admirable. That the art he created is one of formal beauty and expressive power and tenderness will be apparent to anyone visiting the Queens College show. It is worth noting, incidently, that on Monday, Mr. Rosenblum, along with his wife, the photo-historian Naomi Rosenblum, will be given a lifetime achievement award by the International Center of Photography. The honor is richly deserved.
"Walter Rosenblum, Photographs: A Retrospective Exhibition" remains at the Godwin-Ternbach Museum, Paul Klapper Hall, Queens College, Flushing, through May 28.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Walter Rosenblum's "Hopscotch" (1952), from a retrospective of his photographs at Queens College. (Walter Rosenblum); Gilded faces: Large detail of "Gypsy Children Playing Cards" (1938), from Walter Rosenblum's "Pitt Street" series, shot when he was 19. (Walter Rosenblum)

HEADLINE: U.S. Pressing European Union to Be More Friendly to Turkey

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, April 30

 BODY:
Senior diplomats from the United States are engaged in an intense effort to persuade the European Union to adopt a more conciliatory policy toward Turkey, diplomats involved in the effort say.
The diplomats said Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright had made a series of telephone calls to her European counterparts in recent days, urging them to soften their attitude toward Turkey. Among those whom she has called are Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine of France, Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of Germany and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain. 
 The effort is growing as an American mediator, Richard C. Holbrooke, is about to visit Cyprus for a new round of talks with Greek and Turkish Cypriot leaders. His visit to the island four weeks ago ended without visible progress, in part because Turkish Cypriots and their patrons in Ankara were angry at the way the European Union was treating Turkey's application for membership.
Ms. Albright reportedly made some progress in her calls, but also found that fierce anti-Turkish sentiment in Greece and the national election campaign in Germany were major obstacles to changing the European Union position on Turkey.
Greece is Turkey's principal rival in Europe, and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany is facing an uphill fight for re-election. He does not want to be seen as supporting steps that could bring more Turkish immigrants to Germany, which is already home to the world's largest Turkish immigrant community.
"This Turkey question is probably the most serious disagreement we have with Germany," said a State Department official who has worked closely with German leaders.
At a summit meeting in December in Luxembourg, leaders of European Union countries decided to proceed quickly with talks aimed at admitting six additional countries and to place five others on a waiting list. The 12th applicant, Turkey, was effectively rejected.
That set off a storm of protest in Turkey, highlighted by emotional denunciations of Europe and suggestions that Turkey should look for friends elsewhere. American leaders, including President Clinton, criticized the European decision and urged that Turkey not be made to feel unwelcome in the West.
After the Luxembourg meeting, Turkish leaders took a series of retaliatory measures, including asking their Turkish Cypriot clients to stiffen their negotiating stance in long-stalled talks with Greek Cypriots. Mr. Holbrooke said after his latest visit to Cyprus that Turkish Cypriots were refusing to consider serious compromises as long as Europe treated Turkey in a manner that they considered unfair. He is scheduled to return to the island on Saturday.
The next European Union summit meeting is set for June in Cardiff, Wales.
American diplomats across the continent have been instructed to urge European leaders to issue a new statement in Cardiff declaring their desire for better ties with Turkey.
"We are now engaged in a full-court press to get the E.U. to ease up on Turkey, to make the Turks feel more welcome in Europe," said a United States diplomat involved in the effort. "There are intense negotiations going on aimed at getting the E.U. to improve the terms of its offer.
"The European countries have accused us of not understanding their problems. We do recognize that it will be a long time before Turkey is ready to join."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Shoppers Are Starting to See Lower Prices on Asian Goods

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
The signals may be small -- a pink T-shirt here, a baby's rattle there -- but shoppers are starting to see price savings in a number of goods as a result of the protracted financial crisis in Asia.
While the overall Consumer Price Index was flat in March, indicating the absence of any general inflation or deflation, prices in several categories of merchandise, many of which are produced in Asia, have fallen over the last several months. 
 Some manufacturers that have their goods assembled in Asia appear to be keeping cost savings to themselves, leaving retail companies and consumers alike frozen out of any boon. Still, shoppers are starting to enjoy savings in a variety of products, in some cases dramatically. Retail prices of toys, on average, fell 3.3 percent between March 1997 and this March, compared with a 4 percent rise at the beginning of 1997, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which compiles the index.
Leading the way were video games and baby toys like crib mobiles and rattles, where prices fell as much as 20 percent in some cities last month.
Prices of clothes have dropped, especially those for infants and women. Apparel prices, after being on the rise through much of 1997, are now back to where they were a year ago.
The collapse of currencies throughout much of Asia means that the dollar buys much more in countries producing everything from mascara wands to Barbie dolls, from department store sweaters to athletic shoes. And the economic weakness there translates into desperate manufacturers willing to cut prices in order to unload goods that otherwise would go unsold.
Combined with a drop in oil prices and pressure on domestic manufacturers to keep prices down, Americans are enjoying bargain basement deals even as their nominal incomes are now rising at roughly 7 percent a year. Just yesterday, the Commerce Department's report on the nation's economic performance in the first quarter showed that inflation, at least for now, had essentially vanished. Indeed, the domestic purchases deflator -- which tracks prices paid by consumers for goods sold in the United States, both imported and American-made -- actually fell one-tenth of a percent, the first time that has happened since 1959, when Dwight D. Eisenhower was President.
"The American consumer has more spending power," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "Between the strong dollar and the collapse in Asian currencies and the fact that oil prices are coming down so our heating bills are down, we can buy more goods than we used to."
While few shoppers looking for a break on the latest Gucci pump are likely to find one, those who frequent lower-priced or midpriced stores should see bigger bargains. Lower-end stores tend to buy more products from Asia, and have the most clout with their suppliers. Analysts believe that companies like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. will lead the way with price cuts. The company declined to comment.
Stores that do a lot of their own private-label business in Asia have also benefited from the region's woes, although in many cases any gains are offset by the instability of suppliers, some of whom may not stay afloat. And Asian suppliers who buy their raw materials outside their country are being hammered by the currency ills, raising their costs.
But the savings to consumers are clearly beginning to trickle in. "We expect to receive price concessions from our existing overseas manufacturers, allowing us to pass on savings to our customers," said Terry J. Lundgren, president of Federated Department Stores Inc.'s merchandising unit. Federated owns Macy's and Bloomingdale's, as well as other department store chains.
In the consumer electronics business, which has also shown modest price decreases, retailers say that most of the price cuts are in products that have simply lost value with age. Nintendo 64, for example, sold for $249 at Toys "R" Us when it first came out; it can now be purchased for half that price.
The Import Price Index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that prices of imported toys and various other electronic goods fell last month. Indeed, between March 1997 and March 1998, import prices of consumer goods (excluding autos) fell nine-tenths of a percent. "There is a strong correlation between price deflation and deflation in import prices," said Edward Yardeni, an economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in New York.
In some cases, while prices may not be falling, retailers are trying to beef up what they are getting for their money. "There are some opportunities for lower costs," said Susan Eich, a spokeswoman for the Dayton Hudson Corporation, "and we are using that to improve and upgrade quality." Some furniture sold at the company's Target discount stores, for instance, will now have extra features for the same price, she said.
Of course, retailers, especially of things like computers and televisions, where margins are razor thin, would love to bolster their balance sheets with these savings. But with rare exception this will not be possible.
Most of the savings are occurring among routine commodity items, where competition is stiff and price is the main draw. "Retailers are so competitive," Mr. Glassman said, "that if one company gives consumers an edge, everyone else is forced to do it."
A hot brand can occasionally buck the tide, though.
"Hasbro's Star Wars action figures, which are assembled in Asia, went from $3.99 to $4.99," said Vincent Hester, the owner of Toys For All, a small toy store in Houston. "Mattel's Hot Wheels cars went from 79 cents to 89 cents, and I know those are all assembled in Asia or India. If prices are coming down, the companies manufacturing are making more money. The independent stores aren't seeing any price cuts."
Sean Fitzgerald, a spokesman for Mattel Inc., conceded that the cost of producing Hot Wheels cars, which are made in Malaysia, has fallen even as Mattel has raised wholesale prices, thus gaining an extra profit cushion. "But this is in the short term," he said. "The Asia situation is constantly fluctuating and changing daily."
Executives of Hasbro Inc. said that because all their Asian sourcing is done through China, where the currency has remained relatively stable, they have not gained ground. "We have not seen any appreciable benefit," said John T. O'Neill, the chief financial officer of Hasbro.
"The importers like Mattel have a choice," said Steve Radelet, an economist at Harvard University's Institute for International Development. "They can get stuff produced cheaper, but the extent to which they will cushion their own margins will differ from market to market."
While several retailers said they had yet to experience any of the price declines recorded by the statisticians at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, many economists said another wave of low-priced goods was about to hit. "We have seen a lot of stories about how Asia doesn't matter," Mr. Yardeni said. "But by the end of the year, a flood of imports will lead to a windfall for consumers."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Favorable Government Data Spur a Treasury Securities Rally

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
After declining all week on fear of an overheating economy and higher interest rates, Treasury securities surged yesterday for their biggest rally in six months, reacting to Government data showing surprisingly low inflation.
The relief in the bond market reflected greatly diminished expectations that the Federal Reserve is now inclined to raise interest rates to thwart inflationary pressure. Fear that the central bank would take such a step had been coursing through the market since Monday, when The Wall Street Journal reported that Fed policy makers favored raising rates. 
 Traders snapped up the Treasury's 30-year bond, sending it up 1 24/32, to 102 16/32 , the biggest one-day price gain since Oct. 27, when tumbling stocks caused an investor exodus into bonds. The 30-year bond's yield, which falls when prices rise, dropped to 5.94 percent, from 6.07 percent Wednesday and the lowest since April 21.
The catalysts for the bond rally, which sent stocks up sharply, were reports from the Labor and Commerce Departments that portrayed a strong economy with remarkably low inflationary pressures.
The Labor Department's Employment Cost Index rose seven-tenths of a percent in the first quarter, less than the nine-tenths expected. The Commerce Department's preliminary first-quarter gross domestic product figures, the first glimpse of how fast the economy grew from January through March, showed a strong 4.2 percent annual rate. Even so, the inflation component rose at only nine-tenths of a percent, the smallest increase in 34 years.
"Talk of rate increases over the past few days may prove to be just rumors now," said Roger Hamilton, vice president and portfolio manager for the John Hancock Funds in Boston. "Without ammunition, it's safe to assume the Fed will hold off on tightening and will not raise rates this time around. I suspect the bond market will rally over the next few days in light of the good news."
Analysts said the National Association of Purchasing Management's monthly report due today and next week's April employment data would provide the next important insights into the economy's pace. Many said they see the yield on the long bond confined to a range around 6 percent over the near term.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Green at Derby Gate: Fewer Starts for the Starters

BYLINE: By JAY PRIVMAN 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 30

 BODY:
When Indian Charlie, the morning-line favorite, enters the starting gate for the 124th Kentucky Derby on Saturday, he will be attempting to become the first horse in 83 years to win with no more than four career starts.
Not since the filly Regret, in 1915, has such a lightly raced horse been able to capture this demanding mile-and-one-quarter race, which now includes the distraction of having to run in front of more than 130,000 screaming fans at Churchill Downs. 
 This year, an added hurdle looms in the possibility of an off track from persistent rain.
But despite the potential liabilities of inexperience, the trend over the past four decades has been for 3-year-olds to have fewer starts leading up to the Derby. Of the 13 horses in the 1960 Kentucky Derby, the average number of pre-Derby starts was nearly 21. Cuvier Relic and Tony Graff, the most experienced horses, had run a demanding 39 times while the least-experienced horses, Divine Comedy and Henrijan, had run 12 times.
This year, only two horses -- Nationalore and Real Quiet -- have raced as many as 12 times. The 15 horses entered in Saturday's Derby average a mere 8.4 starts.
And no horse in the race has less experience than Indian Charlie, who has run four times and is undefeated, including a victory in the Santa Anita Derby.
There is contention within the racing industry as to why this trend has developed. Trainers and veterinarians said the reason is twofold -- horses are more fragile these days, and modern medical technology enables the animal's caretakers to spot small problems and curtail training before a larger problem emerges.
"I think we're breeding a weaker horse today," said Dr. Alex Harthill, a prominent Kentucky veterinarian. Harthill has helped care for more than 20 Derby winners, beginning with Citation in 1948, and is treating, among others, Cape Town this week.
"People also are learning to stop more at the first sign of swelling or puffiness," Harthill added. "A lot of people in olden times would say, 'That's all right, put some ice on it.' Now, you have X-rays and ultrasound. It's a big help to find things that otherwise might be hidden."
Commercial breeders contend that horses are as strong as ever but that the demands of year-round racing, coupled with lucrative prize money, force a trainer to push young animals. All three Triple Crown races -- the Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the Belmont Stakes -- have $1 million purses.
And the Derby prep races include such lucrative spots as the $750,000 Santa Anita Derby, $700,000 Blue Grass Stakes, $600,000 Jim Beam Stakes, and the Wood Memorial and Arkansas Derby, each worth $500,000.
"I personally don't believe we're breeding a less-sound horse," said Dan Rosenberg, the general manager of Three Chimneys Farm. Three Chimneys, situated 60 miles east of Louisville in Versailles, Ky., is one of this country's elite breeding farms. Its stallion roster includes such prized studs as Seattle Slew, his son Slew o' Gold, Rahy and Wild Again.
"It's a different economy," Rosenberg added. "There are bigger purses for 2-year-olds. There's more incentive to push early."
To be sure, American racing and, in lockstep, breeding have changed dramatically in the past 40 years.
The Kentucky Derby distance of a mile and one-quarter is still considered the truest test in American racing, but fewer other races are run at that distance, and fewer still at longer distances.
New York's premier distance race in the fall championship season, the Jockey Club Gold Cup, was a demanding two miles when it began in 1921. It was shortened to a mile and one-half in 1976, then to its current mile and one-quarter in 1990. The trend toward shorter races has fueled a breeding market seeking to satisfy that niche.
"We're breeding for brilliance, so we end up with very fast horses who don't stay sound," said Randy Bradshaw, who trains Derby entrant Artax. "It's the nature of the beast. We're asking these horses to go 35 miles an hour on ankles that are no bigger than our wrist. If you put too much pressure on them, they unravel."
It was not always so. Carry Back, the 1961 Derby winner, had made 28 starts before his date with destiny. Not until 1981 did the average number of starts by Derby entrants dip below 10.
Since 1985, however, the average number of starts for Derby runners never has been more than 10, and only twice has it been more than 9. In the last four years, the Derby winner has averaged slightly more than seven starts. By current standards, Indian Charlie's lack of experience is not as glaring.
"He doesn't need more seasoning," said Bob Baffert, the trainer of Indian Charlie. "It's not like we're going to eat the son of a gun."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Major Indexes Soar in Response to Benign Inflation News

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Major stock indexes soared yesterday, posting gains for the second consecutive day, after the latest economic data largely erased investor fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon.
Buyers leaped into the equity market on news of the Employment Cost Index and the gross domestic product, which signaled that inflation remained benign despite a strong pace of economic growth. 
 The surge in stocks was echoed in the bond market, where prices surged and yields fell.
Earlier in the week, stocks and bonds had fallen sharply on concerns that the Federal Reserve was set to increase interest rates to curb inflation pressure spurred by strong economic growth.
Yesterday, the Labor Department said employment costs for American businesses rose at a slower than expected pace during the first quarter, as shown by a seven-tenths of a percent rise in the Employment Cost Index. It was the smallest quarterly rise in the index, which is viewed as a broad measure of wage, salary and benefit costs, in two years.
In addition, the Commerce Department reported a 4.2 percent increase in the first-quarter gross domestic product, but that gain was tempered by a modest nine-tenths of a percent rise in a key inflation indicator, the price deflator. The gain was the smallest increase since 1964.
Stocks that perform well in a low- interest-rate environment rose, notably financial services concerns, including BankAmerica, Citicorp and Travelers Group. Drug companies and telecommunication stocks also led the gainers.
The reports "really confirmed that inflation is not a problem," said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York, adding, "It was the shot in the arm the market needed."
"People were concerned that inflation would be just around the corner, but labor prices accelerated at a slower pace than expected," he said. "In the near term, I can't see the Fed doing anything for the next two to three months."
The data as well as relatively strong first-quarter earnings reports reaffirmed the positive economic outlook of the Bryn Mawr Trust Company, said Richard Sichel, chief investment officer at the firm. Last week, the firm increased its equity allocation to 91 percent, reducing cash to 9 percent from 15 percent, Mr. Sichel said.
"Inflation is very, very benign and we are optimistic about the fundamentals of the economy," Mr. Sichel said. The newly invested cash was used in part to buy additional shares of drug stocks, like Merck and Bristol-Myers Squibb, as well as BankAmerica and Chase Manhattan and technology shares like Intel and Lucent Technologies, he said.
But some analysts expressed caution regarding the resumed ebullience.
"Backward looking, things are fine," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at the Nikko Securities Company International Inc.
But, he said, "the unmistakable trend is that inflation is accelerating for benefits and wages." He added: "It's still a bad trend and the market's going to have to deal with this reality further down the road.
"It's like your kid getting all A's on his tests, but refusing to study. You don't think it will last when the work gets harder."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 9,063.37, up 111.85 points, or 1.25 percent, erasing the vestiges of its 146.98-point tumble Monday.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 17.12 points, or 1.56 percent, to 1,111.75.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 16.77 points, to 1,868.41
In the current environment, Mr. Bond said he was focusing less on stock valuations, and instead looking at the growth prospects for individual issues.
He said he favors financial services stocks and drug companies, as well as some of the large, multinational companies that pulled back in the recent downturn, such as Coca-Cola, General Electric, Intel and Microsoft.
"If you get too cute with valuations, you could miss a big move" in stock prices, he said. Internet-related shares, for example, are a good illustration of the trend, where valuations are high, but investors continue to buy shares in the belief they represent growth opportunities, he said.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is 'Encouraged' by Iraqi Progress on Arms Inspections

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he was encouraged by Iraqi cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors and that he expected to reduce the number of American troops who are now deployed in the Persian Gulf region to keep watch on Iraq.
The President's remarks about Iraq were more conciliatory than those heard from other Administration officials in recent weeks, although Mr. Clinton appeared once again to rule out an early end to international sanctions that were imposed on Iraq after it invaded Kuwait in 1990. 
 "We are encouraged by the level of compliance so far with the U.N. inspections and by the evidence that has been adduced on the nuclear side that more progress has been made," Mr. Clinton said at a White House news conference.
Under threat of an American-led military attack earlier this year, the Government of President Saddam Hussein has allowed greater access to United Nations arms inspectors seeking evidence that Iraq has stockpiled chemical, biological or nuclear weapons.
On Monday, the United Nations Security Council decided to extend sanctions against Iraq after inspectors reported that Iraq had a long way to go in accounting for chemical and biological arms.
Still, Mr. Clinton said there was good news in Baghdad's cooperation with inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency, an arm of the United Nations that polices nations for evidence that they are developing nuclear weapons.
The agency is close to declaring Iraq free of nuclear arms, an action that could allow Baghdad to avoid intrusive inspections of its nuclear programs in the future. In a report this month, the agency said its inspections had found no evidence "of prohibited equipment or materials."
Mr. Clinton said that "if Baghdad will continue to work with us," the United Nations could move by October to reduce the severity of the nuclear monitoring. "This is just the nuclear piece, but I am encouraged by that," he said.
The President's remarks will doubtless raise concern among arms control experts who have accused the Atomic Energy Agency of complacency and have said Iraq's record of deception and its wealth of talented scientists suggest that it could quickly recreate an atomic program once rigorous inspections end.
Mr. Clinton said he would wait for a Pentagon recommendation before removing any of the vast American military force that is now patrolling the Persian Gulf region. The force includes two aircraft carriers and more than 300 warplanes.
But he added, "Inevitably, unless we believe there is some reason for it to be there, at some point in the future I would anticipate some reallocation of our resources."
In response to other questions on foreign policy, the President rejected suggestions that the United States should lift its economic embargo on Cuba or allow the Government of Fidel Castro to be reinstated in the Organization of American States.
"To open up the O.A.S. or the Summit of the Americas process to a non-democratic nation, in my view, would be a big mistake," he said.
"This country stands for freedom and democracy," he continued. "We're fighting like crazy to preserve it in countries where it is very difficult to do so, where people literally put their lives on the line every day for freedom. And when people are out there risking their lives, we ought not to send the wrong signal."
Cuba was suspended from the Organization of American States in 1961, two years after Mr. Castro came to power.
Mr. Clinton said the embargo had "been useful, but I also believe that we should do more to minimize the damage to the Cuban people, which is why after the Pope's visit, I relaxed a lot of the restrictions on the transfer of food and medicine and on travel there." Pope John Paul II visited Cuba in January.

HEADLINE: Gang Rape of Three Girls Leaves Fresno Shaken, and Questioning

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: FRESNO, Calif., April 27

 BODY:
On the edge of this working-class city, along a highway not far from the vineyards and the strawberry and cotton fields on some of the richest farmland in the nation, as many as 20 men and boys crowded into a motel room three weeks ago for what the police said was a night of rape.
One by one, they repeatedly assaulted a 12-year-old girl and two 13-year-old girls, who the police said had walked into the motel room thinking they were going to get a ride home from a friend of a friend. 
 What happened on the night of April 6 has shaken many people in this central California city of 450,000 residents. But Fresno lost its small-town innocence years ago, in what the current Mayor, Jim Patterson, called an explosion of crime.
Some residents nicknamed Fresno "Little L.A.," but in the last few years, the crime rate is down, more officers are on patrol and people have been strolling the streets with a renewed confidence. Then three girls walked into room 115 at the Motel 6 on North Parkway Drive.
"Everybody is hurt by this," said Mayor Patterson. "This is one of those God-awful things that could stigmatize a community."
The authorities kept the attack quiet for two weeks while they investigated and tracked down suspects. But over the last several days, as the arrests began, the assault has been front page news here. Last Friday, a 24-year-old man was picked up at his home and a teen-ager was taken into custody at his high school, bringing the total under arrest in the attack to five adults, the oldest 31, and seven juveniles. The police are hunting for three to five more suspects.
The girls and their families have been chased into hiding by telephoned threats.
"We've had gang rapes occur before but not of this magnitude," said Lieut. Jerry Davis, the commander of the city's crimes-against-persons unit. "The crime itself is bad enough, but this was directed at children. It's mind boggling."
A rally is planned on Friday at California State University here to show support for the girls and to demonstrate to the community "that this could be your daughter, that this could happen to any of us," said Kathryn Forbes, a lecturer of women's studies at the university.
Sylvia A. Ogden, the county Victim Witness Service advocate assigned to the case, said: "Those little girls, will never be little girls again. It breaks your heart."
But everyone, from Fresno's Mayor to rape counselors, agree that what happened here could have happened anywhere, perhaps in a fraternity house or in a basement in a predominantly white suburb like Glen Ridge, N.J., where a group of high school football players sexually assaulted a mentally retarded teen-age girl with a bat and a stick in 1989.
Bernard Lefkowitz, who wrote a book about the assault in Glen Ridge, "Our Guys" (University of California Press, 1997), said: "For a lot of boys, acting abusively toward women is regarded as a rite of passage. It's woven into our culture."
Woven into Fresno's subculture are gangs, and the police report on the attack linked some suspects with one called the Mongolian Boys Society. There are a multitude of ethnic gangs here, including a white supremacist gang called the Peckerwoods. Experts on gangs say that the reasons for the high gang activity include Fresno County's 16.6-percent unemployment rate, largely attributable to a lack of manufacturing jobs and the seasonal nature of the region's No. 1 industry, agriculture.
There were 36 group rapes reported to the Rape Counseling Service of Fresno in 1997, and 50 percent of them appeared to be gang-related, said Lee Ann Eager, the service's executive director, who noted that 50 percent were not. Elizabeth Mitchell, the prosecutor in charge of the Fresno County District Attorney's sex crimes unit, said the assault appeared to "have been planned from the get go," adding, "It was anticipated that this was what the room was rented for."
The three girls had apparently run away from home and were stranded about 30 miles south of Fresno when they decided to return to their families. One girl called a friend of a friend for a ride, according to the police report.
The person they called picked them up, but as he drove them home, he said he needed to stop at the motel and visit a cousin. When the girls walked in the room about 9 P.M., the police said, men were already there. One girl was taken into the bathroom and raped several times, according to the police report, and the other two girls were also raped.
When one boy in the motel room went in the bathroom, he closed the door and told one girl he would call for help, Sgt. Tim McFadden of the sex-crime unit said. The girl asked the boy to call her father, who then called the police.
The Fresno Bee reported that when officers arrived at 12:30 A.M. on April 7, most of the men and boys had left, and the officers failed to take the names of those who remained because they had not been aware that a crime had taken place.
The girls' parents were called to take them home. The girls did not report that they had been raped until the next day, April 8.
City officials insist that the officers followed proper procedures, and did take the names of the three men still in the room and allowed them to leave because no one reported a crime. The officials said the delay in making arrests had been to gather as much information before the suspects could leave the city.
Ms. Eager, the director of the Fresno rape center, said people had called her office asking if the girls had been wearing sexy clothing or if they had done something to provoke the attack. One man called to say that because the girls had walked into the motel room, it was not fair to call it rape. Ms. Eager said she silently counted to 10, then to 20, before responding: "The punishment for bad judgment is not rape, for three little girls or for anyone else."
Last weekend, as the arrests were under way, about a dozen teen-agers gathered in the library of a Fresno County Boys and Girls Club, an oasis from places like the motel room on the edge of town. A 15-year-old boy said that after he heard about the rape, he ran home and begged his mother not to let his younger sister out for a week.
Martha Moreno, 13, said she had not been surprised by what happened because too many boys "think girls are their slaves."
"If you try to stand up for yourself, they want to fight you and call you names," she said. "Boys are stupid. That's the main problem."
 The other girls in the room laughed, but Martha did not.
"It really scared me when I heard about what happened," she said. "It makes you think anything can happen to you. But I still tell boys, I'm not a slave."

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Is Star at a Rally for Kennelly

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, April 30

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton gave a talk here this morning, "Women: Finding and Raising Your Voice," but later in the day she had another mission: finding and raising money.
Mrs. Clinton did a star turn this afternoon for Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, the likely Democratic nominee for governor, and helped the eight-term Congresswoman raise more than $100,000. 
 The First Lady was part of an afternoon rally that underscored the Kennelly campaign's strategy of trying to use a woman-to-woman appeal to defeat the incumbent Republican, Gov. John G. Rowland.
A crowd of about 700 people -- about two-thirds of them women -- gathered in the Shubert Theater here, at a $100-a-ticket event sponsored by Women for Kennelly, under the motto, "The power of women will put women in power." Before Mrs. Clinton and Mrs. Kennelly took the stage, a tape of the Aretha Franklin song "Respect" was pumped into the hall, and one speaker suggested that it should become the campaign song.
"Every race I ever have run," Mrs. Kennelly said, "women have made the difference, and they're going to make the difference for me this fall."
This was the latest in a series of moves over the last few weeks by the Kennelly campaign to seek to distinguish Mrs. Kennelly's views from Mr. Rowland's.
Mrs. Kennelly began today with an issue, child care, that appeared to be well suited for her audience. She contended that Mr. Rowland had failed to provide affordable quality child care, saying that the state had 15 inspectors to check conditions in 7,000 programs and that sending a child to day care could cost as much as sending them to a state college.
Mrs. Clinton, who was greeted by a rousing standing ovation, remarked that while Connecticut has the nation's highest average per capita income, it also has the largest gap between the rich and the poor and three of the country's poorest cities. "How could this happen?" she asked, adding that the conclusion was "inescapable."
"For the last couple of years, you have not had the leadership you need," she said.
But there is no question that persuading voters to accept that position will be an uphill battle. A poll conducted by The Hartford Courant and the University of Connecticut earlier this month indicated that 71 percent of those surveyed had a favorable impression of Mr. Rowland and that he would defeat Mrs. Kennelly, 50 percent to 28 percent, if the election were held this month.
Dean Pagani, Mr. Rowland's spokesman, said today that the state has its lowest unemployment rate in 10 years and that growth in the gap between the rich and the poor was the result of wealthy people making more money, not poor people getting less. Though Mrs. Kennelly may criticize the state's child care system, Mr. Pagani said Connecticut set aside tens of millions of dollars last year to expand it.
Mr. Pagani also questioned Mrs. Clinton's point about caring for the cities -- an issue her husband rarely raised in the Presidential campaign two years ago -- noting that the theater she spoke in today was being restored with $700,000 from the state government.
And there were questions about what Mrs. Clinton's and women's support would actually mean for Mrs. Kennelly. Along with the event at the Shubert, Mrs. Clinton also attended a $1,000-a-seat luncheon at a private club here to raise money for Mrs. Kennelly, as well as speaking in the morning at Yale Divinity School to students and faculty, on "Women: Finding and Raising Your Voice."
Although Mrs. Kennelly's supporters said that having Mrs. Clinton here could only help, one student at this morning's event, Jeffrey MacDonald, asked in a question-and-answer session whether what a former Presidential adviser, Dick Morris, had written was true: that he had counseled President Clinton to keep Mrs. Clinton from having a prominent public role in his 1996 campaign.
Mrs. Clinton responded, "I don't think that's an accurate description at all."

HEADLINE: U.S. Economy Grew at Brisk Pace This Winter Despite Crisis in Asia

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The economy grew at a surprisingly strong pace this winter, and inflation remained unexpectedly subdued, the Government reported yesterday.
Instead of slowing down as the Asian recession hit American manufacturers, the economy picked up speed, growing at a 4.2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, compared with 3.7 percent in the previous quarter. And instead of drifting higher as Washington and Wall Street feared, the broadest measure of inflation dipped below 1 percent to its lowest rate since 1964. 
 "We keep expecting a slowdown and it never comes," said Jeffrey A. Frankel of the Council of Economic Advisers. "We're returning to the economy of the 50's and 60's -- a remarkable, remarkable combination of strong growth without inflation."
Investors had been worrying that the Federal Reserve was poised to raise interest rates, a concern that sent the Dow Jones industrial average plummeting more than 140 points on Monday. Yesterday, they decided to focus on the good news on inflation, which touched off rallies in the stock and bond markets, with the Dow climbing 111.85 points, to 9,063.37.
A Labor Department report suggested that wage inflation was not much of a problem despite a tight labor market. The Employment Cost Index rose a mere seven-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter, more slowly than in the previous quarter and far less than economists had expected.
President Clinton called the data more evidence of an "American economic renaissance," boasting that growth was not being "fueled by big Government deficits" -- an apparent reference to the recovery during the Reagan Administration -- and dismissed the notion that the economy was bubbling over with speculative excesses. He gave much of the credit for the economy's performance to Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
The Federal Reserve was probably as surprised by the economy's strength as private forecasters were. And the central bank, like private forecasters, still expects the economy to shift into lower gear on its own over the next few months. The annual growth rate has been greater than 3 percent for six consecutive quarters, well above the 2.4 percent rate that the Clinton Administration considers the long-run historical norm. The question is how and when the economy will slow.
Most forecasters expect the Asian economic crisis to do the job. Indeed, falling exports and soaring imports trimmed $41 billion from the gross domestic product in the first quarter. But a burst of domestic spending -- by consumers, home builders and businesses -- more than offset the drag from the widening trade deficit.
And it is possible that some of the winter's strength was borrowed from the spring as consumers and construction companies took advantage of mild weather. If so, growth will be somewhat slower in the current quarter.
"If we don't slow down in the second quarter, watch out," said William Dudley, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs. "The Fed will have to tighten, and they'll do it more than we think."
While growth was led by exports earlier in this expansion, strong domestic demand is fueling it now.
Consumer spending was remarkably strong in the first quarter, rising at a 5.7 percent annual rate, the fastest pace in six years. Spending on cars, appliances and home furnishings jumped at a 20 percent rate. Consumers also bought a great deal of clothing. Though their spending on services was dampened by lower utility bills, outlays on other services -- everything from vacations to psychiatrists -- rose smartly.
Consumers are in remarkably good financial shape, one reason that they are expressing greater confidence than ever. Household net worth has swelled by $1 trillion in the last three months as the stock market has climbed. Total wage and salary income for all Americans has been growing extremely fast as more people find jobs and corporations raise pay. It is 7 percent higher than a year ago, whereas inflation is up just 1.5 percent. The income growth has been so strong, in fact, that the personal saving rate rose in the first quarter to more than 4 percent -- despite all the shopping.
In recent months, moreover, consumers have benefited from some real bargains. The rise in the dollar has led to lower prices for imports. On top of that, oil prices have dropped sharply. Together, Goldman, Sachs estimates, they were the equivalent of a $14 billion tax cut.
As all the furniture buying implies, home building surged in the first quarter. The pace of new-home construction, which rose at a 17.6 percent annual rate this winter, was the strongest in four years. A mild winter in many parts of the country, lower mortgage rates and the rise in household net worth all contributed.
Households were not the only ones spending. Businesses continued to gear up. Purchases of equipment -- everything from jumbo jets and trucks to laptops and cell phones -- soared at a 29 percent annual rate. Factory and office building, however, remained weak.
The flip side to the high-powered domestic demand during the winter was a sudden onset of weakness on the foreign side. Exports, which remained strong through last spring, declined outright at a $9 billion annual rate -- the direct effect of the recession in Asia. With factory utilization high and unemployment low, strong domestic demand was bound to pull in a wave of imports. Imports grew at a strong 11.6 percent annual rate. The resulting deterioration in the trade balance knocked $41 billion from the gross domestic product.
Economists are divided over whether the trade deficit will continue to deteriorate during the year. If domestic demand remains strong, imports will provide a safety valve.
Inventory investment continued at a rapid clip in the first quarter, but with final sales soaring there was no sign that goods were piling up either at wholesalers' warehouses or retail stores, and the inventory-to-sales ratio remains comfortable. That is not quite as true at factories, where inventory accumulation jumped to a pace of nearly $30 billion, compared with $22 billion last fall. That apparent pileup is probably another sign of the sudden slowdown of demand for United States exports in Asia and may presage some moderation in manufacturing activity -- a development hinted at by yesterday's report by the Chicago Purchasing Management Association.
Investors had been bracing for signs of wage inflation. Very few were to be found in yesterday's quarterly report on wage and benefit costs. For several years, the shift to managed health care and the rising stock market helped hold benefit cost increases to a minimum. Now, with insurers and managed care companies raising their rates, economists expect benefit costs to rise faster. Health benefit costs did indeed pick up, rising 2.2 percent compared with two-tenths of 1 percent a year earlier. But, as the Bureau of Labor Commissioner, Katherine Abraham, pointed out, the rise was partly offset by smaller increases in the cost of legally required benefits, like unemployment insurance and workers' compensation.

HEADLINE: Treasury's No. 2 Rebuts Tobacco Arguments

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 30

 BODY:
A top Administration economist today rebutted the central arguments that cigarette makers had made against tobacco legislation before the Senate as President Clinton urged the companies to return to negotiations.
The rebuttal came from the Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, who told Congress that the Government's economic analyses showed that neither a black market in cigarettes nor tobacco industry bankruptcies would result from a bill approved by the Senate Commerce Committee this month. 
 The major cigarette makers announced within the past month that they were abandoning further negotiations with Congress in large part because they thought Congress was on a course that would lead to contraband cigarettes and would drive some companies out of business.
Tobacco executives also accused the President of double-crossing them. White House officials were instrumental in the settlement the industry reached with state attorneys general last June, but Mr. Clinton has sought measures this year that would be much tougher.
The Commerce Committee's bill, scheduled to be taken up on the Senate floor the week before Memorial Day, would raise the price of a pack of cigarettes by $1.10 over five years, much more than the June settlement, and would give the industry little of the protection it seeks from smokers' lawsuits.
Asked at his news conference today about the companies' walkout, Mr. Clinton replied, "I think it would be better if they were at the table."
He said some parts of the Senate legislation, like restraints on cigarette advertising, might not be possible without the industry's assent.
In a backhanded way, the President also threatened to use the tobacco issue against Republicans in elections this fall if Congress did not approve a strong bill.
"I do not want this to be an issue in the November election," he said, and then repeated the sentence slowly for emphasis. Then he added:
"If it is an issue in the November election, it will only be because those people who have a political or financial interest in seeing that this matter is not resolved between now and November prevent it from being resolved. The worst thing in the world would be to play politics with our children's health. I'm not going to do it, and I hope no one else will."
Mr. Summers, who was one of the country's foremost academic economists before joining the Government, made his comments in testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. He said a black market in cigarettes could be avoided if strict licensing requirements were set for manufacturers, distributors, retail sellers, exporters and importers of tobacco products; if cigarette packs were carefully stamped for domestic or foreign distribution, and if enforcement against smuggling was strengthened.
Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the committee, was skeptical. Holding up a pack of Chinese cigarettes, Mr. Hatch said, "My concern is that we're going to be flooded with this stuff."
As for the financial future of the tobacco industry, Mr. Summers said the Government's analyses showed that a measure like the one approved by the Commerce Committee could cut industry profits by 23 percent a year. But he said that the industry was extremely profitable and that it was not likely that such a measure would have "any decisive impact on the industry's overall health."
While the Senate is preparing to debate tobacco legislation on the floor next month, the matter is on hold in the House. House Republican leaders have expressed a desire to tie an anti-smoking measure to one meant to combat drug use.
Today, the leaders called a news conference to present their drug bill. Among other items, it would crack down on drug trafficking and strengthen the Border Patrol, but no mention was made of tobacco.
Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who heads the House Commerce Committee, told Republican leaders this week that he and the top Democrats on his committee could agree on secondary matters in tobacco legislation, like strengthening the Food and Drug Administration's regulatory authority, and could produce a bill that did not deal with the main issues. They are the price of cigarettes and protection from lawsuits based on illness caused by smoking. The leaders, those at the meeting said, were not enthusiastic about this approach and told Mr. Bliley to set the issue aside, at least temporarily.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strength Without Inflation, Latest Data Show
The economy grew at a surprisingly strong 4.2 percent annual rate in the January-March quarter and the broadest measure of inflation fell to the lowest level in 34 years. 
 The data defied predictions that the Asian recession had begun to afflict American manufacturers and that inflationary pressure from the economy's prolonged expansion had finally started showing up. Page A1.
 
Stocks and bonds leaped in reaction to the economic data, which diminished investor fears of impending inflation that would lead to higher interest rates. The stock rally, led by financial, drug and telecommunications shares, sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 111.85 points, or 1.25 percent, its second consecutive gain, erasing the vestiges of a 146.98-point tumble Monday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose for the biggest
one-day gain in six months, and its yield fell to 5.94 percent from 6.07, the lowest since April 21. D7.
 
Airline Alliance Reached After Delay
United and Delta agreed on a broad marketing alliance after a weeklong delay caused by resistance from Delta's pilots. The linkup still requires pilot union approval. D2.
 
NBC's Marketing Experiment
NBC has taken the first steps toward a regular business in direct marketing to viewers through "800" phone numbers. A1.
 
EMI Shares Rise on Merger Talk
Shares of EMI Group rose 16 percent after the troubled British music company confirmed it was in merger talks with an unidentified suitor, believed to be Seagram. D3.
 
U.S. Favors Indonesia Payment
The United States is preparing to back a $1 billion payment in I.M.F. aid to Indonesia, despite evidence that President Suharto's family and friends are trying to protect monopolies they control. A1.
 
Shake-Up in Pepsi's Marketing
Stung by the lagging performance of its flagship brand, the Pepsi-Cola Company is restructuring the leadership of its marketing for all soft drinks. Pepsi-Cola said its chief global marketing officer, Brian Swette, would leave at the end of the month, replaced by a three-executive marketing council. Complaints about Pepsi's marketing had persisted for some time. D4.
 
Ad Sales Lift CBS's Net
Strong advertising sales, thanks in part to the Winter Olympics, bolstered earnings at CBS. It was the first profitable quarter that did not include an asset sale in nearly two years. D6.
 
MCI Sees Revenue Growth
MCI Communications said first-quarter profit before gains and charges fell 48 percent, but the decline was less than expected. D2.
 
Boeing Wins Big Defense Contract
The Pentagon awarded a $1.6 billion contract to Boeing to oversee the design and testing of a national defense system that integrates satellites and missiles. D2.
 
Cornell's Wall Street Benefactor
Sanford I. Weill, Wall Street deal maker, chief executive of Travelers Group and Cornell alumnus, said he and his wife had pledged $100 million to Cornell's medical college. B3.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 420 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Awkward Answers

 BODY:
In his first solo news conference since December, President Clinton gave his usual fluid performance, but it was obvious that he has paid a high price for his silence on the allegations about Monica Lewinsky. Most of Mr. Clinton's feelings came across through innuendo and body language. His repeated ducking of questions seemed defensive, argumentative and yet uncharacteristically passive. Asked whether his behavior should even matter to Americans, the President all but shrugged and said he was "in some ways the last person who needs to be having a national conversation about this." For a man addicted to conversation, it was a revealing answer.
The President's lawyers have no doubt advised him to maintain his silence, just as lawyers might do for any target of a criminal investigation. But a narrow legal strategy will not help him restore Americans' faith in his character, even if they approve the way he has handled the economy. 
 As we have said repeatedly, Mr. Clinton needs to find some way to assure Americans troubled over the nature of his relationship to a young White House intern and the difficulty that so many of his aides went to in order to find her a job. Instead of taking that route, he made clear that the day that he would address such questions was in the far, receding future.
As for Kenneth Starr, Mr. Clinton spoke disdainfully of the investigation lasting "forever -- 10, 20, 30, 40 or 50 years," and suggested that he would be willing to wait at least that long to clear things up himself. He argued that polls showing that Americans have a low regard for his moral character have resulted from an organized smear campaign rather than anything he has done himself.
At every opportunity, he turned the other cheek so fast that he seemed to be spinning around in circles. It was self-serving spin at that, depicting Mr. Starr and Newt Gingrich as partisans and himself as the victim of a puzzling vendetta. For those who admire Mr. Clinton's rhetorical skills, it was an effective blending of signals. But for those who think the Presidency carries a duty of candor and full, frequent answers to troubling questions, this rare press conference was far less satisfying.
We have little patience for Mr. Starr's assertion that there is "no end in sight" to his inquiry. But by dodging questions and encouraging disrespect for a duly appointed Independent Counsel, Mr. Clinton is doing his own bit to prolong the investigation and drive down the polls rating his character.

HEADLINE: Steinbrenner Delays Move On Stadium

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Concerned about the intense political maneuvering over whether -- and where -- to build a new stadium for the New York Yankees, George M. Steinbrenner 3d will not make a decision about the ball club's future home until after the baseball season ends in the fall, his advisers say.
In addition, the advisers said, Mr. Steinbrenner has been talking to former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo about joining an advisory panel to help him determine his next step in the debate over whether to leave the Yankees' storied home in the Bronx for one that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is considering on the West Side of Manhattan. 
 Mr. Cuomo is one of several consultants Mr. Steinbrenner is courting, executives close to the Yankees organization said. They said that others include Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting firm with a large sports practice, and HOK Sports Facilities Group, the Kansas City architectural firm that designed the celebrated Oriole Park at Camden Yards in Baltimore and Coors Stadium in Denver.
Executives close to Mr. Steinbrenner said that while the Yankees organization appreciated the efforts of Mayor Giuliani to keep the team in New York City, it had become concerned with the furor surrounding the Mayor's proposal that city tax money be used to help finance a new stadium.
The Mayor has said that building a new Manhattan stadium is more economically beneficial than refurbishing Yankee Stadium in the Bronx or building a new stadium near it. But several city officials, from the Speaker of the City Council to the Manhattan Borough President, say that the Yankees belong in the Bronx and complain that the Mayor has not included them in any discussions.
"The Yankees were beside themselves," said one executive who is close to the Yankee organization but who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The whole controversy is counterproductive. That's why it's preposterous for Rudy to run around this way."
As he has done consistently in the debate over the future of Yankee Stadium, Mr. Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, declined to comment yesterday. But those close to the negotiations said that Mr. Steinbrenner wanted to remove the Yankees entirely from the politically charged atmosphere of an election year that includes a race for New York State Governor, involving both Gov. George E. Pataki and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, who is seeking the Democratic nomination.
Mr. Cuomo, who is now a partner at Wilkie, Farr & Gallagher, acknowledged that he had been talking with Mr. Steinbrenner "for a long time," although he declined to define his role. The Yankees had assumed that there would be little discussion about a stadium in an election year, Mr. Cuomo said. "Then bing, it's on the front burner," he added. "And they're talking about a referendum that could kill you.
"The Yankees want to speak now that everyone else has spoken. A lot of people have half-baked ideas. My understanding is that the Yankees want to speak as clearly as they can, given all the voices being heard around them: the Mets, the Mayor, Vallone. They feel they should be speaking now."
Mr. Cuomo has some experience with Mr. Steinbrenner. In the mid-1980's, he and former Mayor Edward I. Koch negotiated unsuccessfully with Mr. Steinbrenner over a 30-year extension on the team's lease at the stadium in the Bronx. In 1993, Mr. Cuomo warned that "there was a real danger that New York might lose the Yankees," and began exploring other potential sites for a stadium, including the rail yards on the West Side. But he lost his bid for re-election in 1994 to Mr. Pataki.
"My personal interest is in New York State and New York City," Mr. Cuomo said. "I love baseball and the Yankees."
As Mr. Steinbrenner and his aides debated how to broach publicly the subject of stadium location, Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Vallone intensified their unusual battle over the issue. Both said they would employ the little-used powers vested in them by the City Charter to block each other's plans; both accused each other of political chicanery.
Mr. Giuliani delivered the latest volley yesterday. He announced that he was creating a Charter Revision Commission that would come up with recommendations to improve the charter. But he acknowledged that the purpose of the commission -- created so suddenly that its members have not been appointed and its cost to the taxpayers is unknown -- was primarily to block Mr. Vallone's plans for a referendum that would ask voters whether the city should help finance a new stadium for the Yankees.
The specifics of the Mayor's strategy, developed after his lawyers had pored over the language of the State Municipal Home Rule Law like scholars studying Sanskrit, hinges on a clause that has never before been invoked. Simply put, the plan would have the commission raise a charter question that would be placed on November's ballot; and the appearance of any Mayor-sponsored charter question would, under state law, knock Mr. Vallone's question off the ballot.
In doing so, Mr. Giuliani broke an agreement that he and Mr. Vallone reached earlier this year to disband dueling charter commissions that each had set up to study the respective powers of the Mayor's office and City Council. Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that he revived his charter commission because he had become concerned in recent weeks that "city government is going to be used in a partisan, political way."
He said that he was concerned by several of the Council's plans, but one in particular: Mr. Vallone's referendum proposal, which the Mayor believes would handcuff the city in negotiations with the Yankees.
"If we submitted the city's negotiations with businesses to referendums, we would become a city government ruled by referendums and public-opinion polls," he said. He later added: 'If we get into the knee-jerk action of doing that, you might as well do away with government and just have public-opinion polls on television, like QVC."
But aides to Mr. Vallone argued that Mr. Giuliani was loath to allow the question to be brought to a vote because the West Side proposal -- which could cost private investors and the public more than $1 billion -- was extremely unpopular.
As for the Mayor's maneuver, Mr. Vallone's aides said that they still had options available, including a lawsuit or, possibly, the creation of the Council's own charter commission whose questions would be allowed to share ballot space with any proposal by the Mayor.
The Speaker also questioned the propriety of creating a charter commission to further the Mayor's political agenda. "These people would have to all participate in a public sham," he said of those who would serve on the Mayor's commission.
City Council staff members acknowledged that the Speaker and the Council already had the power to challenge the Mayor's plans for building a new stadium; the charter gives the Council great say on issues of land use and public financing. Nevertheless, Mr. Vallone defended the referendum option by saying, "I want to keep the Yankees in the Bronx and I think the fans should have a say in the matter."
But aides to Mr. Giuliani -- and even those who advise Mr. Vallone -- said that the Democratic Speaker's push for a referendum had a political component as well, his campaign for Governor. By having a referendum on the November ballot, particularly one centering on an emotional issue like baseball, Mr. Vallone would give a much-needed lift to his name recognition and insure a higher voter turnout.
"If you're going to be intellectually honest about this -- which may be a lot to ask -- you know why it's being done," Mr. Giuliani said to a reporter. "It's being done because there's an election in November, and somebody's trying to drive up the vote."

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Expansion of NATO Wins Senate Approval
The Senate voted, 80 to 19, to expand NATO by admitting to the alliance three of its former enemies: Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. The margin of the vote provided far more than the two-thirds majority needed to approve the resolution. A1 

U.S. Backs Aid to Indonesia
The United States is preparing to back a $1 billion payment in international emergency aid to Indonesia, despite evidence that President Suharto's family and friends are undermining efforts to break up multibillion-dollar monopolies. A1
 
G.I.'s May Start to Leave Gulf
President Clinton said he was encouraged by Iraqi cooperation with United Nations weapon inspectors, and he expected to reduce the number of American troops deployed in the Persian Gulf region. A10
 
Iran Stays on Terrorist List
The State Department noted in its annual report on international terrorism that Iran had adopted "more conciliatory" language and had publicly condemned some forms of terrorism, but remained "the most active state sponsor of terrorism."A11
 
A Very Israeli Celebration
Israel marked its 50th birthday with a uniquely Israeli blend of smoky barbecues, fly-overs, fireworks and controversies. Vice President Al Gore was the guest of honor at the centerpiece of the jubilee. A6
 
Little Progress in Chinese Talks
American officials said after two days of talks with Chinese leaders that there had been only limited progress on key issues for President Clinton's summit meeting in Beijing in June. A3
 
Dalai Lama Supports Clinton
Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, distanced himself from militant Tibetans and some human rights organizations by saying that the Clinton Administration was on the right track in muting public criticism of China. A3
 
U.S. Warns of Crime in Mexico
The State Department toughened its advice for Americans traveling in Mexico in response to a surge in violent crimes against tourists and mounting complaints from Americans that they had not been adequately warned by their Government about the dangers. A15
 
Wartime Camp Leader Arrested
The Argentine police arrested Dinko Sakic, who commanded a concentration camp in Croatia during World War II. Mr. Sakic headed a camp when he was 21, when Croatia was under fascist rule. Croatia has asked for his extradition. A5
 
I.R.A. Supports Overall Accord
The I.R.A. rejected calls contained in the Northern Ireland peace agreement for disarming its guerrillas and dismantling its underground arsenal, but expressed guarded support for the overall accord. A8
 
NATIONAL A18-25
 
U.S. Indicts Hubbell
On Tax-Evasion Charges
Webster L. Hubbell, the longtime confidant of President Clinton and a former law partner of Hillary Rodham Clinton, was indicted on Federal charges of tax evasion that included failure to pay taxes and penalties of more than $850,000 over the past four years. Much of the taxes, prosecutors said, were owed on embezzled money and on income steered to him by friends of the Clintons when Whitewater investigators were seeking information about the President and his wife. A1
 
President Shows His Ire
President Clinton showed contempt for Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating his private and public conduct, but acknowledged that questions about his behavior would persist throughout his term in office. Mr. Clinton said in a news conference that allegations about his conduct were part of a concerted, long-term effort to undermine his Presidency and blacken his reputation. The President declined to offer new information about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky. A1
 
Senate Hearings on I.R.S.
I.R.S. managers covered up corrupt audits of major companies in New York and Los Angeles and protected a rogue agent who tried to frame former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. on bogus tax-evasion charges nine years ago, witnesses told the Senate Finance Committee. A20
 
Emergency Spending Approved
Congressional Republicans stared down the Clinton Administration, passing a $6 billion emergency spending bill and winning President Clinton's promise to sign it, even though it failed to provide money he had sought to replenish the International Monetary Fund. A20
 
Countering Tobacco's Case
A top Administration economist, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, rebutted the central arguments that cigarette makers had made against tobacco legislation before the Senate as President Clinton urged the companies to return to negotiations. A22
 
Warning on Brain Injuries
Athletes at every level, from children's teams to professional leagues, who suffer concussions are frequently allowed to resume playing too soon, leaving them vulnerable to devastating brain damage from even a minor second blow, doctors said. A18
 
Union Official Is Defended
The president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., John J. Sweeney, left, offered his strongest defense to date of the federation's No. 2 official, Richard L. Trumka, who is under investigation over his possible role in siphoning teamster money into the campaign of Ron Carey, the teamster president. A20
 
Teen-Age Birth Rates Decline
Teen-age birth rates declined substantially from 1991 to 1996, a trend that some experts credited mostly to abstinence education and others to better use of contraception. A21

George M. Steinbrenner 3d will not make a decision about the Yankees' future home until the season ends, his advisers said. He has also talked to former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo about joining an advisory panel. B1
 
New Tactic for Housing
The city's housing agency will take direct control of hundreds of city-owned vacant lots used as community gardens to speed up efforts to find developers for low- and moderate-income housing on those plots. B1
 
A Glimpse at Ferraro's Returns
Geraldine A. Ferraro, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the Senate, made her 1997 tax returns available for inspection, but imposed an extraordinary restriction: reporters could examine copies of the returns for only three hours. B1

Sanford I. Weill, who recently merged his Travelers Group with Citicorp, said that he and his wife, Joan, had pledged $100 million to Cornell University's medical college. B3
 
St. Moritz to Reopen as Hotel
The hotelier Ian Schrager said he had snatched the St. Moritz building from Donald J. Trump, who had planned to raze and rebuild it as condominiums, and would reopen it within 30 days as a hotel. B3
 
Holtzman Finding Is Upheld
New York State's highest court upheld an investigative panel's finding that Elizabeth Holtzman, the former New York City Comptroller, violated conflict-of-interest laws when she took a campaign loan from a bank trying to obtain city business. B5

BUSINESS DAY D1-20
 
Economy Stays Strong
Instead of slowing down as the Asian recession hit American manufacturers, the economy picked up speed, growing at a 4.2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, compared with a 3.7 percent rate in the previous quarter. And instead of drifting higher, as feared, the broadest measure of inflation dipped below 1 percent. A1
 
NBC to Sell Program Tapes
NBC's decision to use commercial time at the end of "Merlin" to offer for sale a videotape of that program proved so successful that a network executive said NBC would continue the practice, long a staple on cable television, with other programs. A1
 
Energy Group to Texas Utilities
Texas Utilities won one of the longest and costliest takeover battles ever in the utility industry, gaining control of Energy Group, one of Britain's last remaining independent utilities, after Pacificorp said it would not top Texas Utilities' $7.4 billion bid. D1
 
New Chief at McDonald's
Jack M. Greenberg, the executive behind the reorganization of McDonald's, was promoted to president and chief executive of the worldwide fast-food business. D1
