HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Auto Makers Tell U.S. What It Wants to Hear

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 1

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus with the United States has climbed steadily over the last several months, increasing the likelihood of a protectionist backlash in Congress and industry.
But despite the rising trade tensions, the Japanese car industry -- a favorite whipping dog of American critics in the past -- is all but promising that it will not increase exports over the next year and might even pull back a bit. 
 If that projection proves accurate, Japanese auto makers will be bucking powerful economic forces. One is the weakening yen that enables them to charge lower prices in dollars for their products, undercutting Ford Motor, General Motors and Chrysler. Another is the stagnating Japanese economy, which has dampened demand at home. Only yesterday, the Japanese Automobile Dealers' Association reported a 7.4 percent drop in sales of new cars, trucks and buses in Japan from a year earlier, the 13th consecutive monthly fall.
Moreover, the most promising foreign market to emerge in decades, Asia, has basically dried up, making sales to the United States and Europe all the more crucial to the Japanese manufacturers' profits.
And yet, moderation appears to be the order of the day. "I think the consensus in the auto industry here is that exports to the United States will probably be flat to maybe a little down," said Toshiaki Taguchi, a Toyota Motor director who is in charge of business in the Americas.
The Japan Automobile Manufacturers' Association concurred, saying it expected a decline. And analysts' views were equally soothing. "Rising Japanese exports have been a big concern among holders of G.M. and Ford," said Stephen E. Volkmann, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But that's not nearly as big a risk as many people are afraid it will be."
One reason for the self-restraint is that it applies to a high base; Japanese exports to the United States increased by 10.7 percent last year, to nearly 1.3 million cars. Moreover, Japanese auto makers insist, it is no simple matter to ship more cars across the Atlantic.
"We can't suddenly start exporting more to the U.S. just because the yen falls a little," said Takeshi Sumita, a spokesman for the Honda Motor Company, which saw its exports to the United States skyrocket 37 percent in the fiscal year that just ended. "We're just not that flexible." Mr. Sumita described Honda's fiscal year 1997 export performance as an aberration caused by weak exports the previous year and by an unexpected demand both for Civics and for two new models of sport utility vehicles.
But the biggest factor in keeping a lid on exports is probably the Japanese industry's shift of production to America. The latest-model Honda Accord is wildly popular, for example, but it is made in the United States, not Japan, and thus is not included in export figures.
Moreover, Accord models that are made in Japan lack the size and engine power so popular in America. Indeed, 80 percent of all the cars that Honda sells in the United States, its biggest market, are built in North America largely from components made by suppliers there. "Their parts are purchased in dollars and they are sold in dollars," Mr. Sumita said.
Toyota is rumored to be cutting production in Japan by more than 10 percent, something it could avoid easily by exporting more to the United States. But it will not, Mr. Taguchi said, in part because it has shifted production of some compact truck models to plants in the United States.
The company is trying to expand capacity in the United States and Canada, where it produces roughly 900,000 cars a year. "Our priority has always been to maintain the factories in America at their highest capacity," Mr. Taguchi said. "The sales network is set up to sell our American-made products."
As for Nissan Motor and Mitsubishi Motors, respectively Japan's second- and fourth-largest car companies, they are having trouble selling new cars in the United States, and analysts believe they have such a backlog of inventory there that they cannot risk shipping more cars over. In the last fiscal year, Nissan's exports crept ahead just 1.2 percent, to 273,500 vehicles, while Mitsubishi's dropped 1 percent, to 80,000.
That leaves the Mazda Motor Corporation. Mazda's exports to the United States in the year that ended March 31 were up 15.8 percent, to 115,318 vehicles. But railing against Mazda would be tricky for American politicians because Ford owns a 33.4 percent chunk of it.
To be sure, politics plays a big part in the Japanese show of moderation. All of the big Japanese manufacturers claim to view the American market as saturated, intensely competitive and a huge political headache. Toyota, in particular, is widely perceived as forgoing the opportunity to export more in the interests of two-way relations.
"We consider all the factors in the market," said Mr. Taguchi, the Toyota director. "We do not operate our business on a political basis, but we do pay attention to export levels as one of the factors of doing business overseas."
Not surprisingly, some skeptics question the auto makers' commitment, and predict that the profit motive will triumph over diplomacy. "The natural and obvious conclusion, especially given what's happening in Asia, is that exports to the U.S. and Europe will go up," said Hiroo Tanabe, who sits on the American Chamber of Commerce's ad hoc committee on cars. "How else are they going to make money?"
Where indeed, with sales slack at home and in Asia? One hint comes from last year's figures: While overall exports surged 21.4 percent, to nearly 4.7 million vehicles -- the first time in 17 years that such exports have gone up more than 20 percent in a year -- those to Europe exploded by 35.9 percent.
Watch out, Europe, here they come.

HEADLINE: Bertelsmann Hits a Snag In Acquisition

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
Bertelsmann A.G.'s plan to purchase Random House and merge it with the media conglomerate's Bantam Doubleday Dell unit has temporarily stalled. Faced with an intensive new level of regulatory scrutiny, the German company decided this week to withdraw its application seeking approval from the Federal Trade Commission.
Bertelsmann intends to refile for approval soon, although it declined to specify exactly when. The withdrawal, a rare tactic, comes after investigators were preparing to subject the merger to a rigorous antitrust review that a trade commission survey indicated had happened in fewer than 2 percent of the almost 28,000 applications filed between 1983 and 1996. The review, known as the "second request" phase, gives regulators the power to depose top executives and to subpoena volumes of corporate documents. 
 In almost half of those cases that got such a second-request review, the merging companies ultimately abandoned their deals or prompted legal action by Federal authorities, according to the working paper by an F.T.C. economist, Malcolm B. Coate.
Bertelsmann's merger application was formally challenged last week by the Authors Guild in New York, which had criticized the combination as a "new economic behemoth" that would command more than a third of the adult trade market, a calculation that Bertelsmann disputes. The chief objection of the group is that the new company could diminish outlets for authors' manuscripts and reduce the quality and diversity of books in the marketplace.
Despite its withdrawal, Bertelsmann still expects Federal regulators to approve the media conglomerate's acquisition of Random House this spring, according to the corporation's spokesman in the United States, Stuart Applebaum. That would meet the company's timetable, announced previously, of completing the sale by July.
"This is something that isn't particularly perturbing," Mr. Applebaum said of the withdrawal. "It is routine, we're told, that they want more information. It is a high-profile acquisition and there has been a lot of misinformation and noise."
However, antitrust experts said that Bertelsmann's actions clearly indicated that there was some problem or thorny issue, otherwise Federal regulators would have allowed the merger to proceed following a 30-day period after the application was filed.
"It's not a common tactic," said James M. Spears, a former general counsel for the F.T.C. and a lawyer in private practice. "It's essentially a way to clean up the merger if there's something that's going to give you a problem."
Refiling, he said, gives companies the opportunity to remove any "burrs" -- even to trim the size of merging companies to win approval of Federal authorities. But submitting a new application is no guarantee that a company will ultimately be able to avoid the second phase of intensive scrutiny, which could lead to months of delays.
Mr. Applebaum said that Bertelsmann had no intention of shedding any parts of the two publishing houses and that the corporation would use this period to provide more market information about sales data and revenue figures to Federal regulators. "They have asked us for some specific and focused information to assist them further in confirming that our prospective transaction presents no competitive concerns," he said. "We are voluntarily supplying that information."
According to a person with knowledge of the F.T.C. review -- which is a secret process -- Federal regulators were preparing the questions for the intensive investigative phase, which can sometimes take as long six months while a company responds to demands for information and documents.
The merger of Bantam Doubleday Dell with Random House, which is owned by Advance Publications, would create a company that is the world's largest English-language publisher of trade books, which encompasses adult fiction and nonfiction. In the last two years, there has been considerable shifting among the top publishing houses with Pearson P.L.C.'s purchase of Putman Berkley, which it merged with Penguin; attempts by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation to sell HarperCollins, and Viacom's efforts to sell off parts, or all, of Simon & Schuster.
Victoria Streitfeld, a spokeswoman for the F.T.C. in Washington, said that the F.T.C. would not comment on the status of the Bertelsmann review, other than to confirm that an application had been filed.
It was unclear whether the opposition of the Authors Guild had figured in the regulatory process or Bertelsmann's withdrawal of its application. But yesterday, the guild's executive director, Paul Aiken, called the withdrawal "very good news."
"If they're in a position where they feel compelled to refile, that does sound serious," Mr. Aiken said. "It's an indication that the F.T.C. is properly taking the high level of market concentration in the publishing industry seriously."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
3-Day Market Rally Erases Losses of Earlier in Week

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
After beginning the week with a tumble, stocks recovered to end with a gain for the week yesterday as they rose for the third straight session.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which plunged 146.98 points on Monday, rose 83.70 points yesterday, to 9,147.07, with most of the gain coming in the last half-hour. 
 For the week, the Dow was up 82.45, a gain of less than 1 percent. The Dow is now 37.87 points from its record high reached April 21.
The advance was not as strong as the 111.85-point surge on Thursday, when investors were encouraged by reports that the economy grew at a brisk pace in the first quarter while inflation remained benign.
Data showing a similar outlook yesterday were largely viewed as old news.
Still, yesterday's reports, pointing to a modest slowdown in manufacturing and another showing a sharp decline in construction spending, reinforced expectations that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates before July. Investors are looking ahead to next week's April employment report and other signals for concrete evidence that the economy is slowing in the second quarter to justify further stock price gains, analysts said.
"The reports confirmed what the markets already knew: the economy is growing very fast with very little inflation," said Christine Callies, chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
"Unless the data revealed evidence of widespread weakness, there's little reason to expect stocks and bonds to move higher," Ms. Callies said of yesterday's gains. "A report of the facts is not enough to create a major rally."
Other market measures were higher yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at 1,121, up 9.25 points, just 9.54 shy of its closing high reached on April 22. Technology shares posted the weakest showing, with the Nasdaq composite index up 5.03, to 1,873.44. The Nasdaq ended the week with a 4.48- point gain, leaving it 44.17 points away from its closing high.
While yesterday's economic reports were largely viewed as positive, a closer look at the data reveals some cause for concern, some analysts said.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's index fell to 52.9 in April from 54.8 in March. The index of factory output, however, was still above 50 percent, "which tells us that manufacturing output is expanding," said Kathy Bostjancic an economist at UBS Securities in New York. "Beyond that, the market is not seeing a real slowdown in economic growth," she said.
In addition, new orders and new export orders, two barometers of the impact of Asia, did not slow drastically, a possible indication that "Asia is not having as big a draw down on growth" as expected, Ms. Bostjancic said.
While such news bolsters expectations that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates anytime soon, she said, it does leave room for concern that the economy will not slow enough on its own, nor get the anticipated drag from Asia, which would lessen the need for the Fed to act.
"We've averted an accident, but there's still that tentativeness that it could happen," Ms. Bostjancic said.
Now that the market has turned aside economic news, some analysts predicted that company news reports would power the market in coming weeks.
That line of thinking bore fruit yesterday as gains in oil shares and losses among some drug shares reflected the news of the day.
A rise in crude oil prices, which moved above $16 a barrel for the first time since March 30, pushed oil stocks higher.
Shares of Chevron, Exxon, Amoco and Mobil rose as April production by major oil producers fell in line with targets, minimizing concerns of an oil glut.
Meanwhile, several drug shares, which had been strong gainers in recent weeks, faltered. Eli Lilly, fell 3 1/4, to 66 5/16, amid concern that sales of its cancer drug Evista will not be as strong as expected. Merck fell for the first time this week, closing down 4 3/16, at 116 5/16, as some analysts dampened their outlook for the company.

HEADLINE: NATO Is Inching Closer, But Russians Don't Blink

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 1

 BODY:
The traditional May Day holiday might seem to be the sort of occasion that would mobilize Russian opinion against NATO's decision to take in three of Moscow's former satellites.
But the United States Senate's vote to approve NATO expansion drew a collective yawn today. The big stories on the evening news were a surge in fighting in Tajikistan, the kidnapping of President Boris N. Yeltsin's envoy to Chechnya and the formation of the new Government. 
 The Senate's vote to approve the admission of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic was mentioned, but only in passing. The Kremlin did not bother to comment.
In short, Russians have stubbornly refused to live up to the caricature foisted on them by some Western commentators: embittered nationalists ready to lash out at the West at the first opportunity.
None of this means that Russians are enthusiastic about NATO's move to extend its boundaries to the East. For many Russians, NATO enlargement is part of a broader pattern in which Washington has been deaf to Moscow's concerns and sought to take advantage of Russia during its period of weakness.
"As was the case with missile strikes against Iraq, the Administration prefers to act first and then figure out to do with the results," said Sergei Morozov, a correspondent in the United States for the NTV television network.
The vote has also forced Washington to expend political capital that might have been directed at dealing with other American-Russian issues, like arms control.
But the Russian response has been more modulated than many Western critics of the move suggest.
Russia's foreign policy elite has been opposed. But NATO blunted that opposition by negotiating an agreement that gives Russia a voice -- though not a veto -- in the alliance's decisions, and Moscow seems to have reconciled itself to a bigger NATO.
Russia's politically influential business executives and bankers, for their part, have not been interested in settling scores over NATO. They are more interested in raising capital in the West for investment at home and in developing foreign markets for Russian oil and gas.
Their biggest worry is not NATO's embrace of Eastern Europe; it is the effect of falling oil prices on Russian exporters and the unease Western investors have over emerging markets, an unease sharpened by the downturn in southeast Asia.
Much of the Russian public is too consumed with the daily economic grind to care. Like many Americans, Russians have turned inward since the end of the cold war.
Russia's biggest challenges are the payment of back wages, tax reform and other social and economic concerns, not foreign policy. Public opinion surveys have shown that half of those polled are indifferent about NATO enlargement. Those that have a view, however, tend to be negative.
The temperate Russian response minimizes the risk that a populist could rise to power on a tidal wave of anti-American sentiment.
The notion that the West will "lose" Russia over NATO has always been overdrawn. Nor does expansion mean that Washington will necessarily have to forfeit Russian approval of the Start-2 treaty to reduce nuclear arms. The Russian military has lined up behind Start-2 because its strategic arsenal will continue to shrink anyway, and the treaty will limit American arms, too.
The Communists say they will put up a determined fight when the Start-2 treaty is put to a parliamentare vote, but this probably has more to do with Russian politics than with NATO expansion. Having been humiliated by Parliament's approval of President Yeltsin's new Prime Minister, Sergei Kiriyenko, the Communists are looking for a way to show they are not a spent political force.
There is one important caveat: Russia has drawn the line at NATO's inclusion of the Baltic states, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Their membership would stir up a hornet's nest of official and popular criticism.
But there was little visible anxiety today. The First of May is the start of a four-day weekend, and a vast majority of Moscovites avoided the Communist marches and speechmaking to head for their dachas and the capital's first few days of balmy weather.

HEADLINE: Cigarette Makers' Strategy of '94 Is Echoed Today

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
In March 1994, the directors of the Philip Morris Companies, the world's largest cigarette maker, gathered to hear a warning that their industry faced tumultuous change. Just weeks before, the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, Dr. David A. Kessler, had announced that the agency might regulate nicotine as a drug.
In a slide presentation that day, Philip Morris executives explained how Dr. Kessler, in laying out the Government's options, had "skillfully pursued a flexible strategy." But they promised to fight any regulation of nicotine -- and the industry's counterattack soon began. 
 Tobacco strategists raised concerns that regulating cigarettes like drugs would create a thriving black market. And executives urged allies in Congress to put Dr. Kessler on the "hot seat" in public hearings. "Criticize his investigatory tactics," Philip Morris advised. "Expose his 'witch-hunt' operation."
Lawyers and public relations experts turned up their efforts to influence and intimidate the media. The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation even considered suing the cartoonist Garry Trudeau, the creator of the "Doonesbury" comic strip, for a story line that executives viewed as defamatory.
These and other details are from a cache of more than 38,000 internal industry documents that a Congressional committee released last week, after a long fight by cigarette makers to keep them secret.
While some of the records date as far back as the 1960's, a review of hundreds of documents from the critical years 1993 and 1994 offers new insight into how the industry sought to fend off a gathering regulatory and legal assault, and why five tobacco companies ultimately negotiated a $368.5 billion settlement last June of lawsuits brought by some 40 states.
That agreement collapsed this spring as Congress began considering tobacco legislation, including a bill introduced by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, that would cost the companies $516 billion. The documents show that in their renewed battle against any legislation regulating tobacco, cigarette makers are again employing arguments developed in 1994, that, for example, higher cigarette taxes would create a black market and cause economic havoc for the industry.
The documents may also provide clues to why the industry sought a settlement. As early as 1993, for example, in the draft of a presentation, Philip Morris's general counsel, Murray H. Bring, noted that some analysts believed the industry faced a "doomsday scenario" in which large judgments in smoking-related lawsuits could force companies into bankruptcy, much as had happened to asbestos producers.
Mr. Bring wrote that one of Philip Morris's goals was to isolate its domestic tobacco operations so legal claims against it could not be collected from other Philip Morris operations, including Kraft Foods, Miller Brewing and even Philip Morris's foreign tobacco unit. One way to seal off liabilities, he wrote, would be to reincorporate Philip Morris overseas, but he noted that such a move might be viewed as fraud.
But Mr. Bring, who helped devise the industry's strategy in last June's agreement, may have achieved his goal in that plan, which limited the financial obligations of cigarette makers to their domestic tobacco units. A similar provision is in the McCain bill.
Officials of Philip Morris and Brown & Williamson, a subsidiary of B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., declined to comment on the documents, saying they believed that the records, despite recent court rulings, were protected from disclosure by the attorney-client privilege. A Minnesota state judge ordered the documents disclosed after finding that some contained evidence of fraud and other crimes by industry executives and their lawyers.
Speaking generally, however, a spokesman for Brown & Williamson, Mark Smith, said: "The process of selectively picking out specific documents is distorted. It is like looking at one frame of a feature-length film and trying to make a statement about what the movie was about."
But if a movie was to be made about a pivotal moment in the battle over cigarettes, it could be titled "1994." That year, the Government began its efforts to regulate cigarettes; industry executives, in a dramatic appearance before Congress, asserted that nicotine was not addictive and that smoking did not cause cancer; the Justice Department started a wide-ranging criminal inquiry, and states like Mississippi and Minnesota began suing tobacco companies to recover Medicare money spent on smoking-related illnesses.
Now, as cigarette makers fight legislation in Congress, arguing that the proposals would doom the industry as surely as the impact of any courtroom losses, producers have returned to themes sounded in 1994..
That year, for example, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, a unit of the R. J. Nabisco Holdings Corporation, decided to attack the F.D.A.'s proposal to regulate cigarettes as an "effort at backdoor Prohibition."
"My understanding of the documents," said Tommy Payne, a senior vice president for R. J. Reynolds, "is that they reflect a rational consideration of the regulatory and legislative positions that the industry found itself in in 1994 and are ongoing today."
As part of their drive against the McCain bill, cigarette makers have also remobilized industry-financed organizations like the National Smokers Alliance. The companies used such groups in 1994, according to documents, to fight issues like regulations on secondhand smoke.
The records also include a briefing document for the chief executive of R. J. Reynolds, James W. Johnston, to use in preparing for a landmark Congressional hearing in 1994. To any question about the company's suppressing unfavorable scientific research, the recommended answer was that researchers were free to publish their results, once any proprietary information was deleted.
A recently disclosed R. J. Reynolds memorandum from 1985, however, shows that the company had a policy of suppressing publication of research about the cancer hazards and other toxic effects of smoking.
In a statement, the company said it had long encouraged its scientists to publish research and to make scientific presentations "despite allegations to the contrary."
Some 1994 documents also touch on the Justice Department's investigation of possible fraud by tobacco producers. One Brown & Williamson document provides an extensive inventory of company memorandums and records related to a genetically engineered strain of tobacco known as Y-1 that has twice the nicotine of regular leaf.
The Government is looking into potential Federal crimes involving Y-1, including whether Brown & Williamson officials helped smuggle Y-1 seeds to Brazil and whether they misled drug agency officials in 1994 when asked if they had developed high-strength tobacco.
Brown & Williamson officials have denied any wrongdoing, saying they did not disclose the project to the agency because they were never asked about it. The 1994 Y-1 document was prepared in response to questions from a Congressional committee but apparently never submitted.
Among the documents cited in the inventory is one labeled "Relabeling Y-1 from Brazil" and others dealing with tobacco containing high levels of nicotine and low levels of tar.
Tobacco producers also faced increased scrutiny in 1994 from the news media, just as today. That year, Philip Morris filed a $10 billion lawsuit against the American Broadcasting Company over a segment on "Day One," a news magazine. In particular, the company challenged an ABC claim that cigarette makers manipulated nicotine levels by adding the substance to the product.
ABC, in a decision that caused controversy within the network, settled the claim and issued an apology.
Lawsuits were on the minds of other cigarette makers, too. In 1994, Brown & Williamson considered suing Mr. Trudeau for defamation for a "Doonesbury" strip that depicted the company's chief executive, Thomas Sandefur, as indicted for perjury because of his Congressional testimony.
Also that year, R.J. Reynolds considered suing Dr. Paul M. Fischer, the researcher who wrote a landmark study showing that children readily identified the company's Joe Camel figure with cigarettes. Neither suit was filed, after company lawyers decided they would not succeed, the documents show.
The documents also offer details on the companies' plans for new products and promotions. In a 1993 document, R. J. Reynolds officials reviewed a proposal to decorate a bar in Baltimore around the theme of "Joe's Place," with signs and other marketing tools based on Joe Camel.
In reviewing the proposal, which was made by a consultant, R.J. Reynolds officials rejected the idea of having a "Hump Night" at the bar and said they would have to determine whether Maryland law allowed drinks to be bought with coupons in cigarette packages.
A company official said the "Joe's Place" proposal was not adopted. But the company did begin a promotional program in 1994 called "Camel Clubs" in association with bars nationwide.
 
Receivers Named
A New York state judge appointed receivers today for two tax-exempt, tobacco-funded groups that the state Attorney General is trying to put out of business as industry propaganda fronts.
Justice Stephen Crane of State Supreme Court appointed a former judge, Walter Schackman, to run the Council for Tobacco Research, and a lawyer, Milton Gould, to run the Tobacco Institute.
Judge Crane also ordered each group to file a $500,000 bond and provide a statement of assets and liabilities, names of creditors and claimants and all other information relevant to dissolution proceedings.
Attorney General Dennis Vacco of New York said on Thursday that he was moving to revoke the groups' tax-free status as not-for-profit research and information organizations because they violated their charters. Mr. Vacco accused the groups of posing as nonprofit groups while, at taxpayer expense, they "fed the public a pack of lies in an underhanded effort to promote smoking and addict our kids."

Much of the tobacco industry's strategy for protecting cigarettes from regulation was devised in 1994, as cigarette makers faced growing pressure from lawsuits and regulators. Industry documents made public last week revealed some of the companies' countermeasures.
 
FEB. 25, 1994 -- Dr. David A. Kessler, the Food and Drug Administration commissioner, said the agency might move to regulate nicotine as a drug and cigarettes as drug delivery devices. In a memo later prepared for Congressional allies, Philip Morris officials described ways for lawmakers to question Dr. Kessler in public hearings.
 
APRIL 14 -- Seven tobacco industry executives testified before Congress that nicotine was not addictive and that cigarettes did not cause cancer. To prepare the chief executive of R. J. Reynolds, James W. Johnston, the company prepared mock questions and answers.
 
APRIL 28 -- Two former scientists from Philip Morris testified before Congress that the company dropped efforts to develop a synthetic substitute, or analog, for nicotine that had fewer toxic effects on the cardiovascular system. In devising a response, Philip Morris was apparently concerned about raising the issue of addiction.

HEADLINE: Poles Say, 'Thank You, America,' and Czechs and Hungarians Voice Delight

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, May 1

 BODY:
Poland's leaders and people greeted the United States Senate's vote to approve their NATO membership with relief and delight today, praising the vote as the beginning of a promising new era that would overcome a century of dark history.
"Thank you, America," exclaimed Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek, breaking out into his rarely used English on Polish television today. 
 In the Czech Republic and Hungary, where public support for NATO membership had been more muted than in Poland, the reaction to Thursday night's vote was also enthusiastic.
The Czech President, Vaclav Havel, who is recuperating from an operation in Austria, said in a statement that the Senate vote would help build the "foundations of stability in the entire Euro-Atlantic area."
And in Hungary, Prime Minister Gyula Horn, a former Communist, said his country should interpret the favorable vote as a sign that Hungary met "international requirements for freedom, democracy and a market economy."
The Governments of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic have been working for four years toward the Senate vote, which they regarded as the final hurdle toward NATO membership. To win Senate approval, the three Central European countries have been trying to reform their armed forces and to meet the standards of democracy and free enterprise required by the alliance.
In Poland, the largest and strategically most important of the three, the Government watched the maneuvering in the Senate very closely, and by this week politicians and the media were following the debate in minute detail. There was wide coverage of proposed amendments and apprehension that the vote, delayed earlier this month, might be delayed again.
In a statement issued soon after the vote, Prime Minister Buzek expressed the historical importance for Poland. "The decision of the United States Senate is the final obliteration of Yalta by the only remaining superpower," he said, referring to the agreement in 1945 that placed Eastern and Central Europe under Soviet influence. "The United States has included us in the elite team of NATO allies."
The strong endorsement shown in the Senate vote -- 80 to 19 -- was noted by some with considerable pride.
"Eighty votes in favor is a lot," the Czech Ambassador to the United States, Alexandr Vondra, said in Washington.
"I believe it's more votes than Germany got in 1954," he said, referring to when the allies admitted West Germany into NATO. "It's a communication of trust and confidence."
Then, Mr. Vondra added in a stern tone, "People at home should realize what it means."
The Czechs have been the most equivocal about joining NATO among the people in the three countries, with only 50 percent of Czechs saying they favored membership, according to a poll conducted by the Public Opinion Research Institute in Prague this month.
In Poland, where there is an instinctive fear of Russia and where the military is the most highly esteemed national institution, opinion surveys have shown more than 80 percent support for inclusion in NATO.
The news of the vote came on a major public holiday in Central Europe -- the May Day holiday that commemorates workers. In Poland no newspapers were published, but news of the vote spread quickly. Many people regarded it as a victory.
"I think we will be more secure, and more security means more prosperity," said Jacek Zembruski, 30, a real estate developer, as he walked with his friend Iwona Gawron, 30, in Lazienki Park in Warsaw.
"I hope the NATO documents will be more respected than other security documents Poland had before 1939," added Ms. Gawron, a reference to the failure of Poland's allies to come to her help before the German attack that started World War II in Europe.
One of the most emotional moments came in the gallery of the United States Senate when immediately after the vote, the former head of the Polish section of Radio Free Europe, Jan Nowak-Jezioranska, 87, leaned over to the Polish Ambassador, Jerzy Kozminski, and said, "We lived to see it."

HEADLINE: $2.3 Billion in Housing Aid Is Cut From Spending Bill

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
Buried inside a $6 billion emergency spending bill signed by President Clinton today is a $2.3 billion cut to a Federal program that assists low-income tenants. New York City housing officials and advocates said the reduction could be devastating to big cities if Congress fails to restore the funds later this year.
Mr. Clinton, who had threatened to veto the bill if the housing funds were cut, changed course and decided to sign the measure after receiving assurances from House Republicans that the $2.3 billion would be restored during the appropriations process this summer, Administration officials said. The emergency spending bill provides money for disaster relief and for peacekeeping operations in Bosnia and the Persian Gulf. 
 "The threat of having existing housing decreased was frightening," said Karen Hinton, a spokeswoman for Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. "Once there were assurances the funding would be restored, the Administration made the decision not to veto."
But city housing officials, housing advocates and some Congressional Democrats said that President Clinton, with his signature today, had set the stage for a contentious battle over housing funds later this year, one they said they were not optimistic about winning.
They said it was impossible for Congressional leaders to guarantee that the $2.3 billion would be completely restored, because Congress is already struggling to provide funds for transportation, health care and education programs. And they warned that even if the Republican leadership succeeded in finding $2.3 billion, the money would probably come out of other housing programs.
Officials with the New York City Housing Authority said they were most concerned that Congress would try to provide the $2.3 billion by reducing programs that help cities maintain and operate public housing projects.
"While they say they'll bring the money back, it never comes," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from Queens and Brooklyn. "If past experience is any indication, housing will certainly suffer. It's always been the weak sister politically."
At stake are funds for the Section 8 program, which subsidizes the rents of poor families living in private apartments. The New York City Housing Authority estimates that it provides Section 8 assistance to 74,000 low-income households.
The Department of Housing and Urban Development has estimated that $2.3 billion is enough to subsidize the rent of 420,000 households nationwide, about 20,000 in the New York metropolitan area.
Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Republican from Suffolk County and chairman of the House subcommittee on housing and community development, said he did not think the $2.3 billion would be shifted from other housing programs.
But he said the House Republican leadership might insist that Congress enact major revisions to national housing policy, including allowing cities to place more working families into public housing projects, before it provided funds for existing housing programs. Mr. Lazio is the author of the main House bill dealing with public housing. Mr. Cuomo and many tenant groups strongly oppose Mr. Lazio's bill.

HEADLINE: Beliefs

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
For three decades, Daniel Callahan has been a leader in the field of biomedical ethics. One of the first philosophers to tackle topics that had begun to worry leading scientists, he joined with Dr. Willard Gaylin, a psychoanalyst, to found the Hastings Center in 1969. The institute brought together medical clinicians and researchers, legal scholars, ethicists, theologians, historians, social scientists and government officials to examine issues arising from human genetics, new reproductive technologies, organ transplantation and other developments in biomedicine.
By the time Dr. Callahan retired as director of the center in 1996, what was once a series of ad hoc forays into ethics conundrums had been transformed into a well-established field of systematic inquiry. He now concentrates on writing and, as the center's director of international programs, on promoting similar discussion in Europe and elsewhere. This spring he published his ninth book, "False Hopes: Why America's Quest for Perfect Health Is a Recipe for Failure" (Simon & Schuster). This week, in phone calls and faxes interrupting his preparations for a lecturing trip to South America, he responded to some questions. 
 Q. Over the last quarter-century, there has been an explosion of activity in the field of applied ethics -- books, courses, conferences, journals, institutes, government commissions, all dealing with ethics in medicine, business, law, advertising, journalism. Is so much attention and debate a sign that society has become less ethical, more ethical or simply confused?
A. What's striking about the recent interest in ethics is that there are a variety of motives at work. Part of the interest stems from a general worry about the state of morality, and there the focus is on shaping morally sensitive, decent people -- good family members and conscientious citizens. Courses on ethics or values in high school and at the undergraduate college level reflect that concern.
Another part stems from a desire to reduce overtly bad behavior and to set rules to avoid such behavior. Business ethics, legal ethics and advertising ethics have had a strong thrust in that direction.
Still another part stems from attempting to cope with novel moral dilemmas, well outside the scope of traditional moral codes. Biomedical ethics is the most prominent example of this.
More generally, there is considerable confusion about ethics, and there are plenty of examples of bad ethics around. Are we more or less ethical? We are probably more ethical at the public level -- in our politics and major social institutions -- and less so at the personal level, in great part because the "personal" is thought to be off limits to moral scrutiny, a sad and profound mistake.
Q. Not long ago, you suggested that biology and medicine might be experiencing an ethics backlash. What provoked that speculation?
A. During the early years of American bioethics, in the 1960's and 1970's, many physicians reacted negatively to the thought of lawyers, philosophers and social scientists helping them out with ethical problems. "Stay out of our profession!" That response passed, and by the 1980's bioethics was well accepted.
Of late, however, particularly in the wake of the cloning debate, a number of prominent scientists have said, in effect, "All this ethics talk is just standing in the way of research and progress, and you can't stop any of it anyway!" But if ethics is doing its job well, and not just acting as moral legitimator and research cheerleader, it should be causing trouble.
Q. Your latest book, "False Hopes," follows other books -- about technology, medicine, aging and death -- in which you have dwelt on the importance of a culture that respects limits. In one sense, ethics has always been about limits. But isn't the contemporary approach to ethics, which seems to focus on resolving immediate practical problems, apt to remain marginal to that kind of deep cultural issue?
A. The setting of reasonable limits on technology and our aspirations for never-ending medical progress is, I believe, the single most important challenge in the care of the dying, the future of Medicare, resource allocation and the uses of genetic knowledge, to mention only a few examples.
Yet our culture hates any talk of limits, and so do most professionals in health care. The most common tendency is to think that greater efficiency and better management will enable us to finesse any need to set limits. That's the American way.
My conviction, though, is that ethics must take on our underlying cultural patterns; that's often where the trouble begins. I suppose I would like to see something of a cultural conversion experience at that level, but only in the environmental arena do we see some hints of that possibility.
Q. American health care is increasingly governed by market mechanisms. Is this, too, a "false hope," unlikely to create what you call "sustainable medicine"?
A. I have borrowed from the environmental field the notion of "sustainability" for application in medicine: sustainable medicine. By that, I mean a medicine that is affordable and equitable, which means a medicine of limits and more modest aspirations. The expanding role of the market in health care is one of the gravest challenges to a sustainable medicine. Markets play to our individual wants and desires, and look to profit, not to the health of populations.
It is surely a "false hope" to think that in the market alone lies the way to affordable and equitable health care; there is no place in the world that this has happened or is likely to happen.
Yet there are some market tactics, such as competition and economic incentives, that might effectively contribute to a sustainable medicine. But they must be used carefully and must, above all, be carefully monitored and regulated by government. The key to any success the market might have lies not in less government interference but in thoughtful and judicious interference.

HEADLINE: Blacks at Berkeley Are Offering No Welcome Mat

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., May 1

 BODY:
In springs past, Dana Inman took pains to persuade black students who were offered admission to the University of California's most renowned, selective campus to join her here.
Once the letters announcing their acceptance went out, the hard sell began, and Ms. Inman, a senior at Berkeley now, hit the telephone lines, calling prospective freshmen. 
 But not this year. Reeling from the news that under a new process that eliminated affirmative action, only 191 blacks were among the 8,034 students admitted for the class of 2002, Ms. Inman said she was unable in good conscience to tell those students that they would be wiser to choose the University of California at Berkeley than someplace else.
And when some of those high school seniors visited the campus two weeks ago, what Ms. Inman, director of the Black Recruitment and Retention Center, and several others in the organization gave them was not exactly a pitch.
"We told them that it's a very hostile environment and that we're not welcome here, and they don't want us here because they're not letting us in," Ms. Inman said. "We weren't pushing them to come to Cal."
As black students, administrators and professors here confront the precipitous decline in admissions of African-Americans, there is perhaps no better measure of their anguish than the reluctance or unwillingness of many of them to persuade the black students admitted for the academic year starting next fall to join them.
University officials say that Berkeley is as receptive to minority students as ever, and that the decline was the unavoidable consequence of a race-blind approach to admissions mandated by Proposition 209, a 1996 ballot initiative that barred the consideration of race, ethnicity or sex in public employment, contracting and admissions to public colleges and universities in California. To preserve as much diversity as possible, they have begun an intense campaign to persuade a high percentage of the minority students admitted to enroll at Berkeley.
Nonetheless, many African-Americans feel betrayed and insulted by what happened, and have told prospective students to beware of what could be an isolating experience.
No matter how successful the university's efforts are, black students are likely to make up less than 2 percent of the incoming freshman class, as opposed to 7.3 percent of the current one. Today is the deadline for students to mail letters telling the university they plan to attend, but Berkeley officials said it could be two to three weeks before they receive and open all the mail.
As the deadline approached, some black members of the faculty said they declined or ignored university officials' unusual request that they volunteer to call five or more prospective students to sing Berkeley's praises.
They said that while they knew their lack of cooperation might further reduce the number of black students, they worried about encouraging African-Americans to enter what they regard as a divisive, politically fraught arena, a national laboratory for the dismantling of affirmative action in higher education.
Even Berkeley's director of black student development, Grace Carroll Massey, has decided not to help woo blacks, seemingly in defiance of her job. When prospective black students or their parents contacted her, she pulled no punches.
"This is the first year I've told students who asked me not to go to Berkeley, but to go to Stanford," said Dr. Massey, who is planning to leave her job at the end of this year, but only in part because of this issue.
African-Americans at Berkeley and elsewhere in the University of California system are by no means alone in their alarm over the impact of Proposition 209. This year's undergraduate admissions process was the first affected by the law.
At Berkeley, the number of black students offered admission dropped to 191 from 562 last year, while the number of Hispanic students dropped to 600 from 1,266. Proponents of the referendum said the decline proved that these groups had enjoyed an unfair advantage before.
The declines were smaller at less selective campuses in the system; at one, the University of California at Riverside, the number of blacks accepted rose 34 percent. But many university officials openly agonized over what they said was a dire threat to the multicultural complexion of Berkeley, a place long associated with eclectic ideas and progressive politics. They maintained that every student's educational experience could be diminished by a campus less heterogeneous and less reflective of the society beyond it.
Since the number of minority students accepted at Berkeley was made public a month ago, Berkeley officials have worked to minimize the effect, holding special receptions for minority students and sending out special promotional videos. Chancellor Robert M. Berdahl said he had even called about 50 black and Hispanic students himself.
"We have done everything that we could think of," Mr. Berdahl said.
Meanwhile, many California politicians and corporate leaders have called for changes in the educational system to help improve the academic performance and test scores of minority students.
But nowhere does the anxiety seem as keen as among the African-Americans and Hispanic-Americans on University of California campuses. And it has found particularly compelling expression in the ambivalence that Berkeley students feel over whether to reach out to peers who have been admitted and what to say to them.
On the one hand, they want minorities to remain a visible, vibrant presence at Berkeley. On the other, they have reservations about how comfortable black and Hispanic members of next year's freshman class will be.
Hispanic student leaders and administrators said that despite spirited debate, for the most part they have adopted the same position as university officials and have intensified their appeals to prospective freshmen.
They said they probably felt better than African-Americans about recommending Berkeley because the Hispanic population was larger. While only 6.1 percent of the current 21,738 undergraduates at Berkeley are black, Hispanic students make up 13.2 percent, and three times as many Hispanic students as black students were offered admission for next fall.
To be sure, there are many African-Americans at Berkeley who have urged the black students accepted by the university to enroll. The writer June Jordan, a professor of African-American studies, said she has told prospective black freshmen: "I implore you to come. This is our school. This is our state. This is our country. Let us not yield here."
But even Ms. Jordan feels the tug of the opposite sentiment, which she said was more prevalent among African-Americans on campus.
"What we're talking about," she said, "is that if you can't sit at the table, you're not going to ask anybody to pick up the crumbs that fall to the floor."
The officers of the Black Recruitment and Retention Center said that in previous years, shortly after the university sent out acceptance letters, a group of 15 to 20 students would work the phones at the undergraduate admissions office.
This year, the officers said, they decided not to, although some members of the group did so on their own. They also entertained the idea of canceling the weekend when they entertain prospective black students visiting the campus. Since arrangements were under way before the admissions numbers were made public, they went ahead with it, though less enthusiastically.
"Before, we were ultra-utopian: Berkeley's the best, you've got to come here, definitely," Kerri Harper, a senior who is the center's assistant director, said as she sat in its campus office. There was a poster of Malcolm X on a wall behind her and, on a wall to her side, a T-shirt that proclaimed, "Black by Nature, Proud by Choice."
Ms. Harper said that the message this time around was that Berkeley was a gamble, and that black students might need extra poise to survive in what could be a minuscule minority. "I'm really concerned that a lot of students are going to be left out in the cold," she said.
Gregg Thomson, director of the office of student research, said that if the enrollment decisions made by the top 191 of the 562 African-Americans admitted last year were an accurate harbinger, Berkeley could end up with fewer than 30 percent of the 191 black students admitted this year. At that rate, the incoming class could have fewer than 57 black students, representing slightly more than 1.5 percent of all freshmen.
Indeed, Berkeley accepted fewer black students than Stanford University in nearby Palo Alto, which offered 238 black students admission into a freshman class half the size of Berkeley's.
Stanford, a private university, still practices affirmative action, and several African-American leaders at Berkeley said officials here should have done the same, taking a moral stand against the referendum.
Some also said that there must have been ways, short of violating the law, for university officials to give more consideration to the quality of the high schools that black applicants with lower standardized test scores had attended. University officials said that they did take that into account.
But the disappointment and anger that many African-Americans at Berkeley feel boil down to a fervent belief that California should not have abandoned affirmative action, which they said merely lowers the obstacles created by racism and, in some cases, economic hardship.
Three of four top officers of the Black Recruitment and Retention Center who were interviewed said that without affirmative action, they almost certainly would not have been admitted to Berkeley. But all three are getting good grades and said they deserved to be here, even though they now felt less welcome.
"If the university does not want people like me anymore, that means I'm unwanted," said Jimar Wilson, a junior who is the center's co-chairman for recruiting.
Chancellor Berdahl said he had spent hours over the past few weeks trying to vanquish that thinking and exhorting students like Mr. Wilson not to give up on Berkeley.
"I have said to them, basically, that there isn't any place that I think it's more important to be right now than here," he said. "Because there's no place where this issue is being confronted more viscerally."

Stocks End Volatile Week With Solid Advance
The stock market strengthened for a third day and ended the week with gains that more than erased the market plunge Monday, when fear that the Federal Reserve could move to raise interest rates caused heavy selloffs. Further evidence of benign inflation, seen in a widely followed monthly report on American manufacturing, helped reassure investors that the bull market still has stamina. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 83.70 points, to 9,147.07, finishing the week with a gain of 82.45 points. Page D3.
 
Bonds extended their rebound on eased anxieties about higher inflation, pushing the yield on 30-year Treasury issue down to 5.93 percent from 5.94 D3.
 
Purchaser Data Reveal Weaknesses
Falling orders and a decline in employment helped slow the pace of American manufacturing in April, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report on the economy. Other signs of economic weakness were seen in Government reports that showed sharp decreases in personal income and reduced spending on new construction. D2.
 
Succession Signal at Southwest
Herbert D. Kelleher, the 67-year-old executive who personifies Southwest Airlines, named a new second-in-command and apparently narrowed the contest to succeed him. Mr. Kelleher's appetite for running the fast-growing airline remains strong, however, and he is not expected to retire soon. D2.
 
New Twist in Japan's Trade Surplus
The climb in Japan's trade surplus has increased the likelihood of a protectionist backlash in this country, but the Japanese car industry is hoping to avoid wrath by limiting exports to the American market. D2.
 
Clouds Over Euro Meeting
As European leaders meet this weekend to approve the final preparations for a single European currency, the euro, political squabbles and national differences have taken central stage. A4.
 
Bank of Japan Official Found Dead
An executive director of Japan's central bank, who had been supervising an internal corruption investigation, was found hanged, and police called it an apparent suicide. The official, Takayuki Kamoshida, 58, was not reported to be the subject of any corruption investigation. D2.

Ivan G. Seidenberg, president of Bell Atlantic, took a surprisingly fast step toward the top post of the big local telephone carrier, which announced he would become chief executive June 1, succeeding Raymond W. Smith. Mr. Seidenberg, who began his phone career as a cable splicer's helper more than 30 years ago, had not been expected to take the chief executive job until January. D3.

Hughes Electronics will pay $846 million to raise its stake in Panamsat by 9.5 percent, to 81 percent. Owning more than 80 percent of the satellite company provides a tax advantage to the General Motors subsidiary. D3.
 
Closings in South Korea
Dongsuh and Coryo, two financially ailing South Korean securities firms, faced a Government shutdown after securities regulators recommended revoking their licenses. The closings would be a first in South Korea's securities industry. D2.
 
Oxford Pitching High-Yield Bonds
Oxford Health Plans has started soliciting potential investors as it looks to sell high-yield bonds as part of a $700 million financing package. The move came as Moody's assigned Oxford ratings below investment grade and said it was concerned about Oxford's ability to retain customers. D2.

HEADLINE: Euro Follows American Example

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In two articles critical of the euro, William Safire (column, April 30) and Josef Joffe (Op-Ed, May 1) suggest that the United States did not have a central bank until the Federal Reserve was established in 1913. 
 In fact, one of George Washington's first great successes as President was the Bank of the United States of 1791. This central bank was only decisively destroyed by President Andrew Jackson in the 1830's -- a decision that helped precipitate the disastrous Panic of 1837.
The European Union is moving along the same path traveled by the early American Republic. Fifty years after 1776, the American Union was held together by little more than a customs union, a national bank, a tiny army and a weak judicial system. The development of a national free market slowly prepared the way for increasing political integration.
The European strategy of "economics first" thus has an important precedent.
 
BRUCE ACKERMAN
New Haven, May 1, 1998
 
The writer is a professor at Yale Law School.

LENGTH: 878 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Help for North Korea on Fuel

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, May 1

 BODY:
With increasing urgency, the United States is pressing Japan, South Korea and other countries for more money to supplement North Korea's energy supplies -- a key part of a deal that got North Korea to stop developing nuclear weapons. But Washington's efforts have had little success so far, American officials said today.
Without new money to pay for the heavy fuel oil that North Korea has been promised, the officials said, there is a high risk that the North Koreans might begin to renege on their 1994 agreement to stop operating nuclear reactors and abandon their nuclear weapons program. 
 The United States, President Clinton has promised North Korea, will be the ultimate guarantor of the deal that averted a threat of war on the peninsula four years ago.
The provision of some 500,000 tons of fuel oil a year, worth about $60 million, is largely an American responsibility. But with midterm elections approaching, the Administration has had increasing trouble getting the Republican Congress to finance foreign policy programs without amendments that the White House prefers not to sign.
"There is a gap in funding for fuel oil that we are trying to close," an American official said today. "And if we do not finance the heavy-oil deliveries, there is a grave risk that North Korea will stop cooperating."
The organization set up to handle the provision of fuel oil, the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, is known as KEDO. If it reneges, the official continued, "we expect the North Koreans to react at some point in a way to jeopardize the agreement, which we believe so far that they have been adhering to."
The American officials traveling with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright here on her first official visit with the new Korean President, Kim Dae Jung, are clearly trying to ratchet up pressure on Congress, and other countries, to save the agreement.
In addition to providing the fuel oil, KEDO is scheduled to build two light-water reactors to replace the more dangerous ones being closed.
But the group already owes about $47 million on previous oil shipments. Congress has agreed to help retire that debt, but only along with other countries, which it insists must provide the bulk of the money first.
Over the last two years Washington has paid $20 million to $25 million, and the European Union has contributed $17 million. Japan provided a $19 million line of credit last year. There have also been modest contributions from Australia, New Zealand and Canada.
As one American official put it: "The underlying problem is that the executive branch overestimated the extent to which we were going to be able to secure commitments from other countries." The official added, "KEDO and the United States have been rattling tin cups around the world."
But KEDO has another problem. The financing arrangements for the $5 billion or so to provide the two light-water reactors was also left incomplete. South Korea, which will provide the reactors and the workers to build them, pledged 70 percent of the cost, with the Japanese providing a billion yen. But that is worth less now in dollars, and covers now only about 20 percent of the remainder.
Another $500 million or so -- about 10 percent -- has yet to be found, American officials say. They have tried the European Union and various countries in the Middle East.
There is less urgency on this issue, because work on the reactors is still in its early stages. Large amounts for parts and construction will not be needed for another year.
President Kim renewed his pledge to Ms. Albright today that Korea would keep its money commitments despite the economic crisis here. But worries persist that Seoul will have difficulty down the road. Japan, too, is going through a crisis and has less money to throw around now than four years ago.
Given the seriousness of the threat, an American official said, "we think all of this should have been easier to do." The official added, "We think the accountants shouldn't be running this but the national security councils should be."
But another official acknowledged that the economic climate and the looming expense of the reactors might explain other countries' reluctance to bail Washington out on the fuel oil money just because Mr. Clinton is having problems with Congress.
 Ms. Albright and Mr. Kim discussed this issue and the economic crisis in some detail today, American experts said.
It was their first meeting since 1986, when Ms. Albright, then a Georgetown University professor, came here on a trip sponsored by the National Democratic Institute. Mr. Kim, then an opposition leader, invited her to dinner and presented her with a decorative scroll reading, in Korean, "If you seek real, practical goals, you will achieve them."
Today she brought that gift back with her, offering it to President Kim in recognition of his success, telling him she was moved to see him, a noted fighter for democracy and human rights, as Korea's leader, said an American official briefing the press.
Mr. Kim said the United States had saved his life twice: first when he was kidnapped in 1973, presumably at the instigation of his country's Government, and again in 1980, when he was under a death sentence.

HEADLINE: Leaders in Hartford Agree to Budget Deal With Rebates

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 1

 BODY:
Graced with a large surplus and a strong economy, Gov. John G. Rowland and Democratic legislative leaders have reached a mostly painless budget agreement in which both sides accomplished what they most wanted.
In a compromise made late Thursday, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, secured agreement on the centerpiece of his state budget plan, a proposal that Democrats had at first scoffed at: rebate checks of up to $150 for taxpayers, sent out before the November gubernatorial election. 
 In exchange, Democrats, who control the Legislature, would be able to increase property-tax relief and expand the tax rebates to lower-income people.
Today, hours before legislators began debate on the $11 billion budget, Mr. Rowland said he would have preferred larger rebate checks. But he downplayed his failure to get the tax rate reduced, and said he was pleased with the compromise.
The House passed the spending portion of the budget early this morning, 145 to 4. The Senate is expected to debate the plan and approve it today. Budget negotiations were simplified by a $500 million surplus, caused largely by increased revenue from the personal income and sales taxes. Democrats who called Mr. Rowland's rebate plan a gimmick when he announced it in February said they could no longer oppose it as the surplus grew. After Democrats balked at Mr. Rowland's plan to send checks in late October, shortly before the gubernatorial election, they compromised by agreeing to send checks in late July.
The $115 million in rebates will come from the surplus, allowing about 1.2 million taxpayers to receive rebates: joint filers will receive as much as $150; heads of households, $120, and single filers, $75. Under Governor Rowland's original proposal, about 800,000 taxpayers would have received rebates of as much as $200. The rebate, like a refund, will be taxable for those who itemize on their Federal tax returns, Marc Ryan, the deputy budget director, said.
State Representative Christopher DePino, chairman of the State Republican Party, said the rebate was a political victory for Mr. Rowland.
"It's the Governor's initiative," Mr. DePino said. "It'll be the Governor's signature on the bill, and when the check's in the mail, it will come from the Governor."
Although Democratic leaders have agreed to the rebate, Mr. Rowland's likely Democratic challenger in November, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, said that she would have used the money to reduce property taxes and the state's debt or to invest in education.
Mrs. Kennelly's campaign co-chairman, State House Speaker Thomas D. Ritter, accepted the budget compromise. The $11 billion budget, which takes effect on July 1, adjusts the second half of a two-year budget approved last year by increasing spending about 5 percent.
In addition to the tax rebate, the two sides worked out an additional 1 cent cut in the gasoline tax, which will now go down 4 cents on July 1. The tax is currently 36 cents a gallon. The House approved the gas tax cut at 11:30 last night, 149-0, but the Senate adjourned at 10:20 P.M.
Democrats were able to win $45 million in property tax credits. Currently, people who paid taxes on a car or home can receive a $215 credit on their state income tax; that credit has been raised to $350.
The compromise also has $10 million in reduced sales taxes, including elimination of the tax on newspapers, coupons and rebates.
The budget has several increases in education spending, including $25 million for aid to towns and cities, $20 million for a new reading program, $12 million in scholarships and a tuition freeze for students at state colleges. About $30 million is being budgeted for a new program to subsidize health insurance for uninsured children.
The surplus allows the state to put $162 million into its rainy day fund, increasing the fund to $500 million. This amount is close to what bonding companies recommend: 5 percent.
Michael P. Meotti, president of the nonpartisan Connecticut Policy and Economic Council Inc., said that the rebate checks would have little impact. "I'd be hard pressed to feel people will remember the great rebate of 1998," Mr. Meotti said.

HEADLINE: Democrats Threaten to Oppose I.M.F. Bill

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 1

 BODY:
The House Democratic leader and five other senior Democrats threatened today to withdraw support for President Clinton's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund, dealing a serious new setback to one of the Administration's top foreign policy goals.
Support from the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, and most House Democrats represents the Administration's last hope for pushing the new financing through an increasingly hostile Republican-led House. The Senate strongly supports the financing. 
 Speaker Newt Gingrich threatened this week to bottle up the financing unless the Administration cooperated with a House inquiry into fund-raising for Mr. Clinton's re-election campaign in 1996. Last week Congressional Republican leaders dropped the $18 billion request from a popular emergency-spending bill.
Those two actions, fueled by Republican anger that the fund remains a dangerously secretive agency that rebuffs reforms, have left the financing measure hanging by a thread in Congress.
In a sharply worded letter to Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin today, Mr. Gephardt and his colleagues threatened to snip that thread if the Administration did not stop pressing for the fund's plan to enhance the unrestricted movement of investments in and out of countries.
The lawmakers wrote that "our support for additional I.M.F. funding will be in jeopardy if the U.S. Government continues" to support the fund's plan.
For Congress, there are two major issues related to the fund: the short-term issue of helping to replenish the I.M.F.'s treasury, depleted by more than $100 billion in loans to Asian countries; and what long-term changes in the agency's lending practices the United States should lobby for in the 162-member organization.
As the fund responds to the increasingly global marketplace by enhancing the movement of capital, House Democrats in particular fear that not enough attention is being paid to mitigating the human consequences of this globalization.
The immediate issue that prompted the letter from Mr. Gephardt and other House Democrats is an amendment to the I.M.F. charter that would allow the organization, when studying a country's economy, to examine its openness to all types of investment.
That would include a country's restrictions on allowing foreigners to buy stocks, bonds and factories or make any other kind of investment. But the I.M.F. could not require a country to open its financial markets. At most, it could criticize the country for failing to open up.
Many House Democrats have sought to couple any ability to take money in and out of a country with protections for workers and human rights.
"The amendment talks only about the liberalization of capital," Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts said in an interview. "We thought we had a deal here, and now it looks like they are backing away."
Besides Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Frank, the other House Democrats who signed the letter were David E. Bonior of Michigan, the second-ranking House Democrat; and Nancy Pelosi, Maxine Waters and Esteban E. Torres of California.
Howard Schloss, Mr. Rubin's spokesman, said today: "We agree with the members on the importance of the issues raised in their letter. We have been working with Congress as we carry out discussions in the G-7 and with the international financial institutions. We intend to explore the most effective ways to address these issues, and will continue to work with Congress."
The timing of the letter coincided with news that the United States is preparing to back a $1 billion payment in international emergency aid to Indonesia on Monday, despite evidence that President Suharto and his family continue to undermine efforts to break up the monopolies they control. But lawmakers said that was not the focus of their complaint.
Democratic strategists said the letter was intended to keep Democrats united behind the $18 billion financing package, and to warn the Administration against any changes in the fund's charter that could hurt workers or other people in countries that accept economic austerity measures in exchange for the fund's below-market loans.
"What Gephardt intends here is not for anyone to take the Democrats for granted," said Representative Robert T. Matsui of California, the senior Democrat on the House Ways and Means trade subcommittee.
Despite the Democrats' reservations, the I.M.F. has repeatedly said this year that it favors only "orderly" liberalization of markets.
It fears that if countries open up too quickly, their banking and regulatory systems may not be able to manage the inflow and outflow of foreign cash.
Some nations resist such openings, saying money that flows out of the country too fast could worsen an economic crisis. That happened to some nations in Asia last fall: once economic news turned sour, investors pulled out all at once, making a bad situation worse.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 4, 1998, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about a threat by senior House Democrats to withdraw support for the Clinton Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund misstated the number of countries in the organization. It is 182, not 162.

HEADLINE: Holy Orders

BYLINE: By Paul Baumann; Paul Baumann is the executive editor of Commonweal magazine.

 BODY:

THE SEVILLE COMMUNION
 By Arturo Perez-Reverte.
 Translated by Sonia Soto.
 375 pp. New York:
 Harcourt Brace & Company. $24. 
 Seville is known for its barbers, its Gypsy temptresses, its Latin lovers; for the tomb (if not the actual body) of Christopher Columbus, bullfights, orange blossoms, Holy Week processions and an extraordinary mix of Arab, Baroque and Renaissance architecture. Julius Caesar conquered it; the Roman Emperors Hadrian and Trajan were born nearby; the Vandals, Visigoths, Moors and crusaders grudgingly passed it on to one another. It was the site of the Spanish Inquisition's first auto-da-fe, but, most important, the home port of Spain's bounteous New World empire. "Dramatic extravagance," V. S. Pritchett once observed, "is in the Sevillian nature."
And dramatic extravagance is what the former journalist Arturo Perez-Reverte provides in "The Seville Communion," his third thriller (following "The Flanders Panel" and "The Club Dumas") to be published in English and the second to be translated by Sonia Soto. Perez-Reverte writes with wit, narrative economy, a sharp eye for the telling detail and a feel for history. "The Seville Communion" is good fun, as entertaining as it often is silly.
How silly? Silly enough to describe the Vatican as "40 hectares containing the most powerful state on earth" and to allow its hero to go weak-kneed at the way a woman retrieves her cigarette lighter from under her bra strap. Silly enough to have a cardinal pine for the good old days of the Inquisition and a duchess recall that "great-great-great-grandfather Fernando was governor of California before they took it from us." Still, any novel that can survive its protagonist looking "like Richard Chamberlain in 'The Thorn Birds' but more manly" obviously knows on which side its extravagance is buttered.
The hero in question is the Rev. Lorenzo Quart, the "sexiest priest" alive, outside of the latest Andrew Greeley yarn. A "weary, solitary Knight Templar," Quart works for the Vatican's very hush-hush Institute for External Affairs, from which he is discreetly dispatched to defuse threats to Holy Mother Church. He is emphatically not "the kind of priest who turned the other cheek." He is a St. James Bond, an agent in a Roman collar and handmade leather shoes who wields a Mont Blanc pen instead of a snub-nosed Beretta.
Quart's assignment in Seville concerns the proposed purchase and demolition of a deteriorating 17th-century Baroque church, Our Lady of the Tears. After two people eager to close the church have ended up dead, an anonymous hacker breaks into the Pope's personal computer, leaving an ominous message suggesting that the embattled church "kills to defend itself." Seville's ambitious archbishop, in cahoots with real estate interests, is determined to dislodge Our Lady of the Tears' obdurate pastor and sell the property. But the seemingly unsophisticated parish priest has powerful allies in one of Seville's most venerable families, which happens to have historic ties to the 300-year-old church. That's where the lady with the incendiary cigarette lighter comes in, a raven-haired "Andalusian beauty" who "was too much even for a man with the nerves of Lorenzo Quart."
Perez-Reverte unravels his mystery by cutting back and forth among discrete but converging stories and sets of characters. A hapless trio of henchpersons (including a punch-drunk ex-boxer/bullfighter and a washed-up flamenco singer) bring a welcome bit of slapstick to the proceedings. There is the inevitable ornery, jeans-wearing American nun, as well as a ruthless banker (estranged from the Andalusian beauty) and plenty of viperish ecclesiastical intrigue.
Almost all of Perez-Reverte's characters are plausible, but usually as types. His vivid descriptions of the city, like his stories of Seville's outsize romantic and heroic past, are more resonant. Good at making the reader want answers, he is less good at giving satisfying ones. Finally, motive and explanation are too stagy and, more disappointing, the murderer is too peripheral to the psychological heart of the story. There's also a lot of facile talk about splendid buildings and elaborate ritual as a "means of entrancing the masses" because "naked faith can't be sustained." Much of this seems filched from the Cliffs Notes to Dostoyevsky's "Grand Inquisitor." Still, you'd have to be a remarkably faithless reader not to want to visit Seville after finishing this flavorful confection.
