HEADLINE: American Empire

BYLINE: By Walter A. McDougall; Walter A. McDougall is a professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania and the author, most recently, of "Promised Land, Crusader State: The American Encounter With the World Since 1776."

 BODY:

FROM WEALTH TO POWER
 The Unusual Origins
 of America's World Role.
 By Fareed Zakaria.
 199 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
 Princeton University Press. $29.95. 
 This thin doctoral thesis would ordinarily pass unnoticed outside academic circles, but it should attract wider attention for three reasons. First, its author is no obscure assistant professor, but the managing editor of Foreign Affairs, the premier American foreign policy journal. Second, its tightly argued thesis addresses a question sure to be revisited during this anniversary of the Spanish-American War: to wit, why the United States in 1898 suddenly cast off its traditions and, in an imperialist jag, claimed the role of a global power. Third, its conclusions are both provocative and full of implications for the world today.
Fareed Zakaria begins in the mode of political science by defining a theoretical problem and reviewing two dominant schools of thought. Why, he asks, do nations expand? Clearly they cannot do so unless and until they acquire the requisite material power vis-a-vis their victims or rivals. But mere measures of strength cannot account for the motives or timing of a nation's expansion. That is the weakness of the school of classical realism, which holds that nations define their interests more broadly as their power expands, and that increases in power predictably yield assertive policies.
An alternative explanation is that nations expand their interests when they feel less secure, when they perceive threats that demand a response. But perceptions cannot be measured exactly, while aggressive governments invariably invoke "national security" whether or not it is endangered. That is the weakness of the school of defensive realism, which holds that interests come first, and that power is mobilized when interests are threatened.
That is to say, classical realism cannot explain the "imperial understretch" of the United States between 1865 and 1890 despite its having become one of the world's mightiest nations. Defensive realism, on the other hand, cannot explain why the United States projected its power with zeal after 1890 despite the relative absence of serious threats.
Zakaria endeavors to solve this puzzle by making a distinction between the nation and the state. "The state" is a concept taken for granted in European political thought, but neglected if not despised by Americans.
After the Civil War the American nation quickly surpassed Europe's great powers in size, population, production, technology or all four. But in foreign and military affairs power must be mobilized, which requires that decision makers not only define the national interest in terms of expansion, but command an administration able to harness their nation's might. Throughout the 19th century America never lacked for expansionist prophets -- chief among them William Henry Seward, the Secretary of State under Abraham Lincoln and Andrew Johnson -- but with the exception of the Civil War years Congress reigned as the dominant branch of government. As Senator George Hoar put it, his colleagues would have considered it a "personal affront" for the President to lobby them on legislation. "If they visited the White House, it was to give, not to receive, advice," with the result that, in Zakaria's words, "weak executive power translated into passivity and inaction in foreign policy."
What happened between 1877 and 1896, according to Zakaria, was "the rise of the American state." The proximate cause was industrialization, which threw up social problems beyond the resources of the individual states. So the Civil Service Commission, the Bureau of Labor and the Interstate Commerce Commission were born. Next, the Administrations of Rutherford B. Hayes, Chester A. Arthur, Grover Cleveland and Benjamin Harrison redressed the balance between the executive and legislative branches by wielding the veto, abolishing patronage through civil service reform and choosing Cabinet officers loyal to the President rather than to influential factions in Congress. Third, dynamic secretaries of the Navy and of war and progressive officers like Adm. Steven B. Luce and Capt. Alfred Thayer Mahan persuaded Congress to vote funds for a modern steel Navy and larger professional Army (as opposed to state militias).
Finally, a recondite Supreme Court decision, "In re Neagle," in 1890 paved the way for an "imperial presidency" by holding in a case not connected to foreign affairs that the executive possessed all powers needed to enforce "the rights, duties and obligations growing out of the Constitution itself, our international relations and all the protection implied by the nature of government under the Constitution." This decision -- an "extraordinarily broad" one, Zakaria says -- placed in the hands of a President like Benjamin Harrison, not to mention Theodore Roosevelt, the lever needed to move a nation. Whereas Seward and the embattled President Andrew Johnson had to beg and bribe Congress to acquire Alaska in 1867, Roosevelt could boast about Panama that he "took the Canal Zone and let Congress debate."
"When the interests of the American people demanded that a certain act should be done," he said, "and I had the power to do it, I did it unless it was specifically prohibited by law."
The author does not ignore the subtle crosscurrents of history or deny the importance of personalities. But he argues persuasively that the Spanish-American War, the acquisition of the Philippines, Guam, Puerto Rico and Hawaii, the creation of the nation of Panama and its canal and the other imperial episodes of the Progressive Era were made possible by the fact that "control of the American state and its extraordinary resources had now firmly passed into the hands of the central decision makers who were attentive to the opportunities the international system presented and to the great power at their disposal rather than to the needs of Congressional districts."
This thesis has a number of merits. It allows Zakaria to escape the myth that America was ever isolationist, to demonstrate a certain continuity in American expansionism whether triumphant or thwarted and to identify the second Cleveland Administration not as a last hurrah for an old diplomacy but as the first hurrah for a new. His argument for continuity would have been even stronger had he looked ahead to Woodrow Wilson, whose aggressive expansion of Federal power at home paralleled his globalization of American interests abroad.
However well the author addresses the matter of means, he does skirt the matter of ends. Some may ask why the powerful state was built in the first place, and whether real or perceived interests of business lay behind it. Others may wonder how average Americans persuaded themselves that global power was now their necessary and proper destiny. Zakaria hints at a cultural paradigm shift when he writes that "the reason for the long absence of highly developed foreign policy institutions was . . . America's antistatist tradition," and when he invokes Hans J. Morgenthau's insight into the "restraining influence of a moral consensus . . . that kept in check the limitless desire for power." Something, after all, moved the once anti-imperialist newspaper The Chicago Times-Herald to conclude that "the people now believe that the United States owes it to the world to accept the responsibilities imposed upon it by the fortunes of war." Owes it to the world? That phrase bespeaks a new moral consensus about America's role that cannot be explained by classical or defensive realism, or by Zakaria's notion of the rise of the state.
Even if the author cannot touch all bases in less than 200 pages, his thesis conveys important lessons for our post-cold-war world. One is that the emergence of new major powers need not provoke conflict so long as the transition is "properly understood and properly handled." Another is that one need not fear rising powers that lack the state apparatus to mobilize their national strength. Thus, Zakaria concludes, alarmists were wrong to fear the reunification of Germany or the economic might of Japan, because their constitutional structures and international entanglements inhibit their states from translating wealth into power. The really good news is that China, too, "finds that its central state is challenged by local authorities and constrained by international ones."
Zakaria might also have mentioned Russia, whose central Government seems almost not to exist, and the United States, whose Government most certainly does. Indeed, foreigners may conclude from the argument here that the only power likely to try to impose its will on the world is . . . the United States. Perhaps Zakaria will address that ironic prospect in a sequel to this thoughtful treatise.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: The Talkies

BYLINE: By Michael Wood; Michael Wood is the author of "The Magician's Doubts: Nabokov and the Risks of Fiction." He teaches English at Princeton University.

 BODY:

"You Ain't Heard Nothin' Yet"
 The American Talking Film:
 History & Memory, 1927-1949.
 By Andrew Sarris.
 573 pp. New York:
 Oxford University Press. $35. 
 AS Groucho Marx, in "Duck Soup," leaves the august and matronly Margaret Dumont's bedroom, Chico Marx enters, disguised as Groucho: long nightgown, floppy nightcap, round glasses, absurdly false mustache. We know this is Chico because we have seen him put on his disguise -- otherwise we might have a problem. Dumont is surprised to find this figure still there, since she has seen him leave, and she expresses her surprise.
"Oh no," Chico says. "I no leave."
"But I saw you," Dumont says. "With my own eyes."
Chico replies, in one of the most dizzying philosophical moments in the cinema: "Well, who you gonna believe? Me or your own eyes?"
She has to believe him and her own eyes, as we all do at the movies, silents as well as talkies. Sound increased the range of things our eyes could not tell us, but the need and difficulty of believing them remained. "The art of the cinema," Andrew Sarris wrote in "The American Cinema" (1968), a book many of us carried around till the pages fell out and almost all the directors described there had become old masters, "is the art of an attitude, the style of a gesture." The attitudes and gestures could be aural, but only by extension, by metaphor. And it is striking that many of the sharpest and most memorable moments in Sarris's companionable new book are lucid accounts of visual events or impressions: Chaplin in "The Idle Class" as a repentant alcoholic apparently sobbing, his back to the camera, only to turn and reveal himself as energetically at work with a cocktail shaker; Henry Fonda in "The Grapes of Wrath" as a man whose "physical and spiritual stature is not that of the little man as victim but of the tall man as troublemaker"; Otto Preminger as a director who likes to keep his characters in the same frame; a sequence in D. W. Griffith's last film, "The Struggle," where another alcoholic, having less fun, hears the voice of conscience but expresses it in an attitude: "As an organ plays 'Abide With Me' and a minister begins his sermon about the Resurrection, Skelly coils out of sight of the neighbor's window and contorts himself into a posture of abject guilt such as the screen has never shown before or since."
" 'You Ain't Heard Nothin' Yet' " is loosely organized, although organized might be too strong a term, but it has plenty to say. As he points out, Sarris has after all been "a practicing polemicist" for three decades, and has "more than 40 years of published missionary work" to his credit. The book takes the form of a series of notes and essays covering a small fraction of the films Sarris must have seen. At times he quotes from "The American Cinema," at times he takes off from it into much longer riffs -- on Alfred Hitchcock, for instance, and on John Ford, and on Josef von Sternberg. On two serious points -- the virtues of Vincente Minnelli and Billy Wilder -- he revises his earlier, dismissive opinions that Minnelli had "a fatal flaw as an artist," namely a "naive belief that style can invariably transcend substance," and that Wilder should be classed in a section called "Less Than Meets the Eye."
A great admirer of Andre Bazin and Francois Truffaut, Sarris maintains nevertheless a catholic view of what an author might be in the cinema, and knows dancers and songwriters also count -- and producers and studios too. Still, there is no doubt about where his critical heart is. In this history of American film, there are 9 pages devoted to the studios, 99 pages devoted to genres, 92 pages devoted to actors and actresses and 244 pages devoted to directors. There is also a section (31 pages) on "Guilty Pleasures," which include B movies, Wanda Hendrix, Mary Astor and various versions of "Gaslight."
The book starts with the arrival of the talkies, and Al Jolson's famous line, which provides Sarris with his title, and ends in 1949 for reasons we are not given. The effect is a little eerie, since you keep thinking Sarris is going to talk about later films, and then you put your own memories of the films into the silence. There is not a lot in this book about the industry, technology, audiences, economics, censorship or politics -- much of which Sarris dismisses as "sociological." Even information about directors' careers is quickly plowed back into reports of what's on the screen. As Sarris put it in "The American Cinema," "The best directors generally make the best films, but the directors must be discovered through their films." This is a viewer's cinema, a matter not only of believing our eyes but of deferring to them. This is entirely appropriate for a book by a movie critic, and the result is pretty exuberant, but we have to know what we are not getting.
But, then, is the book a history at all? It's a history of what was to be seen at the cinema, and of what Sarris himself saw and heard there. And also, often moving, always irreverent, a history of who he is. We learn about Sarris's father ("a Mr. Micawber awaiting the apocalypse"), about the ethnic tilt of Sarris's tastes ("Given my first generation Greek-American background . . . I found myself less drawn to the wide open spaces of the western"), about his seeing "Gold Diggers of 1935" when he was 7 years old ("For years and years I retained the image of a playgirl plunging to her death from a skyscraper ballroom"), seeing Bogart when he was 9 ("I found something so sneaky and malignant in Bo-
gart's personality that I was not able to respond to him for years after"), teaching a class on Buster Keaton at Columbia in 1969 ("It was the most extraordinary learning and teaching experience of my life"). The prose is full of bounce and opinion ("Mea culpa, and all that," "So much for the legend. Let's get on with the revisionism"); it has good jokes ("Detective ex machina"), some real insights ("Death generally finds Hitchcock's characters in the wrong mood and the wrong costume") and plenty of finely flung allusions. Chaplin's movie persona "is clearly and congenitally one of the poetically unemployed, Mr. Micawber masquerading as Mother Courage. . . . All in all, Chaplin's Tramp gets off quite a few stops before the Finland Station."
The writing is also pretty slack at times, as if a zombie journalist were still at work when Sarris had gone home. Fritz Lang, we learn, "prowled the dark corners of the soul, where destiny collided with depravity." And there is quite a bit of gushing when the polemicist and memorialist take time off. "No still picture however luminous can do her ineffable beauty justice," Sarris says of Vivien Leigh, "for she lives in our minds and memories as a dynamic force rather than as a static presence."
But then, it's important that film images should move us as well as just move, and moving images are what we may all become if we are lucky -- if we are happily remembered. When asked if he knew Cary Grant, Sarris says he said no "very quickly," and then adds:
"But having seen 69 of his 72 movies, and having witnessed his marvelously gracious performances at several public occasions, can I be said to have 'known' him less intimately than I would have if I had peppered him with journalistic queries at some marathon interview or other? Very probably, I 'knew' much the best part of him, a part that I suspect he would have wanted me to know if he had had any inkling of how much I respected and admired all that he was."
Moving images in the cinema are constantly in dialogue with other moving images, and it's worth remembering that Chico couldn't have made his enduring wisecrack if Margaret Dumont had not been ready to say what she saw. "People sometimes ask me," Sarris says, "why we don't have people like the Marx Brothers anymore, and I reply that we do have people like the Marx Brothers, perhaps too many, but we don't have anyone like Margaret Dumont anymore."

PUB-DATE: May 3, 1998,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 43; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 7228 words

HEADLINE: Don't Even Think About It. (The Cupid Cops Are Watching.)

BYLINE: By Philip Weiss; Philip Weiss is a contributing writer for the magazine. His last article was about Southern retirees living the good life.

 BODY:
"Were you and sally making out in the back seat of a car at 11 last Friday night?"
It was lunchtime at the Bell Tower Club in Bakersfield, Calif., and Holly Culhane, a sturdy, black-haired woman in her late 30's, clad in a wine-colored polka-dot shirt, bent toward me, seeking an answer. 
 I sat up straight. "I've got to tell you something, Holly. I've worked for this company from 9 to 9 sometimes. What I do on my own time is none of your business."
"I understand how you feel. I understand that it's a frustrating situation." The wavelet of sympathy dissolved as quickly as it had appeared. "The only issue is whether you and Sally were making out in the back of a car and have a relationship that goes against what our policy allows a manager to be doing, a manager who is a direct representative of the company."
"We were in a car at 11 on Friday night," I said. "But we weren't in the back. We were in the front, and I don't know what 'making out' means. At one point . . .she and I are very. . .we worked together for four years. . .I put my hand----."
I reached for Culhane's shoulder. We were just role-playing. Culhane is a human resource consultant to small businesses in California, and she was showing me how she does her job. Many of the companies she advises have dating policies; sometimes she has to investigate. It was all hypothetical. So why was I stammering?
"You have to be more specific," she said. "The employee said she saw you guys kissing and groping in the back seat of this car."
"A member of this company is skulking around my car at 11 at night? Is that a good workplace environment?"
Culhane stirred her tea.
"You're more than welcome to talk to your boss about this," she said. "We want to deal with your concerns, too. You're not on trial by any means. The reality is that we have to go back to the question at hand. Is there a relationship between you and Sally?"
I folded. You would have, too.
"Let's say there was a relationship. Let's say I've been married 20 years and the passion's gone out of my marriage----."
"So you admit to having a relationship with this employee?"
"What is the confidentiality of the comments I'm making to you? My wife does not know about this."
"I understand. As I mentioned to you when we began the investigation interview, the comments you make to me will not even go back to your boss. They will go directly to your employer's attorney. We will tell your boss the results of the investigation, but we will not give him any specific statements. They're signed by you so----."
A waitress, aproned and cheerful, materialized with the dessert truck. Tarts. Mousses. Flan. Rule of thumb in Bakersfield: stick with the berry cobbler. As I dug in, I tried a new tack.
"Yes. We were kissing in that car. We're in love. I've never been so much in love in my entire life! I don't know why this has anything to do with harassment."
Culhane didn't blink. "Whether or not you're in love is not the issue. Whether or not you've never been this happy before is not the issue. The issue is, We have a complaint from someone. If this employee chooses to state that this romance has created a harassing or uncomfortable situation in the work environment, we just have to investigate."
Her cobbler was gone. Mine, too. But who was tasting anything? We tumbled back into the afternoon, and she went off to an appointment. I got into the rental car and cranked the music. Someone breathy and urgent came on, singing, of course, about sex.
 
Getting From Yes-Yes to No-No
The American people seem tolerant enough. They appear willing to accept the possibility that President Bill Clinton had a sexual relationship with an intern less than half his age. In Colorado, the citizens seem already to have forgiven Gov. Roy Romer's longtime relationship" with an aide. But that popular feeling is at sharp odds with a growing consensus among workplace professionals about how to make the office a fairer place. Labor lawyers, human resource managers and consultants like Holly Culhane agree: sex and romance between co-workers may be O.K., but almost never between people of unequal power. Policies at I.B.M., General Motors and other leading companies reflect this thinking. And by "unequal power" they don't mean simply the C.E.O. and his secretary. In the new economy, among educated professionals and all those managers and would-be managers who work so closely together in teams and late into the night, and often on the road after wine-besotted expense-account dinners. . .you get the picture.
Rules on consensual relationships are not, strictly speaking, sexual harassment policies. But they grow out of sexual harassment theory and practice. The average judgment in a successful harassment suit is $250,000, and that doesn't count legal costs or the negative publicity. "Surveys have asked executives what kind of a scandal would they least like to have presented to them," says Burke Stinson, senior public-relations manager at AT&T. "Product failure is at the top of the list, but I think sexual harassment is a horse that's getting to the front of the pack now."
Romances between unequals are seen as a breeding ground for harassment complaints especially after "they go south," to use the term of art; now two people in the same department are not talking to one another, and the subordinate doesn't get a promotion she feels she deserved and files a complaint. To prevent this, frightened corporate boards have teamed up with feminists dedicated to sexual equality and human resource managers dedicated to harmonious office life to regulate these affairs. As never before, your business is their business, for 40, 50, 60 or more hours a week.
The new rules come at a time when people are spending most of their waking hours at work. And now that there are more women in the workplace, offices are increasingly the backdrop for mating rituals. It has been said that the modern novel wouldn't exist without adultery. Well, "Ally McBeal" wouldn't exist without office romance. Not to mention a dozen other TV series set in law firms, hospitals and precinct houses that are hugely popular among professionals. Edward Harold, a labor attorney in New Orleans, says: "A lot of work today is like in the movie 'Speed': a man and a woman in a high-pressure situation where they have to solve a problem together. So it's no surprise they become romantically involved." But there is a phalanx of human resource types whose job it is to make sure life doesn't imitate art.
There are, of course, countless examples of unequals marrying: Microsoft's C.E.O., Bill Gates, and a former product manager, Melinda French; the chairman of G.M., John Smith, and his former secretary, Lydia Smith; Liz Tilberis, the editor of Harper's Bazaar, and a former professor at her art school, Andrew Tilberis. What would a human resource manager have made of those? Drawing the line at inequality would seem to be especially difficult in a contemporary workplace, where hierarchies have become both flatter and more fluid, where today's boss may be next month's co-worker, or vice versa.
But today some managers are paid to draw that line, to do something the poets have struggled to do through all of time, parse love. Many an intimate office relationship is clandestine and confusing; but instead of going to a therapist or a friend or a novel to help sort things out, modern lovers are expected to go to the guy on the 11th floor, in human resources. Modern lovers have to be documented. Modern lovers have to have their job assignments separated. Modern lovers have to visit what one human resource manager referred to, with only a little irony, as the Cupid Cops.
"If I hear rumors of a romance, I'll call up the line manager who's involved in the romance and ask him if it's true, and if it is, I'll take him, his manager and the employee and talk to them," says C. Anthony Ladt, the vice president for human resources of a large leasing company based in Louisiana. "I'll tell them we want to make sure that all parties understand it's consensual. I'll give her two numbers, my number in the corporate offices and the number of her manager's manager. That tears down the wall that ordinarily exists. And I'll say we frown on it. These relationships are great for the times they work out for the two people. But in this day and age, that doesn't happen a lot."
 
Among the Cupid Cops
In March, human resource people from around the country gathered on Capitol Hill; this was the annual legislative conference of the Society for Human Resource Management, an organization of 95,000 members. That's where I met Anthony Ladt. In olden days, managers like him were responsible for pension plans and 1099's. Today, the human resource manager has far greater powers, stemming in part from sexual harassment.
"It's not what most H.R. managers signed on to do, be a watchdog, be a policeman," Ladt said. But his job description includes eight-hour flights at the drop of a hat to deal with a harassment claim in one of his company's branches, instructions to employees not to leave things like roses on a co-worker's desk if their relationship is over and warnings to managers that if they want to invite one subordinate to a party, they better invite them all.
A quarter of American companies now have policies dealing with romance, according to a society survey. (Only half of them are written.) But the conventioneers I met in the basement of the Hyatt Regency are in the vanguard. In their workplaces, a Monica Lewinsky-Bill Clinton-like relationship would simply be out of the question. Whether or not the two had sex, the relationship was plainly a "special" one and likely a "sexually charged" one, to use two terms of opprobrium; such a relationship could demoralize a work force. "It goes to perceptions of leadership," said Susan Meisinger, the society's senior vice president, referring to the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal. "It's a dumb idea for him even to put himself in that position where questions of unfairness could arise. Think of a C.E.O. having a special relationship with the person that delivers mail or the person that works in the corporate cafeteria. The imbalance in power is just stark."
The workplace these H.R. managers survey is one where perceptions of unfairness become complaints in no time, and where complaints become nightmares.
"There is no notion of safe sex when you talk about supervisor-subordinate sex," Jonathan Segal, a Philadelphia employment attorney, told a conference gathering one morning. "Many of you have been to Ocean City, Md., seen the beautiful summer homes there. Well, a lot of them are owned by lawyers who have clients whose employees have unrestricted dating."
What do those lawyers tell their clients? Michael J. Lotito, a San Francisco employment attorney, leaned up against a wall outside a banquet room at the Hyatt and described one predicament.
"Here's a concrete situation," Lotito said. "The president of an organization that has operations around the country -- he inquired about whether it would be advisable for him to get involved in a welcome relationship with a woman at one of the stores. She was a clerk at a store 1,000 miles away. He wanted to know whether or not he could give her a letter that she could countersign, saying that the romantic relationship was welcome, that he wouldn't participate in personnel decisions that affected her. The advice that I gave him was, The welcome relationship today is the unwelcome relationship tomorrow. And what kind of a tone are you setting for other people in the situation? You're telling me it's discreet. You're going to try to keep it discreet, but everyone is going to find out about it in two seconds. And what if the manager of Store 1 wants to go out with someone in Store 2? Or a V.P. of operations is going to stores and asking people out?"
I went into lunch and sat at a table with four of the society's staff members. The conversation turned to flirtation on the job, and Sharon Leonard, manager of state legislative affairs, brought up a favorite loaded problem: two workers go on the road for a job, and one says, "Can we get adjoining hotel rooms?"
Leonard was disapproving. But I remembered similar situations in my own life and tried to hold a brief for the passionate.
"I can see wanting to do that," I said. "It's the flirtation process. You're taking a risk, putting yourself out there, seeking to establish if there's any interest."
Sara Costello, who works in customer relations, said: "I don't think you should establish that in the workplace. If you're interested in that, establish it outside the workplace."
"Aren't we making the workplace a sterile place?" I said.
"Maybe that's true," she said. "But on the other hand, we want to have fairness in the workplace."
 
How It Came to This
In 1975, a landmark speak-out was held in Ithaca, N.Y., on behalf of Carmita Wood, a 44-year-old worker at Cornell University who had done what so many women did when they faced unrelenting sexual pressure on a job -- given the job up. The following year, Redbook published a groundbreaking survey of sexual harassment in which about 90 percent of 9,000 women who responded said that they had been sexual harassed in the workplace.
"There was a grass-roots women's movement that started to identify this as a collective issue," says K.C. Wagner, who now works at Cornell's school of industrial and labor relations. "What was so powerful was that it gave a name to an experience that all women had, but didn't have a conceptual framework to address."
A legal effort paralleled the grass-roots one. Lawyers sensed that the Civil Rights Act of 1964, barring job discrimination on the basis of sex, might be used against sexual coercion on the job. But the courts were not sympathetic. They tended to rule against individual women, saying that what each of these women had experienced was strictly personal. What was required was a grand theory that established that sexual coercion in the workplace was a form of discrimination suffered by women. This theory was supplied by a young Yale legal scholar named Catharine A. MacKinnon, who in 1979 published "Sexual Harassment of Working Women."
MacKinnon, who now teaches law at the University of Michigan and at the University of Chicago, says that she showed that sexual harassment wasn't personal, it wasn't biological, it wasn't trivial or interpersonally romantic. What it was was group-based, based on sex -- because a person is a woman, a member of a social group."
MacKinnon's brilliant, cold classic went hard at the notion that women who got involved with their superiors were consenting to sexual activity in the workplace. They had no choice, she argued.
Consent was made to stand for desire," MacKinnon says. "It's a pathetic term for desire. Did you ever hear a man come back from a great night out and say, 'I consented to sex last night!' Consent means something you put up with whether you want to or not."
Her argument had tremendous influence. In 1986, the Supreme Court, in a unanimous decision affirming that sexual harassment was a form of sex discrimination, accepted her theory that "consensual" sex could still be coercive. This case, Meritor Savings Bank v. Vinson, involved voluntary sexual acts -- indeed, H.R. types call it the "safe sex" case because Mechele Vinson, a bank teller, said she had had sex with her boss 40 to 50 times, more than one of them in the vault. MacKinnon was one of Vinson's attorneys, and William H. Rehnquist, an Associate Justice at the time, endorsed the view that it didn't matter whether Vinson consented to the sex. "The correct inquiry is whether respondent by her conduct indicated that the alleged sexual advances were unwelcome, not whether her actual participation in sexual intercourse was voluntary," Rehnquist wrote.
Much of the public discussion of sexual harassment during the 90's has been about a range of abuses less invasive than sleep-with-me-or-you're-out: lewd managers, frightful offices, unwanted back rubs, birthday parties with strippers. In the wake of the national speak-out that followed the Clarence Thomas hearings, the number of sexual harassment claims soared, and there is widespread acknowledgment among experts that things have got better. More recently, in the matter of Paula Jones, both the public and Judge Susan Webber Wright seem to have concluded that boorishness need not be sexual harassment; things have got not only better but more nuanced.
Meanwhile, pioneers have moved on to all sexual relationships between unequals. So what if they are consensual? What if the subordinate in the relationship should one day say the attention was unwelcome? To avoid lawsuits, some companies have adopted rules not only against gropers and lewd-joke tellers but also against the manager who asks a subordinate out on a date. "It's difficult for a subordinate to say no to a requested date from a supervisor who has control over his or her employment destiny," says Jonathan Segal, the lawyer from Philadelphia.
The unstable nature of consent was an issue not long ago in a case at Yale University. Months after a consensual relationship between a 17-year-old student and 32-year-old faculty member ended, the student came to regret the relationship and said that she had felt coerced. While the faculty member denied that the relationship had been sexual, Yale found that it had been "sexually charged" and reprimanded him for sexual harassment. Then the school adopted new rules last year that flatly bar relationships between teachers and their students.
In calling for the change, Richard H. Brodhead, dean of the college, acknowledged that many happy marriages had come out of unequal relationships and said that he valued "the right of adults to make their own choices and to take responsibility for the consequences of their choices with a minimum of institutional interference." But in the end, institutional interference won the day. Far better to say, "Just don't," Brodhead said.
Another problem surrounding consensual relationships is how they affect others in the workplace. When a supervisor has a relationship with a subordinate, other workers often sense unfairness, experts say. Remember Mary Cunningham, whose relationship in the 80's with William Agee, the chairman of Bendix, promoted scandal? It's hard to imagine Cunningham's rapid rise at Bendix occurring today without others filing some sort of grievance. "It's always been a factor, but now it gets surfaced much faster as an issue and it takes on ramifications," says a vice president for human resources at a large food-industry company. "Others will go complain if they see the favoritism. And there is a hostile work environment because of this."
The legal concepts evolving in this area can make your head hurt. Paramour preference -- is it illegal for a boss to give preference to a lover? Depends on what it does to the rest of the workplace. Could create "ugly duckling" litigation, complaints filed by those who were passed over. Especially if there was gossip about the liaison, which would contaminate the workplace, making it a hostile environment.
So TV pours out stories about sexualized workplaces, and we go to offices where there are smooching police?
"Employers have argued just what you are saying to me, that we are used to a certain amount of sexual freedom in this society, of sexual speech and content," says Eric Matusewitch, a specialist with New York City's Equal Employment Practices Commission. "And the courts have said that the so-called First Amendment freedoms don't exist in the workplace and can't exist because employees are a captive audience. We all basically have to work for seven or eight hours a day. And behavior that may be O.K. outside is not acceptable inside."
 
Nothing at the Office Is Zipless
Perhaps the best known consultant on sexuality in the workplace is Freada Klein. Based in Cambridge, Mass., Klein, who is 45, works with blue-chip companies all over the world, billing an average of $3,500 a day. The first time I spoke with her, by phone, she told me she has never called for flat prohibitions.
I thought I could catch Klein out. I alluded to the Lewinsky scandal.
"Is there any way a 48-year-old C.E.O. could have sex with a 21-year-old intern and it would be O.K.?"
"It certainly raises huge questions," she said. "Not to be evasive, but that depends on the corporate culture. If it's an operation with a truly effective practice, a corporation with an ombudsman with a direct line to the board, where the subordinate would have no fear of retaliation -- that's a very different environment from the overwhelming majority of corporate structures in place today. A very enlightened corporation, a very mature 21-year-old and a single rather than married 48-year-old----."
"What does marriage have to do with anything?"
"It has the possibility of being a real relationship rather than an extramarital fling," she said. An interesting distinction for a human resource consultant to be worrying herself about.
The first appointment I could get with Klein was on a Sunday. I flew up to Boston and took the train to M.I.T. and got out in a cold, empty square. The modern tower where her offices were was a few steps away.
Klein turned out to be a small, pretty, mirthful woman. She was wearing a purple sweater and was accompanied by a slightly owlish man, who went to get us tea and coffee from an Au Bon Pain. He looked familiar. He turned out to be Mitchell Kapor, the man who founded Lotus Development -- where Klein had once run the H.R. department! (Their relationship did not begin until nine years after she left Lotus.)
Klein talked about sex and power. In the early 70's, she was at Berkeley, getting a B.A. in criminology and working Sunday mornings at a rape crisis center. One morning Klein had a revelation when a woman called to talk about being raped the night before by a stranger.
"She was sobbing, and I remember almost verbatim her expression was, 'The hardest part is realizing how similar this is to sex with my boyfriend,"' Klein said.
"A light bulb went off?" I asked.
Klein nodded. "I began to think about something that Mitch and I will talk about because I will come home and say: 'How do you understand your gender? I don't understand how sexual activity with an unwilling partner is pleasurable."'
I told Klein that I might stand up for the unreconstructed male, and she smiled politely. I asked her if there was a difference between male and female managers as sexual predators.
"Women are less likely to be counting up notches in the belt," Klein said. "Sort of emotionless or acontextual sexual relationships----."
"What is an acontextual relationship?"
"There isn't an emotional context to the relationship. There isn't an exchange that an act of intimacy both reflects and furthers----."
"That's a value-laden comment," I said.
"Of course."
"Erica Jong used the term zipless favorably to refer to sex without consequences. That would fall into the category of acontextual relationship."
"That's the notches on the belt."
"Is that a bad thing?"
"That's a tough one," she said. "I don't want to condemn a competent grown-up who chooses it. I think it's a low value for a culture."
Kapor leaned into the discussion.
"When it happens in a workplace, it typically has consequences that are adverse to one or more of the participants. 'Zipless' was about strangers meeting in an encounter; they pass on. If people think about their past sexual relationships, they're just as happy not to see that person every day. Somehow one of the things we don't contemplate about office romances is that not only did this person not drop off the planet when we stopped being involved with them, they don't leave the cubicle next to ours. And that's what makes it an organizational issue. Which is to say that in practice 'zipless' just doesn't work. Ever. Hardly. It's an ideal. Erica Jong is a novelist."
 
No Sex, Please. We're Lawyers
I wanted to learn how people actually draw the line in the workplace so I gave Klein a letter to give to her clients. She sent it around the country, and it got just one taker, a big Newark law firm, Gibbons, Del Deo, Dolan, Griffinger & Vecchione. Two progressive partners there had spearheaded the policy over resistance from other members of the firm, and one recent morning I met with them: David Sheehan, the managing partner, and Christine Amalfe. Sheehan had soft blue eyes and a ready sense of humor. Amalfe wore a tomato-red power suit with gold buttons.
The old Gibbons, Del Deo policy was unspoken; people weren't to get involved. Good employees were lost. The new one says dating between co-workers is fine, but that relationships between unequals present great difficulties and must be reported.
"Let's say the junior person wanted to end it, and the senior person starts acting differently, puts pressure on the junior person," Sheehan said. "It happens every day out there in the world. That's not a healthy situation to be involved in, to have to work with that person. Very few consensual relationships result in sexual harassment, but one can cost your company a whole lot of money, a whole lot of time, and hurt your reputation."
I brought up my favorite scenario: an affair on the road; in this context, a partner and associate on the West Coast working on a case together for months at a time.
"Why not have a relationship?" I said.
"Sometimes it happens," Amalfe said. "You can't prevent two people from traveling together just because they might, if the moon lined up correctly, and the stars, become an item. If they become an item, you deal with it."
"I guess I'm thinking of the movie version," I said. "If they had a discreet affair on the West Coast, no one learns about it and it ends when they get back, so what, none of your business."
"Correct," Sheehan said.
"Well, it would violate our policy," Amalfe said. "But it is none of our business."
Everyone laughed.
Then I said: "What if an associate says, 'I'm getting ignored because X is having a relationship with a partner and she's getting preferential treatment. I don't want to be identified. Everyone in the office feels this way."'
"We now have to investigate," Amalfe said.
"Do you respect the claim of confidentiality?"
"It makes it a little difficult," Sheehan said. "Let's assume I went to you, you're the person who's having the affair, your first reaction is, 'Who told you that?' I say, 'Well, I can't reveal my sources.' 'Well, how am I supposed to deal with these baseless allegations? That's just a baldfaced lie.' First rule of every relationship, by the way, is you deny it exists."
"Really?"
"Absolutely."
I asked Amalfe how she felt about the possibility that she might have to go to a partner senior to her and ask whether he or she was having an affair.
"It doesn't bother me in the least," she said.
"What do you ask?" I said. "'Are you having an affair?"'
"'What's going on?"' Amalfe said.
"I don't know that I'd be that direct," Sheehan said. "I think I'd ask a lot of other questions that would be difficult for him to answer without suggesting that there's more than just a casual relationship. For example, if people have seen them having dinner together on a Saturday evening, in a candlelit restaurant, just the two of them, that's a fact. I don't have to reveal my source for that. You were seen. I'd try to infuse into the scenario facts that would demonstrate that they've created an inappropriate relationship that has to then stop."
"Because the relationship is special?" I said.
"That's right," Sheehan said. "It does go back to Washington. We will never know until either Clinton or Lewinsky tells us, and we believe one or another, what actually happened. The only way you would ever know whether two people were having an affair, unless somebody's got some great photos, would be whether one of them gives you the kind of detailed information that would establish the fact. Trying to prove that is almost a fruitless task. So you pound away at the fact that all the other activities that they're engaging in create a clear appearance of improper conduct."
"David," I said, "you seem like a very tolerant person."
"Sure."
"Is this what you imagined your life would involve? You're in a room telling this guy what's inappropriate behavior?"
"I understand that, and maybe it's a denial of who we are as human beings, we have natural drives and passions----."
"And you're divorced!" I said, remembering something he'd told me at the start.
"Indeed."
Then Sheehan looked away, out the picture window filled with Jersey smokestacks, Jersey malls.
"I don't want to sound like a therapist, but you can't deny what your background is," he said. "My mother made tubes for RCA over in Harrison. She got to be a supervisor. I used to hear her every night at the dinner table complaining that she couldn't be a foreman because only men became foremen. My mom got held back inappropriately by a society that never should have let that happen. I met the foremen, and she could run them into the ground; she was much more talented than they were. That's always been with me. That's the real touchstone."
 
The End of the Affairs
I had a list of H.R. consultants and managers whose names I'd gotten off the Society for Human Resource Management Web site, and I flew west, then drove from San Francisco to Fresno to Bakersfield, down through El Nino and Modesto into the central California valley, past almonds blooming mauvely and pistachios bloomingly something elsely, experiencing that post-Lewinsky frisson of terror and prurience as modern lovers' business became the Cupid Cops' business. One H.R. person hung up the phone, saying, "I stay away from the he-said-she-said stuff," but for others it was grist.
"At one point, we asked the senior manager to end the relationship; he agreed," one H.R. manager said, describing a situation. "He said, 'I will do nothing that will jeopardize my career.' Well, he did not end it. You can understand his not breaking it off. If he were an average performer, we might press him a little harder. This guy was doing an outstanding job. We didn't really press it. We ended up getting an agreement, in which the woman is transferring into another environment."
Ruth Evans, an H.R. consultant in Fresno, told me of an investigation she'd once done of a consensual relationship gone sour: "There were gifts given. She wrote him a letter in which she expressed her interest. He had saved the letter, which I found very interesting. I couldn't prove it one way or the other that there was a relationship. But there was enough there to show that he may have led her on. So some sort of action had to be taken. In this case, reprimand and training."
And Holly Culhane: "She thought she would be laid off for lack of work, so she filed a sexual harassment suit against him. Finally he broke down and told us what was going on. It was still an ongoing relationship. She never divulged it was an affair, because he was married. He came clean. We transferred her to another department."
The consultants were all principled, well-meaning people, but the pop-culture scenarios of love in the workplace didn't play much in their minds. Culhane told me how unpleasant it was to have to tap out obscenities on her laptop as she did in an interview, then to have to repeat these words to an attorney over the telephone.
The most idealistic was Evelyn Foster, a consultant in Mill Valley who met me in the lobby of the Westin Hotel on San Francisco's Union Square. She wore brown suede flats and a dark blue blazer; she was steely and competent, a product of small-town Nevada whose talents had been taken for granted when she came into the work world and who had been chased around a desk more than once by an abusive manager. She had the H.R. religion: when sex is in the air, business suffers, people are less productive.
We talked about investigating romance, and I asked whether Foster made any judgment about the emotional content of a relationship.
"Yes," she said. "You don't punish people because of love. If they honestly fall in love, bless them, two good competent employees and they fall in love -- you try and accommodate that situation. Is it true love or just a very exciting fling? And I would say, one probably encounters more of the fling, the short-term affair. And there's all sorts of things going on in that dynamic: the power play, the subordinate figuring they're going to get ahead, that they're getting an edge above everybody else. The context isn't a long-term meaningful love relationship. It's something else, but generally it's not to anybody's advantage in the end."
"What if a person confessed to you: 'I fell in love. I'm married. What should I do?"'
"I would try to determine, Is this person antagonistic toward his wife, is he going to marry this person? If it feels more like true love, then maybe you accommodate it in the sense that you pull the subordinate out of that department and try to find them a job somewhere else in the company and really distance them and then it takes that problem out of his department. You honor that this is true love. But if the person has no intention of divorcing his wife, if it still has the aura of being an affair and an affair in direct line like that is against the company guideline.. . ."
 
The Power of a Desirable Subordinate
A few years ago, a campus forum on sexual harassment would be sure to focus on its horrors, but when I squeezed sideways into a standing-room-only hall at the City University of New York's gay and lesbian center late last winter, the panel's talk was about the joy of sex between people of unequal status. For whatever reason, protests against consensual sex codes seem to be coming, at least for now, from the gay quarters on campuses.
The star of the panel was a forceful and attractive woman with a booming voice and tangled dark hair: Jane Gallop, a feminist literary scholar and the leading critic of the new rules barring relationships between unequals.
"I think they can be abusive, but always abusive?" she said. "There are few people in the world between whom there isn't a power differential. And so that would make all sex abusive, except between identical twins." (A pair of identical twins approached Gallop after the panel to say that there are stark power issues between twins.)
Five years ago, the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee investigated Gallop for sexual harassment over flirtations that she said were consensual. Gallop was teaching at the university. The flirtations were with two female students. Gallop was living (and still is) with the father of her two children.
"My first response was shame," she told me. "The administration and my lawyer told me to be silent. A lot of friends said I should be silent. Because the worst thing that could happen to me is it would come out publicly. But the worst part was the two months of silence."
Gallop was cleared, then turned the situation to her advantage by writing a book, Feminist Accused of Sexual Harassment. In it, she relates the pleasure she experienced in the sexual tension between herself and one accuser, whom she had kissed, and celebrates the erotic charge that exists between teachers and students. She describes her own days as a graduate student, when she seduced two male members of her dissertation committee.
"Lots of smart, ambitious young women, many of them likewise feminist academics today, have felt powerful because they seduced their teachers," she wrote. Her professors "were brilliant. I wanted to get them into bed to make them more human. I wanted to see them naked."
Oh, that Monica Lewinsky might someday scour her soul!
But Jane Gallop's backlash is fairly lonely. Men who have suffered in consensual- relationship investigations almost invariably go to cover. Martin Hanaka left the presidency of Staples last fall after a relationship he had with a line employee came to light. (The employee accused him of assault, a charge later dismissed.) Hanaka said that the relationship had not been sexual. But it had plainly been special -- Hanaka had met with her for breakfast and lent her $10,000, even as she was seeking a promotion -- and thus violated Staples's strict fraternization policy barring undisclosed relationships between supervisors and subordinates. Hanaka left for a job in Florida and doesn't want to talk about it.
Nor does the former assistant professor of the now notorious case at Yale. His reprimand for having a "sexually charged" relationship with an undergraduate woman has dogged him around the country. The man's attorney begged me not to mention his case by name, even though it has been published.
"Every time his name is mentioned in the press, more nails are added to the coffin," the attorney, John A. Stewart, said. His current faculty position, Stewart said, "is based on the fact that he's not in the newspaper. People are scared to death of the publicity he might bring to their campus."
Stewart went on to denounce the "administrative, nonjudicial, non-due-process types of investigation" to which people in his client's position are subjected. Valerie Jenness, an assistant professor of criminology at the University of California at Irvine, expressed similar views. Jenness was teaching at Washington State University when the school investigated her two years ago. A minor dispute had arisen over Jenness's contribution to a short paper written by her former girlfriend, and because the girlfriend was a graduate student and Jenness was faculty, the investigation turned to sexual harassment. It did not matter that Jenness was 33, the girlfriend 35, or that they were in separate departments. After what Jenness says was a harrowing year, she was exonerated. But W.S.U. did not renew her contract.
"It gets mean; it makes life pretty miserable," says Jenness. "If I'm charitable, I can say that institutions are in a tough position. They don't want to be caught not caring. They know if there's any hint of sexual harassment and they fail to move aggressively, they can be liable. So what we have is an exaggerated response -- cutting corners, aggressively pursuing stuff."
A faculty grievance committee at W.S.U. found that the school had violated Jenness's privacy and right to due process. At one point, for instance, her notes and letters to a student who had sought a romance with her were passed out at a faculty meeting, apparently as evidence of what one official called "bad boundary maintenance."
Bad boundary maintenance! Passion and boundaries have always been on difficult terms. Jane Gallop was accused, among other things, of putting her bare foot on a student's chair and rocking it inappropriately. It's little wonder she has cast these consensual-relationships codes as antisex.
"Because I believe so strongly that sexual harassment is wrong, I object to the way in which it's become diffused so that sex in and of itself is a bad thing," she says. "You cannot be human, you cannot have human feelings about other workers, you cannot respond as you would when you hear a song on the radio.
"I actually believe that when a person in power chooses to have a relationship with someone below them, they're endangering their power. It makes them more vulnerable. Saying that women need protection turns them into poor pathetic people who must be protected against their own sick desires. Seeing women as objects, as passive, as victims, with no sexuality on their own. And seeing men as totally predatory, purely active in the most evil sense of the word."
Though it may be tempting to imagine a libertine army brandishing Gallop's text and holding out for the right of adults to navigate power relationships in the workplace, I doubt that the "pro sex" position will prevail here. The understanding that romance between unequals can disrupt a workplace is today the reigning human resource orthodoxy. The American sense of fairness and meritocracy recoils at the notion that sex is the score by which women should advance. The chaste feel they have a grievance. The courts have given companies wide latitude to bar unequal relationships.
Catharine MacKinnon has supported some of these codes, too. In the wake of the Lewinsky case, she wrote that organizations have a right to bar relationships that are both "wanted" and "exploitive."
I asked her why she feels that way. "Because when men get done with women sexually -- she was talking about the workplace, which she says the courts have deemed "an island of equality" -- they're done with them. They're slime."
So why shouldn't there be laws against these relationships? She said she had problems with that. Women plainly want these relationships. A law won't do the trick. There has to a national discussion. People have to talk about it.
"If all such relationships were ended, how many relationships would be left between men and women?" she said. "I make people think about these issues, and they don't want to. They want to jump out of a 30th-story window, or push me out of it."
 
Getting a Little More Personal
Late in March, I met Freada Klein for dinner at the Ambassador Grill near the U.N. We both lunged for the wine list and decided to split a $42 bottle. As a result, we had a merry time that got confessional after 10 o'clock.
It began when I told her that as a reconstructed male, I had called a couple of women I'd had sexual encounters with years before to see if these encounters were, as I feared, "consensual but unwelcome."
"Good," she said. "That speaks volumes about you. I'm very careful to say it is completely unfair to judge a 1970's relationship by a late-1990's standard."
"Thanks," I said. "You may have just got me off the hook."
Klein smiled and said that helping to change these rules was for her a "true joy and honor."
Then she told me that as a 16-year-old college student she had had "a completely consensual relationship" with a professor 20 years older than herself.
I was stunned. "How long did it last?"
"On and off for a decade. This might be news to my parents but, hey, it's all right."
"Did you get a lot out of it?"
"Of course. It took place within a particular context within a particular social era, and I did not then, nor do I now, define that as a coercive relationship. But would I want my niece, for example, who is 16----."
"On its face it, has certain inequities," I said.
"Absolutely. Do I imagine that there are other students who are my peers that he or another professor could have made moves on and would have been a devastating experience? Yes."
"For someone, it's devastating. For you, it was O.K. This is all about context."
"Exactly," she said.
Having started out with the hammers of law, we'd arrived at the more delicate workings of etiquette. It struck me that this was one of feminism's most enduring contributions. Having persuaded our society that the personal was political, sometimes it could go back the other way. Sometimes the political could be merely personal after all.

HEADLINE: Touring Percussionists Who Aren't Really Offbeat

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
ONE might have thought that five percussionists who wanted to band together as a full-time touring ensemble were unrealistic, even slightly eccentric. The repertory for percussion quintets, after all, is slender. And although such a group is, strictly speaking, a chamber ensemble, its potential audience is likely to come not from the string quartet and piano trio circuit but from the more constricted world of new music.
Yet Bob Becker, William Cahn, Robin Engelman, Russell Hartenberger and John Wyre joined forces in 1971 to form Nexus, and now they have plenty to show for their persistence. The quintet, based in Toronto, gives about 100 performances and master classes a year. It has released more than a dozen recordings on its own label, Nexus, and it just cracked the majors with new recordings of Toru Takemitsu's "From Me Flows What You Call Time" (on Sony Classical) and Gavin Bryars's "One Last Bar, Then Joe Can Sing" (on Point, Philips's new-music imprint). 
 These works are among the two dozen or so scores commissioned by or for Nexus; Steve Reich, Michael Colgrass, Bruce Mather and John Cage have also composed for the group. But Takemitsu's "From Me Flows What You Call Time," a concerto for percussion and orchestra commissioned as part of Carnegie Hall's centenary celebration, has become Nexus's signature piece.
Its title, taken from a poem by Makoto Ooka, was meant to evoke the musical memories of a century at Carnegie Hall. The group gave the premiere at Carnegie in 1990, with Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony, and has played it more than 60 times. On Tuesday, it returns to the hall to perform it with Jukka-Pekka Saraste and the Toronto Symphony.
"Takemitsu approached writing a piece for us with a different esthetic than you would expect," Mr. Cahn said recently of the gracefully exotic 36-minute work, which is scored for both Western and Asian instruments, and includes a section in which the players use streamers to animate wind chimes mounted above the audience. "You would think that a work written for Carnegie Hall's anniversary and for the Boston Symphony would be an occasion for bombastic music, with all the force percussion can present. But Takemitsu was more interested in quiet music."
The Bryars score, too, is quiet and moody, and in fact much of the Nexus repertory confounds a listener's expectations. The players have expanded it by composing works of their own, and because they have collected dozens of folk instruments from around the world, their pieces often incorporate African and Asian drumming traditions. Nexus concerts also include improvisations, which are entirely unscripted.
"The one time we tried to plan an improvisation," Mr. Hartenberger said in a conversation with the group, "was about 25 years ago, when Bill had the idea that we should go out onstage and pretend to hit our instruments without actually touching them."
William Cahn took up the story: "The underlying philosophical idea was that if there are radio waves that you don't see and can't hear without a radio receiver, then perhaps there is something about music that can be communicated through means other than sound. So the plan was that we would set up the instruments; we'd try to feel inside what we feel when we're making music; we'd make the gestures and do everything we could to communicate a musical idea, without producing a sound.
"I still don't have an answer as to whether that communicates or not."
"I do," Mr. Hartenberger said, drawing laughter from the rest of the group.
"At any rate," Mr. Engelman chimed in, "we agreed to execute Bill's idea, and we went out onstage. And in the first gesture Bill made, he accidentally hit his instrument, ruining the whole concept."
The interaction among the five musicians in conversation is not unlike the give and take in their concerts. Now all in their 50's or just out of them, they say they have maintained their friendship after 27 years of working and touring together, a rare circumstance, given the tensions and potential ego clashes inherent in a musical collaboration. Few ensembles endure that long without personnel changes.
"People ask us if we get along, probably because there is that history of tense relationships, especially among string quartets," Mr. Wyre said. "I think the difference in instruments may have something to do with it. String players punish themselves to learn those instruments, and maybe when it comes time to share that in an ensemble, there's less joy. We don't have the weight of 300 years of pedagogy behind our playing. We don't have to share bowings, and we have never told each other how to play."
Mr. Hartenberger added: "We started out as friends. We were five guys meeting in one another's living room and setting up instruments and playing. From that the group evolved."
Nexus also has the luxury of working in a field that is not overcrowded. Its biggest European rivals -- apart from soloists like Evelyn Glennie -- are Les Percussions de Strasbourg, a venerable French ensemble, and the Kroumata Percussion Ensemble, a Swedish sextet that has made extraordinary recordings. The New Jersey Percussion Ensemble, directed by Raymond DesRoches, and Pulse, directed by Claire Heldrich, are active in the New York area, but their personnel changes regularly, and they don't tour as widely as Nexus.
"The guys in Nexus are the high priests of the percussion world," said Daniel Druckman, a percussionist who performed with several New York ensembles before joining the New York Philharmonic. "They are all really fine players and very interesting musicians. Before world music became such a cliche, they were out there exploring the percussion music of other cultures, not in a cynical, marketing way but out of sincere interest."
Nexus has its frustrations. The players would like to do more commissioning, but the composers they want are expensive. Even getting a work from Takemitsu, a composer who admired their work enough to sponsor some of their Japanese performances, was difficult.
"We gave him about $10,000," Mr. Engelman began.
"It was more like $2,000," said Mr. Cahn, who is the group's business manager.
"O.K., $2,000," Mr. Engelman continued. "Later he told us he had started our piece at least three times, but it wasn't coming together." It wasn't until Carnegie Hall arranged for a $55,000 commissioning fee from the Suntory Corporation, that Takemitsu produced "From Me Flows What You Call Time."
Another obstacle in Nexus's commissioning program is that composers don't always listen carefully when the players convey their needs and desires. Composers often give little consideration to such practicalities as how much equipment Nexus can economically take on tour.
"SOMETIMES pieces just don't work out," Mr. Wyre said. "If someone writes a work that includes five bass drums, we can't take that piece on the road. It's just too massive. It's one thing to learn a work and give its premiere. We try to choose music that will become part of our repertory, works that we can play over many years and know there's going to be some growth in what we can do with them."
There is, to be sure, a small repertory of classic works on which Nexus can draw, including works of the 1940's by John Cage and Lou Harrison.
"With Cage in particular, the instrumentation allows for a lot of flexibility," Mr. Becker said. "He might ask for something that rattles, for example, and there are a lot of possibilities you could choose. So when we play those pieces, they sound very different from when another percussion group plays them. I think that the farther up you come to the present-day repertory, the less that's the case. The instrumentation becomes more specific, and the sound becomes more stable, so we are less able to make those pieces distinctively Nexonian."
When the players find a score that works for them, the first thing they do is decide how to distribute the instrumentation, taking into account personal strengths. Mr. Becker and Mr. Hartenberger, who also play in Steve Reich's ensemble, are expert players of mallet instruments, for example, and Mr. Wyre is especially fond of exotic gongs, bells and temple bowls.
In the work by Takemitsu, who died two years ago, the composer spared them the task, designating parts for each of them in the score.
"We've been spoiled by this piece," Mr. Cahn said. "It not only gives us a piece by a great composer, but it gets us together with symphony orchestras, and it showed us what that level of creative production can bring in terms of response."
Mr. Engelman added: "Still, when we were in Japan to perform the work there, Toru said to me, 'Do you want your $2,000 back?' I said, 'Yeah, maybe with interest.' And he said, 'I'm sorry, but I spent it a long time ago.' "

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut;
For Shelton, Fairfield's First Spec Building in Decade

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

DATELINE: SHELTON

 BODY:
GROUND is to be broken next month for Fairfield County's first speculative Class A office building in a decade -- not in Stamford, but at the northwestern edge of the county in Shelton. The construction is to start without the developer, the Davis Companies of Boston and Wilton, having a single lease in hand.
The move comes at a time when at least four major office projects approved for construction in downtown Stamford remain unbuilt for lack of committed tenants. 
 "Suburban buildings are being built first, in the Boston area, Atlanta, Dallas and San Francisco," said Paul Marcus, president of the Davis Companies, a 23-year-old real estate investment, management and development concern with more than 3 million square feet of properties in New England, New York, Pennsylvania and Texas.
"Only one building is going up in downtown Boston," he explained. "Cities have no room for companies to grow."
Mr. Marcus noted that Shelton, a 32-square-mile town, had plenty of room for expansion and that taxes and the cost of land were both low, all attractions for financial partners.
"I have five options -- all pension funds willing to invest because my first building of 157,000 square feet will cost $120 a square foot rather than the $200 a square foot required in Stamford," said Mr. Marcus. "Moreover, with a 20-acre parcel in Shelton I can build in phases rather than requiring financing for a 400,000- to 600,000-square-foot building that must go up all at once."
Another attraction is the tax rate in Shelton: $22.77 per $1,000 assessment, as opposed to $25.60 to $28.10 in Stamford.
Mr. Marcus has received approval from the Shelton Planning and Zoning Commission to erect 400,000 square feet of offices. Associated with him in the venture is David A. Mack Properties of Southport. The project, to be called Reservoir Corporate Center, will eventually contain three buildings on a hill overlooking the scenic Trap Falls Reservoir, near Exits 11 and 12 of Route 8.
Twin five-story buildings of 157,000 square feet each will be connected by a one-story structure housing a full-service cafeteria and fitness center. Rents will be in the low $20's a square foot compared with Stamford Class A rents that have reached as much as $35 a square foot.
Occupancy of the first building is scheduled for next March. Construction of the second and third buildings will be contingent on substantial leasing of the first building. The third building will be marketed as a corporate headquarters. "We would build to suit for a single tenant," Mr. Marcus said. The tract will be enhanced with walking and jogging trails and extensive landscaping.
His confidence in proceeding without tenants is bolstered by the vacancy rate of about 5 percent for Class A space in the Shelton-Trumbull marketplace. The demand is such that a 119,000-square-foot office building still under construction by Robert D. Scinto -- a major local developer -- has been fully leased. Major lessees are Brand Direct, a marketing company for financial institutions, with 35,000 square feet, and Clayton Group, managers of real estate portfolios for those institutions.
Other positive factors include easy access to labor via Route 8, significant amounts of new reasonably priced housing, and the fact that companies pressed for space in lower Fairfield are moving parts or most of their operations to cheaper locations.
An indication of Shelton's rising status, said Mr. Marcus, was the sale of his company's building at 1000 Bridgeport Avenue. Bought for $65 million 18 months ago, he said, it has just been sold to Mack-Cali, a New Jersey real estate investment trust, for $120 million.
Shelton's commercial-building surge is taking place in a triangle extending from the reservoir to Bridgeport Avenue at the west and Commerce Drive to the north. Nearly 750,000 square feet of offices have been approved or are now rising, and the planning department expects more applications through June. The town now has a total of 3.4 million square feet of office space.
Two new hotels, an AmeriSuites and a Homestead Village, have broken ground and the Hilton hotel chain has applied for approval of a two-building complex consisting of a moderately priced inn and an upscale hotel and conference center.
Five new restaurants, a Marriott Residence Inn, a Ramada Inn, a Sears Hardware, Bradlees, TJ Maxx, Wal-Mart and Staples, plus numerous smaller stores and buildings housing offices and light industry, have opened at various times over the last three years.
"The city is coming to fruition now," said Mark A. Lauretti, Shelton's four-term mayor, whose family-owned restaurant, Lauretti's, will move to a new location to make way for the Hilton project.
"I've been here since the population was 12,000, now it's 36,000," said the 43-year-old Mayor, a lifelong resident. "We started with an industrial base, now we have a corporate roster that's the envy of this region."
Indeed, the city has come a long way from 1975, when the Goodrich sponge-rubber plant burned down, putting 4,500 people out of work. During the building spree in the early 80's a concerted effort by the town to refocus its economy on offices rather than smokestack industry brought a crop of large buildings to newly established corporate parks -- just in time for the crash of 1987.
By 1989 the vacancy rate for its six million square feet of office and industrial buildings was 37 percent. With prices down everywhere, tenants could afford the more fashionable towns along the Gold Coast, leaving Shelton with a crushing number of empty buildings, some not even finished.
I N 1990 Auguste-Thouard, a French real estate firm whose subsidiary, the ATC Group, is based in Greenwich, bought a 155,000-square-foot building at 1 Research Drive in Shelton for $5.6 million, well under the asking price of $12 million. "We still own it," said Alain LeBleu, president of the ATC Group.
Last year he sold a 450,000-square-foot building on 50 acres at 710 Bridgeport Avenue for $26 million; he had bought it in 1991 for $22 million. It was purchased -- fully occupied by Philips Medical Systems and Timex -- by Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a Melville, L.I., REIT. "We sold off another building in Shelton," said Mr. LeBleu, "and although we are approved to build a 60,000-square-foot office building at 1 Research Drive, we will not do so until we have a prelease situation."
"I think Shelton is a good, longterm, stable market, but we haven't the same perception of a turnaround that others have," he continued. "I don't think there will be a huge demand in the next two or three years."
In 1991, Zell-Merrill Lynch, now Equity Office Real Estate Investment Trust, bought and still owns Shelton Pointe on Trap Falls Road, a five-story, 160,000-square-foot office building with a cafeteria, fitness center, and an eight-acre campus graced by a pond and five fountains.
"We think of Shelton as a complementary situation to our presence in Stamford," said Jeff Johnson, chief investment officer for Equity Office Properties in Chicago. "It was one of our first Northeastern assets, and it remains a low-cost alternative to Stamford and New York."
Companies and projects that have been drawn here over the last 17 years include Pitney Bowes, Physicians Health Services, Tetley USA and the Shelton Square Shopping Center. In addition, Mr. Scinto has built several office parks including Enterprise Park -- a complex of four office buildings, two currently under construction -- and two additional buildings on Commerce Drive.
Housing priced from $190,000 to $600,000 is available in hundreds of varied housing units scattered across the rural countryside or close to the office complexes.
"Some enclaves have pools, jogging paths and tennis courts," said Linda Schauwecker, a partner at Real Estate II, a local firm.
Since the Goodrich fire, Shelton's downtown has deteriorated and its lack of a movie theater or cultural offerings is somewhat off-putting. But, said Kevin M. Foley, a broker with Cushman & Wakefield in Stamford, leasing agent for Reservoir Corporate Center, "the lack of night life is not an argument we hear."
"Restaurants and shopping are more important than theater and the arts," he said, "and those things are available in Stamford -- only 30 minutes away. Trumbull has a 12-screen theater, Bridgeport has 25 screens."
"The big complaint is not enough hotel rooms -- you have to book two weeks in advance," he continued. "Because of the location Shelton is expected to accommodate people on extended stays, doing business from Stamford to New Haven."
Said Paul Kauffman, head of a Cushman & Wakefield team servicing Reservoir Corporate Center:
"Shelton will not attract financial services headquarters or major New York City Fortune 500 headquarters. But it will continue to attract middle management divisions of Fortune 500's for its ability to draw on a widely diversified labor force in a broad geographic area. Basically, Shelton is now a mature, stand-alone market with a stand-alone address. People know where it is."
