HEADLINE: Bond Sale to Lower Electric Rates

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
In a matter of days, the first segment of the largest sale of municipal bonds ever undertaken in the United States will mark a milestone in Gov. George E. Pataki's plan to cut Long Island electric rates by 20 percent.
Mr. Pataki said the rate cut would take effect immediately after the partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, which is imminent, and will last for at least five years. 
 It will be the largest single reduction in electric costs in the region's history.
Although Long Island's rates will still be among the highest in the country, regional economists have said the reduction will create tens of thousands of jobs, help retain and attract businesses and boost a regional economy that is already robust.
Critics, calling the savings illusory, said any initial benefits would be far outweighed by the eventual cost of the plan for electric customers and by blocked competition.
A long-term result of the Pataki plan, they said, would be to dam up competitive pressures that would transform the electric industry in other parts of the state and country over the next 30 years.
One group, the Hauppauge Industrial Association, said it and other opponents to the plan were deciding whether to sue to stop the issuance of the bonds.
But the bond sale advanced decisively last month. A little-known but very important state panel, the Public Authorities Control Board, approved the sale by the Long Island Power Authority, a state agency, of the first $3 billion of a record-breaking $7.3 billion to be sold by the end of the year.
The sale's success with investors was virtually assured last week when a financial rating agency, Standard & Poor's, gave the bonds an investment-grade of A-. (Ratings range from AAA to D.)
The agency noted, but downplayed, some predictions that technological innovations and competition in the electric industry would lead customers to abandon the new state power system, depriving it of revenues to pay off the bonds.
"We don't think the technologies are advancing enough at this point to suggest that cash flow will be at risk," said Marla A. Fox, a director in the public finance department of Standard & Poor's. The agency also noted that competition would be limited because Long Island had few prospects for importing power.
"Lipa's vulnerability to competitive forces is expected to be limited," the agency said, referring to the power authority by its acronym. "Competitive risks are tempered by transmission constraints and customer-base demographics. Consequently, Lipa should achieve the sound financial performance that it is projecting."
The agency also noted "the stability associated with a transmission and distribution system that serves a broad, predominantly residential and affluent customer base."
Ms. Fox said this statement referred in part to the lack of major industrial power users on Long Island, whose future withdrawal from the electric system could greatly reduce revenues.
The Standard & Poor's rating is the first close look at the Pataki plan from the perspective of potential investors and almost certainly guarantees buyers in a Wall Street market that experts said was hungry for new municipal bond issues. A second agency, Fitch IBCA, gave the bonds a similar rating.
Experts said the bonds would be especially attractive to New York investors because they are triple tax-exempt, meaning they are exempt not only from Federal, but also from state and local taxes.
Richard M. Kessel, the executive director of the Long Island Power Authority, said marketing of the bonds should proceed quickly to take advantage of low interest rates.
Experts estimated that interest on the first segment of bonds would be about 6 percent.
Critics of the plan say it will saddle electric customers with billions of dollars in debt over the next 30 years and hold customers hostage to a state-owned utility dependent on customer revenues to avoid bond default. But they acknowledged that in the current market, the bonds were likely to sell briskly.
"You can sell almost anything in a bull market like this," said Charles M. Studness, an analyst of utility finances. "But that doesn't mean what's going to happen is good for Long Island."
The bond sales will finance a sweeping restructuring of the source of Long Island's electricity by replacing the Long Island Lighting Company, the region's privately owned utility and power provider since 1910, with a public-private hybrid unlike any other power company in the country.
The plan calls for the Long Island Power Authority to purchase Lilco's transmission and distribution system as well as Lilco's 18 percent ownership share of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power facility near Scriba.
Following a planned merger with Brooklyn Union Gas, Lilco will continue to own Long Island generating stations, selling power to the power authority and managing the delivery system.
The power authority will have jurisdiction over electric rates, an aspect of the plan that alarms some critics. Rates for private utilities are set by the New York State Public Service Commission.
The key provision in the Pataki plan will convert a paper asset held by Lilco -- representing more than $4 billion in uncollected costs and interest for the never-operated Shoreham nuclear power plant -- into a cash payment to the company. This measure precludes the possibility of writing off some or all of the remaining Shoreham debt.
The Internal Revenue Service helped assure the plan when it said Lilco would be exempt from about $2 billion in capital gains taxes on the sale of the Shoreham paper asset to the authority.
The Pataki plan will raise $4.2 billion through the sale of tax-exempt state bonds to refinance the Shoreham debt at lower interest.
Critics said the payment for the paper asset was a bailout of Lilco for costs the company and its shareholders should assume for the failed nuclear project. Construction costs for the plant caused Lilco to institute a series of major rate increases during the 1970's and 80's.
In a 1989 settlement with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Lilco agreed to sell the plant to the Long Island Power Authority for $1 in exchange for the creation of a $4.5 billion regulatory asset that allowed the company to collect on all prudent costs and interests for the plant project.
Mr. Kessel and other backers of the Pataki plan have said the 1989 agreement makes it legally impossible for state regulators to compel Lilco to write off some or all of the Shoreham costs. Critics of the Pataki plan strongly disagree.
The unanimous vote by the Public Authorities Control Board last month approving the initial bond sale was the final state approval necessary.
The board has three voters: Mr. Pataki; Joseph L. Bruno, Republican of Rensselaer, the Senate majority leader; and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, Democrat of Manhattan.
With his vote, Mr. Silver chose not to exploit an opportunity to delay or thwart the Republican governor's plan in a gubernatorial election year.
As the likelihood of a 20 percent rate reduction increased, it was hailed by some officials. "I don't think any of us should have cold feet," said Bruce Nyman, Democrat of Long Beach, a member of the Nassau County Legislature. "A lot of people have been waiting for this for 20 years.
"Interest rates have never been lower," Mr. Nyman said. "A few years ago, I was getting more interest in my Christmas club."
Critics said they saw trouble ahead. "The bonds are fraught with risk, but buyers will be well compensated," said Gregory A. Palast of Southold, a utility regulation analyst.
"But we don't know what the future electric market will be," he added. "And there is a practical limit to how much you can squeeze from people on Long Island to pay off these bonds."

HEADLINE: The View From/Exeter;
Postgraduate Programs -- of the High School Variety

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
DAVID CADELINA, football coach and math teacher, is introducing his students at Central High School in Bridgeport to another world, a world few of them even dream about. He is recommending his most academically promising players for a postgraduate year at Phillips Exeter Academy, one of the nation's most prestigious independent schools, which counts among its graduates Daniel Webster, John and David Rockefeller, George Plimpton and Pierre Dupont, former Governor of Delaware.
"You get very close to your players if you are coaching your sport the way you should. You become coach, teacher, parent for the players. You want to see all good things happen for them," explained Mr. Cadelina, who is in his first year at Central. 
 So this spring he discussed a possible plan with his football players -- who had never heard of Exeter, never heard of a postgraduate year and were unsure of the advantages of staying in high school another year. One not only decided to try, but made it, with Mr. Cadelina working on college placement for other players.
The fifth year, called a postgraduate year, is not well known but many private schools offer it. Students have a chance to mature, to grow academically and for athletes, especially important, to grow physically.
A graduate of Amity High School in Woodbridge, Mr. Cadelina recalled his own postgraduate year at Choate prior to entering Hamilton College. "I was fortunate to have parents who pushed me to take the P.G. year and got me into a very good liberal arts school," he said, "so I've seen what a good education can do." This is what he wants for his students.
He contacted a friend in the admissions office at Exeter and learned that the school, in a bucolic setting in New Hampshire, "sought students from every quarter." This language appears in the school's charter and is interpreted today to mean students from different economic circumstances as well as geographical areas, according to Tom Hassan, admissions director. When Mr. Cadelina arrived with the three nervous candidates on a campus visit, they saw they would not be alone among the elite. "There's a group of students up there just like them," said their coach.
Lee Young of the Exeter admissions office said the school's recruiters visited 30 cities last year, seeking a diverse student body for the 35-person postgraduate program. Two of Mr. Cadelina's applicants did not have adequate grades or test scores to do the demanding work at Exeter, she said.
But Antonio DePina, 18, of Cape Verdean extraction, who speaks Creole and Portuguese and dreams of becoming a history teacher, was accepted and will be at Exeter this fall. He played defensive end and guard on the Central team and has already met the football coach at Exeter.
This year, Tony, as he is known, is in rigorous honors classes but he said that in his freshman year, his grades were not outstanding. He attends Central High School's magnet component, a school within the high school for 730 students that focuses on college preparation. Patricia Cucuzza, the supervisor of the school, reports 96 percent of its graduates continue their education, some at Yale, Harvard and Princeton. Seventeen advanced placement classes are offered.
Tony has his eye on Trinity College in Hartford and believes the additional year at Exeter will pull up his grade point average. "If I go to high school another year I will have more choices," he explained.
At Exeter, he found the students friendly, the food good and the campus college-like. "The kids were really outgoing," he said. "Here they are outgoing only if they know you." In fact, he added, "For being one of the top prep schools in the nation they were pretty much down to earth."
Tony said his family thought he should go directly into college from Central but his sister urged him to take the postgraduate year. "These kids seem more mature I think because they live away from home," he said, thoughtfully. He is a self-sufficient young man and plans to make his own meals when he misses his mother's Creole specialties.
Tony credits the coach with turning the team around, as well as landing him at Exeter. "He's done a lot to pick up morale," Tony said. "Everyone thought the football program was dead."
The coach runs a rigorous sports program, with strict rules that whittled down the number of players to 33 from 90. Players must stick to a strict weight-lifting regimen, sign a code of conduct promising to be good citizens and perform academically as well.
"We want everybody to think positive things when they hear 'Central football,' " said the coach, adding, "a lot of kids don't make it but the kids who do become a permanent part of our football family."
The coach's attention showed fast results. In the fall of 1997 his players' grades were at their highest. Parents called Coach Cadelina to express their appreciation. He worked with teachers and asked them to notify him of academic or discipline problems among his players. First he and the other coaches discipline faltering players by making them runs laps, many laps. Then they require them to attend extra help sessions held Wednesday evenings after practice.
Coach Cadelina said, "As far as Exeter is concerned I'm not looking at it nearly as much from a coaching standpoint as I am an overall life experience. College coaches look favorably on the postgraduate year because players are a year older, a year faster, a year stronger, just a year better."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Antonio DePina, headed for Phillips Exeter Academy in the fall, gets some pointers from his football coach, David Cadelina. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Active-Adult Communities Gaining in the North

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
SLOWLY but steadily, the construction of active-adult communities is pushing deeper into the northern part of the state, where developers say the demand for such housing outstrips the supply.
Three projects, one each in Warren, Passaic and Morris Counties, in various stages of development will produce a total of 1,300 housing units over the next five years or so. Such projects, which offer social and recreational services and someone else to do the chores, cater to buyers 55 and older who are entering their retirement or preretirement years. 
 Analysts and developers say several factors -- beyond the supply-demand imbalance -- are stoking the northward expansion of these communities, long linked to Ocean County, to which legions of older households in the state have migrated for decades.
The factors include the rising sale prices and real estate taxes in such communities in the southern half of the state and a corresponding rise in traffic congestion.
In the last four years the average sale prices of such homes in the southern half of the state rose from $135,000 to $170,000, with some selling in the low- to mid-$200,000 range, said William E. Becker, a housing consultant in Teaneck who specializes in active-adult retirement communities. Taxes, on average, have also increased, to $4,500 from $2,575, he said.
There is also the trend, which shows no signs of abating, of older people retiring closer to where they once lived or where their children live. And they want to be near employment centers because 30 percent of the people living in active-adult housing communities today still work, Mr. Becker added.
Ocean County is not in danger any time soon of losing its position as a choice address for retirees. But the fact that many people in the aging population -- in 1996 (the latest date for which figures are available), 15.9 percent of the state's 8 million residents were between the ages of 55 and 74 and the numbers are expected to grow to 19.2 percent of 8.5 million residents by 2010 -- will help make areas of North Jersey potential alternatives. Mr. Becker estimated that some 12,000 active-adult housing units were in the planning stages in the state, half of them outside Ocean County. State figures show that there are now 20,946 units in New Jersey.
The new momentum in active-adult community construction is driven by the strength of the state's overall housing market. Sales of existing homes rose 6.7 percent last year to 157,247, the highest level since 1987, according to the latest figures from the New Jersey Realtors Association in Edison. The projection is that the state will maintain that sales level this year, said Meredith LaVecchia, a spokeswoman for the association.
And what of active-adult units? For the last two years, Mr. Becker noted, about 2,500 such units have been sold a year, nearly double the number sold in 1994 before the housing market began to shake off its recessionary stagnation.
ALL of these factors played a part in the decision by Belvidere Development, of Far Hills, to move forward with Brookfield, a gated community in White Township in Warren County. Work is to begin this month on the project's first phase -- 300 detached homes costing $40 million.
Later phases will include 185 apartments and 18,000 square feet of commercial space, as well as 100 assisted-living units. Designed for residents usually 70 and older, they offer health care as well as social and recreational services. The project, which will cost an estimated total of more than $70 million, is to rise on 140 acres of farmland along Route 519.
"This area is analogous to what Ocean County was 20 years ago," said Eric M. Levin, president of the company. "And it is close enough for buyers to be near their families."
The site is near the historic town of Belvidere, the Warren County seat, and not far from the township of Mount Olive, an employment hub in Morris County. Also, it is accessible to Interstates 80 and 78, putting it within an hour's drive for potential residents who live in Morris, Passaic, Essex and Bergen Counties -- the market, along with local residents, the company hopes to attract.
In contrast it is a two-hour drive to Ocean County, Mr. Levin noted.
Nine years ago the company's owner, Kevin G. McDermott, purchased the site, then zoned for industrial and residential use; he won rezoning to build the project the same year. But then the recession hit and it was put on hold until the market improved.
With all the elements -- from location to support services -- in place "now, is the ideal time for this type of development." Mr. McDermott said, adding "the market is demanding it."
The project's detached houses were modified to meet current consumer preferences. The houses, with 1,280 to 1,950 square feet of space, have been widened to 34 to 40 feet from 28 to 38 feet and two-car garages have been added. Houses will sit on 86 acres of the site, with 35 acres left as open space, 25 acres of it deeded to the town for the public. Preconstruction sales of the first 73 homes, priced from the low $120,000's to the mid-$150,000 range, will begin in June and occupancy is expected to start by the fall.
Planned amenities include an outdoor pool, a boccie court, a nine-hole putting green and a 9,600-square-foot clubhouse with a fitness center. Monthly maintenance fees will be $120.
The pace of construction will be tied to sales and after two-thirds of the detached houses are built construction of the apartments will start. Mr. McDermott said it had not yet been decided whether they would be rentals or condominiums.
"What we are selling is country charm and affordability -- an alternative to Ocean County," Mr. Levin said.
OFF Pike Road in Wayne Township in Passaic County, K. Hovnanian Enterprises, based in Red Bank, is moving ahead with plans for a 23-acre gated community with 230 condominium apartments. The project, called K. Hovnanian's Four Seasons at Wayne, is the fifth active-adult community for the company, which is planning six others in the state.
The two- and three-bedroom units at the Wayne project, in 14 two-story buildings with elevators, will range in size from 1,600 to 2,000 square feet.
The buildings, with 12 to 19 units each, will have underground garages; buyers each will be assigned one parking spot as well as garage storage space. Prices are to range in the low- to high-$200,000 range.
Amenities will include a 5,000-square-foot clubhouse, outdoor pool and tennis court. Monthly maintenance fees, though not yet set, are estimated to be about $200. Models are expected to open in October.
The Fox Hills Corporation of Randolph, has started work on a 600-unit gated condominium community on Mount Hope Avenue in Rockaway Township in Morris County. The $110-million project, called Fox Hills, will contain one-, two- and two-bedroom-with-den units, in 13 three-story steel-and-concrete buildings with elevators. The buildings, set atop underground garages, will be spread over 88 heavily wooded acres, half of which will remain undeveloped. A later phase will have 100 assisted-living units.
Mort Solkind, president of the development company, said the focus of the project "was on having a suburban community, not one in the middle of nowhere." The project is one-half mile from Exit 35 of I-80 and close to the Rockaway Town Square Mall.
The condominiums will have 817 to 1,781 square feet of space and purchasers will have garage parking spots. Initial prices range from $129,900 to $209,900. The focal point of the community will be a two-story, 23,250-square-foot clubhouse with an indoor pool, library, a TV recording studio, fitness center and game rooms.
Sales opened last month and 54 units in the initial 84-unit section have been sold, said Mr. Solkind. Occupancy is scheduled to begin in December.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1703 words

HEADLINE: Disappointment Follows Vetoes Of State Spending

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
IN Westchester, as in other parts of the state last week, bitter disappointment followed Gov. George E. Pataki's veto of $1.6 billion in proposed state spending. High hopes were dashed for new library services, improved school buildings, richer arts programs and other items included in the original fiscal proposal. And many state legislators who had been exulting about this year's almost on-time budget -- one that was hammered out in the open rather than behind closed doors -- were forced to deliver bad news to constituents in an election year.
"Money for Westchester Community College and SUNY Purchase, gone! Money for the Arts Council, gone!" exclaimed an indignant State Assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky of Greenburgh, reeling off a list of Mr. Pataki's cuts. "The vetoes are especially bad for Westchester." 
 Mr. Brodsky described the reductions in schools and public health programs and the elimination of initiatives to clean up hazardous waste sites and devise a state map showing cancer rates as "direct attacks on the ability of the state government to help New Yorkers live decent lives."
Using his line-item veto for the first time, Mr. Pataki whittled out of the budget $760 million in spending this year and more than $800 million in borrowing for future programs. The State Legislature, which would need a two-thirds vote in both houses to override a veto, was not expected to mount that fight. The last time a veto was overridden was in 1996. Although legislators last week were still trying to sort out which items had survived and which were excised, it appeared that Westchester Community College lost at least some of the $1.14 million it had expected to spend on capital projects. It also lost $150 for each full-time student, money that the college president, Dr. Joseph N. Hankin, said would have been used to hold the line on tuition.
"Well, it still won't force us to raise tuitions," Dr. Hankin said, "but it will hold back some of our expansion plans. In general, they are discouraging colleges, and that's shortsighted." Financing for child-care programs at the college, aid to part-time students and technical improvements were also cut.
Also, Purchase College, part of the State University of New York, faced a reduction in the $33.4 million that state lawmakers had proposed, money planned for library upgrades and new stage lifts at the Performing Arts Center, among other things.
Local public schools, too, were disappointed, especially by the Governor's veto of a $500 million bond program for school construction.
"I've learned not to expect anything until I see it in writing," said Superintendent Saul M. Yonofsky of the White Plains public schools, sighing deeply. "No sooner do we start planning than it gets taken away." White Plains was to have got $1.1 million for construction work.
The district may also lose a proposed $300,000 increase in state aid for magnet schools, as may New Rochelle and Mount Vernon.
County Executive Andrew J. Spano said he was sympathetic to the Governor. "We all share the same problems, the need to reduce the cost of government," he said. Still, he said, he was asking his commissioners to assess the impact of the vetoes on the county's ability to provide services.
Yonkers faces losses of $5 million for construction, $250,000 for a computerized student record-keeping system and $1.1 million in salary increases -- part of a $77-million-a-year statewide support aid program, which helps urban school districts raise the compensation for city teachers, who generally receive less than their suburban counterparts.
"We're disappointed, to say the least," Superintendent Reginald Marra of Yonkers said. "Some things will have to just get put off."
In another category, the Westchester Library System, which serves 38 libraries in the county, lost about $50,000 for an Electronic Doorway Library project to offer the public computer terminals with Internet access. Mr. Pataki cut $3 million for similar library projects statewide.
"The Governor has always reminded us that his mother worked in a library and that he was a strong supporter of libraries," Maurice Freedman, the director of the county's library system, said. "This was a very strange way of demonstrating that support."
The Westchester Arts Council, too, was stung by the Governor's veto. The county's designated arts services organization in White Plains was to have received $250,000 to buy a permanent home, but after the veto announcement it was looking at half that amount. Janet T. Langsam, director of the council, said the organization had been considering the purchase of either a house near the downtown area of the city or a former bank on a block where a multiplex cinema is planned.
"It's going to be a much steeper climb now," she said.
Another $250,000 for sound barriers on the southbound side of the Sprain Brook Parkway was cut from the budget, as was $90 million for highways statewide. About $2 million for economic enhancements at the Yonkers Raceway and $60,000 to study the possibility of building a convention center and hotel at the site remained in the budget.
So did $500,000 for the Westchester Institute for Human Development in Valhalla, which provides out-patient services to people with developmental disabilities like mental retardation and autism.
Uncertain was $50,000 in financing for Tara Circle, an Irish artistic and cultural organization; $125,000 for a breast imaging center and a military health center at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers and $100,000 for an early-intervention children's program at the County Mental Health Department.
Although State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, chairman of the county's Republican Party, said he considered Mr. Pataki's vetoes "generally prudent," he was hopeful last week that some items could be restored,
"We can either try to override the vetoes, compromise or let the budget stand," Mr. Spano said. "Maybe we can negotiate."
Mr. Spano said Mr. Pataki had indicated that he would be is willing to compromise and that conversations with him would begin immediately.
But state Assemblywoman Audrey G. Hochberg, Democrat of Scarsdale, was furious with the Governor, calling the vetoes "arbitrary and ill advised."
Her district, which includes White Plains, lost $6,000 for a teen-age-pregnancy-prevention program and $6,000 for an enrichment program at the White Plains Child Care Association, among other items.
Speculating that other factors were at work, she said: "I'm puzzled why it was done and what the criteria were. Many of the member items vetoed were beneficial. I think the vetoes were more a matter of smart politics than anything else."
Mr. Pataki -- a Republican who is running for re-election and is widely believed to have aspirations for higher office -- announced the vetoes after the Assembly and the Senate, for the first time in history, drafted a budget through conference committees without the executive branch present.
Mr. Brodsky, a Democrat, agreed with Mrs. Hochberg that the vetoes represented a power move on Mr. Pataki's part. "This is about the Governor trying to re-create the 'three men in a room' syndrome as a way to solve his political isolation," Mr. Brodsky said, referring to the former system under which the Governor and the Senate Majority Leader and Speaker of the Assembly forged budgets behind closed doors.
Some political observers, however, believe the new budget process may have actually given Mr. Pataki even more power, because it left him free to veto whatever he disliked.
Calling the legislators' proposal "an election-year spending binge," Mr. Pataki reduced its size to $71.4 billion, which still represents a 6.9 percent increase over last year, the largest rise in a decade. The budget, even with the cuts, is almost 17 percent more than when Mr. Pataki took office nearly four years ago. The original 7.6 percent election-year spending increase, to $71.9 billion in the fiscal year that began April 1, had originally drawn harsh criticism from conservatives.
"Obviously, in an election year, I would have liked to have not vetoed these," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference last weekend.
But bowing to the demands of fiscal conservatives, whose votes he values both on the state and the national level, Mr. Pataki said, "We have got to have budgets that are soundly balanced and that meet the needs of the future."
But in 14 consecutive years of late budgets, this one was the least tardy, being passed on April 14.
In Westchester, fiscal conservatives were pleased that the Governor took a tough stand. Before the vetoes, Urs Broderick Furrer, a Mount Pleasant Councilman and vice president of the Taxpayers' Alliance of New York, described the proposed budget as "far too loose" and said he was appalled by the pork-barrel spending. After hearing that Mr. Pataki had vetoed more than 1,000 separate spending items, he said he was somewhat pacified but "would like to see Mr. Pataki go even further." "There's still plenty of pork in there," Mr. Furrer grumbled.
Richard Hallinan, treasurer of the Taxpayers' Alliance, said he had been worried that the Governor was setting a precedent for excessive spending that "would be difficult to reverse when the economy cools, which it always does."
"The veto is a step in the right direction," he said.
Mr. Pataki said his thumbs down on some budget items will "maintain the reputation for fiscal prudence that New York has earned over the last three years by keeping spending under control, while also allowing the state to continue its aggressive fight against crime by constructing a new maximum security prison this year."
The Governor let stand the largest corporate tax rate reduction in state history. It was also the first rate cut in more than a decade.
About the only really good news from the perspective of all sides was that the Legislature completed the budget just two weeks into the new fiscal year, in contrast to the 18 weeks beyond the April 1 deadline it took to pass a budget last year and the 15 weeks required in 1996. In fact, the last time that the Legislature finished a budget this early was in 1993.

HEADLINE: GUGGENHEIM MUSEUM;
Taking Another Look

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I have not visited the Guggenheim Museum of Art in almost 10 years. A frequent museumgoer, I have been partial to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the New-York Historical Society for most of my life. In my first and last visit to the uptown facility, I found the Guggenheim to be a very uncomfortable space that detracts from an unimpressive collection. Although the Frank Lloyd Wright structure itself demands attention, I have never felt tempted to venture inside again. But after reading Michael Kimmelman's article describing Thomas Krens's tenure as director of the Guggenheim "The Globe Straddler Of the Art World," April 19 , I have been persuaded that the interior of the Guggenheim deserves another look. 
 Art is the ultimate confirmation that we (collectively as a species) have transcended our environmental limitations. Once reserved for the courts of kings, decisions about which artists should be supported and what works should be conserved for posterity have now been relegated to the white knights of capitalism -- the not-for-profit organizations. I believe that the peace, prosperity and high quality of life that we enjoy as Americans is due in a large part to the free-market structure that underpins our nation. Because capitalism works, and we as a people have become more efficient at exercising it, our economy has succeeded.
Mr. Krens's approach seems to be the natural synthesis of state control and the free market. The markets have taught us that growth is good, that able-bodied management teams will be rewarded, and that the union of two organizations with similar interests and different types of asset pools can create synergies that add value beyond the scope of an audited balance sheet. As such, Mr. Krens's accomplishments should be lauded. He is a visionary. His approach to accumulating and displaying art is as fresh and as apropos as Cubism was in the 1920's.
As a capitalist, I am proud to be an American. As an American I have always been perturbed by the lack of cultural awareness among my fellow citizens. As an art lover, I am hopeful that "Krensian tactics" will win favor among our white knights and contribute to America's statement of emancipation from our environs.
 
ROY OPHIR
New York

SECTION: Section 11; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1440 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
On the North Shore, Restoration's the Word

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: UPPER BROOKVILLE

 BODY:
ZVIA GUTMAN's regular occupation is managing the apartment buildings she owns in Washington Heights, Harlem and the Bronx. But she also spends long hours at her future residence here on Terrace Lane, supervising the restoration of a playhouse that once belonged to Josephine Hartford Douglas, sister of Huntington Hartford, founder of the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company.
One of only four surviving outbuildings of a grand 90-acre Gold Coast estate called Farlands, which once stretched up the hill from Mill River Hollow Road, the brick structure contains not only a pool but also a 65- by 125-foot indoor tennis court that was once connected to the vanished manor house by an underground tunnel. 
The tennis-court wing's 50-foot-high roof, originally corrugated frosted glass, is now made up of plastic panels imported from Israel that, together with huge windows, let a flood of soft diffused light into its vast interior.
Switching to plastic from glass is one of the few compromises Ms. Gutman and her architect, Mojo Stumer of Roslyn, are making in restoring the brick building, which when completed will have 6,500 square feet of living area, including a finished basement connected to the main level by an elevator. With the tennis court and pool, the building has a total of almost 16,000 square feet of space.
"The idea is to restore this building to the way it was," Ms. Gutman said. "But to replace the glass in the ceiling would have cost $250,000 so that is something I decided not to do."
Ms. Gutman would not disclose how much she is spending on her house. But the likelihood is that renovations together with the purchase cost of the building, which is on two acres, will come to well over $1 million.
Buyers like Ms. Gutman who have the means to build substantial houses in exclusive areas like Nassau's North Shore, but who elect to buy -- and in many cases painstakingly restore -- old estates or their major outbuildings are rekindling the market for authentic period houses.
"The economic times have made it possible, because it not only takes money to restore an old house, but also to maintain it," said Barbara Candee, director of Daniel Gale Sotheby's International Realty in Locust Valley. "The request now is for a true traditional house that has been restored, not changed, that is 60 to 80 years old, with wonderful moldings, wonderful floors, wonderful hardware and with high ceilings," she said. "People prefer that to what you might call a faux traditional house."
She was referring to reproduction Georgians and other brick manor houses that are under construction in exclusive areas of the North Shore.
Mrs. Candee said that in her market area -- Sands Point to Stony Brook, Sotheby's sold 15 houses for $1 million or more last year, compared with seven in 1996. Of both years' sales, she said, 75 percent involved older estates.
Among reasons buyers are seeking out existing houses is that "the older house is usually in more of an estate setting, property-wise, with mature, ancient trees and wonderful plantings," she said.
AMONG her listings, for example, is a French Regency-style house in Matinecock whose six acres of gardens originally were designed by Frederick Law Olmsted, the designer, with Calvert Vaux, of Central Park in Manhattan. The asking price is $2.25 million.
"Older homes are highly desirable because they can't be reproduced," said Thomas B. Anderson, who heads the country home division of Sotheby's regional office in Manhattan. "In this healthy economy, what we have noticed without question, particularly over the last year and a half, is that the beautiful grand old homes are the most desirable properties we have," he said.
Potential buyers come from around the world. They include people in such diverse fields as investment banking and the entertainment industry, said Eileen Cornacchia of Palm Beach, Fla., who, with her husband, Joseph, has their summer house in Southold on the market for $5 million.
Such people have been intrigued by their 1927 Adirondack Lodge-style house "because when you pass the iron gates and go up the drive you enter a world like no other," she said.
The house, which has been restored, is on six acres, has 1,600 feet of beachfront on Southold Bay, dock space for 20 boats, a helipad and room for 24 house guests. It is being marketed through the Chace & Friends real estate agency in Greenwich, Conn.
Whenever restoration is needed, however, it can be an expensive undertaking, easily costing $300 to $400 a square foot, said James Smiros, a Glen Cove architect.
He recalled a client who had purchased a house on 20 acres in Mill Neck called the Cliffs which the financier James W. Beekman built as a summer house in 1863. The gardens were designed by Olmsted.
The plan was to knock down the 11,000-square-foot house and replace it "and that would have been a lot less expensive," Mr. Smiros said. "But as we studied the house we found it had such great architectural qualities that we instead chose to restore it," he added.
There are also environmental concerns that have to be addressed, said Edward C. Vassallo, the owner of the North of 25A real estate agency in Brookville. Asbestos usually has to be removed at great cost. And old oil tanks buried in the ground pose another problem, he said. "But people are willing to put the money in now because they feel the market is on the rise and that their investment is secure," said Mr. Vassallo.
There are other factors behind the rekindling of interest in period houses, said Robert B. MacKay, director of the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, a nonprofit group with offices in Cold Spring Harbor. "There is a greater appreciation of history in this country than ever before, and old houses are tangible history," he said.
Popular television programs such as "This Old House" and restoration fairs that are being held around the country have helped to galvanize that interest, he added.
Mark D. Stumer, one of the principals of the Mojo Stumer firm, which is working with Ms. Gutman on the Upper Brookville playhouse, said that although most of the new home construction today is taking the shape of traditional architecture, old estates "have a design and a presence that you could never afford to duplicate today."
Although the playhouse Ms. Gutman is restoring does not fit the mold of classic residences, it nevertheless mirrors an opulent way of life that no longer exists.
"Long Island Country Houses and Their Architects 1860-1940," an authoritative illustrated survey of that era published last year by the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities in association with W. W. Norton & Company, includes an aerial photograph of Farlands showing a massive Neo-Federal-style mansion surrounded by landscaped gardens and a golf course.
The house, designed by Guy Lowell, was built in 1918 by Guernsey Curran. A racetrack now occupied by the James H. Vernon Middle School was also on the property.
FARLANDS was demolished in the 50's to make way for a housing subdivision. The playhouse, the former gatehouse, a carriage house and the former dairy barn -- the latter two converted to residences -- and linden trees lining Lawn Lane are all that survive, said Peter M. Weiler, the Village Attorney for Upper Brookville, whose father, William, was superintendent of the estate.
Ms. Gutman is determined to restore what details she can to an interior that was neglected and partly ripped out by previous owners. All doors and windows are being replaced, but they duplicate the originals. The wooden walls of the tennis court wing, a balcony overlooking it and the pool house are being restored. "We're trying to make it look like it always did," said Michael R. Doyle of Mojo Stumer, who is the project architect.
The interior of the building, which once also contained a music room, a playroom, a kitchen and staff quarters, is being adapted for today's living needs. An attic ceiling in the former playroom, now the living room, was removed, for example, and the attic vents were enlarged into windows to allow light to pour down from above. And the elevator was installed.
"People live differently now than they did 80 years ago," said Brian Shore, a Locust Valley architect with a client who is restoring an Old Westbury mansion once owned by Harry and Gertrude Whitney.
"You can accommodate that, and still preserve the character and quality of the old house," he added. "And when you're done, there is something very self-fulfilling about bringing that old house back to life."

LENGTH: 419 words

HEADLINE: CHATTER;
Sport Utility Vehicles

 BODY:
Should there be a special driver's license required for sport utility vehicles, with their safety problems?
 
Unsafe for Everyone 
 As a driver of several smaller vehicles, I must say that the increase in the number of sport utility vehicles has made it very difficult to maintain visibility and safety on the road. On the highway I do not feel threatened, but in traffic I am frequently blocked in by sport utility vehicles and mini-vans. I cannot see pedestrians or traffic signals and signs. I find it especially treacherous to drive in the city near these vehicles.
The utility vehicles should be used for hauling large loads of materials and people. It's a waste of resources and a threat to the safety of everyone, including their drivers and passengers. In addition, many sport utility drivers have a tendency to be unnecessarily aggressive, similar to drivers of expensive sports cars, and that again poses a safety threat. I just don't see the point in John Doe four-wheel driving it to the office. It's a really obnoxious trend.
 
DENISE FUNARO
Edison
 
Unfairly Singled Out
Why are we sport utility vehicle owners suddenly becoming so maligned? As I approach retirement age, I purchased mine for the comfort of having the four-wheel drive to get my wife and myself around when it snows.
 
ALAN LOVITCH
Pompton Lakes
 
For Special Conditions
Drivers of sport utility vehicles should have a special license to drive on mountain roads or in bad weather. There is no other reason for a special license, though.
 
KRISTEN TORRES
Midland Park
 
Little Cars a Threat
Drivers of smaller sport utility vehicles seem to feel they are impervious to tipping over and safe in any road condition. All sport utility vehicles are subject to the effects of ice, no matter the size of the vehicle.
What about the number of mini-cars? A look at the bumpers of these small vehicles makes it obvious that with them, safety takes second place to economy.
 
TERENCE FERRARO
Edison
 
Warning Will Suffice
It's the drivers' responsibility to understand the risks and decide if they want to take them. But not everyone understands that the vehicles are more dangerous than regular cars, so they should be warned when they purchase one.
 
EVAN STEINER
Midland Park
 
Plenty of Licenses
Drivers distracted by quarrelsome kids, drivers on car phones, drivers whose minds are occupied by problems at work: maybe we all need special licenses.
 
AUDREY CORN
Denville

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2639 words

HEADLINE: Homebuyers Spending for the Extras

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
AFTER living in six homes in the last 24 years, two of them newly built, Kevin E. McKenna, a marketing executive, and his wife, Susan, a registered nurse, are now building another. This time, Mr. McKenna said, they are putting in all the extras they never got around to before.
In all, they have ordered $54,000 worth of options for their new four-bedroom colonial in a Milford, Conn., development, increasing the price of their house by more than 21 percent -- from $252,000 to $307,000. The 334-home development, called Lexington Green, is being built on 140 acres by the Baker Firestone company of Pleasantville, N.Y. 
 That amount of spending on extras is not unusual. Housing experts say that in these economic boom days, even first-time buyers are no longer satisfied with the standard items provided by builders, even if they include such niceties as fireplaces and two-car, instead of one-car, garages -- which themselves were considered options not that long ago.
Gone are the days when people want a house just for shelter, said Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington. "Now they are buying for a life style and this is happening all over," he said. Surveys have shown that on average $5,000 to $7,500 worth of options are added to every new house sold throughout the country, he noted, and in more affluent areas like metropolitan New York the numbers are much higher.
With two out of three buyers of new houses now move-up buyers, many are part of "the baby-boomer generation, well educated, both husband and wife working, at the best period of their working careers, and with money to spend," Mr. Ahluwalia said.
"They ask themselves the question: 'Should the money sit in the bank, or should they put it in the house?' " he said. "And the answer is the house."
Kenneth R. Nadler, a Mount Kisco, N.Y., architect whose clients include people building multimillion-dollar houses, summed it up this way: "People are willing to spend more on a house because they reason that while things are good, the house is a good place to put their money while they have it. The feeling is, If you're going to do it, now's the time. Everyone's dream is the same basically. It boils down to how much money do you have."
"People are looking at homes not just for living, but for total enjoyment"' said Mark D. Stumer of the Mojo Stumer architectural firm in Roslyn, L.I. "People are working very hard, they are under a lot of stress, and they're saying, If we are going to make all this money, we might as well enjoy some of the amenities of life."
To make their lives easier, Jyl Camhi and her husband, Keith, are adding two home offices costing $46,000, along with other options, to a $639,000, four-bedroom house they are buying in a Stamford, Conn., development called Westover Woods.
She is a computer software consultant. He owns a software consulting company. "We both work tons of hours," Mrs. Camhi said.
So does Frank Vella, a senior vice president at Chase Manhattan who commutes to Manhattan from Mount Kisco, leaving home at 6:30 A.M. and returning at 8 P.M.
When he and his wife, Melinda, bought a four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 3,752-square-foot house a year ago in the Mount Kisco Chase development under construction by Toll Brothers of Huntingdon, Pa., they added $92,400 worth of options to the basic house, which was priced at $568,900.
"This house came pretty well equipped," Mr. Vella said, "but we wanted to do something we felt really good about and a house we can have fun in. When you deal with people all day long, you just need a place to get away."
THE options they added included an extra room over the garage, a greenhouse breakfast room off the kitchen and a whirlpool bath and other upgrades. They spent $20,000 extra on the kitchen, adding such upgrades as a granite countertop that cost $7,500 and a designer tile floor that added $2,000. They also paid $15,000 extra for an oversized 1.45-acre lot.
Robert I. Toll, chairman of Toll Brothers, a national builder of houses that average $400,000 in price, said he is sometimes taken aback at the extent of options his customers add to houses that already have an extensive amount of amenities included in the basic price.
"It's an ego fulfillment kind of thing to some extent," he said. "There has been a remarkable increase in wealth in recent years and people are spending this money on themselves."
Music conservatories, billiard rooms, elevators, four-car garages, two-person showers and tubs "with pillars going to the ceiling so Augustus would be comfortable" are all available, Mr. Toll said. "We have a huge, thick customization catalogue, but people want to go beyond even that," he added. "They want to put something unique into their homes and to make their own home different from anybody else's."
Toll Brothers made an analysis of what buyers spent on extras in houses in different price ranges over a six-month period ended March 31. It showed that, on average, options added 13 percent to houses selling for $200,000 to $300,000; 17 percent to houses selling for $300,000 to $400,000 and 18 percent if the house sold for $400,000 to $499,000. Above $500,000 the number declined to 14 percent.
Among favorite add-ons were a greenhouse, a third garage, a bathtub with jets and a "princess suite," which is a second master bedroom with a bath for the daughter in the house.
Richard R. Girouard, a New Canaan, Conn., builder, has sold 63 custom houses over the last five years. Over the last two years, moving up from the $600,000-to-$900,000 market, he has sold 16 houses priced at $1.8 million to $4 million. In the category in which he is now building, he said, wine cellars complete with tasting rooms are now very much the thing. They cost $50,000 to $200,000. Home theaters add an average of $60,000 "and everyone has one." Kitchen cabinets alone can cost $100,000, he said.
"It's not that our need for creature comforts has changed," said Alan Yassky, a Spring Valley, N.Y., real estate broker who acts as a consultant to home builders in Rockland County. "Our perception of what that means has changed. Thirty years ago, a creature comfort was a finished basement. And now it's a separate great room, or a separate library where the husband and wife can be alone without the family. Having a paneled library isn't that unusual any more."
Beyond that "it comes down to absolute convenience for the buyer," said Carl R. Kuehner 3d, president of Building & Land Technology in Wilton, Conn., a builder of housing both on the East and West Coasts. "How do you become more efficient? By having an office in the home. How do you not have to water the lawn? By building in a sprinkler system. The new trend is gas-fired fireplaces, so all you do is push a button. People want to do something other than maintain a home."
Families are now staying in their houses longer than they used to -- 12 years on average, according to a 1997 report by the Chicago Title Insurance Company. "You don't mind spending money on a house you know you're going to stay in," said Joseph M. Forgione, the principal of Sterling Properties in Livingston, N.J., a builder of houses in the $250,000 to $700,000 range.
"Years ago, when you wanted to upgrade," Mr. Forgione said, "you could always buy another new house in the same town. Now land has become so scarce, people don't have that option any more."
To accommodate buyers who need help in picking what they want, some developers are building elaborate design centers. K. Hovnanian of Red Bank, N.J., which opened a 5,000-square-foot center for its Four Seasons at Lakewood and Four Seasons at Wall developments in Monmouth County. N.J., two years ago, now has another, of 15,000 square feet, about to start construction in Edison, N.J., within an hour's drive of several of its projects. The company builds 4,000 houses annually nationwide, more than half of them in the Northeast.
"Ten years ago, we did mostly entry level housing and we didn't do any customization," said Ara K. Hovnanian, the president of K. Hovnanian. "But we have been following the baby-boom generation and as they change from entry level to move-up age, we have moved along our company to meet their needs."
But it isn't just baby boomers who are loading up their houses. Retirees, even those on modest incomes, are on the same train, as are first-time buyers.
Jan A. Kokes, vice president of the Kokes Organization of Whiting, N.J., which builds developments in Ocean County for people whose average age is 63, said he was selling houses in the $137,000 to $202,000 price range, to which people are adding $15,000 to $20,000 in extras.
A sunroom adds $6,000 to $8,000, a fireplace $3,500, a screened porch $5,500 to $7,000, and a basement $25,000. "They all want something," he said. "People are saying, 'My children are gone, I'm going to build a new house, and I am finally doing this for me, the way I want it.' "
"In the past," said Mr. McKenna, the Lexington Green buyer, "we always said, 'The next house, we'll do it.' And we always regretted it later. Now we're putting in all the bells and whistles that we think we will enjoy."
FORMERLY a regional director of sales and marketing for Nabisco, the packaged-foods company, he now is the national sales manager for Inter Act Systems, an electronic marketing firm based in Norwalk, Conn. He and his wife hope their relocation days are over, another reason they are adding more to their house, he said.
"No one is buying just the basic house any more," said Lawrence Blum, the sales director at Lexington Green, where prices range from $180,000 to $270,000. The options buyers select add a minimum of 12 percent to the basic price and in some cases have added as much as $100,000 to the cost of the house, Mr. Blum said.
The extras the McKennas chose included finishing the 1,200-square-foot basement with a bedroom and a bathroom, building an unfinished 650-square-foot loft over the three-car garage, upgrading the kitchen and bathroom cabinets, adding extra telephone and cable lines, adding ceiling fans and improving the lighting.
They are replacing the carpeting on the main floor with hardwood floors, adding two-zone heat and central air-conditioning, and installing a woodburning fireplace in the living room with yet another extra -- a gas line that will give them a blazing hearth at the touch of a button.
In a consumer survey on housing conducted last year by Professional Builder magazine a trade publication for home builders published in Des Plaines, Ill., 529 would-be house buyers who indicated they were seriously in the market for a new home were asked what products they would select as options if they were offered. Of those sampled, the largest group -- 155 house hunters -- was looking at houses selling for $100,000 to $150,000.
Percentages varied by geographic region and by the price of the home people were looking at. But in summary, among options priced from $800 to $1,000, upgraded carpeting was the favorite, a porch came in second and double-glazed windows came in third. Among products priced from $1,600 to $2,000 each, the top favorites were storm windows, security systems and whirlpool baths. And among products priced from $3,000 to $6,000 each they were central air-conditioning, fireplaces, and screened porches.
In the $12,000-to-$20,000 price range, swimming pools, basement recreation rooms and home offices were the favorites with 31.4 percent of the 455 buyers who responded to that category indicating they would want a pool, 21.3 percent opting for the recreation room and 19.1 percent selecting the home office.
Not all builders are thrilled about custom-building for buyers, especially in a hot housing market. "I'd rather cookie-cut and deliver houses faster, but those times have gone," said Steven A. Klar, president of the Klar Organization in East Meadow, L.I., which builds everything from town houses to large single-family residences on individual lots.
"In new construction," he said, "there is a statement, 'As long as I'm doing this, I might as well.. . . If I'm going to go for the marble bathroom, I might as well put in the whirlpool.' I hear it all the time."
One of his recent buyers. Thomas Nester, could have been listening. Mr. Nester and his wife, Lois, both accountants, bought a house last April in a Klar development in Dix Hills, L.I., called Longmeadow. The basic price of the five-bedroom, 3,800-square-foot house was $505,000. With upgrades, the house cost the Nesters $580,000.
"We walked into the model, and we could easily have lived with the house without any extras," Mr. Nester said. "But we said, 'If we're going to do it, let's do it the way we want it.' " So they made the bedrooms larger, extended the living room, put in extra phone and computer lines and upgraded the kitchen and the bathrooms.
As first-time buyers, Carolyn Williams and her husband, Thomas, weren't going to leave anything out either. "We saved two-and-a-half years to buy our house, and we wanted to do it right," Mrs. Williams said.
Parents of three young children, they are purchasing a house in a Holtsville, L.I., development called Summerfield, under construction by the Emmy Building Group and Stanley Gross of Smithtown.
The $195,000 house, for which they had signed a contract six months ago, won't be ready until October because adding the options they wanted is slowing construction, Mrs. Williams said. Plus it's costing them an additional $35,000 for such items as a front porch, central air-conditioning and a whirlpool tub and a stall shower in the master bathroom suite.
At first they were going to forgo the $4,200 whirlpool tub and stall shower combination, she said, "but one of the guys at work told my husband, 'Just do it, because it's more expensive to add it later.' So we went for it."
ADDING options as the house is built makes a lot of economic sense to buyers. For the Williamses, who are making a 20 percent down payment on their house, their $35,000 extra outlay will cost $7,000 more for the down payment and about $140 a month more on their mortgage payments, said Mr. Williams, who is a financial planner.
"One reason I decided to put the extras in is because interest rates are so low." he said. "Factoring the cost into my mortgage is a lot cheaper than borrowing down the road if you want to do it then."
"People used to want to pay off their mortgage as soon as possible and have a mortgage burning," said Mr. Blum, the Lexington Green sales director. "Now they put in as many options as they can, put down as little as they can, and pay off the mortgage over the longest period of time they can. It's a whole different outlook."
Outlook and life style are the expressions industry experts and builders use most often when attempting to sum up what motivates home buyers who spend much more on their houses than they really have to.
"It all has to do with life style," said Mr. Ahluwalia of the National Association of Home Builders. "And what is life style? It means that when you have enough money to meet your basic needs, you also spend it on something that doesn't mean anything. Many of the things people are buying in a home have no functional use; it's all for show."
Mr. Hovnanian of the K. Hovnanian building company has a pragmatic viewpoint. "Ozzie and Harriet died a long time ago," he said, referring to the radio and television show. "The perfect family of the husband who goes to work, the wife who stays home to take care of 2.5 children, and the white picket fence, is gone. With dual-income families, two singles, divorced fathers and single mothers buying houses, the standard house just doesn't work for everyone anymore."

HEADLINE: HEALTH;
Mental Patients in Shore Towns Are Moving to New Homes

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
Some Jersey Shore towns that have been inundated with former mental patients since the 1970's are experiencing some relief, thanks to a carefully planned program that closed five troubled boarding homes and found new, often better housing for about 200 residents.
"We're really pleased with it," said Richard Cuttrell, the business administrator for Neptune Township, Monmouth County. The township includes the quaint Methodist summer village of Ocean Grove, where the Breakers, a 35-bed boarding house, was shuttered in 1996. Mr. Cuttrell said the closing was a major factor in Ocean Grove's renaissance. "The entire town has seen a turnaround in the last five years," he said. 
 The program, called Shore-EASY (for Shore Homeownership Opportunities, Restoration and Economic Assistance Strategy), has almost finished spending the $10 million allocated to Ocean Grove, Asbury Park, Long Branch and Lakewood to improve some boarding houses and increase social services for their residents, as well as to buy houses and move residents. Planning for redevelopment of the sites of the closed houses is in progress, and negotiations to buy one or two more houses in Lakewood are under way.
But the program's most powerful legacy may lie beyond the physical changes in the shore towns, in its multifaceted approach. Representatives of several state departments, including Health, Community Affairs and Human Services, as well as the state mortgage and finance agency that buys the properties, frequently met and discussed relocation and service options with local agencies, officials and advocates for the mentally ill, all with the participation and oversight from the Governor's office.
"Everybody there knew it was supposed to work," said Carolyn Beauchamp, the director of the Mental Health Association of New Jersey. "And if it didn't, who knew who would be taken to task for it?"
A result appears to be that rarest of government programs: one that is praised even by its harshest critics.
"I really feel this whole Shore-EASY thing was a violation of the Fair Housing Act," said Bill Nordahl, a former mental patient who works with the Collaborative Support Program of New Jersey. "I believe that we, as ex-mental patients, have the right to live wherever we choose." Another flaw, he said, is that Shore-EASY created a net loss of affordable housing units.
Even so, he said, the state "was more sensitive than they ever were in the past" and had worked very hard to give residents a choice of new homes. "They took some people to as many as 12 places," he said.
Residents said they had mixed feelings, but often very positive ones.
Laurie Marino, 40, who lived at the Asbury Carlton, a former hotel, for more than four years, is now living with two other women in their own suburban house in Freehold, supervised by the Easter Seal Society. "For myself, it was good," said Ms. Marino, who has a schizoaffective disorder, an illness that can resemble schizophrenia. "But I was one of the younger people there. A lot had been there 15, 20 years. That was their home. Now they're scattered all over."
One longtime resident was Mary Uminowicz, an elderly woman. A native of Jersey City, she moved to the Asbury Carlton in 1968, having spent 20 years at the Meadowview County Hospital for "a nervous breakdown," she said. Now she is living in a small boarding house with four other tenants, looked after by a kindly landlady whose cooking she praises. "I told them I want to stay," she said. "She's nice to me. She does my laundry."
Ray Licata, director of the Monmouth County Division of Social Services, said he was surprised by the program's success. "It went much better than I thought it would," he said. "I thought there would be more problems, and I didn't think we'd be able to keep as many patients in Monmouth County."
Of the 197 people relocated, 9 remain in Ocean Grove and 24 in Asbury Park. Elsewhere within Monmouth County, 51 people have been placed; 33 went to Ocean County, 25 to Camden, 16 to Essex, 11 to Union, 25 to other counties. Three moved out of state.
Shore-EASY was created in 1995 in answer to furious protests from shore communities to a plan to close the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital (on schedule for next month).
In the 1970's, a social movement to minimize constraints on people with mental illnesses or mental retardation coincided with the advent of psychotropic medications like lithium, prompting a wave of discharges from mental hospitals. But the former patients often received little in the way of monitoring or follow-up care.
The shore areas were experiencing a downturn in tourism, and small, floundering hotels began reinventing themselves as boarding houses. Former mental patients began moving in by the score; when the state announced its plan to close Marlboro, there were about 100 such houses in the four towns, ranging from dilapidated homes with a dozen or so beds to the notorious Asbury Carlton, with 163 beds. Any remaining tourism was driven away, town leaders said, by the former patients, who forgot to take medication, wandered the streets, panhandled, and bought and sold drugs.
Governor Whitman's office responded to the town's arguments with Shore-EASY. "I think it was the first real sign that the state recognized that there was a problem," Mr. Cuttrell said. "That alone did a lot of good."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Pattern and Decoration, Abstract and Otherwise

BYLINE: By BARRY SCHWABSKY 

DATELINE: SUMMIT

 BODY:
"GO west, young man" may have been the catch phrase for 19th-century pioneers, but for artistic pioneers, then and now, a more appropriate slogan might be "Look east."
It's what painters like Whistler and van Gogh did, enamored as they were with Japanese prints, and it's what a number of young artists in the 1970's did as well. That's when Robert Kushner, along with colleagues including Valerie Jaudon, Joyce Kozloff and Robert Zakanitch, began looking to Islamic tiles, Japanese kimonos, Turkish rugs and the like as inspiration in their efforts to find ways to expand the vocabulary of painting. These artists became known as the Pattern and Decoration movement. 
 As Mr. Kushner's current exhibition at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts demonstrates, their efforts may not always have been successful but were never less than thought-provoking, and their ideas were perhaps more deeply ingrained in the Western tradition than they may have seemed.
In contrast to an older artist like Miriam Schapiro, who had slowly worked her way toward the Pattern and Decoration idea, Mr. Kushner may be said to have grown up into it. While still an undergraduate at the University of California at San Diego, from which he graduated in 1971, Mr. Kushner studied with Amy Goldin, the art historian and critic who would soon become known as the voice of the movement; a few years later, they would travel together through Afghanistan, Iran and Turkey.
Inspired by the chadors worn by Iranian women, Mr. Kushner's early paintings like "Biarritz" (1975) were often made on pieces of fabric that were squared off at the top but formed a semi-circle at the bottom. These works were actually meant to be worn in performances the artist staged (it would have been helpful if the exhibition catalogue had given more details of these, and perhaps even shown a few photographs of them) but at the same to function as pure painting to enliven a wall.
Many modernists, especially women like Sonia Delaunay and Natalia Goncharova, had ventured into clothing and costume design, but the idea that the very same object could be at once a costume and a painting was something new. Still, as painting, "Biarritz" is very much within the modernist tradition, reflecting the influence not only of early 20th-century originators like Matisse and the Delaunays, but also of the color field painters of the 1950's and 60's, like Helen Frankenthaler and Kenneth Noland. They, too, had painted directly onto unprimed canvas so the color would float within its surface rather than sit atop it, and their quest for a simplified imagery often brought them to the point of patterning, as in the case of Mr. Noland's concentric circles, stripes and chevrons.
In fact, while Pattern and Decoration has often been seen as a rebellion against the austere rigors of late modernism, a way of reclaiming simpler and more spontaneous pleasures, the patterning impulse can just as easily be seen as proceeding from one of the bases of modernist esthetics: the determination that rather than being divided into areas of greater and lesser significance (for instance, figure and background), every portion of a painting ought to be of equal importance, and realized with equal intensity. What better solution to such a challenge than the repetitive force of pattern, which demands that every area under its sway be treated equivalently?
A painting like "Two Birds" (1977) shows considerable change: while the shape of the painting still recalls the idea of clothing -- the reference is a kimono -- it is no longer actually wearable. Furthermore, the imagery is not, as in "Biarritz," completely abstract: there are now flowers, which will henceforth form a major part of the artist's imagery, as well as the birds of the title.
By the time he made "Sail Away" (1983), the largest painting here, Mr. Kushner was no longer painting patterns but collaging them. Here, as in other paintings of the decade, he has drawn, with acrylic paint, schematically rendered nudes along with floral forms on his cotton ground, then sewn blocks of often gaudily printed textiles around the drawn lines. As Sara Lynn Henry remarks in her catalogue essay, the figures become "embedded . . . in the kaleidoscopic shifting of decorative patterns."
The end of the decade brought new changes, as Mr. Kushner resorted for the first time to conventional stretched canvas and added the physicality and chromatic richness of oil paint to the fluidity of acrylics. The human figure has disappeared; the floral and other botanical imagery that accompanied it has taken center stage, as in "Artichoke Apotheosis" (1995). Yet the sensual appeal of this artist's flowers is, if anything, even greater than that of his nudes.
Perhaps there's some clue there to an artist whose exploratory sensibility has not yet found its ideal vehicle. Back in 1986, Mr. Kushner said: "When you first start making art, everything is possible and desirable. Then the patterns of ideas start to emerge and you say, 'What do I really want to do?' " His patterns, overloaded as they may be, have never been as sensuously rich as he intends, but rather intellectually willed, "patterns of ideas."
Nor has deciding what he really wants to do been this artist's forte. The lesson the great modernists learned from Asia was economy: how to leave things out. Matisse may have been the great decorative artist of the century, but he was never indulgent; rather, he was ruthless in his exclusions, severe in his simplifications. The colors and patterns in just one of Mr. Kushner's paintings would have served Matisse -- who observed, "An avalanche of color has no force" -- for 10.
There are fine, occasionally even gorgeous passages in these paintings. Just look at the bunch of small white and lavender flowers just right of center in "Pomona Pavane" (1996), for example. Yet rarely does the whole hang together. Decoration, which in its Matissean sense implies expanding space rather than filling it, remains more of an aspiration than an accomplishment here.
 
ROBERT KUSHNER: 25 YEARS OF MAKING ART
Palmer Gallery
New Jersey Center for Visual Arts, 68 Elm Street, Summit
Through May 31. Hours: Mondays through Saturays, noon to 4 P.M.; Thursdays, 7 to 9 P.M.; Sundays, 2 to 4 P.M.
