HEADLINE: Pine Barrens on Edge

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
THE bungalows on the back roads of Pine Ridge South here are spanking new, and so is the life of the place. Tom Koehl, newly retired and resettled from Secaucus, says that although "they roll up the sidewalks too early around here," regular bingo games are under way and the pool hall is open; shopping and restaurants are "not bad." As he speaks, a gleaming silver bus pulls up at the clubhouse around the bend as residents return from an Atlantic City day-trip.
Mr. Koehl also talks gratefully about deer and tree frogs while pointing behind his house, where bulldozers have just munched into the pines for new lots. "We had swamps when we moved to Secaucus, and they built all that up," he says. 
 This is the Pinelands, or, more specifically, an intersection between the Pinelands and the rest of New Jersey. The people moving to Manchester, where a concentration of retirement communities has put the over-65 population at more than 70 percent, want to have it all: tree frogs and malls, neighbors and nature trails. And more and more people are joining them.
In the vast land-use plan drawn up nearly 20 years ago to protect the sandy forest that most people know as the Pine Barrens, some pockets of Manchester were designated to absorb development, and they have: the population has grown by a third since 1980, with more than 5,500 building permits issued.
The pattern is even more striking in the designated "regional growth areas" near Atlantic City -- Galloway Township's population has increased 123 percent since 1980 and Hamilton Township's by 88 percent. Evesham Township, on the Philadelphia side, grew by 79 percent in the same period.
All that, too, has proceeded according to plan. But it's in areas like these that the land-use plan, the state's foremost sprawl-prevention mechanism, is feeling strains. The plan, covering about a million acres in seven counties, was the state's way of preserving a rare and huge ecosystem by closing off its heart and channeling development to the edges, where it seemed inevitable.
It was, in effect, a zoning plan writ large. A 15-member commission was set up to figure out what everybody in its jurisdiction would be allowed to do with their property, and it infuriated farmers and developers while barely mollifying preservationists; only in the last few years has it achieved an uneasy peace with local officials and agricultural and real-estate interests.
"We can't say very much about the commission," said Patrick O'Keefe, chief executive officer of the New Jersey Builders Association. "What that reflects is the fact that the commission in essence has set itself up, adopted the Comprehensive Management Plan and really just left very little room for interaction. With a few exceptions of the growth townships, Hamilton or a couple others, there's very little by way of activity in the Pinelands. That's by design; the design was basically to shut down the industry in the whole area."
But along the perimeter, the "growth townships" have not escaped the classic dilemma of the suburban fringe. They are caught between spillover growth from Philadelphia, New York and Atlantic City, with the promise of ratables, and the desire of those who got there first to lock the gate.
Warren G. Sweeney, chairman of Manchester Township's environmental commission, said that many residents "are from areas that have already reached their capacities, and those that got here first don't want to let anyone else in."
"Also, we're in a very sensitive area environmentally," Mr. Sweeney said. "A lot of people are trying to prevent what's there from being bulldozed and macadamed over. It's a considerable treasure to be aware of and to protect."
Now the Pinelands Commission is about to receive the Whitman imprint. Its chairman of 10 years, Richard L. Sullivan, has announced that he will retire in June, leaving Governor Whitman with a critical environmental job to fill.
Mr. Sullivan recommended three possible successors: Sally Dudley, executive director of the Association of New Jersey Environmental Commissions; Candace Ashmun, a member of the 15-member commission from its start in 1979, and Michael Catania, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Nature Conservancy.
Ms. Ashmun said that "the very towns that were frantic because they didn't think they could get enough development are now complaining that they have too much."
The Commission's managed-growth plan insures that suburbia doesn't creep into the heart of the Pinelands. "The shore is getting worse and worse, and the Highlands is being attacked now," she said. As for controlling sprawl, she said, "the Pinelands is the only place we've had the nerve to do it."
But along the periphery, "the number of building permits is incredible," she said. "It's scary to me."
According to the commission's statistics, economic growth in its jurisdiction is actually higher than in the rest of the state. It estimated in a report issued last year that the population of "Pinelands municipalities" -- some of which, like Manchester, are partly outside its boundaries -- grew 30 percent between 1980 and 1996, as against 7 percent in the remainder of South Jersey and 5 percent statewide. Other economic indicators, including growth in personal income and building permits, also were higher inside than outside the Pinelands.
"People have to understand that this is not a park," Mr. Sullivan said. "It's not a wilderness. Some people think there are 111 people down there."
In fact, there are more than 570,000, according to Census Bureau estimates. The plan would theoretically accommodate as many as a million.
"That's not too many if residents and businesses go in the right places," Mr. Sullivan said. He said 95 percent of the development since 1980 had occurred in the "growth areas" set aside by the commission.
But in those areas, the effect was one dreaded 20 years ago by the preservationists who dominated the commission and by their early rural adversaries: it's suburban.
In Manchester and neighboring Berkeley Township, the commercial strip is Route 37, just outside the official state Pinelands boundaries and lined with strip malls and fast-food places. In Hamilton Township, the Hamilton Mall could not contain retail growth; around the corner, the Consumer Square Mall -- Target, Seamans, HomePlace and more -- is pushing outward. In the wedge between them, new townhouses ($74,990 to $85,990) are rising at the Timber Glen development.
Is this what the Pinelands plan contemplated?
"I don't think the plan cared what kind of development was going to occur," said John W. Sinton, a professor of environmental studies at Richard Stockton College who served on the commission for several years. "The commission is a negative force -- stop development. All of the effort went into that. My thought was always that if there was a positive force -- here's how we should develop, let me suggest that you build in these areas or do some real local planning -- that would have been a positive development."
In a 1985 book on the Pinelands, "Water, Earth and Fire" (Johns Hopkins University Press), Mr. Sinton and his co-author, Jonathan Berger, argued that the plan restricted some areas too severely while making others "dumping grounds for future development."
In sum, Mr. Sinton said in an interview, "it's the kind of top-down planning that doesn't work in a place where local power tends to rule."
The early commissioners "were never very much in touch," he said. "I would invite them down to go canoeing or whatever, and it was clear that they really didn't like the place much."
But for all his reservations about the "Princeton mafia" that engineered the plan -- "the wealthy have always wanted to preserve things" -- Mr. Sinton said the Pinelands are probably better off with the plan than without it, if only because it had slowed growth in the central Pinelands.
To Mr. Sullivan, "top-down planning" is the only kind that works. "The virtue of this system is that it is treated as an ecological entity," he said. "You put things in places that can accommodate them. If we left it up to the 53 towns, the chance of preserving this special place would be blown. It's the most likely way to protect the Pines and the way of life people come down here for."
Mr. Sullivan, 71, who served as the Department of Environmental Protection's first commissioner, was appointed by Gov. Thomas Kean. Mr. Sullivan is identified with the preservationist wing of the Pinelands Commission, if there still is such a thing in an agency where politics and economic interests have grown awfully tangled in two decades.
The commission has seven members appointed by the Governor, seven appointed by the freeholders of the Pinelands counties and one by the Federal Government, which in 1978 designated an area slightly larger than the state's Pinelands area as a "national reserve," provided funds for land acquisition and directed the state to set up the land-use plan.
When the commission was formed, its mission was not to oversee a million acres worth of zoning matters but to protect the region's forests, rivers and especially the aquifer beneath it all -- 17 trillion gallons of fresh water easily contaminated by anything leaching through the sandy soil. But acquiring the whole area for a park or preserve was politically and fiscally impossible, so the commission would have to deal with thousands of private owners, who even now hold more than half the acreage.
The state marked off a 339,000-acre "preservation area," all but closed to new development. It assigned the new Pinelands Commission to carve the remainder into districts for forest preservation, agriculture (especially cranberry and blueberry farming, a mainstay of the region's agriculture) and residential development.
The commission, set up in a slightly ramshackle old farmhouse in Pemberton Township, which it still occupies, drew the blueprint. There had never been such an all-encompassing plan in the United States, and there hasn't been since, said Charles L. Siemon, a leading land-use lawyer who worked on the plan and now practices in Boca Raton, Fla.
 
From Effusive Praise To Ringing Denunciation
Conceding some bias, Mr. Siemon said: "I don't think I have any doubt that it's the greatest American planning initiative and success in this century. The ecological integrity, the character of communities, the basic systems are still functional today. And I'm sitting in South Florida right now, where I think the built environment and the natural environment are in tragic condition."
Now, everyone seems to agree, it is the Pinelands fringes that are causing concern. "The issues now seem to revolve around places where growth is taking place where they now aren't sure they want growth to take place," said Ms. Dudley of the state advisory group on the environment.
Ms. Dudley, like other environmental advocates and like the commission's officials, says the plan gives developers the advantage of predictability: the areas for growth are clearly set out, they say, as are the maximum densities.
Some developers agree. Kevin Johnson, a builder in Jackson Township, said that his still-unbuilt Savannah Ridge subdivision had been approved years ago but that builders "shied away" because Pinelands regulations required costs that they thought would make the housing too expensive.
Mr. Johnson bought the tract, drew up 3.2-acre lots for houses starting at $270,000 and a week after opening for sales last month had two contracts and a binder. His dealings with the Pinelands Commission, he said, consisted of "a couple of phone calls and faxes."
Some developers do not agree. "You couldn't give me property in the Pinelands," said one Gloucester County builder, who refused to permit his name to be used. "They're an awful, awful state commission. They'll stonewall you to death."
Farmers, too, have complained about the commission for two decades, mostly because it effectively rezoned the land that many had once contemplated selling to developers. "That's perceived wipeout," said Terrence Moore, the commission's executive director. "And that's very understandable. One farmer who's very respected said it's good for agriculture, it's just not good for farmers."
The commission did devise a limited mechanism for compensation, in the form of development rights that can be sold by landowners in restricted areas to builders in growth areas. Tom Darlington, a Burlington County cranberry grower who has served on the commission from the beginning, said this provision had eased some pain, though "not all farmers are overjoyed with the commission."
"When I voted for the Pinelands master plan," he said, "all my farmer friends almost tarred and feathered me." But he said that one who barely spoke to him for 20 years told him recently that "he now realized that the commission was a valuable thing and without it we growers would have been wiped out of business."
Then there are those who maintain that the commission has not saved enough, though the principal watchdog group, the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, is more ally than adversary.
"If the scales can be tilted to the environmental side, we'll put the pressure on," said Theresa Lettman, the project manager for the group. "As much as we'd like to fight it, we accept the plan.
"Now we hope the Governor appoints someone to that chair who understands the importance of the plan," said Ms. Lettman, who is also a Whitman appointee to the New Jersey Natural Lands Trust. She said the Pinelands group would support any of the three possible successors whom Mr. Sullivan recommended.
Environmental advocates are relieved that the Governor, whose record as a conservationist is equivocal, proposed this year that the state preserve one million acres of open space, some of which would naturally be in the Pinelands.
"The majority of people in the state feel preserving open space is the way to go," Ms. Lettman said, "and the Governor is taking that direction."
In Manchester, hundreds of residents, most from retirement communities, have turned out at public hearings to oppose a plan by H. Hovnanian Industries for another senior-citizen development on 7,100 acres just outside the Pinelands boundaries. And the township is negotiating with the Pinelands Commission to lower the building densities allowed in the Pinelands area.
The adjacent township, Berkeley, which has had about 10,000 new housing units since 1980, is also feeling squeezed. Mr. Catania's group, the Nature Conservancy, recently struck a deal with a developer to acquire 4,000 acres in the Pinelands there.
All over the Pinelands, Mr. Catania said, "I think there's going to be another boom, and in the next 5 or 10 years, I expect the areas that need to be protected are either going to be protected or they're going to be gone."

Map/Chart: "It's Not Barren, And It's Getting Less So"
The Pinelands National Reserve is governed by an intricate map that tries to channel most of the area's economic development into "regional growth areas" shown here in black. Even in towns and villages, development is permitted only if it is "compatible with the existing character." At the other end of the scale are the most ecologically sensitive zones, the "preservation area" and the "special agricultural areas" at its core, where economic activity is largely restricted to blueberry and cranberry farming; other forest and agricultural zones impose varying restrictions on housing density and agricultural use.
 
Preservation area
Largely undeveloped, but with some farming; reserved mostly for recreation and wildlife management.
 
Forest management areas
Low-density housing and commercial development is allowed; current density is only one house per 22 acres.
 
Agricultural production areas
Reserved almost exclusively for farms and the people who own them and work on them.
 
Special agricultural production areas
A preserve for the region's traditional cranberry and blueberry farmers.
 
Rural development areas
Residential zoning in these areas averages one house per five acres.
 
Regional growth areas
Designed for economic development "while protecting the essential character and environment of the Pinelands." But housing density ranges up to 8.5 units per acre.
 
Pineland villages and towns
High population density is allowed, subject to the "existing character" criterion.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 1; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1741 words

HEADLINE: Bosom Foes Together Again

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
IT would have been an odd evening, that's for sure.
Hugh Hefner, the man who put women in bunny costumes and set the wheels of the sexual revolution in motion for millions of Americans, and Gloria Steinem, the crusading leader of the women's movement, were supposed to go on a blind date a few decades ago, as Mr. Hefner tells it. 
 In a funny way, it would make sense if the two had hit it off. He, the creator of Playboy, and she, the founder of Ms. magazine, ran spectacularly successful publications at the forefront of social change, then watched the circulation -- and relevance -- of their magazines dwindle. Both have made enemies of the right wing. Both ran through a series of romantic partners, wrote about sex, support gay rights and think Al Gore would make a fine, if boring, President.
But they hate each other's guts.
The long-ago meeting never took place, and instead, time pulled Mr. Hefner and Ms. Steinem further and further apart. But last week, cultural kismet -- or just a shrewd publicity coup -- brought them together after all these years for something resembling a blind date. The American Society of Magazine Editors chose the two of them to be inducted into its hall of fame at a luncheon on Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria.
His hair gray and his waist thickened with age, Mr. Hefner eschewed his trademark pajamas for a suit and tie, and clutched the lucite podium a tad shakily as he accepted the award from his daughter, Christie Hefner. He brought the house down when he said, "It takes something special . . . to get me out of my pajamas."
Ms. Steinem, clad in black pants and a black scoop-neck shirt, accepted her award from the economist John Kenneth Galbraith, who praised her beauty and intelligence. The audience of magazine editors obediently ate their poached chicken and drank their white wine. The proceedings were terribly civil.
Things didn't turn frosty until Ms. Steinem and Mr. Hefner retired to a hotel suite for an interview. There they proved two things: that decades-ago date would have been a disaster. And it takes an awful lot to get a tough-as-nails Playboy press agent to cry.
Ms. Steinem, 63, insisted that except for the coincidence of their awards, she would never have found herself in the same room as Mr. Hefner. "I would not -- no, I would never under normal circumstances even think of Mr. Hefner," she said. "And I doubt that he would think of me at all."
She looked at him defiantly.
"That's not true," Mr. Hefner said, hunched stiffly in his chair, his eyes cast toward the beige plush carpet. "I would think of you. Sure I would."
In Ms. Steinem's presence, Mr. Hefner, 72, seemed crumpled, almost deflated. It was unclear whether he was responding that way out of a misguided, gentlemanly deference to her as a woman or whether he was genuinely terrified of her.
Their history is laced with ironies. In the early 1960's, Mr. Hefner said, Ms. Steinem wrote to him to suggest they meet socially. A rendezvous never took place despite what Mr. Hefner called "a flurry" of telephone calls and letters. Ms. Steinem denies ever trying to set something up. Mr. Hefner's office later faxed the interviewer a letter from Ms. Steinem dated July 7, 1962, in which she said she hoped to meet him. Ms. Steinem said later by telephone, "It was not to set up a date, I assure you."
The following year, Show magazine published an instantly famous expose by Ms. Steinem, then 28, about going undercover as Bunny Marie (she began as a Playboy door bunny, moved on to hatcheck bunny and graduated to table bunny). The article was included in Ms. Steinem's best-selling 1983 book of essays, "Outrageous Acts and Everyday Rebellions," and it was made into "A Bunny's Tale," a television movie starring Kirstie Alley. In an interview of Mr. Hefner for McCall's in the mid-60's, Ms. Steinem described him as "a skinny, apologetic white man" and called the Playboy philosophy "boyish, undeveloped, anti-sensual, vicarious and sad."
Mr. Hefner never concealed his distate for Ms. Steinem or her activism. In the McCall's interview -- the last time they met until last week -- he said of the women's movement, "Women shouldn't be wasting their time on this foolishness."
But 1998 finds them, if not exactly mellowed toward each other, at least close on some issues. For example, there is Viagra, the male potency drug. "The implications of Viagra go far beyond just male sexual impotence," Mr. Hefner said, fumbling with his Playboy cuff links. "It will go on to much more serious stuff. There is some evidence that it may have positive physical effects for women as well."
Had he tried it?
"Sure," he said. "And the Monday afterward I went out and bought a chunk of Pfizer stock."
Ms. Steinem said she was disgusted that some news reports said "it was impossible for women to even tell if it worked," and that it looks as if insurance companies may cover the cost of Viagra for some male patients, but exclude women. "It's already scandalous that insurance companies don't cover birth control, contraception and even abortion," she said, the color rising in her cheeks. "Now this. It seems like Viagra in about two minutes has become more likely to be covered by health insurance than birth control, contraception and abortion combined."
Then there is Paula Jones, another topic that has made Ms. Steinem and Mr. Hefner into strange bedfellows (only metaphorically, to be sure). Ms. Steinem angered feminists by refusing to support Ms. Jones's allegation of sexual harassment against the President. Mr. Hefner wrote essays critical of Ms. Jones.
"I have always supported her access to the legal system," Ms. Steinem said. "But her case was always borderline legally. She was never told what her real chances were. I wish with all my heart she had gone to a women's group in Arkansas at the time. Even if it wasn't a good legal case -- which it wasn't -- there are ways of making complaints that she should have been able to use."
Ms. Steinem sat utterly still, her legs crossed at the knee and her hands locked in her lap.
Mr. Hefner, who wrote in a Playboy essay that "the President's enemies are enemies of sex," added now that Mr. Clinton's detractors "have a serious conservative agenda."
In the last decade, Ms. Steinem's brand of feminism and Mr. Hefner's libertine Playboy philosophy have undergone major transformations. Ms. Steinem has weathered the onslaught of so-called bimbo feminism, exemplified by women strippers who say they are empowering themselves by stripping for men and by young women who pose topless for the jackets of their books, which are purportedly about empowered, independent women. "The question is less what is done than who has the power to decide what to do and how to do it," Ms. Steinem said. "Remember, it's the right wing that is anti-sex -- not feminists."
Mr. Hefner has, for his part, watched his empire steadily erode as Playboy's circulation, which peaked at 7.16 million in 1972, fell steadily to 3.15 million. A chain of Playboy clubs closed in the 1980's, and Mr. Hefner had to endure the ignominy of selling his purple corporate jet with built-in discotheque. He married for a second time. The bride was Kimberley Conrad, the 1989 playmate of the year. They have two sons, 6 and 8, but are now separated.
Recently, there have been signs of a small Playboy revival. The Playboy manner -- with its winking, now-ironic images of martini-sipping lounge lizards and coquettish women -- is in style with a retro-loving subculture. Esquire is working on a profile of Mr. Hefner. The Friars Club will roast him as its man of the year in the fall. Playboy Enterprises is underwriting an exhibition of stag films at the Whitney Museum of American Art, to open in December. Next year, the magazine will celebrate its 45th anniversary, and the best part of it all, Mr. Hefner said, is that "the year 2000 is the Chinese year of the rabbit."
Ms. Steinem and Mr. Hefner agreed that reaching old age no longer means what it did to their parents' generation. "Sixty and 70 doesn't mean much anymore, as long as you retain your health," Mr. Hefner said.
Ms. Steinem agreed. "There is a great unexplored land after 60," she said. "It may be best indicated by who you were when you were 9 or 10 and a little girl. Climbing trees and saying: 'I know who I am. I know what I want.' That's before the feminine role has come down upon you. Then at the other end, when the feminine role has run out, you become this independent creature again, only now you have your own apartment, and you can reach all the light switches. It's also a time when you are no longer obsessed with sex, so that really helps."
Mr. Hefner's eyebrows shot up.
Ms. Steinem argued that postmenopausal women are free from the storms of sex and romantic love, and so are happier. She said: "When I meet women who are over 55 who have just fallen in love and are miserable, I always ask, 'Are you on hormone replacement therapy?' "
How many centerfolds were feminists, Mr. Hefner? "I wouldn't know," he said. "I have no idea."
"Of course not," she said.
Mr. Hefner shook his head woefully. A photographer asked them to pose together, holding their etched-glass awards from the editors.
"Do we have to do that?" Mr. Hefner asked. "Haven't we done enough?" He turned to Ms. Steinem and asked, "Are you comfortable with that?"
"No, I don't think so," she said. She accused the magazine editors' board of arranging the joint awards to her and Mr. Hefner as a publicity stunt. "We've done enough," she said. "We can't pose with our awards. It's not the awards that are the problems. It's us doing it together. I am not going to pose with him."
Mr. Hefner, clearly uncomfortable with her rising anger, paused to wipe a hand across his brow. His publicity agent, Cindy Rakowitz, walked over to guide him out of the room.
"This was obviously an error in judgment," a furious Ms. Steinem said of her decision to accept the award. Her eyes followed Mr. Hefner as he shuffled away. "It's just so outrageous."
Mr. Hefner returned to his hotel suite to change his shirt. Outside, Ms. Rakowitz dabbed at her mascara, tears falling.
"She was so mean to him," Ms. Rakowitz said, the spangles on her navy suit sparkling in the dim hallway light. "She doesn't understand, he's such a nice guy. He is so nice to the women who work for him."

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1247 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen New Beetle;
After Beetlemania Fades, Will the Beat Go On?

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
ENOUGH, already. Yes, the Volkswagen New Beetle is cute. It is adorable. It is unique. It is cool. It gets attention -- so far, at least -- everywhere it goes.
But now that the novelty has begun to wear off, the first-look articles have all been written and Viagra has supplanted Volkswagen as the hot product of the moment, it is time to look at the New Beetle not as a social phenomenon, but as just a car. 
 And as extraordinary as it looks, the 1998 New Beetle is a fairly ordinary, though perfectly capable, car to drive. And it is a real car despite its toy-like looks. The smooth, arcing lines could have been drawn by Fisher-Price, and they suggest that this is a car to play in. Indeed, people smile and giggle when they see it, though that will end as the cartoonish shape becomes more familiar.
The premiere has been spectacular and the crowds are S.R.O., but critics and consumers are wondering if VW's show has legs. Even the company refers to the reincarnated Beetle as an experiment.
Underneath the familiar but updated silhouette, the car rides on a thoroughly modern platform that it shares with the VW Golf, a modest success in America but one of the best-selling cars in Europe.
Mechanically, the New Beetle is the opposite of the original, which was designed by Ferdinand Porsche in the 1930's and was sold in the United States from 1949 to 1979. The original had an air-cooled engine (a horizontally opposed four-cylinder) in the rear, it was driven by the rear wheels and it had drum brakes. The new car has a liquid-cooled engine (also four cylinders, but in a straight line) up front, driving the front wheels, and it has disk brakes.
During my test drive I encountered a University of Michigan graduate student who passionately insisted that because of these differences, the 1999 version was an impostor. But buyers should be thankful for the changes, which make the car safer, more reliable and much more pleasant to drive.
Even though the New Beetle is built in Mexico, it has a solid German feel. Its rigid structure and firm suspension give it the responsive handling of a European sedan, along with a comfortable ride.
The acceleration could be quicker, but that shortfall will be remedied as other engines become available. I had no problem keeping up with highway traffic in the test car, which had a 2-liter, 115-horsepower, four-cylinder gasoline engine with an economy rating of 23 miles a gallon in town and 29 on the highway. One other engine is available now: a 90-horsepower, four-cylinder, direct-injection turbo-diesel with a highway mileage rating of 48 m.p.g. and a driving range of nearly 700 miles.
Those wanting more zip will have to wait until year-end, when the New Beetle gets the 1.8-liter, turbo-charged four-cylinder gasoline engine from the Audi A4 1.8T. There is speculation that the new car will eventually get Volkswagen's very hot VR6 engine, but the company insists there will be no V6 in the foreseeable future. There is other speculation that future Beetles could come with all-wheel drive, a convertible top or even an alternative-fuel powertrain.
A five-speed manual transmission is standard; a four-speed automatic is optional. Having driven both, I'd opt for the better-performing manual, which also seems more appropriate in light of Beetle history.
The New Beetle is larger than the original Bug, though its length of 161 inches is about the same. But it is more than 7 inches wider, and its cab-forward architecture, with little overhang beyond the wheels, makes it much more spacious inside.
When you slide behind the steering wheel the cabin actually feels big. In the original Bug, you were face to face with the windshield, but in the New Beetle, nearly two feet of dashboard separate front-seat occupants from the glass. This long dash is, at first, disconcerting and will certainly be a giant dust collector. But I quickly grew accustomed to looking past it. The headroom is immense, and front legroom is generous. Even very tall drivers have plenty of room.
The rear seat is a different story, because of the perfect curve of the roofline. Headroom and legroom are adequate only for very small people, like children. (My head brushed the rear glass, and I'm only 5-foot-2.) A 6-foot-plus companion was uncomfortably bent at the neck, his knees scrunched up, when two other 6-footers took the front seats. When unoccupied, the rear seat can be folded to expand the 12 cubic feet of cargo space under the rear hatch.
The front seats, which adjust in various ways, are fairly comfortable, and are covered in an attractive velour cloth, leatherette (a no-cost option), or real leather ($700). A tilting and telescoping steering wheel is standard equipment.
The Beetle's interior design is distinctive, too, with styling cues that hint at its predecessor. The upper door sills are metal, painted in the body color; it looks as if the metal is folded like a hem from the outside. The interior has a round theme, including a simple curved dashboard with a circular speedometer. When illuminated, the gauges' red needles are set against a backdrop of indigo blue. The steering wheel, shift knob and hand brake are trimmed with a material that looks like brushed aluminum. And there is a bud vase on the dash to the right of the driver. The plastic vase is a standard feature; flowers are optional.
In contrast to the Spartan original, the New Beetle is well-appointed. Standard features include a pollen and odor filter, a six-speaker stereo, an anti-theft alarm system, halogen projector-beam headlights, four-wheel disk brakes and a central locking system with remote entry. Options include a CD player, anti-lock brakes, alloy wheels, cruise control, integrated fog lamps, heated front seats and power windows.
The materials and workmanship were outstanding on the test car. On the trunk, a chrome VW logo swivels to reveal a lock and an integrated hatch handle. Inside, the door grab handles had a soft, silky feel, in contrast to the hard plastics in many $15,000 cars.
Volkswagen's quality control slipped for a few years, particularly for Golfs made in Mexico, but Consumer Reports has given it higher marks for reliability of late.
I had one quality problem with my first test car, an early-production model. The doors froze shut and could not be opened, apparently because of a bad seal. Some colleagues reported similar problems with their test cars.
In terms of safety, the New Beetle has pretensioning front safety belts, front and rear headrests, daytime running lights, dual air bags and side air bags inside the front seats. And the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety reported last week that it did well in low-speed bumper tests, suffering only $134 in damage after four tests. (Compare that with the Hyundai Elantra, which suffered $3,042 in damage, according to the insurance industry group.) The institute is expected to announce tomorrow that the VW excelled in front-end crash tests.
The New Beetle starts at $15,700, including delivery; the diesel version is $16,975. A two-year warranty includes scheduled maintenance at no charge. Still, the VW is not cheap compared with small cars like the Dodge Neon and Honda Civic. Indeed, there are better bargains in price and performance, but the New Beetle makes a truly distinctive fashion statement.
And the look is what this car is all about.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Flower power? Yes. Staying power? Maybe not.

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
Calling the Tune, Raising the Money, Fixing the Plumbing

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN David Rivel assumed leadership of the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music in 1995, the Park Slope institution was withering on the vine. It had had six executive directors in the previous three years. Its enrollment was stagnating. And its fund-raising efforts were yielding just $59,000 a year toward a budget of $1 million.
The 114-year-old brownstone that it calls home was crumbling, too. Mr. Rivel would arrive in the morning and sweep bits of building off the front steps. Water was leaking into classrooms and creating pools in the basement. On one occasion, a piece of ceiling landed on his desk. 
 But today, the conservatory, one of the city's 18 community schools of the arts, is shrouded in scaffolding. It is in the first stage of a project to restore the building, increase access for the disabled and make the place more music-friendly, in part by expanding its teaching space by 30 percent.
The school is progressing on other fronts, too. It is raising more than $250,000 a year, and it has amassed $1.7 million so far in a $2.5 million capital campaign. Enrollment has never been higher; there are now 1,400 students, including 500 at another school, in Flushing, Queens, that was established in 1955. The conservatory has also built up its jazz program, which is the largest in any of the country's 400 community arts schools.
Much of the credit is given to Mr. Rivel, a wiry, energetic 36-year-old who left the apex of culture -- a vice presidency at Lincoln Center -- for the grass roots. "If David hadn't come along, the conservatory probably would have gone out of business," said Emilie Roy Corey, a social worker who began taking lessons at the conservatory in 1992 and now serves as its chairwoman.
When a headhunter approached Mr. Rivel about the job, he had never heard of the conservatory, even though he lives just 12 blocks away.
After eight years at Lincoln Center, however, Mr. Rivel had begun to see audiences fall off, the consequence of drastic cuts in music education in the public schools over the last generation. Wanting to address the problem, he took the conservatory job.
The conservatory was founded in 1897 by Edward Adolf Whitelaw, who headed it until he died in 1944. Under his leadership, it was a place for elites, modeled on European conservatories, for which students had to audition. After World War II, the G.I. Bill sent a flood of veterans and their families through its doors, permanently altering the institution. It became a community school of the arts, which provide quality arts education to all, regardless of ability or resources.
"We're trying to be a force for music," Mr. Rivel said. "It's not all about turning out great musicians. It's about turning out great citizens."
At the conservatory, that process starts early: preschoolers as young as 18 months are eligible for its Songs, Sounds, Leaps and Bounds program. On a recent Wednesday afternoon, 4- and 5-year-olds in the group were banging on drums and racing around the room to music.
"My son has a lot of fun here," said Judith Conley, explaining why she brings 5-year-old Brandon. "And he comes to the dinner table singing things like, 'Isadora Duncan was a modern dancer.' "
The conservatory, where the as-yet unrestored interior has a homey if shabby feel, offers private lessons as well as group instruction and ensembles for those wanting to learn a new skill, start a career or exercise a talent untapped by 9-to-5 duty as a computer analyst or nurse.
Lessons are free or subsidized for those who cannot pay the fees; the teachers are professional musicians who often perform at the conservatory or outside it.
Besides these on-site activities, the conservatory has a Music Partners program, which takes music into 14 public schools and reaches 2,500 students a year. "Basically, we're the music departments that were gutted in the public schools," Mr. Rivel said.
To keep these many programs going and to continue the school's rebound, Mr. Rivel is relying on his job experience and fund-raising contacts from Lincoln Center. His basic premise is that a small arts organization can and should operate like a large one. He has hired a director of development and one for public relations and marketing. He has put in place an annual budgeting process, with monthly reports. He has created a personnel manual and established an endowment to maintain the building.
There are still bumps in the road ahead, of course. The renovation and its disruptions will take two years more -- if all goes well -- and the capital campaign, like all such efforts, is vulnerable to economic downturns and other dangers.
Meanwhile, the show goes on. Downstairs from the preschoolers, Zoe LaMarche, 11, is taking a saxophone lesson from Benny Russell, struggling -- and succeeding -- with Jackie McLean's "Dig." Several floors up, Cleve Guyton is giving a clarinet lesson, as trumpet sounds filter in from another room. (After renovation the rooms will be soundproof; now, they most definitely are not.)
In another studio, Hiromi Matsunaga finishes one piano lesson and begins another. Her student is Fern Gentile, a lawyer specializing in elder law, who just began taking lessons. She had always wanted to learn, she said, and then her 9-year-old son started studying at the conservatory.
"It gave me a huge desire," she said, "and we got a piano."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In describing his mission, David Rivel says: "It's not all about turning out great musicians. It's about turning out great citizens." (Photographs by Chang W. Lee/The New York Times and Linda Rosier for The New York Times (inset))

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Debating the Merit of a Social Security Cap

BYLINE: By JANE HODGES 

 BODY:
IN his early 60's, Alfred Armand set up a telecommunications consultancy in San Francisco. But in recent years, he turned down some jobs.
The reason, said Mr. Armand, now 70, wasn't so much that he wanted to cut back on business. Instead, he said, he passed up the work because taking it would have pushed his income well beyond caps imposed by the Social Security Administration's "earnings test," which penalizes benefit recipients ages 62 to 69 who earn more than certain amounts. 
 "I could have used the additional money I generated, but I always tried to hold down my income," said Mr. Armand, who works part-time as a telecommunications instructor at Skyline College in San Bruno, Calif. When he first set up his consulting business, he recalled, he lost $3,000 in benefits one year and $6,000 another year.
Earnings limits have long come under fire from older Americans and their advocates. This year, though, the prospects for their elimination may improve as Congress and the Clinton Administration, operating in an economy with almost full employment, consider proposals to assure Social Security's long-term health.
"There's a sentiment growing that it's illogical," John Woyke, a principal at Towers Perrin, the management consulting firm, said of the earnings cap. "It's definitely on the table and could be one of a set of reforms."
This year, workers who began collecting Social Security benefits at age 65 can make up to $14,500 in salary and wages without having their benefits cut. Those who make more will see their benefits cut by $1 for every $3 of additional earnings.
The ceiling is lower for workers 62 to 64 who chose to take Social Security benefits early and continued to work. The maximum they can earn is $9,120; any more than that, and their benefits will be cut by $1 for every $2 of additional earnings.
According to Social Security estimates, about 329,000 Americans lost part of their benefits last year because of earnings caps.
To improve their situation, Congress in 1996 approved a new schedule of earnings caps for people 65 to 69; the limit gradually climbs to $30,000 in 2002. Moreover, there is no limit on income from investments, rents, royalties and capital gains; there is also no limit on earnings for those 70 and older.
Even so, some people have argued that the earnings test discourages sixty-somethings from working during a still-productive life stage. And as Washington prepares to deal with the future of Social Security, those arguments have gained ground.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, and Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, are proposing to eliminate the test. Mr. Moynihan's measure is part of his bill to revamp Social Security; Mr. McCain's initiative focuses specifically on the test.
Mr. Moynihan has said that in the current economy, the labor force has more room for older workers -- something that was not true when Social Security began in 1935. David Podoff, an economist who works with Senator Moynihan on the Senate Finance Committee, said: "The test is a relic of the Depression era, when we were trying to discourage people from working. Now we want to encourage them."
Senator McCain's plan would repeal the test only for those 65 and older. "This would provide economic freedom to lower-income seniors," said Nancy Ives, a spokeswoman for Mr. McCain. "By keeping seniors in the work force, it would be a net plus, because of the tax revenues this would generate."
Opponents of caps also say their benefits for the Government do not justify keeping them. Not only do they create administrative burdens, Senator McCain contends, but they have cost the nation an estimated $15 billion annually in lost productivity in recent years.
Those who want to keep the test say its elimination would impose large short-term costs on the Federal budget. Mr. Moynihan's plan would cost $10 billion a year over the next 10 years, according to Congressional Budget Office figures, though other provisions in his proposal would help offset that. Ms. Ives said the short-term costs of Mr. McCain's bill would be less than $10 billion a year.
Social Security administrators and test supporters also say that any perceived unfairness may result from a misunderstanding of how the test works.
Michael Leonesio, an economist for the Social Security Administration, noted that the test does not permanently hold cash from workers. Those penalized in their 60's recover withheld earnings through adjustments to their checks after they reach 70.
The test is "actuarily fair" for those 62 to 64, Mr. Leonesio said, and will become so for those 65 to 69 within 10 years. That means it will not affect the total benefits collected over a lifetime.
"With actuarial fairness, there's no reason to get rid of it at all," said Henry Aaron, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.
He added that eliminating the test might only benefit higher-wage earners. "I can think of few lower-priority uses of funding than letting lawyers, doctors and professionals keep a cash advance," he said.

HEADLINE: VIEWPOINT;
Deflation Isn't a Worry, Either

BYLINE: By NORBERT WALTER; Norbert Walter is chief economist for Deutsche Bank Research in Frankfurt.

 BODY:
MORE than a year ago, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, warned about the danger of an "irrational exuberance" on Wall Street, prompting me to write an article for this space titled "Deflating an Inflation Worry."
Recently, though, the Asian financial crisis and an economic downturn in Japan have raised fears of a vicious downward spiral in the global economy. So this may be the right time to deflate a deflation worry. 
 There is no question that the Asian crisis has radically altered the global economic climate. While Asian currencies and stock markets have recovered somewhat, the situation remains precarious, despite financial rescue missions by the International Monetary Fund. Excessive short-term borrowing by Asian companies -- a key contributing factor in the crisis -- has forced banks and other private lenders in the United States, Europe and Japan to roll over billions of dollars to Asian borrowers.
Many analysts fear that the plunge in asset prices in Asia, combined with the harsh economic therapy required by the I.M.F. for its aid, will lead to deep recessions and soaring unemployment in Asia. As Mr. Greenspan has noted, such doom could spill over into the United States, Europe and the rest of the industrialized world.
Prices of oil and other raw materials have been pushed sharply lower worldwide by expectations of slower economic growth. Currency devaluations have made Asian suppliers much more competitive, and pessimists worry that the crisis will cause an old-fashioned price war and a decline in global investment activity. It is also widely argued that the creation of a single European currency, with its rigid fiscal rules, is adding ice to the baby's bath water.
It all sounds so convincing -- and alarming -- until one looks at the facts. Many economists and analysts who are sounding the global deflation alarm are the same ones who were convinced just a few months ago that the American economy was growing too strongly.
But they were wrong then, and they are wrong now. The United States economy is in quite good shape. Production is booming, domestic demand clearly is continuing to rise and credit is readily available. Despite last week's nervousness about interest rates, long-term rates have been trending down. The real costs of financing -- the prevailing rates of interest minus inflation -- are not low, but they are not dangerously high, either. In fact, they compare quite favorably with financing costs in Europe and many countries in the developing world.
Inflation in the United States, meanwhile, remains well-behaved. Barring further economic shocks in Asia that might push the dollar higher, or drive oil and other commodity prices lower, the inflation rate is likely to trend higher, but not to levels of serious concern.
Given that the Asian crisis is likely to prompt the world's central banks to hold interest rates relatively low -- at least in the short term -- there seems little risk of a dangerous contraction in the global supply of money and credit. Accordingly, the notion that the world is poised at some sort of deflationary abyss seems far-fetched.
If the continuing problems in the Japanese financial system can be contained and if the Chinese Government can resist pressure to devalue its currency against the dollar, a gradual re-acceleration of inflation, not deflation, is likely in 1999 and thereafter. For that reason, the Fed and the world's other major central banks are unlikely to maintain their benign stance for more than the next few quarters. Indeed, 1999 may be the year when the Fed and the newly created European Central Bank will have to start nudging short-term interest rates higher to keep inflation at bay into the next decade.
This should not pose a serious deflationary threat to the world economy, particularly if battered Asian economies have by then restored their credibility in the global financial markets. This will require a radical program of social, political and economic reforms, including greater corporate transparency. Asian countries will also have to attract more direct foreign investment in factories and other productive assets rather than simply repeating the potentially destabilizing inflows of "hot money" portfolio capital, in which investors try to chase the latest fad in emerging markets.
THESE changes will require a Herculean effort by the countries involved. But even more is needed to restore stability to the region: Archimedean support for good governance must come from friends in the leading industrialized countries and major international financial institutions.
These reforms -- not some panicky response to an imaginary deflationary crisis -- will be the key to safeguarding global prosperity in the next century.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 3; Page 12; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1761 words

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Keeping Up With the Gateses?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
HER car is a second-hand 1989 Acura, a bit of resistance on the part of Juliet B. Schor to the "competitive consumption" that she describes so vividly in her new book, "The Overspent American." The television set is in the coldest, least inviting room of her house -- another bit of resistance. But the well-dressed Ms. Schor gives ground on clothing, participating despite herself in the new consumerism that has been reshaping behavior since the 1980's.
Ms. Schor, an economist at Harvard University, argues that the vast majority of Americans aspire in their spending to the life styles of the wealthiest 20 percent. They go into debt trying to acquire the trappings of that world, or the portrayal of it offered incessantly on TV. For tens of millions of Americans, consumption has become the route to a sense of well-being and identity. But that route always seems to require more purchases, which in turn become new status markers in an endless "ratcheting up." 
 "The comparisons we make are no longer restricted to those in our general earnings category, or even to those one rung above us on the ladder," Ms. Schor writes. "Today, a person is more likely to be making comparisons with, or choose as a reference group, people whose incomes are three, four or five times his or her own. The result is that millions of us have become participants in a national culture of upscale spending."
In an age of income inequality, that is not easy. The incomes of the top 20 percent, which start at $75,000 a year and reside mostly above $90,000, have been growing faster than the incomes of everyone else, so keeping up means going deeper into debt. That, in fact, has been happening, particularly among households in the $25,000-to-$75,000 income range, the group that is trying hardest, in Ms. Schor's view, to rise in status. Simply having all the basics -- being comfortable -- now fails to be sufficient.
"While politicians continue to tout the middle class as the heart and soul of American society," she writes, "for far too many of us, being solidly middle class is no longer good enough."
Only determined "downshifters" -- and they are growing in number, Ms. Schor reports -- manage to immunize themselves, by altering their lives, working less and spending less. Ms. Schor is with them in spirit, if not always in practice. The black nylon shoulder bag that she tosses on the floor behind her as she settles into the driver's seat of her car is smart-looking and bears a designer label. Her black, knitted European suit is similarly upscale; not high couture -- she got it on sale for $200, marked down from $1,200 -- but certainly stylish.
TWO findings stood out in a lecture about the book that Ms. Schor gave last week to 50 students at Brandeis University, 20 minutes by used car from her Harvard office. Television is a big driver of consumer aspirations, she said -- not just the commercials, but the stylish clothing worn by actors and the affluent settings of so many shows, particularly soap operas. Tabulating a survey of employees at a big, unnamed telecommunications company, Ms. Schor found that for every hour of television watched weekly, spending rose by $208 a year. This group watched enough TV to cost each person more than $2,200 a year.
"People from really opulent families use TV as a reality check," Ms. Schor said. "But for the vast majority of Americans, TV upscales their perceptions."
And their aspirations. Another poll asked where people wanted to end up. Eighty-five percent said they wanted to be rich or upper middle class; only 15 percent sought to "live a comfortable life" -- a code phrase for middle class. The Brandeis students, in a show of hands, fit this pattern. Only one saw herself as becoming middle class, and she raised her hand meekly.
Ms. Schor -- 42, director of studies at Harvard's Women's Studies program, married to another economist, raising two children in a recently purchased three-bedroom suburban home -- wrote a best-seller in 1991 entitled "The Overworked American." Instead of working fewer hours and having more leisure, which had been everyone's expectation, Americans were actually spending more time at work, she reported. It was a finding that struck a public chord and that Government data later confirmed. Among the reasons she gave for the trend: People needed the extra income to pay for their consumption.
And now, in the midst of a stock market boom and an outburst of consumption, "The Overspent American" (Basic Books) tries to explain what makes people such driven consumers. Ms. Schor, in effect, has written a modern-day version of "The Theory of the Leisure Class," in which Thorstein Veblen chronicled the "conspicuous consumption" of America's wealthy at the turn of the century, noting their spending on luxury goods (gold-handled walking sticks, for example) to call attention to their wealth and thus gain social esteem.
A HALF century later, after World War II, James Duesenberry, another Harvard economist, updated Veblen. Neighborhood life flourished then. Incomes were much more evenly distributed than in Veblen's day -- or now -- and Mr. Duesenberry popularized the phrase "keeping up with the Joneses" in his classic description of neighbors matching neighbors in the purchase of dishwashers, televisions, second cars and the like.
Another 50 years have passed and people today hardly know their neighbors. Civic activity, a potential substitute for spending, has declined. Income inequality has dissipated the egalitarian ethos. Religious and social taboos against excessive consumption have deteriorated. And the new view of life, Ms. Schor argues, is not through the kitchen window, but through the television screen or in catalogues and advertisements that endlessly promote luxury products, or in office settings where lower-level workers are often in contact with wealthier colleagues who lead fancier lives.
Ms. Schor's book describes this new milieu. The story she tells may be the most eye-catching so far, but she is not alone. Robert Frank, a Cornell University labor economist who recently co-wrote a book entitled "The Winner-Take-All Society" (Free Press), is completing a new book, "Luxury Fever," in which he shares several of Ms. Schor's views, though not her finding that most Americans are trying to mimic the lives of the upper 20 percent on the income ladder.
In Mr. Frank's analysis, the goal may be the top rung, but the mimicking is mainly a process of trying to keep up with those only a little higher in income. And since income inequality has created many rungs, starting at the top with Mr. Frank's big winners, it is a busy process. "If you read about someone high on the ladder buying a $50,000 wristwatch, then you don't feel like such a spendthrift if you buy a $1,000 watch," Mr. Frank said. "That is what is happening."
Both Mr. Frank and Ms. Schor would curb the spending through a consumption tax that bit hardest at the biggest spenders. A goal would be to push more spending into investment, public and private. But the solutions, particularly in Ms. Schor's case, are less interesting than the sociology and the economics.
Criticism of Ms. Schor's book is already coming from some traditional economists. The mainstream view is that consumers act rationally, buying what they need or value and can afford -- if not right away, then with earnings that they expect to receive later in life. Ms. Schor accepts this thesis, but she argues -- as did Veblen -- that such theorizing fails to recognize that spending takes place in a social framework.
"People have choice; they can opt out of the game," she said. "What I am saying is that opting out is a socially costly thing to do. It is very difficult."
A $30,000 outlay for a Volvo or a sport utility vehicle may buy true value in the eyes of the purchaser, specifically crash protection and durability. But the payment is also made to buy status, which Ms. Schor argues is often a waste of national resources and an unnecessary invasion of savings. Her thinking helps to explain the 1989 Acura, and the decision to run her family with only one car, not two or three -- another bit of American spending in which the line between utility and social pressure is often obscure.
The red-brick colonial home that Ms. Schor and her husband, Prasannan Parthasarathi, bought in Newton is ideal for this one-car family -- within walking distance of Mr. Parthasarathi's new teaching job at Boston College, and also a short walk to the playground and the neighborhood elementary school.
The family resists, too, the home improvements so dear to Ms. Schor's new consumer. The bathrooms, never updated since the house was built in 1929, are just fine, she declares. So is the kitchen, last remodeled in the 1960's. "People say we have to change the cabinets," she said. "But we don't."
When it comes to clothing, though, sorting out value and status is not so easy.
"For most women, clothing is an area of conflict," she said. "You need an upscale wardrobe for your job. But we are also socialized in a culture that generates a lot of desire for apparel and accessories. I have that. One year, it was 1985 or 1986, I sat down and totaled up what I had spent on clothes, and I was horrified to find that I had spent $8,000 and I had only earned in the $30,000's."
THE nuances of the new consumerism are noteworthy. The college-educated, Ms. Schor found in her polling, are bigger consumers than the less educated, perhaps because college raises their aspirations. Gift-giving for weddings, birthdays, bar mitzvahs and the like requires ever-more expensive presents, sucking an age-old practice "into the larger vortex of consumerism."
Less noticeable spending -- expensive vacation travel abroad, say, or having children at Ivy League schools -- also plays a growing role in establishing status, and people find ways to advertise these invisibles, with school decals, for example, on the family car.
Contrary to mainstream economic thinking, Ms. Schor found, people pass up practical purchases that add value, like aluminum siding. Siding reduces home maintenance and improves insulation, but is often rejected as declasse. So are high-quality drugstore lipsticks, lacking only the high sticker prices of the high-fashion brands.
"In fact, with lipsticks, the higher the price, the more consumers tend to purchase them," she writes, summarizing her research. "This finding flies in the face of the received wisdom that a higher price discourages buyers."

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
An On-Line Rush Is On

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE future of the mutual fund industry is wired, and that may be good news for Internet-wise investors. Their rewards could be a greater variety of funds and lower expenses, according to the authors of a Goldman Sachs & Company report on the money management business.
The report cites a study by Forrester Research, a technology market research firm based in Boston, that predicts mutual fund assets in on-line accounts will grow from an estimated $47 billion today to $241 billion by 2002. That pace is five times the expected growth rate for overall household assets. 
 Retail investors stand to benefit from the trend. "The Internet represents growth, variety and a low-cost means of distribution which could lead to lower fund expenses," said Richard K. Strauss, an analyst at Goldman who was co-author of the report. The increasing ease with which money managers can distribute funds will insure a continued supply of new offerings, he said.
The added variety of funds can be useful to investors: Research has shown that newer, smaller funds tend to outperform older peers that have greater assets, especially in certain asset classes like small-capitalization stocks.
The growth in on-line fund investing should also drive down fund expenses, said John J. Moon, another co-author and an associate in the investment banking division of Goldman. And such a decline would be a break for fee-weary investors.
For example, American Century Investments, the fund group based in Kansas City, Mo., is considering adding a share class for sale over the Internet that charges less than its other share classes. "It's in recognition that a growing portion of our customer base is interested in doing business on the Web," said Chris Doyle, a company spokesman.
Mr. Doyle said that 10 percent of the company's two million investors had indicated they wanted to do business with it over the Internet and that about 4 percent did so already.
The Internet reduces fund companies' need for expensive toll-free telephone numbers and customer service staff and cuts postage and printing costs, he noted. "The thinking is that you could share these cost savings with the investor," he said, perhaps through a reduced management fee.
For the fund industry, Mr. Moon said, the growth of on-line fund investing will result in clear-cut losers as well as winners.
"We believe the largest mutual fund providers will be best prepared to reap the rewards, because they will have the reputation and the brand names to differentiate themselves," Mr. Moon said.
Smaller companies will benefit from the low-cost distribution provided by the Internet, helping them proliferate. "It has truly leveled the playing field," Mr. Strauss said.
But middle-tier companies will be increasingly squeezed as smaller fund companies, which generally have lower overhead, crowd onto the Internet to peddle their wares. Indeed, the report noted that midsized companies' share of mutual fund assets had already dropped from 33 percent in 1988 to 22 percent in 1997. The market share of the 10 largest companies, by contrast, has risen slightly, to 51 percent from 49 percent, and that of smaller companies has climbed to 27 percent from 18 percent. (In a universe of 706 firms, the top 10 in assets were defined as large companies, the next 20 were considered midsized and the remainder were considered small.)

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Captive REIT's: A Tax Shelter Makes a Comeback

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
IT'S hard to keep a good tax shelter down.
After nearly disappearing in the late 1980's, so-called captive REIT's are making a comeback, with half a dozen begun in the last three years. And again they are sending some eyebrows to the rafters. 
 Like an ordinary real estate investment trust, or REIT, a captive REIT provides shelter from Federal taxes and derives income from ownership of real estate assets.
What makes a captive trust different is that, at least at the outset, all its properties are obtained from, and leased right back to, a sponsoring company whose main business isn't real estate, and the trust takes no role in managing the properties.
Captive trusts first became widespread in the mid-1980's, when nursing-home companies, in particular, set them up as a way of using their sizeable real estate holdings to raise capital off the balance sheet. To some extent they took the place of a so-called stapled REIT, under which shares of a trust and its sponsor traded as a unit.
The captive trusts traded separately but remained at the mercy of their only sources of income -- their sponsors. When the sponsors ran into trouble in the last recession, the trusts suffered badly and grew scarce.
Lately, though, new trusts have been popping up in property-rich sectors like golf courses, movie multiplexes and prisons. Last week the Wackenhut Corrections Corporation, the second-largest prison operator, took its Correctional Properties Trust public; the new trust, offered at $20 a share, closed at $23.0625 on Friday.
The Wackenhut offering followed by a week the announcement by the Corrections Corporation of America, the industry leader, that it would merge itself into its captive trust, CCA Prison Realty Trust, and create a private prison-operating company that the trust will partly own. The novel deal's baffling complexity has sparked a class action lawsuit and sent the stocks of both the trust and the sponsor sliding. The trust, whose share price doubled after it was begun last summer, closed on Friday at $35.5625, off $9.0625 from its peak.
Captive REIT deals are so advantageous for sponsors that some analysts expect many more of them. "There's potential here for an awful lot of industries," said Michael Kirby, a co-founder of Green Street Advisers, a research firm in Newport Beach, Calif. Mr. Kirby added that the trusts allow companies to make money off underappreciated real estate assets.
And despite the controversy surrounding CCA Prison Realty, the new crop of trusts may prove more attractive to investors than their failed predecessors. For one thing, they appear to have somewhat better growth prospects.
"In the old days, with nursing-home companies, these REIT's generated returns that were relatively fixed," said Barry Vinocur, the editor of Realty Stock Review, a newsletter based in Shrewsbury, N.J. "But during the recent wave they've been restructured to give them some kind of growth aspect" in their income stream, like a built-in rent escalator. These trusts will never grow as quickly as their sponsors, he said, but their rich dividends can make up for slow growth.
Still, the trusts can run into stadium-sized conflicts of interest. Most share managers, boards of directors or even their chief executive with the sponsoring company, opening the door for the sponsor to veto a rent increase or a potential acquisition that might benefit the trust.
The market can penalize trusts that are too much in thrall to their sponsors. "The main difference between the REIT's that have done very well and those that haven't has been their structure," Mr. Kirby said. "The less captive, the better."
Mr. Kirby points to health care trusts from the mid-1980's, like Nationwide Health Properties, that later became independent.
"Nationwide's success has been particularly striking," he said. Under Beverly Enterprises, the nursing home operator that sponsored the trust, "it got run into the ground," he said. "But since it became independent, it's turned into one of the best-performing REIT's."
Entertainment Properties Trust has plenty of independence but hasn't done half as well. The trust owns 13 multiplex cinemas run by AMC Entertainment. It shares no top executives with AMC, has only one AMC employee on its five-member board and faces no bar to doing business with other theater chains; in fact, AMC encourages it. But the trust's stock has languished near the offering price of $20, closing on Friday at $19.6875.
David M. Brain, the trust's chief financial officer, thinks his company is being penalized because it doesn't yet do business with anyone but AMC. But the lackluster performance may have more to do with worries about a coming glut of movie theaters.
Some trusts, like National Golf Properties, take steps to establish independence but never stray far from their sponsors. All but five of National's 120 golf courses are leased to the company that spun it off in 1993, American Golf; National leased those five to other operators just "for the sake of doing it," according to James F. Wilson, an analyst at Jefferies & Company, a stockbroker in San Francisco.
"There are pluses and minuses to all this," Mr. Wilson said, crystallizing the conundrum facing many captive REIT's. "This is a company that has to ask itself: Does it want to have all independent operators to avoid conflicts, or does it want to have the best operator that will maximize revenues?"

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Are Trusts' Stocks Poised for Revival?

BYLINE: By RICK GLADSTONE 

 BODY:
SO far, 1998 has been a bust for real estate investment trusts. Indexes of REIT stocks are down for the year, while the broader market has soared. As speculation mounts that the Federal Reserve will soon raise interest rates to brake a speeding economy, are REIT's headed from bad to worse?
Quite the opposite, analysts say: REIT stocks may be on the brink of a revival. 
 The trusts produced steady double-digit returns from 1995 through 1997, reflecting the vibrant economy and widespread resurgence in property values since the days of half-vacant Houston skyscrapers and foreclosed Boston condominiums. In 1998, analysts said, fear of a speculative bubble in the property market, along with worries about overbuilding and tighter Government regulation, have held REIT stocks back.
"This has been the worst period of REIT performance in REIT history," said Martin Cohen, president of Cohen & Steers in New York, a leading manager of REIT securities. "The economic recovery is getting old, and prices for property are getting high. So sentiment is not as positive."
The relative weakness in REIT stocks, however, does not necessarily signal a downturn in the economic cycle or underlying vulnerability in the REIT industry.
On the contrary, these publicly held property companies are generally considered to have durable strengths, with low debts and steady income from rents.
"The REIT stocks tend to be defensive-type stocks," said David Lerner, chief executive of David Lerner Associates, a Syosset, N.Y., dealer in municipal bonds and other conservative investments. "We've been going through a very strong bull market, and the REIT stocks have not been in favor. But that's not because there's anything wrong with them."
REIT's have become the dominant force in real estate, amassing a broad array of reliable income producers, from shopping malls to theaters to hotels, and they show few signs of slowing down. The aggressive REIT of the real estate billionaire Sam Zell, Equity Office Partners, was the buyer in 5 of the 10 largest commercial property transactions last year. Starwood Hotels and Resorts has become the world's biggest hotel company. Vornado Realty Trust has invested $3 billion in the last year in everything from offices to cold storage vaults.
So some analysts expect a rebound in the second half, with gains in the 10 to 12 percent range, and say REIT stocks could even benefit from a rise in interest rates, which would tend to hurt other stocks.
"Interest rates tend to go up when the economy is strong," said Ritson Ferguson, president of CRA Real Estate Securities in Radnor, Pa. "If I'm a real estate owner, that's the kind of environment where I get to raise rents and make more money."
