HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Spiders and Diamonds and Dogs, Oh My!

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
WANTING a piece of the action on Wall Street but lacking the expertise to go it alone, millions of Americans began investing in mutual funds during the last decade. Then, as most equity funds failed to keep up with the bull market, investors embraced index funds as inexpensive shortcuts to owning the most-sought-after stocks.
Now, legions of individual investors have apparently decided that they are ready to go one-up on Wall Street after all. 
 They are pouring billions of dollars into unit investment trusts -- products that let them time the market by actively trading in and out of broad indexes like the Dow Jones industrial average or the Standard & Poor's 500. Almost overnight, unit investment trusts with catchy names like Diamonds and Spiders and Webs have become Wall Street's hottest products.
A sort of hybrid between a mutual fund and a stock, a unit investment trust holds a fixed portfolio of bonds or stocks for a defined time. The most popular trusts trade like stocks on the American Stock Exchange, where they are single-handedly responsible for an increase of about 25 percent in daily trading volume in the last three years.
Investors like unit trusts because they are easy to understand; stock brokers like them because they are even easier to sell -- and because of the fat commissions many offer, compared with similar mutual funds.
Sell they have. Americans funneled $38 billion into unit trusts last year, nearly two-thirds more than in 1996 and three and a half times the 1995 total, according to the Investment Company Institute, a trade group. In the first two months of 1998, the trend continued, with an additional $11 billion flowing in, up 14 percent from the corresponding period last year.
Unit trusts are by no means new; they have been around at least as long as mutual funds and are regulated under the same Federal laws. And like their fund cousins, they have been transformed by Wall Street's marketing gurus from a sleepy backwater of slow-and-steady bond investing into a fast-paced forum for speculating in stocks.
Whether most investors should buy in, however, is a complex issue. Much of the fervor, trumpeted in electronic chat rooms dedicated to market topics, seems to come from those who have mistaken an uninterrupted bull market for their own investment brilliance.
Many investment professionals agree that unit trusts make a world of sense for some people -- among them, those who want to invest for a fixed time and who do not feel comfortable picking stocks themselves. The low annual expenses of some trusts -- in some cases, less than a quarter of the cost of the average mutual fund -- earn them grudging respect even from executives at the Vanguard Group, the king of low-cost index funds. But for other investors, including those who focus primarily on long-term investment goals, there are cheaper, more effective alternatives.
Moreover, many unanswered questions remain about unit investment trusts, including how the most popular ones will perform in a market downturn. While that issue looms for all types of funds, it is aggravated for Diamonds, Spiders and the like by the volatility of their trading patterns. In addition, there is far less oversight of unit trusts than of mutual funds.
A minimum of checks and balances may have made sense not so long ago. Historically, the structure of unit investment trusts -- they generally are prohibited, for example, from replacing a security in the portfolio -- made the products most popular as a way to invest in bonds. And municipal bonds, most often bought and held until maturity, proved particularly appropriate.
Indeed, trusts investing in tax-free bonds still held about 40 percent of the estimated $97 billion in assets in unit investment trusts at the end of 1997. But that share had fallen by more than half, from 87 percent of trust assets, since the end of 1990.
The percentage of assets in equity trusts has soared, meanwhile, to roughly half the total. More than 97 percent of the new money that flowed into unit trusts in the first two months of this year went into equity portfolios, as did 93 percent of last year's flows, according to the Investment Company Institute.
 
On the Amex, a Breed Apart
 As with mutual funds, much of that money is headed into trusts that track popular stock market indexes. Strategic Insight, a New York investment management research firm, estimates that individual investors poured about as much new money into index-tracking unit trusts last year as they invested in index mutual funds -- roughly $30 billion.
The Strategic Insight figures include money that flowed into trusts that invest in only a portion of an index, like the popular portfolios that buy the highest-yielding stocks in the Dow industrials -- a group often referred to as the "Dogs of the Dow."
But the biggest portion of the index-trust money has gone into a handful of unit trusts that trade on the American exchange and have names that seem drawn from "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland."
There are Diamonds, which track the Dow industrials; Spiders, which track the S.& P. 500 (phonetically, their name is an acronym for Standard & Poor's Depositary Receipts, or S.P.D.R.'s); Midcap Spiders, which track the S.& P. Midcap 400 index, and Webs, which track Morgan Stanley's world equity benchmark indexes. Combined, the four products account for about one out of every six shares traded each day on the Amex.
These Amex unit trusts are a breed apart from the traditional unit trust. Most trusts are set up by brokerage firms, which pick a portfolio of stocks reflecting a specific objective or theme and then sell shares to interested investors on the understanding that their money will be put to work beginning on a certain date. On that date, the sponsor buys a set amount of each of the stocks, which it holds for a defined period, usually one year but sometimes longer.
Investors in traditional trusts usually pay a sales fee, or load, of 3 to 6 percent for their initial purchase. Beyond that, annual expenses are usually quite low -- usually less than one-third of 1 percent of the trust's assets -- because the sponsor has little to do. Stocks are replaced only for big events, like an acquisition or bankruptcy. Investors can cash out any time for the net asset value of their shares, and new investors can usually buy only shares that have been redeemed.
The Amex-sponsored trusts, by contrast, were created for the purpose of trading. As with mutual funds, an infinite number of shares can be created and sold, and securities in their portfolios can be replaced when a company is deleted or added to the underlying index.
The Amex-traded trusts also let investors do many things that investors in index mutual funds cannot, like shorting the index, just as one would sell a stock short, or buying on margin. And the trusts can be traded at any time during the market day, at the going price; mutual funds, by contrast, are offered and redeemed just once a day, at the fund's closing net asset value.
These attributes have proved popular not only with individuals, but also with all types of institutional investors, like mutual fund managers, corporate treasurers and even foreign governments, many of which use the Spiders and other trusts to manage cash reserves while staying invested in the market. They are especially useful tools for institutions, like pension funds, that are not allowed to use futures to achieve the same ends. In March, for example, the Government of Singapore disclosed that it owned 3.5 million Spider units, worth $393 million and representing 8.3 percent of the total units outstanding at the time.
Keeping spare cash invested in the market, so as not to miss out on any of its seemingly continual rise, was the very reason that the Motley Fool, an on-line investment forum geared to individual investors, began early this year to invest a portion of its primary portfolio in Spiders.
"We don't try to make market calls," wrote the Motley Fool investment analysts in explaining the decision. But if they cannot find enough stocks that they think will beat the market, "for the time being we want to be in the market as a whole through the S.& P."
And while no one knows how stocks will perform, the analysts wrote, "the way to conquer that disadvantage is to always own them."
 
A Speculation Tool
That logic made sense to Derek Banducci, 21, a junior studying economics and philosophy at Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., who monitors the Motley Fool Web site for help in investing the money he has saved for college.
"My basic assumption is that the market as a whole is going to be going up," Mr. Banducci said. Therefore, he has bought Spiders for both his "conservative" portfolio -- the money given to him by relatives to pay for college -- and, using borrowed money, or margin, for his "aggressive" portfolio, which includes money saved from his summer jobs.
"It's turned out pretty well for me," Mr. Banducci said. "The only risk is that over the long run, I know stocks have averaged a 10 percent return, and I'm paying margin interest of 9 percent. But looking over the past five years, the S.& P. is up significantly more. So I should be able to easily beat what I'm paying for the margin loan."
Market speculators like Mr. Banducci are aggressively trading in and out of Spiders and their kind. Last year, trading volume in Spiders totaled 14 times the number of shares outstanding. By comparison, of the 10 most actively traded stocks on the American exchange last year, only one traded more than four times its available shares.
Vanguard and other mutual fund companies whose index funds might have appealed to such investors just a year or two ago say they are happy to see market speculators investing in the trusts.
Frequent trading forces an index fund to buy and sell more shares of the indexed stocks. That, in turn, raises the fund's expenses, which causes it to lag behind the benchmark. So Vanguard, among others, takes steps to discourage such trading, like requiring written notice of an exchange in or out of its index funds and not allowing investors to make more than two round trips in and out of an index fund each year.
Of course, the flexibility of unit trusts has a cost. While the Amex trusts have very low continuing expenses, investors must pay a brokerage commission to buy or sell them, as they would with a stock -- commissions that can build up quickly if an account is actively traded.
Nor are the prices of the trusts as predictable as investors might expect. Though each Spider, for instance, represents one-tenth the value of the S.& P. 500, it does not automatically trade at that price. Instead, the Spiders sell for what another investor is willing to pay, which often is less than their theoretical value -- particularly when many investors are trying to sell.
Consider last Oct. 27, when stock prices fell more than 7 percent, their worst slump since 1987. The S.& P. 500 closed at 876.98, slightly above its lowest value for the day, 876.73. One might assume that Spiders would have fallen as low as $87.67 that day and closed at $87.70. In fact, they fell nearly a dollar lower, to $86.84, and closed at $87.19, about 50 cents below the index equivalent.
The next day, the stock market declined sharply at the opening bell before making a remarkable reversal and soaring upward. And the discrepancies between the value of the Spiders and the S.& P. 500 were even greater than they were the day before. Spiders traded as low as $84.38, or $1.15 below the lowest equivalent value of the index, and bounced as high as $92.88, or 57 cents above the index's peak.
The differences stem from the fact that Spiders trade through a specialist on the exchange, whose job is to match buy and sell orders and to step in, trading for his own account, to keep the market orderly. But he is not obliged to guarantee that a trust tracks its index on a wild day.
"The specialist's job in those situations is to look at a market that is moving rapidly and determine where it is going," said Michael T. Bickford, a senior vice president for derivatives marketing and research at the Amex. "Sometimes the last sale is not indicative of where those indexes are headed. On those days, and any day like them, you're absolutely going to see larger-than-normal differences from the index."
Mr. Bickford added that the exchange had had no complaints about the trading of Spiders shares last October. "It was as stern a test as we have had since the events of 1987, and I think the specialists distinguished themselves," he said. Officials of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, the specialist responsible for the trading of Spiders and Diamonds, declined to comment.
 
A Recipe for Trouble?
George U. Sauter, who oversees stock-index funds for Vanguard, is among those who say such pricing discrepancies in times of high volatility could one day cause problems for individual investors in unit trusts.
"I think that in a market break, if the pressure gets pretty severe, the specialist could get mowed down," Mr. Sauter said. "I think you will see the shares going to a big discount because the specialist won't be able to keep up."
Not so, pledge officials of the American exchange. Institutional investors will step in quickly to buy large volumes of the underpriced asset -- either the unit trust or the individual stocks in the index it tracks -- and sell short the overpriced asset, said Joseph B. Stefanelli, the exchange's executive vice president for derivative securities. The opportunity to lock in the resulting profits will cause the two values to return to equilibrium, he said, and so the Amex expects that Spiders and Diamonds "will never sell at a big discount or premium."
If the exchange is wrong, the risks will likely be greater for small individual investors, who are virtually the entire market for Diamond shares. The institutions that the American exchange is counting on to restore equilibrium to the unit trusts use the S.& P. 500 as the benchmark for their portfolio performance and hence are big traders of Spiders, not Diamonds.
Witness the difference in trading volume of the two trusts. Last Monday, for example, when the stock market dropped nearly 2 percent, 14.5 million Spider shares changed hands on the Amex, compared with only 1.9 million Diamonds. Spiders trade an average of more than five million shares a day, roughly 10 times the average daily volume of Diamonds.
The liquidity picture could become even worse if individual investors abandon the market in a steep downturn. Unlike Spiders, which began trading in 1993, Diamonds began trading on Jan. 20 and have yet to experience a volatile session like those of last October.
Further confusion could arise for individuals and institutions alike if a market drop triggers the market's newly approved circuit breakers. Mr. Stefanelli said that under current plans, futures exchanges might be closed while stock markets continued to trade. That could shift waves of trading from the futures markets to the Spiders and similar securities, "which could be dangerous for our floor and our customers," Mr. Stefanelli said.
"We haven't made a definite decision about what to do in that case, but we would consider closing down the Spiders," he added.
But in general, the American Stock Exchange wants to expand the success of its Spiders and Diamonds, Mr. Stefanelli said. "We do not trade options on the trusts at this moment, but we'd like to do so, and we're investigating whether we can," he said. In addition, the exchange would like to introduce products that track more specialized indexes, like a small-cap index or one measuring the performance of a particular industry, like technology.
And why not? The Amex makes a few pennies on each transaction, and "the volume adds up," Mr. Stefanelli said, though he declined to offer details on revenues and profits.
One big question for investors is whether the Amex is keeping close enough tabs on all the parties involved in its unit trusts.
Until hearing the news from a reporter, Mr. Stefanelli acknowledged that he was unaware, for example, that the Denver broker-dealer appointed last December as the official distributor of the Spider and Diamond contracts had to correct a net capital deficiency eight days after it was awarded the business.
The firm, Alps Mutual Fund Services, also acts as the de facto underwriter of the trusts, transmitting orders from institutional investors to create Diamond and Spider units, maintaining certain records and taking responsibility for some regulatory compliance functions. Edmund J. Burke, a senior vice president at Alps, said the company was now in compliance with capital requirements, which were established by regulators to insure that securities firms could meet the demands of their customers' business.
It is unlikely that investors were endangered by the capital deficiency of Alps; its role is different than if it were the underwriter of stocks or mutual funds, when its own capital would be at risk.
More obvious risk factors lurk in the traditional unit trusts sold by brokerage firms. Primary among them is that the trusts are open to the same vagaries of stock-picking as any mutual fund -- with the important difference that they cannot replace a poorly performing security with a better one.
Investors should also be aware that, unlike the returns of exchange-traded trusts, the performance of trusts sold by brokerage firms often can be tracked only by contacting the brokerage firm itself.
And most unit trusts are watched far less closely than are mutual funds. Kathleen H. Moriarty, a partner at Carter Ledyard & Milburn, a New York law firm, noted that unlike mutual funds, unit trusts have no directors whose duty it is to protect the interest of shareholders.
There are, of course, unit trusts that make investing sense and investors who should consider buying them. An investor inclined to work with a full-service broker may find them a low-cost alternative to broker-sold mutual funds or the commissions on trading individual stocks, said Avi Nachmany, an analyst at Strategic Insight.
"I think the day that most investors want to sell 1,000 shares of this and buy 1,000 shares of something else are rapidly coming to an end," added Robert E. Holley, a senior vice president at Paine Webber and director of its unit trust department.
Trusts can have minimum investments as low as $250, one-fourth or less the minimum for many mutual funds. But an investor in a trust like Merrill Lynch's Premier American Portfolio, which invests in a group of 36 name-brand stocks, would end up paying the equivalent of a 5.35 percent load in the four years over which the trust extends.
These days, investors are likely to find little to attract them to a traditional municipal bond unit trust. With interest rates low, brokerage firms and investors have found that it takes incredible performance for the bonds in a trust to overcome the typical sales charge of several percentage points.
So for now, the old-fashioned trusts have lost out in investors' minds to trusts that can be used to try to time the market. But investors are likely to discover that timing strategies in general can be a losing game.
"Most times investors fail to do it correctly," Mr. Nachmany said, "especially in a market that goes up all the time."

GRAPHIC: Photo/Chart: "A Cozy Scene Belies A Feverish Market
Unit investment trusts: The name is a mouthful, but investors are having no trouble spitting out buy orders to their brokers. The trusts are Wall Street's hottest product, drawing $38 billion from investors last year, triple the amount of two years earlier. By investing in a fixed portfolio of securities for a defined length of time, the trusts keep costs low. But they usually carry a sales fee that can eat deeply into returns.
 
DOGS OF THE DOW
Some of the most popular unit investment trusts buy the 10 highest-yielding stocks in the Dow Jones industrial average each year, pursuing the so-called Dogs of the Dow theory. Since 1973, that strategy has out-performed the Dow index by about five percentage points a year. But it has lagged behind the index in three of the last four years -- per-haps because so many investors have started to invest in the Dogs.
 
DIAMONDS
Diamonds are shares in a unit trust that tracks the Dow Jones indus-trial average; the shares trade on the American Stock Exchange. Diamonds are highly popular with individuals, who seem to be using them as a simple tool for making broad bets on the direction of the market. Institutional investors are far more attracted to Spiders.
 
WEBS
A variety of world equity benchmark shares, or Webs for short, track the 17 foreign stock market indexes maintained by Morgan Stanley. With fewer than 100,000 shares of most of the securities changing hands each day, investors could have trouble finding buyers. But the Webs offer access to some markets for which there are few comparable investments.
 
SPIDERS
Shorthand for Standard & Poor's depositary receipts, Spiders are essentially an S.& P.-500 index fund that trades like a stock on the American Stock Exchange. But the shares do not track the index exactly. Instead, they act much like a futures contract, often hitting higher highs and lower lows during volatile trading sessions.
 
(Samarra Khaja for The New York Times)(pg. 1)
 
Charts: "Unit Trust Buyers Opt for Equities...Transforming the Trust Business" shows new deposits to unit investment trusts, by type, and assets of unit investment trusts at end of 1990 and 1997. (Sources: Investment Company Institute; estimates by The New York Times (1997 assets))
 
"Whom Do You Trust?"
Unit trusts charge low annual fees, but their sales charges can make them more expensive than no-load funds with similar objectives. The performance of unit trusts, meanwhile, can closely track or vary widely from the performance of similar mutual funds, as shown below. Returns shown are for periods over which both the trust and the similar fund have been available.
 
"Not Quite Tracking the Market"
When the market is in turmoil, Spiders and other exchange-traded unit trusts can prove more volatile than the indexes they are supposed to track. That was the case for Spiders last Oct. 27 and 28, when the market dived 7 percent and then rebounded in the most tumultuous trading since the 1987 crash.
 
Near the end of trading on Monday, the S. & P. 500 dipped to 876.73 before closing at 876.98. But the Spiders fell farther, trading for as little as $86.84 and closing at $87.19, about 50 cents below its index equivalent. (Spiders are designed to represent one-tenth the value of the index.)
 
When the market opened even weaker the next day, the S. & P. 500 tumbled to 855.27, but the Spiders fell as low as $84.38, or about $1.15 below what the index indicated.
 
And as the market recovered, the Spiders' volatility drove them as high as $92.88, or 57 cents above the index's peak of 923.09.

HEADLINE: The Last-Chance Season

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
BY the eighth inning of this season's opening game, in a muddy park in East New York, Brooklyn, Misael Quiroz's fingers were weak and numb with cold. The players on the benches were shivering in the icy drizzle, and about a dozen fans -- mostly their wives and girlfriends -- watched from the stands, hunched into parkas or blankets. A few players, trying to get warm, bounced up and down like children on Pogo sticks. But Misael, 21, did not suggest calling the game, and neither did anybody else, not even jokingly. On both teams, each player was intensely focused on the game, each as serious as if they had, after all, made it to the major leagues.
Misael pitches for the New York Yankees. Not the New York Yankees of the American League, but the New York Yankees of the Pedrin Zorilla League, a group of eight teams of Hispanic players, most, like Misael, from the Dominican Republic. Hispanic leagues have been playing in city parks for at least 50 years, said the Zorilla league's president, Vidal Maldonado. Their games often draw hundreds of spectators, the most ardent from the Dominican Republic. 
 In recent years, the island has become a factory for Major League Baseball, with academies that turn out hundreds of young, talented players who can usually be signed for much less than American-born players. The number of Dominican players in the majors has grown to 111 from 12 in 1968. A few make it to the very top, like Pedro Martinez, the Boston Red Sox pitcher with a six-year, $75 million contract, and Sammy Sosa, the Chicago Cubs outfielder with a $42.5 million, four-year deal.
But for each Dominican player who makes it to the major leagues, scores -- if not hundreds -- of others never get past the farm teams. The major league clubs do not keep track of the numbers. Nor do they offer advice or job counseling for the newly released players. They just give them a one-way ticket home. But rather than return, defeated, to the stark poverty and scant opportunities of their homeland, many exchange their tickets for one to New York. They settle in the Dominican neighborhoods, especially Washington Heights, working at menial jobs and playing ball on weekends.
"There are more and more Dominican ballplayers coming here," said Julio Pabon, the president of Latino Sports Ventures Inc., a sports marketing company in the Bronx. "It's a new frontier. Players are on their own." And often they cling to only one hope: to catch the eye of a big-league scout who will give them a last chance.
"We get them out of the minor leagues," Jose (Cano) Ramos, a postal worker who lives in the South Bronx and is the manager and coach of the Zorillan League's Yankees, said of his players, nearly all of whom are Dominican. "They are cut out, they feel isolated. They want to be with other players. They come here and see their friends. We put them back in the game. You never know."
Only three months ago, Misael was in his second season pitching for a Pittsburgh Pirates farm team in central Florida. But then came the tersely worded letter that told him his life's dream -- the one that he had worked toward so single-mindedly and that had seemed so close -- was denied. He would not be a big-league pitcher.
The exact words have blurred, but the sickening feelings remain all too vivid. "I felt cold in my stomach," he said. "I thought I was progressing well. I loved it. It was my life."
As a child, Misael had played outfield. But his pitching is what drew the attention of the Pittsburgh Pirates scout's attention and a place in the big-league team's academy in the Dominican Republic. There, he got food, a bed, coaching and a bit of instruction in English and American customs. Within two years, he was among the one out of 10 boys signed to a Pirates farm team. His signing bonus was less than $5,000, or a quarter of what most American players get.
The day before he left home, his mother, two sisters and neighbors gathered to pray for him. "They were asking God to make things go well for me," Misael said in Spanish. "There were a lot of emotions. My mother was happy and sad. I am her only son."
But things did not go well in Bradenton, Fla. English bewildered him and the strange food made him sick. The first month, he lost 20 pounds. But, he said, he still practiced for hours each day with the other rookies. "I practiced my curve," he said. "My pitching was good."
But not good enough. A Pirates coach, Pablo Cruz, said Misael's fastest pitch was clocked at 89 miles an hour. For a shot at the big leagues, he needed at least 92 miles an hour. "He's a good boy, a super boy," Mr. Cruz said. "He comes from a good family. He's got a loose arm, a strong arm. He worked as hard as anybody. But the fastball is not fast enough."
Mr. Quiroz was in Santo Domingo visiting his family when the letter arrived. "I was depressed," he said. "I did not eat. I did not go out. I could not go to the field anymore."
His reaction is common among Dominican farm-team players, who have devoted their lives to baseball, said Mr. Pabon, the Hispanic sports marketer.
"They feel totally lost and rejected," he went on. They feel their lives have been a waste. Everything they have dreamed of, struggled for, is totally lost. They feel embarrassed -- so embarrassed they won't go home."
Misael gave away his Pirates cap and glove. He fled to New York, to live with the only friend he had in the city, and got a $6.25-an-hour job washing dishes at the Silvio Claridad restaurant in the Parkchester neighborhood of the Bronx. He wanted to get as far as he could from anything that reminded him of baseball. The mere thought of it shamed him. But escape was not so easy. It seemed that everywhere he turned he ran into other players from the Dominican Republic who, like him, had not made the grade. His friend's roommate, now Misael's roommate too, introduced him to Mr. Ramos, who persuaded him to pitch for the Yankees of East New York.
"They are friends," Misael said. "There is a lot of talent on the team. My arm feels ry good. If I dedicate myself, if I get another opportunity, I think I can make it."
 
Bodgea Owner, Sponsor And Second Baseman
 In the early 1980's, corporations looking to court Hispanic customers, like Goya Foods and Bustello Coffee, sponsored 27 Hispanic baseball leagues in New York, Mr. Maldonado said. The Federation of Hispanic Leagues set the rules and scheduled playoffs. But by the late 80's, corporate donations dried up and the federation disbanded. Today, the remaining leagues are grass-roots organizations that are run independently. They return year after year to the same fields, in East New York, and Williamsburg in Brooklyn, Crotona Park in the Bronx and Central Park in Manhattan.
On the cold, drizzly opening Sunday, Domingo Bonilla is, as usual, covering second base for the Yankees. The owner of a Brooklyn bodega, he is also the team's sponsor, a dual role that helps fulfill his own long-held dream. As a child in Santo Domingo, he said, he yearned to play baseball but had to work in a grocery store to help support his family. "I lost my chance to be a pro," he said. Now he, his wife and two daughters live above the bodega in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and above them are tiny rooms -- large enough for only a bed and a chest of drawers -- that he rents to Dominicans who have been released from the minor leagues.
Mr. Bonilla says he spends about $18,000 a year to support the Yankees: $3,000 for bats and balls; $3,500 for 22 uniforms; an untotaled amount for after-game beer and dinner; $50 and $100 bills to reward the team's best players, and $2,000 to the Pedrin Zorilla league, which goes toward an end-of-season prize for the championship team: a trip to the Dominican Republic to play its baseball teams.
"I am not supposed to be spending the money," he said. "I should be spending it on my family. But I love it."
Up in the bleachers -- and despite the rain, in a suit and tie -- Alex Mendez, the sponsor of Alex Travel, the Yankees' opponents, watches intently. Although he too grew up in Santo Domingo, his boyhood dreams were not those of most Dominican boys. "I used to put a telephone on a desk, pretending I was a boss," he said. Now he prepares tax returns and owns Alex Travel, an East New York agency that books flights for Dominicans.
"I wanted to give back to the community," Mr. Mendez said, explaining why he spends $12,000 a year on the Alex Travel team. "And it is more publicity for the business." Unlike Mr. Bonilla, Mr. Mendez does not deal directly with the players. "I trust in my manager," he said. "I own the team because it feels good. I see a hat on my players and I feel proud."
 
Shortstop Carried Carpets On Opening Day
Jose Santana, the Yankee shortstop, could not take the field on the bone-chilling Sunday of his team's season opener. Instead, he went about grimly rolling, carrying and delivering rugs at ABC Carpet in Manhattan. At $6.50 an hour, it is not a bad job. And not only does he need to support himself but also to send $100 a month to his mother. But missing the game bothered him a lot. "Baseball is baseball and I love baseball," he said. "This is my profession. This is all I know how to do."
In Santo Domingo, Jose was accepted into the academy run by the Houston Astros. "Everybody told me: 'Santana, you can play baseball. Santana, you can make it.' " he said. "I got confident." He played for Astros farm teams in Orlando, Fla., then in Iowa.
"Nobody -- white or Hispanic -- ever worked as hard as Jose," said one of his farm-team coaches, Mike Rojas. "I put him into games just to reward his hard work."
But, again, it was not enough. Jose said Iowa's cold and the long absence from his mother dispirited him, He injured his right knee, which was operated on. When he tried to play again, he said, the knee still hurt. In 1994, the Astros let him go.
Many farm-team players are knocked out of the running by relatively minor injuries, said Roger Angell, the New Yorker baseball writer. The path from minor to major is a "Darwinian triangle," he said. "It eliminates the ones who can't keep up. The truth is, you really can't afford to be injured if you're a marginal player."
Jose said he decided to travel to New York "to make money," and to move to Brooklyn, where he has relatives. A friend introduced him to Mr. Bonilla, who offered him a bed, a job in his bodega and a spot on the Yankees. After four years, he still harbors hopes that a big-league scout will pick him out and give him another chance. "Everybody knows I can play," he said. 'Everybody says: 'What happened, Santana?' I think about it. I should try to come back, but I need connections."
During the week, delivering carpeting, he says he feels haunted by his old dreams. But on weekends, he and his teammates can one again sweat and strain and once again experience the unity and exhilaration of belonging, of playing the game.
"It's guys together, being in teams, with the rituals, habits, stories," Mr. Angell said. "La vida, the life. Old players never forget. When they talk about stuff in the past, they immediately talk in the present tense: 'I'm on first . . .' No association could be closer or tighter than baseball. Once you're in it, you're always a member."

The Pedrin Zorilla Baseball League was founded in 1956 in Brooklyn, its president, Vidal Maldonado, said. It was named for Mr. Zorilla, a third-baseman who played on teams in Puerto Rico in the 40's and 50's. Mr. Maldonado said Mr. Zorilla was talented enough for the major leagues but that he was discriminated against because he was a dark-skinned Hispanic player. Since 1957, the league's has been playing in a park at Fountain and Atlantic Avenues in East New York. Mr. Maldonado said they hoped to persuade the Department of Parks and Recreation to name the park for Mr. Zorilla. These are the league's eight teams, their managers and their day jobs:

Cepeda Blue Jays -- Luis Garrigas, unemployed, Park Slope, Brooklyn.
Cleveland Indians -- George Abreu, women's clothing factory foreman, South Bronx.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1346 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Chaos Theory;
Unlearning the Lessons of Econ 101

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
THERE it goes again. Just when economists were wisely preparing a fat and happy America to face the inevitable unpleasant fallout from last summer's Asian financial crisis, the Government reported last week that things are going better than ever. Inflation is more or less gone. Jobs keep going up and growth continues.
That's been the story of the current economic boom, one of the longest and healthiest in American history. It has confounded everybody, not least of all the folks who are supposed to know what's going to happen and when to expect it: professional economists. Economic tenets, taught half a generation ago as immutable laws, are turning out not to be true. 
 Not all of them, of course. The vast bulk of mainstream economic theory has held up fine. Trade can make everybody better off. Free markets usually work best. High tax rates undermine incentives to work. The bedevilment is in the details.
Here are five economic principles, some called laws, others merely rules of thumb, that seem to have broken down:
 
Low unemployment = High inflation
Since 1960, the famous Phillips Curve posits that there can be low inflation or low unemployment, but not at the same time -- at least for long.
But so far in the 1990's, unemployment and inflation have not only been marching in the same direction -- south -- but they are now at their lowest levels in a generation. After seven years of economic expansion, unemployment dropped below 5 percent last fall for the first time since the early 70's.
Instead of accelerating, inflation has slowed even more. In the quarter that ended in March, the Government's broadest measure of inflation rose at an annual rate of less than 1 percent, the slowest rate since 1964.
What gives? Most economists agree with the Nobel Prize-winning economist Milton Friedman, who says the economy has a "natural" rate of unemployment, below which inflation accelerates, and above which inflation decelerates. Until recently, economists thought this natural rate was about 6.0 to 6.5 percent. It could be that the natural rate, which is affected by changes in demography, education and labor market institutions, has fallen sharply, perhaps to 5 percent, some economists say.
One intriguing explanation is offered by the Princeton economist Robert Shimer, who says, "The U.S. employment rate is so much lower because the population is so much older." Teen-agers have an unemployment rate roughly five times that of adult workers, the thinking goes, and the declining number of teen-age workers is enough to pull down the overall unemployment rate to its current low level.
Robert Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University, points to possibly temporary factors -- including falling computer prices, the strong dollar, the shift to managed health care and more accurate measurements of consumer prices -- to account for the unexpectedly low inflation rate of the late 90's.
 
Shrinking deficits = Slower growth
Ever since President Herbert Hoover made the Depression worse by trying to balance the budget as the economy was failing, deficit reduction has been widely held to be a drag on economic growth.
But growth has been stronger in the 1990's despite Washington's shift toward fiscal prudence. The Federal budget deficit, nearly $200 billion in 1992 and heading higher, is now effectively zero. Meanwhile, growth in the past eight quarters has averaged 3.8 percent.
The Government's most recent economic report drove the point home even more dramatically: In the first quarter, as Federal spending fell at an annual rate of $8 billion, the economy sprinted ahead at a 4.2 percent annual rate.
Today economists are more apt to claim, as the former Clinton economic adviser and Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Alan Blinder did last year, that deficit cutting can lift the economy by encouraging lower interest rates and more capital spending. Proof of the turnaround in thinking can be found in the 1998 edition of Paul Samuelson's classic introductory economics textbook, which asserts, "a large public debt is likely to reduce long-term economic growth."
 
Rapid money growth = Higher inflation
Mr. Friedman's famous dictum that "Inflation is always and everywhere a monetary phenomenon," -- meaning that inflation is caused by the Government's decision to print too much money -- is in no danger of becoming obsolete. Nonetheless, the historical link between the nation's money supply and inflation has all but collapsed. The money supply jumped sharply in the mid-1990's, yet no acceleration of inflation followed.
In the early 80's, the German, American and Canadian central banks adopted targets for money growth. But that experiment had barely begun when new financial innovations -- everything from money market accounts to electronic money transfers -- produced gyrations that all but rendered the money supply useless as a target for controlling inflation.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made it official in 1993, announcing that he was no longer paying attention to the money supply -- even though the Fed is still required by law to publish monetary growth targets.
 
World growth = Higher oil prices
Since energy stokes the machinery that drives the global economy, it seems perfectly reasonable to expect oil prices to rise during periods of economic growth.
Much of the global economy is growing now. But the price of a barrel of oil, if one takes inflation and changes in the value of the dollar into account, is about the same as it was on the eve of the Arab oil embargo of 1973 (around $3 in 1973 dollars). "It's definitely a surprise," says Geoffrey Heal, an economist at the Columbia Business School: "The conventional wisdom is that growth pushes up commodity prices."
What happened to the forecasts of $20 a barrel oil? Three things. Despite the proliferation of four-wheel-drive vehicles and outsized family homes, average energy efficiency is way up. Second, the spreading recession in Asia, a heavy user of oil, has cut into demand. But the main reason for low prices is a flood of new oil supplies. Not only is Iraq back in business, but hardly a day goes by without an announcement from another former Soviet republic of a pipeline project.
 
Stock prices = Earnings expectations
The value of stocks has quadrupled in the past six years, adding a staggering $1 trillion to household balance sheets in the last three months alone. Share prices are so high, in fact, that almost all measures of valuation are at record levels (and these records go back in some case to 1871). The rule of thumb is that when prices step out of the bounds of historical norms, investors had better watch out.
Some experts argue that the old rules no longer apply. Stock prices reflect the riskiness as well as the expected future returns of the investment. Jeremy Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School, argues that stocks aren't as risky in the long run as everybody always thought they were, compared to low-risk investments like bonds. Since 1871, stocks have risen more than twice as fast as bonds -- 7.0 percent a year versus 2.8 when adjusted for inflation.
Thus, Mr. Siegel says, people are smart to pay a lot for the fast-growing stocks of the present bull market. There is some evidence, from surveys as well as the investment choices of participants in large retirement funds, that investor attitudes have indeed changed.
If Mr. Siegel is correct, the fact that today's share prices are historically high in comparison to companies' earnings doesn't necessarily mean stocks are overvalued.
But the Yale economist Robert Shiller cautions that the same "new era" claims were being made during another huge run-up in the stock market. He quotes a fellow Yale economist, Irving Fisher, who said in 1929 that, "It was only as the public came to realize . . . that stocks were to be preferred to bonds . . . that the bull market began in good earnest to cause a proper valuation of common shares."

 The Phillips curve depicts the relationship between unemployment and inflation. The red wage-change scale on the right-hand vertical axis is higher than the black left-hand inflation scale by the assumed 2 percent rate of growth of average labor productivity

HEADLINE: The Wrong Lessons

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "First Lessons in the Power of Money" (April 12), which looked at efforts to teach economics in primary and secondary schools: 
 As a college professor, I am well aware of the paucity of economics training for young people. Yet the economics curriculums described seem less like education than like one-sided indoctrination.
Consider, for example, one of the 20 principles from the National Council on Economic Education, an organization started by business leaders. It basically says that when people and countries concentrate on what they do best and cheapest, and then trade with others, a result is greater overall prosperity. This is false history and reflects the corporate view over any other consideration. The antebellum South did pretty well producing cotton, but one might wonder if overall prosperity was extended to slaves. Today, Indonesian workers might work cheaply and well for a big American corporation, but it is hardly clear that they have prospered.
With this kind of economics education, it is no wonder that ordinary Americans seem to submit as corporations and the elite few reap virtually all the gains from the last decades of economic growth. And no wonder I spend so much time stimulating real student debate about economic "principles" that pose as science but that are only justifications for power and inequality.
 
RAYMOND SEIDELMAN
Ossining, N.Y., April 13
 
The writer teaches political science at Sarah Lawrence College.

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
Growth Without Inflation
Instead of slowing down because of Asia's recession, the American economy has picked up speed. It grew at an unexpectedly strong 4.2 percent annual rate in the first quarter, up from a 3.7 percent rate the previous quarter. And the broadest measure of inflation, instead of drifting higher as Washington and Wall Street had feared, dipped below 1 percent, to its lowest rate since 1964. "We keep expecting a slowdown and it never comes," said Jeffrey A. Frankel of the Council of Economic Advisers, citing instead "a remarkable combination of strong growth without inflation." But consumers see no slowdown. The Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index approached a three-decade high, rebounding to 136.7 in April, from 133.8 in March. 

MARKETS
Battered, Then Buoyant
Displaying the stability of a windsock, the stock market soared on the buoyant economic news. The Dow Jones industrial average tacked on more than 100 points on Thursday, its second consecutive day of gains, and erased the vestiges of its 146.98-point tumble on Monday. That plunge followed a report that the Federal Reserve had adopted a bias favoring higher interest rates -- a report that some in Washington viewed as having been planted by the Fed itself as a signal to investors. But the latest economic data largely erased any lingering fears of a rate increase soon, and the yield on the long bond fell back below 6 percent. The Dow average ended the week up 82.45, at 9,147.07, while the Nasdaq composite index edged up 4.48, to close at 1,873.44.
 
SOCIAL SECURITY
Doomsday Delayed
Young adults have been given a reprieve -- three more years to hone their survivalist skills, learning to prepare meals of berries and bark, say, or build shelter from tender young saplings. Thanks to the nation's booming economy, the Administration reported, the Social Security system's solvency has been extended by three years from the date projected last year, 2029. Even with the new projections, Social Security would be able to pay only three-quarters of promised benefits after the system exhausts its reserves in 2032. The Government reported that Medicare, the health care program for the elderly, would remain financially sound until 2008.
 
DEALS
BMW Captures Rolls
Vickers P.L.C. formally accepted a $566 million takeover offer for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars from BMW, subject only to shareholder approval. But BMW's German rival, Volkswagen, vowed to fight on, promising a sweeter price for Rolls, Britain's premier luxury-car maker. . . . United Airlines and Delta Air Lines agreed on a broad marketing alliance, subject to approval by pilots. The deal would link the airlines' frequent-flier programs, allow each carrier to sell seats on the other's flights and give United passengers access to 39 new cities and Delta passengers access to 17 more. . . . Lucent Technologies agreed to acquire Yurie Systems, a maker of devices to send data and video over the Internet, for $1 billion. . . . Times Mirror will sell its legal publishing business to the British-Dutch publishing giant Reed Elsevier for $1.65 billion in cash.
 
HEALTH CARE
Limits for Viagra
Fearing huge payouts to millions of American men, large insurers, including Wellpoint Health Networks and Cigna Healthcare, are adopting strict reimbursement policies for Viagra, Pfizer Inc.'s new pill for impotence. The insurers require proof of a medical cause for the problem, and Cigna will pay for only six pills a month. Kaiser Permanente plans a similiar policy. Since its introduction in late March, Viagra has had one of the most successful debuts in pharmaceutical history, with some 20,000 prescriptions written daily.
 
EUROPE
Locking Exchange Rates
The dollar, after reigning supreme in global finance for the better part of this century, will soon face a new rival that could prove much more powerful than the German mark or Japanese yen: a single European currency, the euro. This weekend, 11 of the European Union's 15 member nations -- those that have chosen to participate in the first stage of monetary union -- will lock their exchange rates together. "The euro has the potential to reshape European and international financial markets," the I.M.F. said, and to transform the world monetary system.
 
MICROSOFT
States Slam Windows
Attorneys general from 13 states are preparing a joint antitrust action against Microsoft, seeking to block the company's release in June of Windows 98, the next version of its ubiquitious operating system for personal computers. Several said they would rather act with the United States Department of Justice, which has been conducting its own antitrust investigation, but they fear that the Federal agency is acting too slowly. Any lawsuit would become much more complicated, they added, once the software goes on sale.
 
PEOPLE
Honda's New Driver
Honda's president and chief executive, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, will retire. An engineer, he led the company to record profits and market share in the United States and Japan over the last eight years, after making his mark in 1974 as a member of the team that designed the first engine to meet Federal clean air regulations without a catalytic converter. Mr. Kawamoto has infuriated Detroit executives by contending that global warming is a serious problem that the auto industry should address. He will be succeeded by Hiroyuki Yoshino, Honda's head of research and vehicle development and a close associate. . . . Mario J. Gabelli, the mutual fund manager, wants to sell part of his fund and investment empire to the public. But he plans to keep control of the company -- and, perhaps, many of his best investment ideas. . . . Pepsi-Cola, stung by the lagging performance of its flagship brand, said its chief global marketing officer, Brian Swette, would leave at the end of the month and would be replaced by a three-executive marketing council.
 
UTILITIES
Pollution Sale Halted
At the urging of New York State, the Long Island Lighting Company said it would stop selling, to polluters in the Midwest and South, pollution credits it earned by cleaning its own smokestacks. The 1990 Federal Clean Air Act established the marketplace trading of the right to pollute as an inexpensive way to clean up the environment. But as New York State and its neighbors have learned, the marketplace cannot stop the wind from blowing pollution eastward. . . . Texas Utilities won Energy Group P.L.C., one of Britain's last remaining independent utilities, after another American utility company, Pacificorp, said it would not try to beat a $7.4 billion bid. . . . Two fast-growing Nevada utilities, Nevada Power and Sierra Pacific Resources, agreed to a $1.2 billion merger.

PUB-DATE: May 3, 1998,

SECTION: Section 1; Page 26; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1056 words

HEADLINE: An Anniversary Brings Pride and Resentment

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: MADRID, N.M., April 28

 BODY:
Swords of Toledo steel sparkled in the sun, the red and gold banner of King Philip II flapped in the breeze, helmeted pikemen stood at attention. Everything was in place for Manuel Gullon de Onate, a nattily dressed lawyer from Madrid, Spain.
With a flourish, he pulled a covering from a bronze statue erected here, showing his ancestor, Don Juan de Onate, pointing north. On April 30, 1598, Onate and 500 colonists from Mexico crossed the Rio Grande at El Paso and embarked on a journey that ultimately established the first European settlements in the American West, predating the first permanent English settlement in the present United States, Jamestown in Virginia, by almost a decade. 
 The 400th anniversary of Onate's journey has inspired 185 events and projects in New Mexico, celebrating the state's Spanish roots, like the ceremony here in Madrid, about midway between Santa Fe and Albuquerque.
At a thanksgiving dinner last Saturday night in El Paso, attended by 2,000 people, Mr. Gullon, Vice President Francisco Alvarez-Cascos of Spain and other dignitaries were feted with 16th-century dishes. El Paso is constructing an Onate statue that is to be the nation's largest equestrian bronze.
The next day, Mr. Alvarez-Cascos reviewed plans for a Camino Real museum to be built with Spanish, American and Mexican money near Socorro, N.M. The Camino Real, an ox cart track by which the Spaniards reached the Southwest, stretched 1,800 miles, from Chihuahua, Mexico, to Santa Fe, N.M. And on June 1, Albuquerque, N.M., will begin construction of a $45 million complex that will be the nation's largest Hispanic cultural center.
But beneath all the festive pageantry and construction plans, many Hispanic residents in the Southwest express an irritation that the rest of the nation is largely ignoring their anniversary. It is evidence, they say, of an enduring "English-centric" view of America's past.
"We are saddled with the history that England was the mother country -- well, Spain was also a mother country," said Thomas E. Chavez, a 13th-generation Santa Fe resident who directs the musuem at the Palace of Governors, which was built in 1610 and is the oldest government structure in the United States.
Although anniversary organizers say they notified 1,200 media outlets in advance, coverage has been limited largely to reporters from New Mexico and Spain. Frank Ortiz, a retired diplomat and a descendant of an Onate-era colonist, called the response odd, considering that "Hispanics are the fastest growing community in America, and that by the year 2020, one out of four Americans will be of Hispanic origin."
Resentment over the English interpretation of American history also echoed at the Rancho de Golondrinas, a ranch museum here that traces its beginnings back to 1710, when it was built as a way station on the Camino Real, or Royal Road.
"Who wrote the history? The Anglos," complained Rosana Ubanell, Washington correspondent for the Spanish weekly magazine La Tribuna and one of a large contingent of Spanish reporters here. "My son is in the fourth grade in Virginia. Their history starts with the Mayflower."
While the anniversary may not have made much impact outside the Southwest, it seems to have furthered a centuries-overdue reconciliation between American Indians and Spain. In January, New Mexico's anniversary year got off to a fractious start when an Indian commando group sawed off the right foot of an Onate statue in Alcalde, about 40 miles north of here. The attack was in memory of an incident in 1599 when Onate punished the rebellious Acoma tribe by cutting the right feet off 24 captive warriors.
This winter, Indian opposition forced Albuquerque to abandon plans to erect an Onate statue. Instead, a city board voted recently to build a memorial highlighting Spain's positive contributions to North America -- the introduction of horses, cattle, sheep, fruit trees, irrigation, wheat and chilies.
Worried about possible protests by Pueblo Indians, the tribes conquered by the Spanish, state officials and Spanish diplomats negotiated a "reconciliation" ceremony. Last Sunday, most of the 19 Pueblo governors traveled to the pueblo that was the site of the first Spanish village here, San Juan de los Caballeros, or Oke Owingeh in the local language, Tewa.
"Settlement of New Mexico by the Spaniards caused great conflict and suffering among all our people," said Earl N. Salazar, governor of Oke Owingeh. In 1680, a man from this pueblo known only as Pope organized an uprising that killed many Spaniards and that drove the rest down to El Paso. Spain reconquered New Mexico 12 years later.
Neither side apologized for the past bloodletting.
"Our Pueblo religion, our Pueblo philosophy and way of life," said Roy Bernal, chairman of the All Indian Pueblo Council, call for "respect and compassion for all people and the responsibility of maintaining balance and harmony in our personal lives, for our people and as well as those all over the world."
Mr. Alvarez-Cascos, who represents Spain's new conservative Government, called for "a new and prosperous relationship between us," offering the possibility of Spanish economic development aid and of joint business ventures. Spain's Vice President pointed to 17th-century royal decrees that recognized Indian sovereignty and granted ceremonial silver-tipped canes, which are sacred objects that for almost 380 years have symbolized Pueblo sovereignty.
Away from the ceremonies, Spanish officials and reporters contrasted the impacts of Spanish and British colonialism on North America's Indians. While New England's vanished tribes are remembered largely as place names, New Mexico's Indians still speak their ancestral languages, practice their ancestral religions and live on their ancestral lands.
In a peacemaking move, New Mexico's Governor, Gary Johnson, held a private dinner at his house here on Monday night for the visiting Spanish dignitaries and Reginald T. Pasqual, governor of Acoma Pueblo. As the guests were departing, Mr. Pasqual turned to the Spaniards and invited them to visit Acoma.
"It was enormously moving," Mr. Gullon, the Onate descendant, said. "It was such a generous, open attitude. It seemed incredible after all that Juan de Onate did to his people -- the massacre, the feet."

HEADLINE: Promise and Pitfalls of the Euro

 BODY:
Eleven of the fifteen members of the European Union are preparing to discard their marks, liras, francs and other national currencies by 2002 in favor of a new currency, called the euro. Their goal is to boost economic growth and political ties. But the euro could backfire, trapping unlucky regions in recession and triggering political resentment when no authority comes to the rescue. Americans can hope that the brash policy works because prosperity in Europe helps the United States grow, even if the rise of the euro diminishes the international clout of the dollar.
By adopting the euro, every country in the European Union except Britain, Sweden, Denmark and Greece would create the kind of common currency in Europe that Americans take for granted with the dollar. The euro is likely to boost economic activity by cutting the cost of buying and selling. Rather than juggling 11 different yardsticks, consumers can instantly compare the price of goods in Finland, Italy and other countries in between. The euro also eliminates the risk for investors that exchange rates will fluctuate and sabotage long-term contracts. 
 But a single currency also poses risks, because it robs countries of control over their own economies. If the French economy takes a nose dive, the Government can pump in francs, devalue the franc or cut taxes and raise spending. But under the euro, France would have no francs to inject into the economy or to devalue and would operate under rules that severely limit deficit spending.
Unlike the United States, where citizens commonly move from one state to another in search of economic opportunity, Europeans are unlikely to migrate to countries with different languages, cultures and laws. If the French economy slows, and the European central bank does nothing because the rest of Europe is thriving, the French may be resentful. A policy designed to unify Europe could intensify divisions instead.
If the euro boosts the European economy, it will also boost America's. But to the extent that it replaces the dollar as the currency of international trade, it will also trim some real financial benefits that come from America's current role as the world's banker. But the threat is small. The best guess puts the loss at a few billion dollars a year, nothing to fret about in an $8 trillion economy.
A more amorphous threat is political. If managed properly, the euro could assume an international presence comparable to the dollar's. There would be pressure on the Europeans to create a political body able to manage the euro for international purposes, like the bailout of South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand led by the United States. Some in the United States welcome the political evolution of the European Union as a way to lighten the United States' economic and political burdens. Others fear Europe's potential political clout. The impact of this momentous decision goes way beyond economics in unpredictable directions.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Urges Sudan to End Restrictions on Food Airlift to South

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
Warning of a "human catastrophe" in which hundreds of thousands of people face death by starvation, the Administration has agreed to provide tons of food for the southern Sudan and is trying to bring pressure on the Sudanese Government to lift its restrictions on the distribution of food and medicine.
Administration officials say the Sudanese Government appears to be willing to allow mass starvation in the southern half of the country as a way of punishing rebels there, a view widely shared by international aid organizations. 
 The Government in Khartoum has limited relief flights to the southern Sudan for most of the year, arguing that the region is too insecure to allow the food to be delivered.
"The U.S. Government is gravely concerned about the human catastrophe that is unfolding in southern Sudan," said J. Brian Atwood, administrator of the Agency for International Development, in announcing this week that the United States would provide more than 7,000 tons of food to the Sudan, worth about $9.2 million.
"We strongly urge the Government of Sudan to carry out its obligations under international humanitarian law by affording full air access to the war-affected populations, including approval of additional aircraft to deliver food and non-food items to the region," he said.
Administration officials acknowledged that they had no way of guaranteeing that the food would reach the remote areas where it is needed most urgently.
"They've always played political games on this, and I think the Government has been fully prepared to let people starve," said Dick McCall, chief of staff to Mr. Atwood. "What is required now is for relief workers to have access to virtually every area of the region because people are too weak now even to walk to landing sites."
Since the early 1980's, rebel groups from the mostly Christian and animist southern states of the Sudan have been fighting successive Governments dominated by Arabs from the mostly Islamic north. The rebel groups are demanding greater autonomy for the south and the repeal of harsh Islamic laws.
As a result of the 1989 famine, the United Nations began an airlift operation from northern Kenya that has provided most of the medicine and relief food provided to the southern Sudan in recent years.
But in February, the Sudanese Government imposed a ban on relief flights in the region, citing fighting with rebel groups. The flight ban was lifted for 4 airstrips in late February and for 46 other airstrips earlier this month. But aid workers say that unless the ban is lifted for all airstrips in the area, tens of thousands of people may die.
While the Administration has protested to the Government of President Omar Hassan al-Bashir over its handling of the food crrisis, the United States and other Western nations have little leverage there.

Seeds Are U.N.'s Priority
 NAIROBI, Kenya, May 2 (Reuters) -- The United Nations said today that it hoped famine in Sudan could be averted and that a priority for tens of thousands of farmers in the south was seed for this season's crop.
"We believe we have all the food we need to meet the immediate needs of the population of south Sudan," said Brenda Barton, a Kenyan-based information officer for the World Food Program, a United Nations agency.

HEADLINE: China Protests Tibet Movie At Festival in Washington

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 2

 BODY:
A movie about young Tibetans searching for fulfillment and success has angered the Government of China, which complained this week to organizers of a film festival that the movie was meant to smear Chinese policy.
The Chinese Embassy sent a letter on Thursday to the head of the Washington International Film Festival, asserting that the story depicted in the movie, "Windhorse," was "completely false" and demanding that it be withdrawn. 
 The festival's director, Tony Gittens, said on Friday that the commitment to the film would be honored. "We will stand firmly by our decision and we will not compromise our right of free cultural expression," Mr. Gittens said.
"Windhorse" was shown at the Kennedy Center here on Thursday night, and it was to be shown tonight at a downtown theater, also as part of the festival.
The Chinese Government has been accused of widespread human rights abuses in Tibet, an autonomous region in southwest China that was occupied more than 40 years ago. In his embassy's letter to Mr. Gittens, the Chinese Minister-Counselor for Cultural Affairs, Li Gang, said China's policies had helped Tibet achieve "remarkable economic growth and social progress."
The film's director, Paul Wagner, said on Friday that the film was shot in October 1996, partly in Tibet and partly in Nepal. The Tibetan scenes, in particular, were shot clandestinely, with a small digital video camera more like a tourist's than a movie maker's, to thwart Chinese security forces, Mr. Wagner said.
The film "is the Tibetans' own story, told with their own voices," Steven Schecter, the cinematographer, said on Friday. The movie, 97 minutes long and with English subtitles, deals with the torture of a Buddhist nun and her relatives' decision to defy Tibet's Communist rulers.
"Windhorse," whose name is derived from the prayer-inscribed pieces of paper that Tibetans traditionally throw from high mountains in religious homage, was named best American independent film at the Santa Barbara International Film Festival in California in March. Mr. Wagner won that festival's best director award. Earlier, he produced award-winning documentaries.
Mr. Gittens said he had sent an advance copy of the film to the Chinese Embassy as a courtesy and had invited the embassy to send representatives to see the film at the festival. "I respect the opinions of the embassy officials, and I hope they will also respect mine," he said.
Now in its 12th year, the Washington film festival began on April 22 and will end on Sunday night. The event drew about 30,000 people to about 70 movies last year, said Bill Bronrott, a festival spokesman.
In 1996, the festival annoyed the Chinese by showing "The Gate of Heavenly Peace," about the 1989 Government crackdown in Tiananmen Square, Mr. Bronrott recalled.
Mr. Gittens, the festival director, added: "Each year we travel the globe to bring back the best in world cinema. The films are chosen because of their high quality and interest to our audience -- not because of any political position they might express."

HEADLINE: Albright Finds Unalloyed Love in a Newly Minted Democracy

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: ULAAN BAATAR, Mongolia, May 2

 BODY:
After her difficult and often tendentious negotiations with Chinese leaders over everything from human rights and democratization to trade and Tibet, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright basked today in the attention of the plucky young democratic reformers of Mongolia.
"This is definitely a feel-good stop," said a senior American official. "They love us here." 
 A country of only 2.5 million people, 40 percent of them nomadic, Mongolia shed 70 years as a Soviet-occupied client state in 1991, embracing democracy and market reforms.
Relics of Soviet colonial power are everywhere here -- from the mini-mausoleum that dominates a grandiose public square to the 36 MiG jets abandoned when 60,000 Soviet troops left. But despite the loss of markets and jobs that Moscow's retreat made inevitable, the Mongolians have taken up free-market democracy with astonishing ardor.
Even more remarkable, given the sour experiences of many new democracies in the region, last month Mongolia experienced another peaceful change of Government.
Its new Prime Minister, a 35-year-old former journalist named Tsahiagiyn Elbegdorj, spoke along with Ms. Albright here today in words that made her beam. Chinese leaders try to separate political and economic development, and leaders like Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore criticize Western notions of human rights as foreign to Asian culture and values. But Mr. Elbegdorj asserted that the Mongolians were "challenging and breaking this stereotype."
"Mongolia is implementing political and economic changes simultaneously in Asia," he said. "This is the choice of our people."
Even more, he said, "we are showing that we can twin reforms in the political and economic field, while cherishing human rights as a universal value."
In turn, Ms. Albright spoke of Washington's strong support for Mongolia and enthused about Jeffersonian democracy. "When I leave here," she told the Grand Hural, or Parliament, "I will be able to tell all the people in my country and around the world that here in Mongolia, government 'of the people' has had a new birth, and is thriving in a distant but beautiful land."
She said she "couldn't feel more at home," adding, "The message of friendship and support for Mongolian democracy that I bring could not be more important." Mongolia's example, she continued, "is of fundamental importance to developing countries around the world."
In fact, Mr. Elbegdorj's ascension as Prime Minister is a result of a backlash against the economic costs of reform. He replaced Mendsaikhan Enkhsaikhan, who had directed an International Monetary Fund-approved reform that cut inflation but increased unemployment.
Still, American support is highly valued here, given Mongolia's position as a sparsely populated country sandwiched between Russia and China, each of which has dominated it at one time or another.
Mongolians like Uuganbayar, a 29-year-old medical technician who works with the Peace Corps, remain grateful to Russia for helping to modernize. Russian remains the second language here. And Mrs. Uuganbayar, who like most Mongolians uses only one name, said her parents still worked in a Soviet-developed copper mine that continues as a Russian-Mongolian company.
"We miss the Russians a bit," she said. "There is a whole district of the city built by Russians and given to Mongolia, and we can't say that the Russians did nothing for us."
Ariunbat, a 30-year-old Mongolian journalist, said Mongolians feared the Chinese more than the Russians. China's last imperial dynasty ruled Mongolia until 1912, and its Communist Government rules Inner Mongolia as an autonomous region.
But American officials say that China has little interest in being seen to bully or threaten another country.
Ms. Albright is the second Secretary of State to come here. James A. Baker 3d arrived in August 1990 from Irkutsk, Russia, just as Iraqi troops crossed the border into Kuwait. He spent the night in a state guest house and then quickly flew to Moscow for consultations before returning to Washington. He visited again a year later.
The United States has provided Mongolia $80 million in aid over the last five years, some of it as emergency assistance for fuel, to keep Soviet-built power plants running through the long and deep winters.
The cold is so severe in Mongolia that many Ulaan Baatar residents abandon their city dwellings during the worst of it in preference for traditional felt tents, or gers, which Americans know as yurts. The gers are simply warmer than poorly heated Soviet-era apartment blocks.
On Capitol Hill, American officials said, Mongolia's democracy is extremely popular. The country, which was allotted $12 million in American aid last year, is one of the few to receive more money than the Administration requests. The amount may not seem enormous -- especially when compared, for instance, with the $225 million sent to Ukraine. But Ukraine's population is more than 25 times larger than Mongolia's.
Today, Ms. Albright delivered about $200,000 for women's projects here. A coalition of about 20 women's groups, all of which get some American aid, includes professionals, legislators and those working against domestic violence.
Ms. Albright approved a modest joint statement on United States-Mongolian relations that the Government here had sought as a formal recognition of American interest and support.
Washington is also supporting Mongolia for membership in the regional forum of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, an effort to pull the country from its isolation.
Mrs. Uuganbayar, the Peace Corps worker, said she had high hopes for her son, now 4. "We think all this will work," she said. "My sister, my mother, my husband, we all look forward to American help."
