HEADLINE: In Niagara Falls, Pataki's Vetoes Rouse Anger as Economy Slumps

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., May 1

 BODY:
Roger Spurback, a lifelong Republican in this city of Democrats, used to heap praise on Gov. George E. Pataki and his fiscal policies. But his feelings changed when Mr. Pataki cut $20,000 from the state budget for a neighborhood crime prevention program that Mr. Spurback supervises from his home here.
The program is among hundreds that suffered when Mr. Pataki vetoed more than $1.5 billion in state spending last week, saying legislators had pledged far too many tax dollars to programs great and small. While the vetoes will affect the entire state, people like Mr. Spurback say their impact will be harshest in depressed upstate cities like Niagara Falls, where many community programs rely almost entirely on state aid. Even politically conservative residents like Mr. Spurback are livid, saying the vetoes will lead many to vote against Mr. Pataki this fall. 
 "When you batter the people who do the voting, you're going to hear back from them loud and clear," said Mr. Spurback, whose program provides walkie-talkies to residents who volunteer as neighborhood security guards, deadbolts for elderly people's homes and extra lighting for dark streets. "He's crushing these simple little programs that do so much good."
Mr. Pataki also vetoed $1,000 for a children's chess club, $2,500 for pregnancy prevention programs and $7,500 for the city's drug court, an alternative to prison for low-level offenders who abuse drugs and alcohol.
The Niagara Falls Fire Department lost $2,000 for a fire prevention program for schoolchildren, and a nonprofit group lost $2,500 that would have helped renovate a home for the mentally ill. The Legal Aid Society of Niagara County is $67,000 poorer, and the city will have $2,500 less to spend decorating neighborhoods for Christmas.
Niagara Falls will receive about $100,000 more in municipal aid than last year, city officials said, but Niagara County Community College, like others across the state, will lose some state aid and might have to raise tuition.
And while school aid will increase slightly, the Governor vetoed $500 million that would have renovated or replaced aging school buildings across the state. All in a year when Wall Street is thriving and state tax revenue is exceptionally high.
"All I can do is scratch my head and ask why," said Senator Anthony Nanula, a Democrat whose district includes Niagara Falls and who tucked money for some of the programs into the state budget last month. "One can only guess there is a political motivation behind Governor Pataki's actions here."
Others say the State Legislature's $72 billion budget was a foolish spending spree, contending that Mr. Pataki delivered the state from fiscal chaos by making painful but courageous cuts.
"The Governor had to make some cuts," James C. Galie, the Democratic Mayor of Niagara Falls, said. "I've done it myself, even at election time."
Chuck Steiner, the president of the Chamber of Commerce, also defended Mr. Pataki's vetoes, saying the tax cuts in the new budget would bring businesses to depressed cities like Niagara Falls. Many of those businesses would donate money to programs like the ones suffering from the vetoes, so they could thrive even without state dollars, he said.
But to many residents of Niagara Falls, who have seen business after business close and repeated attempts to rejuvenate their downtown fail, those arguments carry little weight. Unemployment hovers around 11.5 percent, compared with the statewide average of 6.5 percent. Even tourists, who used to count Niagara Falls among their favorite destinations in the world, do not come so eagerly anymore -- although Mayor Galie says 10 million a year still visit.
Mr. Pataki has called for reviving the tourist trade, describing Niagara Falls as one of "New York's treasures" in his State of the State Message in January and saying it was time to "make it the great national tourist attraction it should be." But last week he vetoed $5 million to help replace the observation tower at the falls. The next day, he announced the project would receive state aid after all, from a special fund for community projects.
Some question why the Governor would invest state money in a tourist attraction instead of programs that directly help the people of Niagara Falls. About half of the 55,000 residents receive some kind of public assistance, and a growing number are elderly. Although they are overwhelmingly Democratic, most voted for Mr. Pataki in 1994, hoping he would work some economic magic where Gov. Mario M. Cuomo could not.
But residents say Mr. Pataki has pulled no rabbits from his hat for Niagara Falls. In particular, they say he did not work hard enough to build legislative support for a bill to allow casinos in town. The Legislature rejected the bill last year, destroying what many residents saw as their best chance for steady work.
"If we had one it would help us, no doubt about it," said Edward Grochala, a retired mail carrier who was sitting in a used furniture store on Pine Avenue. "It's dying slowly, yet this town should burst right open, with one of the seven wonders of the world right here."
Mayor Galie said Mr. Pataki has promised to encourage lawmakers to reconsider the casino bill.
"I think the Governor is going to support casinos here," he said. "And in the next 10 to 15 years this town will compare with Disney World in terms of visitors. You can go anywhere to see a casino, but not with Niagara Falls alongside it."
But Judge Mark A. Violante, who runs the local drug court, and John Herowski, who runs the after-school chess club, said the local economy would never recover without the programs Mr. Pataki vetoed.
The drug court puts low-level felons who abuse drugs or alcohol through intensive monitoring and counseling instead of sending them to crowded jails. None of the 40 defendants who have completed the program since it started in 1996 have been arrested again, Judge Violante said.
The state funds would have been used to buy a computer for the courtroom and chemicals used to test for drugs and alcohol, he said.
Mr. Herowski started the chess club last year, when residents were complaining that too many children were wandering the streets after school. The $1,000 would have bought new chessboards and clocks and helped members travel to tournaments in other upstate cities, he said.
"These are underprivileged kids and we can change their lives," said Mr. Herowski, who added that members of the club would write to the Governor pleading for support. "I just wish they would take a better look at exactly what $1,000 can do. I know there's a ton of money going somewhere in this state."
Rosario Corieri, a barber who has owned Rosario's Hair on Pine Avenue for 30 years, said he knows where the money is going: to New York City and the surrounding suburbs, which he said get more attention because they have far more voters than far-flung rural counties like Niagara.
"When they take anything away from an area that's hurting this bad, they're going to have problems," Mr. Corieri said. "We don't ask for much compared to downstate. Why would he take this stuff away?"

HEADLINE: Rosie Speaks, and Broadway Ticket Sellers Cheer

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
It is a testament to the changing culture of Broadway that in the final weeks before the opening of "The Lion King" last fall, the show's producers and publicity agents turned their attention to winning the favor not of a theater critic but of a talk show host and comedian, Rosie O'Donnell.
First, they got the cast booked to perform on Ms. O'Donnell's show. Then they got her to see a preview performance. She was so bowled over, she returned with her 2-year-old son the next day, then went on the air the following morning and pronounced it "the best show I have ever seen in my 35 years." 
 She called it brilliant and astounding; she said she had been reduced to sobbing; she told John Travolta he had to see it. Buy your tickets today, she exhorted her audience of six million or so, because when the reviews come out, there will be none to be found.
"Based on that particular moment, our ticket sales took off," said Peter Schneider, president of feature animation and theatrical productions for Disney, which produced the musical. "The minute Rosie went on the air, we started to sell out. The impact of her personal opinion was phenomenal."
Rosie O'Donnell has become to Broadway what Oprah Winfrey is to books: a big-time celebrity with a hit television show and a largely female following who has made it her mission to breathe new life into a corner of American culture that badly needs help. Day after day, she executes the unlikely stunt of promoting Broadway theater from behind her knickknack-bespangled desk on a daytime talk show devoted to "celebrity-friendly" chat with the likes of Antonio Sabato Jr. and to upbeat banter about such cultural icons as Barbra Streisand and Drake's cakes.
Ms. O'Donnell's influence is indisputable. When she used her show, broadcast each weekday morning at 10 in New York City on ABC, to inaugurate a new toll-free line for ordering Broadway tickets, 5,000 people called the line in the first 45 minutes. When the cast of "Titanic" first performed on her show, box office sales doubled or tripled for that day.
Ticket sales for "Street Corner Symphony" rose by 50 percent and remained elevated for days after its cast performed on "The Rosie O'Donnell Show." And when Ms. O'Donnell was the host of the Tony Awards ceremony last spring, something she will do again next month, its television ratings leapt nearly 50 percent.
All of which is, in a way, Ms. O'Donnell's gift to Broadway. In an era in which television bookings are calculated to promote people or products for immediate consumption, Ms. O'Donnell has gone way out of her way to further the interests of an industry out of the reach of most of her viewers.
Tomorrow morning, the wisecracking Ms. O'Donnell, whose brain is an archive of plot lines from 1970's sitcoms and who redefined the role of Betty Rubble in the film version of "The Flintstones," will join the actors Peter Gallagher and Bernadette Peters to announce the 1998 Tony nominations at Sardi's.
"I believe Rosie has got our foot back in the door of popular American culture," said Bill Evans, a Broadway press agent. "It's the best thing that has happened to Broadway to have her be the enthusiast and the symbol. She represents Broadway."
The rise of Ms. O'Donnell as a force on Broadway exemplifies a shift in the culture and economics of New York theater, at least that of big-budget musical theater. Ten years ago, less than half of all Broadway ticketholders came from outside New York; now, two-thirds live outside New York.
With so many theatergoers living elsewhere, the power of critics has declined and the influence of marketing and promotion has grown, says Jed Bernstein, the executive director of the League of American Theaters and Producers, the trade organization for Broadway theater in North America.
"Rosie O'Donnell is the personification of a trend toward the mainstreaming of Broadway as an entertainment form," Mr. Bernstein said. "Rosie is part of that phenomenon, but she really takes it to the nth degree."
Ms. O'Donnell's taste in theater might best be described as expansive. When asked, she said she could not think of a show she had hated. She never says anything negative about a show, and she said she could not remember having seen a show and not having mentioned it on the air.
On any given day, Ms. O'Donnell might be found raving to her band leader, John McDaniel, about Natalie Portman in "The Diary of Anne Frank," lip-synching a song from "Titanic," reminiscing with Hinton Battle about his Broadway roles or introducing a scene from "Cabaret."
She gives away free tickets and compact disks. She brandishes Playbills before the camera. She is not above using triple-exclamation-point adjectives like astonishing, phenomenal and epic. Often, she is simply an awestruck fan.
"Nothing quite excites me like a Broadway musical," she said on her show one morning earlier this year. "Except, maybe, a TV star from the 70's. Can you imagine my delight when I learned that my favorite star of the 70's was here in Broadway's 'The King and I'?"
And in walked Marie Osmond.
Ms. O'Donnell grew up listening to Broadway musicals. That is, her mother used to put on cast albums (and Streisand records) while cleaning the house. As Ms. O'Donnell puts it, she and her four siblings were the only second graders in Commack, N.Y., who knew all the words to "South Pacific."
But when she was 10, her mother died of cancer. She describes her father as remote. As soon as she was old enough, she says, she started stealing $20 bills from his wallet, cutting school, riding the Long Island Rail Road into New York City and going to Broadway matinees.
"In many ways, it was my moral guidance as a child," she said of musical theater. "I learned about good and evil and the Nazis from 'The Sound of Music.' It sounds so trite to talk about it, but I feel the human spirit is alive and thriving in musical theater."
That exposure also influenced her decision to perform. The world of movies seemed distant but Broadway was within reach. Standing outside a stage door, she says it was possible to think, "On this block, in this theater, people are doing what I hope to do."
It was there, too, that Ms. O'Donnell first uttered the words "I love you." The recipient was Lucie Arnaz, emerging from a stage door of "They're Playing Our Song."
"We were not an 'I love you' household," Ms. O'Donnell recalled recently. "That's odd to me that this was the first time I blurted that out."
She ended up doing stand-up comedy, television and movies instead of theater. (She did make it to Broadway in 1994 in a revival of "Grease.") But when she began her talk show in 1996, she deliberately made it a throwback, "a Merv Griffinesque show for the 90's," as she put it, with a lot of exposure for Broadway.
"I'm just trying to have people love it as much as I do," she said. "I want to try to encourage the 8-year-old kid sitting there to become the next Stephen Sondheim. I want to inspire people to create this kind of art."
Now in its second season, the show is the third-highest rated syndicated television talk show, after "The Oprah Winfrey Show" and "The Jerry Springer Show." It is especially popular among women, who also happen to dominate the ranks of Broadway ticket buyers.
Yet Ms. O'Donnell said she encountered resistance at first. When she wanted to book Julie Harris or Cherry Jones, she said, she got quizzical looks from her staff. "Or Patti LuPone for the Mamet play," she said. "They'll say, 'Can't you wait till she does an episode of 'Frasier?' "
But soon, the show was booking Broadway cast members to perform. It would share the costs with the Broadway producers -- sometimes tens of thousands of dollars to pay actors, wardrobe people, dressers, hairdressers, prop people and stage managers for a three-minute number.
In the case of "Titanic," Ms. O'Donnell and Mr. McDaniel both saw it in previews, then talked it up and played the cast album on the air. When it opened to mixed reviews, Ms. O'Donnell booked the entire cast to perform the opening number.
"I really sort of did pump it," she said. "One reason was I did love it. And another is that a show with bad notices is always in danger of closing, and I knew that I had a really enjoyable evening of theater and that I thought that people who valued my opinion would enjoy it as well."
According to Adrian Bryan-Brown, the publicist for "Titanic," box office sales rose by 100 to 200 percent after the cast appeared on the show. The impact lasted several days, but Mr. Bryan-Brown said there was also "a residual effect you cannot measure."
There are, of course, shows that even Ms. O'Donnell cannot save. One was "Side Show," the critically admired musical about a pair of Siamese twins. Ms. O'Donnell went to the opening night, led the standing ovation and, along with Mr. McDaniel, admired it effusively and repeatedly on the air.
But the subject proved daunting to potential audiences. When the show slid into trouble, its publicity agents turned to Ms. O'Donnell for help. She exuberantly doled out tickets and compact disks, and offered her own seemingly spontaneous testimonial: "It is not gross or scary at all."
To no avail; "Side Show" closed. But that has not stopped others from trying to enlist Ms. O'Donnell's support.
"That's the only negative thing about the clout of my show," she said. "When a show is up and in danger of closing, they want you to promote it and say, 'Go see it.' And I can't really do it for every show. Because then no one will believe me when I say, 'That's astounding!' "

HEADLINE: The Very Rich Pay to Learn How to Give Money Away

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
For most Americans, the formula for giving money away is easy enough: Choose the charity and write the check.
But for the mega-rich, that approach is hopelessly simplistic. They need professional help in parting with their money -- and some are willing to spend up to $20,000 to get it. 
 So they go to philanthropy school.
In recent years, a growing number of foundations and other organizations have begun holding workshops, field trips and even therapy sessions to teach the wealthy and -- in the words of one provider of such services -- the really extremely wealthy the finer points of giving. These include not only practical considerations such as how to evaluate organizations for their financial responsibility but also a lot of intellectual soul-searching about what values the givers are hoping to spread.
For $650, a Boston program will put you through the paces in a weekend. And for $150 an hour, another Boston outfit will provide one-on-one counseling and hand-holding for those traumatized about coming into sudden wealth. But the Rolls-Royce of this new educational discipline is without question the Rockefeller Foundation Course in Practical Philanthropy.
Created in response to demand from affluent families worried that the younger generation was losing the philanthropic touch, the course isn't easy to get into. To separate real grant-making material from hangers-on hoping for a chance to schmooze with the rich, the foundation puts candidates thorough a series of interviews, asks questions about their backgrounds and looks into their finances. Students pay $10,000 in tuition, plus $10,000 for travel and lodging.
During the course -- which meets for one week in October, January, April and June -- students read Aristotle, learn to analyze financial statements, travel abroad (this year to Rio) to view third world poverty close up and practice meditation.
But can't these folks figure out themselves how to donate their money? Not really, says Jacqueline Novogratz, one of the program's directors. "Philanthropy is no longer about writing a check for $10,000 to the opera," Ms. Novogratz said. "We're exposing our students to a whole new innovative way of looking at strategic philanthropy."
And the Rockefeller students seem satisfied with their investment. Elizabeth Wallace-Ellers, a former investment banker who lives in Philadelphia, took the course last year, she said, "as a reality check, to make sure that in all my self-education I hadn't missed anything."
Chara Schreyer, a current student, joined to get a better grasp of how to run her San Francisco organization, the Kadima Foundation, which distributes $1 million a year for causes ranging from the education of underprivileged teen-agers to diabetes research. "I guess I could have done this myself," she said, "but I wouldn't have gotten a complete overview. I wouldn't have even known where to begin."
On a gray afternoon in January, seven students -- from 30-somethings to graying baby boomers -- sat around a conference table on the 23d floor of the Rockefeller Foundation's Fifth Avenue headquarters, munching soggy tuna sandwiches and sipping soft drinks, their pens poised over note pads and their brows furrowed in concentration.
The talk among the group, which included Bob Vila, the television home-repair guru; Jeffrey Soros, a nephew of the billionaire financier and philanthropist George Soros; and Ms. Schreyer, a California construction heiress whose father founded the Holocaust Museum in Washington, D.C., was high-minded, almost solemn.
"I don't intend to emerge from this course as a fully fledged philanthropist," said Mr. Soros, 37, who is taking the course this year with his wife, Catherine. (Another Soros, George's daughter, Andrea, took it during its first year.) "What I hope to have are the skills necessary to continue my education as a philanthropist. To learn enough so that I know how to structure a grant, that I can be a vital, active part of my philanthropic giving."
Mr. Soros, who lives in Los Angeles and writes screenplays (although he has yet to see one produced), said that since he had started taking the course, he had been invited to join the boards of two nonprofit groups.

The Classics First, Then Practical Matters
Students start with the basics, reading and discussing great works of literature, such as Aristotle's "Nicomachean Ethics," James Agee's "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men" and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s "Letter From Birmingham Jail." Their purpose, Ms. Novogratz said, is "to focus people on what their own values are, how they see the world, and how they see the good society."
"We use those texts as a jumping-off point to discuss the notions of leadership and responsibility," said Ms. Novogratz, whose office displays a flier that reads "Kill Your Television."
During the course's second week, students learn practical skills, such as how to evaluate an organization and read its financial statements, aimed at deciding whether it deserves a grant. They also spend an afternoon observing proceedings at New York City's Housing Court, so that those who have never seen an eviction notice might understand the human side of economic deprivation. Guest speakers -- from organizations like the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. and the Natural Resources Defense Council -- pay frequent visits. Students are also encouraged to seek advice from Rockefeller Foundation alumni -- who now number 17 -- on what groups are most deserving of their money. Ms. Novogratz said that at least one philanthropist-in-training had denied a grant to an organization as a result of a conversation with a graduate.
In a millionaires' variation of the Junior Year Abroad, the third week of the course takes students to impoverished areas of a foreign country. This year, they spent a week in Brazil, first checking into the Copacabana Palace and then setting to work studying the problems that besiege the poverty-stricken slums of Rio de Janeiro.
"Apparently, we may be able to draw conclusions about problems that we see in the U.S.," Mr. Soros said. "Maybe there are similar root causes in both New York and Rio."
Students also have to wrestle with the jarring contrast between the cosseted lives they lead and the struggle for survival they witness among the poor. In the course's first year, they flew to Nairobi, Kenya, to observe an AIDS program for prostitutes. One participant, who requested anonymity, remembered the shock of returning from a prostitute's one-room shack to the luxury of his room at the Intercontinental Hotel.
"Five days in Nairobi slums changes you," Ms. Novogratz said.
During the fourth week, students submit "mission statements" of their philanthropic goals, and go before the Rockefeller Foundation board to be grilled on a hypothetical grant proposal they have written.
As high-sounding as all of this might sound, not everybody is a fan of the program. Some politically conservative foundations see partisanship in the place of philanthropy. James Piereson, executive director of the John M. Olin Foundation in New York, said he believes that organizations like the Rockefeller Foundation focus their attention on issues dear to Democrats. He regards their programs as a frilly boot camp for wealthy leftists.
"It's an attempt to spread the influence of the Rockefeller Foundation, assume the ends of the foundation, and discuss the means to get to those ends," Mr. Piereson said. "The approach of the liberal foundations used to be that they would go after the professional managers, and they would use the professional, liberal managers to bend the previously conservative donors." Now, he said, Rockfeller is "going straight to the source." The Olin Foundation sponsors its own annual philanthropy meeting, the Philanthropy Round Table.
Ms. Novogratz brushes aside the criticism, insisting that her group has no political agenda. "I'd say one of the perceived strengths is that we are nonideological," she said.
While the Rockefeller Foundation program might well offer the best Philanthropy 101 course money can buy, it tops an increasingly crowded field. Advisory services have popped up all over the place -- and no wonder. A few years ago, two Cornell University economists estimated that baby boomers would inherit $5.6 trillion from their parents over the next several decades, the biggest intergenerational transfer of wealth in American history. And that was when the Dow Jones industrial average was below 3,000. Since then, the number of the nation's millionaires has risen sharply.
In 1989, an estimated three million United States households had a net worth of $1 million or more; seven years later, that figure was 4.1 million, according to Edward N. Wolff, a New York University economist. Americans' giving has kept pace, according to "Giving U.S.A.," an annual report on philanthropy published by the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel, soaring to $151 billion in 1996 from $111.5 billion in 1990, 43 percent above the gain necessary to keep up with inflation.
"We'd like to capture the hearts and imaginations of these people to be philanthropic with this newly acquired wealth," said Salvatore LaSpada, the co-director of the Rockefeller Foundation's course.
So would other groups. The Philanthropic Initiative Inc., a nine-year-old Boston nonprofit, charges $650 for weekend seminars that it holds twice a year on charitable giving. The retreats draw hundreds of people, "from the wealthy to the really extremely wealthy," said H. Peter Karoff, the founder and president, who considers just plain wealthy to be a net worth about of $25 million.
The Philanthropic Initiative has instructed about 7,000 people. "We are trying to promote philanthropy in an aggressive, marketing-savvy way," Mr. Karoff said. "The Rockefeller program is the high end of what's available." While his program is more modest, he added, "We had no idea when we started how much we would grow."

Invaluable Training At Bargain Prices
Most training programs teach the basics for prices that are pocket change to their customers. The Council on Foundations in Washington, D.C., a nonprofit membership association for charitable foundations and corporate grant-making programs, charges $1,000 for three-day annual workshops that have drawn 50 students in four years.
And the Impact Project, a Boston outfit founded seven years ago, advises younger people, for about $150 an hour, on how to deal with sudden wealth. The organization's newsletter, More Than Money, has 1,100 subscribers and offers first-person tales of philanthropic anguish. "My parents are terrified of being judged as wealthy, but they live in this enormous dream house and make large institutional donations that get the wings of buildings named after them," reads one, by a reader named Bob Styles. "They fight constantly because my Dad wants to give away more than my Mom."
In another issue, Patrick Reynolds, an heir to the R. J. Reynolds tobacco fortune, explained why he used his wealth to found the Foundation for a Smokefree America.
According to Christopher Mogil, the director, the Impact Project is unique in combining consulting and therapy. In one case, he sat side by side with a young woman who was afraid to look at the stock portfolio she had just inherited to see how much was in it. After he soothed her nerves, she opened the folder and learned she was worth $10 million.
"There can be a lot of guilt and trauma in the philanthropic community," Mr. Mogil said.
Of course, it's possible to learn how to give away money without attending philanthropy school. Twelve dollars will buy you a one-year subscription to the Better Business Bureau's quarterly newsletter, Give But Give Wisely. Or, if you have two years to invest, you can apply for the Nonprofit Management master's program at the Yale University School of Management.
But the Rockefeller Foundation is the place to be if you have deep pockets and a yearning to change the world. And the people who run it are delighted at the opportunity to show you how.
By midafternoon on that day in January, the seven students had made their way by taxi to the Rheedlen Center for Children and Families on West 144th Street in Harlem. They spoke with staff members, observed a class, then returned to downtown Manhattan to dine with Geoffrey Canada, the center's president.
"It's very interesting to know that there are folks out there who are that affluent coming to us to try to learn something," Mr. Canada said. "The best part is that we get to talk to them while they're still deciding what to do with their money."

HEADLINE: EUROPEANS ACCEPT A SINGLE CURRENCY DESPITE LATE SNAG

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Sunday, May 3

 BODY:
A bold European Union plan to begin a common currency among 11 countries next year got underway this morning after temporarily running aground over a dispute between France and Germany about who should run the new European central bank.
Instead of celebrating economic and political unity by formally proclaiming the plan on Saturday afternoon, leaders of the 15 European Union countries spent hours in bitter argument between the two countries that have been at the heart of the European idea for decades. 
 France, apparently alone, had insisted that Wim F. Duisenberg of the Netherlands, the German-backed candidate to head the central bank that will run the new currency, the euro, should agree in writing to retire four years after the start of an eight-year term so that the president of France's central bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, could take over.
Germany balked, citing the statutory eight-year term of the European bank's president and concerned about any compromise that would turn the euro into a poor substitute for the German mark.
The dispute was finally resolved at midnight by an agreement to appoint Mr. Duisenberg to an eight-year term after he suddenly let it be known that he planned to retire of his own free will by mid-2002, but gave no date, satisfying the German demand that none be specified.
The wrangling was an inauspicious start to a project intended to be a signal demonstration of European political will to become an economic superpower as strong as the United States. And it could weaken European currencies against the dollar when the financial markets open on Monday.
"There are no reasons for laughing," President Jacques Chirac of France chided reporters who hooted when Mr. Chirac told them that he and his fellow leaders had decided that Mr. Trichet would replace Mr. Duisenberg in about four years.
Jose Maria Gil Robles, president of the European Parliament, which has to ratify today's agreements later this month, said, "Let us hope that the baby which has been born in such bad form can recover."
The countries taking part in the new currency are Austria, Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Portugal and Spain. Britain, Denmark and Sweden decided not to join and Greece did not meet the criteria.
"I want to make the process irreversible," Chancellor Helmut Kohl had said of the often tortuous emergence of European unification, but even he described Saturday night's discussions as "combative." He sees European unity as the best guarantee against the wars that devastated the Continent twice in the first half of the century.
But as the latest dispute showed, the barriers were formidable.
Creating a central bank before a political union has never been done before in Europe; the European Union has often failed to agree on common foreign or security policies, as in Bosnia during the war there.
Setting up a common currency means that countries with very different economic needs will be bound by one common economic policy. That has already exacted political consequences. The French public's dissatisfaction with the austerity measures the Government proposed to keep its budget deficit low enough to qualify to join the euro was a major reason the Gaullist party lost in elections last spring.
Such tensions are bound to arise in the future. What if one country's economy is doing well, but another's needs relief? One policy will have to fit all, whether unemployment is at 6 percent, as in Austria now, or 22 percent, as in Spain.
In effect, the countries are giving up some part of their sovereignty to a central bank -- one reason why Britain has resisted joining.
Yet President Jacques Chirac of France was insistent on making Mr. Trichet, 55, a candidate for the presidency of the European central bank even after all the other countries and their central bankers had agreed on Mr. Duisenberg, 63.
Alistair Campbell, spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, whose country presided over the heated closed discussions, said Mr. Duisenberg had agreed to step down after the euro actually replaces the franc, the mark and other national currencies in mid-2002.
But Germany, where popular resistance to the new currency is strong and Mr. Kohl is battling against the odds for election to a fifth term in September, backed Mr. Duisenberg in refusing to agree in writing to a specific date, officials said. The bank's charter, the 1992 Treaty on European Union, specifies that the president's term is eight years.
"Mr. Duisenberg has indicated he doesn't want to stay for a full term," Mr. Campbell said. "Mr. Duisenberg should decide when he goes, rather than politicians."
But Peter Praet, a Belgian economist, said: "The central bank will have to recover from this attack on its credibility. The damage is done." Any damage will be attributed to France, which more than any other country wants a strong euro to stand up to the dollar on world markets.
The nations that join the common currency have agreed to keep their budget deficits to 3 percent of their gross national product. Germany insisted on that stiff requirement because of concerns about giving up its strong mark. That requirement has caused years of anti-inflationary, deficit-cutting policies by countries that wanted to join the euro. Those austerity measures, skeptics say, have taken a terrible political and economic toll, causing governments to fall, driving unemployment up to double digits and dooming much of the Continent to years of stagnation.
"The common currency has become the emperor's clothing in the Andersen fairy tale, with no important responsible politician willing to play the role of the little boy and tell the emperor, in this case the people, the truth," Emmanuel Todd, a French historian, wrote in a best-selling book, "The Economic Illusion," this spring.
Nobody really knows how a common currency will work among countries so big and economically disparate. "If the common currency works well, Great Britain will be in a position to take a decision very rapidly," Mr. Blair said before the meetings started.
But his Labor Government decided to wait and see what happens in 2002, when the the euro actually replaces national currencies, before deciding whether to join.
People and companies can start writing checks and keeping accounts in euros starting in January.
The European leaders here also planned to fix the value of the 11 currencies that are to be merged, freezing them against each other until the end of the year, when the value of the euro will be decided. If it were established on Monday, the euro would probably be worth about $1.10, close to the value of the floating European Currency Unit now on international currency markets.
The common currency is not yet the single currency that European Union leaders dreamed of in 1992, when the last customs duties were eliminated among European member nations. Even the 11 countries that will share the euro do not always think about money the same way, laying the groundwork for potential political clashes over the right monetary and economic policies they should follow with the euro when the next recession strikes.
Germany's collective memory includes the trauma of 1923, when hyperinflation made the mark worthless, and the German Bundesbank's charter in 1957 gave it the sole mission of "safeguarding the currency." But in 1958, France's currency had become so inflated that the Government took the step of decreeing 100 old francs worth a single new one and started all over, and millions of French people still tote up sums in their heads in old francs.
So central bankers and conservative politicians in Germany and the Netherlands tend to be much more skeptical than their French counterparts that Italy and Spain have actually got the better of free-spending deficit habits that sent inflation spiraling in earlier decades.
Despite the high hopes that are accompanying the adoption of the euro, the experience of the European Union suggests that abiding by a single monetary policy will not be easy. The European Union today is the world's biggest trading power, with a single trade policy for all its members, a single agricultural policy and a single market of 340 million people in its 15 member nations, expected to swell to 20 or more countries in the next decade.
European nations linked their currencies loosely together in the 1970's after the United States abandoned the gold standard and currencies were allowed to fluctuate in value on world money markets. Most were following Germany's lead by the late 1980's, since Germany had been most successful in fighting inflation.
But when Germany raised interest rates to ward off inflationary pressures caused by unification in 1990, its neighbors had to follow suit or see their currencies devalued by the markets. A result in France, Britain and eventually Italy was a recession and double-digit unemployment.
Britain and Italy had to bail out of the system in 1992. Liberated from the need to keep interest rates high and free of many of the inflexible welfare-state work rules of continental economies, Britain has boomed ever since.
France pursued monetary union as a way of getting out from under the domination of the Bundesbank while leaving most of its welfare state intact. Mr. Chirac, earlier a skeptic about the process, rallied to it and backed deficit-reduction measures that included an attempt to cut back retirement pensions for railroad workers.
That aroused French public outrage, which helped defeat the Gaullists last spring. French workers staged a national transportation strike in 1995 that paralyzed the country for three weeks and forced the Government to back down.
Last year, Mr. Chirac lost a gamble that voters would grit their teeth and back more conservative austerity moves to make the common currency a reality. Instead, they voted for a Socialist Government headed by Prime Minister Lionel Jospin.
So far, the French have been able to avoid making further budget cuts because the French economy bounced back at the end of 1997. But Mr. Jospin, backed by Mr. Chirac, pressed other European partners to keep political pressure on the new central bank to make job creation and economic growth as much a priority as controlling inflation.

HEADLINE: WEEKEND GETAWAYS;
The Madison Tale

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER; BARNABY J. FEDER is a reporter in the Chicago bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
I'M affectionate, loyal and a touch sentimental, but I have no flair for romance, which explains why I was a bit worried last spring as my 10th wedding anniversary approached. We had agreed to celebrate with an overnight getaway from Chicago and our three small children, but it was my job to choose the spot and I fretted that my wife, Michele, would be disappointed. My anxiety grew when I discovered that my first choice, the historic lodge at the scenic Starved Rock State Park on the Illinois River, was fully booked through winter.
Fortunately, I had a safe backup less than a three hours' drive away, in Madison, Wis.: a combination bookstore, cafe and inn called the Canterbury. We had enjoyed a brief stop at the cafe and bookstore a year before when our family passed through town. And I figured that the inn, with each room lavishly painted to celebrate a different chapter of Chaucer's "Canterbury Tales," would provide a mix of bawdiness and whimsy appropriate to a happy decade of marriage. 
 The July Saturday our trip began was the hottest day of the year. And the drive to Madison from Chicago, through miles of suburbs followed by vast corn- and soybean-covered prairie, will never make anyone's list of vacation thrills. But from the moment we passed along the shore of Lake Monona into Madison, we knew we had come to the right place.
Madison is routinely voted one of America's most livable cities. Founded in 1836 and named for President James Madison, who died that year, the city is blessed with a stunning setting: Lake Monona is flanked by two smaller lakes, Wingra and Waubesa, and the downtown area is squeezed into a hilly, eight-block-wide isthmus between Monona and the far larger Lake Mendota. Boating, swimming, hiking and biking opportunities abound -- with nearly 100 miles of bike trails, the city claims to have more bikes than cars. The 200,000 residents enjoy a strong economy and the rich cultural life that goes with being both the state capital and the home of the University of Wisconsin, which occupies a wooded 1,000-acre campus on Mendota's shore.
But Madison is really more like a large town in many ways, which is helpful to anyone making a quick visit. We were more than ready for lunch when we arrived, so we were delighted that it took us less than 15 minutes to get across Madison and check in at the Canterbury.
In the heart of the city in a nondescript 70-year-old brick building, the Canterbury once housed a car dealer, a nightclub and offices before Trudy Barash decided to open a bookstore and coffeehouse there in 1991. Two years later, Mrs. Barash and her husband bought the building and converted the upstairs into a six-room bed-and-breakfast. A small sitting room serves as an upstairs common area. The cloakroom-sized check-in desk at the base of the stairway has a separate entrance from the bookstore and cafe (the coffeehouse became a cafe as the menu expanded to serve overnight guests).
Since the Canterbury's rooms are not usually ready for occupancy until 4 P.M., we left our bag at the desk and zipped into the cafe, which features pastas, sandwiches, salads, desserts, wines and local beers and, of course, a wide range of coffee concoctions. The cafe is a roomy alcove with sit-down service for about 50 patrons. Some of the tables are set up to accommodate chess players, and other board games are also available, along with newspapers.
Once we had refreshed ourselves, we ventured out into the oppressively tropical air. We were thankful that the inn is only half a block from State Street, a funky half-mile strip of food, music, craft and clothing shops that runs from the university campus to the imposing state capitol building, which took over a decade to build starting in 1906. The domed white granite structure sits surrounded by lawn, gardens and towering trees on a hilltop in the center of town.
On another day we might have been sorry that we arrived too late for the Farmers' Market, one of the Midwest's largest, which rings the capitol on Saturday mornings from May through October. And had it been cooler, we would have stuck to our original plan to rent bikes and head out to the University Arboretum, a 1,200-acre refuge on the south shore of Lake Wingra with gardens and miles of trails through prairie and woodland landscapes. But it was so hot that we were content to dip in and out of the shops. I bought a sports shirt on sale at Jazzman and Michele struck paydirt at the Peacock, a quirky import boutique where she found two dresses, each less than $80, and a patchwork something-or-other that had the cut of a sweatshirt and the feel of a thinly quilted jacket, 50 percent off at $24.
In one of the music shops we found cassette tapes by Peter and Lou Berryman, a local folk-singing duo. I snapped up "Double Yodel," which has their song "Orange Cocoa Cake," a snapshot of a mother trying simultaneously to telephone a friend with a recipe and handle three children. It has been my nominee for the funniest song about motherhood ever since I first heard another singer's live version three years ago.
We left the stores behind to visit the Elvehjem Museum of Art on the university campus just beyond the end of State Street. Like many museums in smaller cities, it has that special mixture of secondary works by famous artists and beautiful surprises by local painters or other less familiar artists. We loved a small Georgia O'Keeffe painting of a single turkey feather in a ceramic vase and a Jack Butler Yeats longshoreman. There was also a large exhibition of Hiroshige prints that were originally collected by Frank Lloyd Wright, who got his start in Madison and was deeply influenced by the brilliant Japanese printmaker. (Wright's best known work in Madison is the First Unitarian Society Meeting House; he also designed a few houses there.)
The museum visit came to an unexpectedly dramatic finale shortly before closing time when tornado sirens began wailing. After a brief wait in the basement, we headed back down State Street to the inn under glowering but rainless skies.
We returned too late to sample the complimentary wine and cheese the Canterbury sends to the sitting room each afternoon, but our room, the Reeve's, turned out to be so delightful we could not help laughing. Although it is the second-smallest of the six at the Canterbury (only the Clerk's offers tighter quarters), it felt intimate rather than cramped. In addition to vivid murals depicting the avid bed-swapping of the characters in Chaucer's Reeve's tale, there was framed poetry and artwork celebrating books on several walls, a huge armoire containing a stereo system with CD player, TV and VCR facing the queen-sized bed, a love seat, a beautifully tiled bathroom stocked with luxury soaps, a small kitchen area with freshly baked cookies and a refrigerator containing free juices, bottled water and soda.
A copy of "The Canterbury Tales" lay on the bedside table, a version of the Reeve's tale with space for guests to leave their impressions on many pages lay by the telephone, and the bookcase was filled with an eclectic assortment of novels, poetry and nonfiction. I enjoyed discovering the poetry of Ronald Wallace, a local writer who described memory as "God's best punch line."
Our room, and the others we peeked into Sunday before we left, also had Scrabble and chess sets. The top-of-the-line Merchant's Room has a separate sitting and reading area and a whirlpool in the bathroom.
It was hard to leave such a cozy space once we settled in. Still, we were not going to miss our 7:30 dinner reservation at L'Etoile, one of Madison's most popular restaurants. L'Etoile had been fully booked when our check-in clerk at the Canterbury phoned for us shortly after our arrival, but happily there was a cancellation. It was a short walk to the restaurant, on the second floor of a small building at the north end of the Capitol grounds. Our window seat allowed us to watch fireflies popping up from the Capitol lawns.
L'Etoile's menu is built around organic meat and produce. My main course was tender pork garnished with currants accompanied by a potato-hickory nut side dish. Michele's Black Angus tenderloin was perfect. The hickory nut cake with peach ice cream we shared was delicious and the whole thing, with drinks, came to about $80.
Afterward we strolled to the new Monona Terrace convention center on Lake Monona, which had opened only the week before. Based on a bold 1938 proposal by Frank Lloyd Wright that the site be used for a huge architecturally dramatic civic center topped with fountains and glass domes, the center's public space includes rooftop gardens, where we encountered endearing evidence that Madison is a big town at heart. Visitors wended their way over hundreds of tiles bearing names, dates, or brief inscriptions from local residents who had donated money to the project. Almost all the people around us seemed to be looking for their own tiles or those of someone they knew, generating wonderful eavesdropping opportunities for us.
Back at the Canterbury, before heading for bed, we tarried for well over an hour in the bookstore and more than used up the $10 gift certificate that came with our room.
Our Continental breakfast was also included in the price of our room ($175, with tax). We chose a cheerful mixture of fresh fruit and muffins, served in the small upstairs sitting room. Other visitors preferred to have breakfast in their rooms.
State Street was just beginning to come to life when we ventured out. We headed for Shakespeare's, a huge second-hand book store facing the Capitol. While the Canterbury bookstore is fun, it had surprising gaps. Michele had been disappointed not to find a copy of Allen Ginsberg's "Kaddish." Shakespeare's had it, along with a copy of "Yankee From Olympus," Catherine Drinker Bowen's out-of-print biography of Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. that we had been looking for ever since we realized that ours had not come back the last time we lent it out.
After prying ourselves loose from Shakespeare's, we visited several art galleries, had terrific hamburgers for lunch at the accurately named Sunroom Cafe a block from the university, and then reluctantly gathered our gear for the drive home.
We stopped by Babcock Hall, home of the university's school of dairy science, in search of straight-from-the-cow ice cream but discovered that the ice cream parlor was closed on Sundays. Well, no getaway is perfect. We drove off, the Berrymans on the tape deck.
 
If you go
 
Where to Stay

Where to Eat
Canterbury Cafe, 315 West Gorham; (800) 838-3850. Specialty coffee and desserts for two, about $13 with tax. Meal with dessert and beer for two, about $32 with tax.
L'Etoile, 25 North Pinckney, (608) 251-0500. Dinner for two (including appetizers, desserts) with wine, about $100 with tax.
Sunroom Cafe and Gallery, 638 State Street, (608) 255-1555. Burgers and iced tea for two, about $15 with tax.
 
What to See
Elvehjem Museum of Art, 800 University Avenue, (608) 263-2246. Free. Open Tuesday to Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., Saturday and Sunday 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Closed Monday.
Monona Terrace Community and Convention Center, 1 John Nolen Drive. (608) 261-4000. Open daily 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tours available at 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. for $2; free on Monday and Tuesday.
State Capitol, (608) 266-0382. Free hourly tours start at 9 A.M. Monday through Saturday, 1 P.M. on Sunday.
For more information via the Internet, go to www.visitmadison.com.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
The Piggy-Bank Chronicles

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE

 BODY:
YOU know the type.
* Suzanna Markstein, 26, and an editorial assistant at Mademoiselle magazine, bought her first I.R.A. when she was 22. She had just graduated from college and earned only $6,000 that year but still managed to stash away $2,000. "Friends with similar salaries are certainly better dressed than I am," she says with little regret: Her $2,000 could grow to $55,000 or more by the time she reaches 65 -- in 2037. 
 * Kathryn and J. P. Clejan, a Manhattan couple in their 30's, put aside money every month for college for their 2-year-old son, Andre, and analyze every spending decision to a fare-thee-well. When the Clejans -- she works for a health company; he's a computer management consultant -- bought a ski house in Vermont, their preproject estimate of $20,000 for furnishings "came in so close it was scary," Ms. Clejan said. "We don't spend like most people in New York, on big dinners out and Broadway shows."
* Jim Flewelling saved enough of his earnings managing a small manufacturing company to toss it all in 1995, live off his nest egg and take things easy, doing a little traveling and dabbling in financial writing. At 48, he tells people he is "voluntarily unemployed": "Nobody likes to hear somebody in their 40's say they are retired."
They're the people who floss their financial teeth after every meal. They have zero-body-fat credit cards. They are supersavers.
And they can drive the rest of us, who struggle to salt away a little money for retirement or beat back impulsive spending, more than a little crazy. Sure, the supersavers' prudence and self-denial will probably leave them in the catbird seat financially come retirement, while most people wonder how they will ever catch up. But it may not just be envy that leads ordinary people to wonder whether supersavers might be overdoing it just a little.
Take heart: there may well be such a thing as oversaving.
Needless to say, very few people save too much. Most Americans are woefully unprepared for retirement, which nowadays might last longer than careers do.
And, of course, calculations about financial conditions many years in the future are fraught with uncertainty: Someone could save far too much, or far too little, and not know which for decades to come, because of imponderables like the fate of Social Security and inflation rates, wars and the stock market. Any decision is ultimately personal, springing as much from one's comfort zone as from material circumstances.
But it is clear that some members of the middle class have made themselves ultra-ready for whatever the future holds -- and actually relish life on a budget.
Such thriftiness can give a great sense of security to ride out storms, but it can also set some often-overlooked traps for the unwary. "If done to excess, savers take quality out of their lives," said Stephen M. Pollan, whose advice is summed up in the title of his business best seller, "Die Broke" (Harper Business, 1995), written with Mark Levine. "The guys who built the Pyramids were savers," putting aside possessions for the next life, Mr. Pollan said.
For instance, giant nest-egg builders might find themselves disqualified from Government benefits like Social Security and Medicare that now use or may adopt means tests. "You could save yourself out of a program you would otherwise be entitled to," Mr. Pollan said.
Tightened means tests for college financial aid already make it difficult for average middle-class families -- let alone supersavers -- to qualify for grants.
Supersavers may also be overreacting to the sirens of Wall Street, who have a strong vested interest in promoting oversaving because savings are generally invested in ways that will generate fees and commissions.
Those whose main focus is retirement may discover that they have tied up too much of their money in illiquid, though lucrative, retirement plans, and have trouble coping with big expenses or buying a house.
And extreme thrift can be dangerously habit-forming. Some people who make a cause of putting away for a rainy day find that, after decades of strict saving, they can't flip off the switch, and they miss out on some joys of life.
"The healthy use of money is really a reflection of self-image," said Kathleen Gurney, who runs the Financial Psychology Corporation, a company on Lake Tahoe in Nevada that tries to give clients insight into their financial behavior. The goal, according to Dr. Gurney, is to save and spend flexibly, not rigidly, and to make choices based on a sense of one's self and one's family.
CLOCKWORK savers who lack such flexibility may also lack the dash of the true entrepreneur, who earns more but saves less. Entrepreneurs "allow money to flow in and out of their lives and tolerate anxiety or volatility in the market," Dr. Gurney said.
Supersavers, on the other hand, often emphasize economy for its own sake. Dr. Gurney cites the example of a retired pediatrician who always wanted an ocean view but lived in a little trailer to get it. "She said, 'I never felt I could afford anything.' "
Dennis Filangeri, a certified planner in Metairie, La., described a client who lives on $75,000 a year, though he has a gross income of $150,000. He drives a Lexus, but he bought it used.
But Mr. Filangeri said that client hardly fit the caricature of a miserable miser. "He's not unhappy and doesn't feel he's depriving himself," Mr. Filangeri said. "And he's not going to stop being frugal."
Annoyingly, perhaps, there is no law requiring that zealous savers be maladjusted personalities.
In his career as a manager, Mr. Flewelling, the 48-year-old retiree, "never made close to earning $100,000 in a year and never expected to come close." When he turned 30, he and his wife, Sandra, a software engineer, decided to save their way to early retirement, and for the next 15 years the Flewellings put aside an average of 60 percent of their gross income every year. "We wanted to have the choice to work, or not," he said. Now, Mr. Flewelling doesn't, and she does, but only three days a week, two of them at home.
And the childless couple still keep saving money. "We've planned through age 90 to make sure the money lasts," Mr. Flewelling said.
But deep down, he says, "the purpose of having money isn't to have it, it's to be able to use it, whether now or 40 years from now," The Flewellings mete out their fun, traveling once or twice a year.
A balance of saving and spending is emphasized by Dr. James Gottfurcht, a psychologist in Los Angeles specializing in behavioral issues related to money. He says that when he meets clients, he asks: "What's the quality of their life? How much is money interfering in their free time? Are they obsessive, or enjoying life? If they are enjoying it and each other, and a rich quality of life, that way threads their needle."
NONETHELESS, some zealous savers may need a bit of reminding, especially at retirement. "To my extreme surprise, half the time I tell retired clients not to spend as much, and half the time to spend more," said Robin Sherwood, a financial planner in New Canaan, Conn. "One of my key jobs is to tell them what's appropriate to spend."
Dr. Gurney said that when she bought a cottage in a French village, she dismissed the questions from friends who wondered, "Couldn't you have used your money more wisely?" No one in France would ask that question, she said:
"I go to France to feed my soul. It is one of the wisest things I have ever done for myself."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TRIBECA;
Trees, Traffic and a Street Fight

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
The greening of Greenwich, a plan to plant trees on Greenwich Street and narrow it to two lanes from six on the eight blocks between Hubert and Chambers Streets, is a relatively small project. But there is nothing small about the dust-up it is causing, involving a titan of commerce, well-known restaurant owners and a movie star.
Conceived more than a decade ago, the plan was delayed by financing and planning difficulties until last year, when everything seemed to fall into place. The $2 million project awaited only final approval from the city's Economic Development Corporation. 
 But some residents and business owners began complaining that the street would be too narrow, resulting in traffic congestion. Among the most vocal critics were the restaurateurs Tracy Nieporent and his brother Drew, who own TriBeCa Grill on Greenwich Street and Nobu, the celebrity favorite on Hudson and Franklin Streets. They want three traffic lanes, and have said so, repeatedly, to local and city officials.
Now the plan has stalled again. "These guys seem only to be concerned about continuing the double- and triple-parking of their customers' limousines," said Paul Goldstein, the manager of Community Board 1.
Tracy Nieporent insists that is not true, and that a new traffic study will back up his concerns about congestion. But John Petrarcha, a community board member and a director of Friends of Greenwich Street, a group supporting the plan, said four studies have found no potential traffic problems. A state study, he added, showed that unless Greenwich Street is narrowed soon, traffic will spill over from newly reconstructed West Street, which will have more signals.
A February meeting between project advocates and opponents ended in a standoff. Since then, proponents of the plan have secured letters of support from, among others, Representative Jerrold L. Nadler and from Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of the Travelers Group, whose headquarters are diagonally across from the TriBeCa Grill.
Even Robert De Niro, who is a restaurant partner with the Nieporents, favors the project. "Tracy Nieporent does not speak for Robert De Niro on this issue," said Jane Rosenthal, co-founder of Mr. De Niro's TriBeCa Film Center, in the same building as the TriBeCa Grill. "He has always been in favor of the greening of Greenwich."
Charles Millard, the chairman of the E.D.C., said he hoped to help the parties "resolve their differences." He declined to respond when asked whether the Nieporents are applying behind-the-scenes pressure, as some local officials privately suggest. Tracy Nieporent said that despite such talk there has been no such pressure. He said he and his brother "want trees."
"Our opposition has nothing to do with limousines," he said. "It has to do with the future of Greenwich Street." BERNARD STAMLER

CORRECTION-DATE: May 10, 1998, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption last Sunday about a street-widening plan in lower Manhattan misidentified the street. As the article said, it was Greenwich Street, not Greenwich Avenue.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 29; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 1266 words

HEADLINE: Over the Moon About Cows

BYLINE: By SUZANNE WINCKLER; SUZANNE WINCKLER is the author of "The Heartland" volume of the Smithsonian Guides to Natural America series.

 BODY:
IN Texas, where I am from, I spent a lot of time driving around. After some years of traveling up and down U.S. Highway 77, which cuts through the vast King Ranch, on trips related mainly to watching birds, I developed a love for Santa Gertrudis cattle. Love is not exactly the right word, but something synonymous, like fondness, is even farther off the mark. There may not be a word to describe how I feel. I just know that Santa Gertrudis became important fixed points in my moving landscape.
A Santa Gertrudis is boxy and chocolate brown and looks like a plush ottoman for a giant. It has big, brown eyes rimmed in pink, a detail that, improbable as it sounds, is visible from a vehicle moving at a fairly high rate of speed. 
 The breed was developed on the King Ranch in the early 1900's by crossing British Shorthorn and Indian Brahman cattle. It was named for Santa Gertrudis Creek, the sweetwater stream flowing through the otherwise arid coastal plain where Capt. Richard King, who once commanded steamboats, set up headquarters in the 1850's for the cow camp that eventually became the King Ranch. The mission was to create an animal capable of withstanding the hostile conditions and stifling heat that prevail much of the year, and the mission was achieved. Santa Gertrudis standing in the shade of a live oak motte on a hot, windless day is the essence of South Texas. Just the thought of this tableau makes me homesick.
It wasn't only Santa Gertrudis. I became enamored of Brahman cattle, which are also fixtures on the mirage-shimmering South Texas landscape. Brahmans are lean and bony and draped with an ill-fitting hide that is mottled in many beautiful shades of gray. One of my proudest possessions is a 12-inch-tall ceramic Brahman bull obtained from the proprietor of a used-furniture and knickknack store I stopped in years ago near McAllen, Tex. She would not sell me the one behind the counter -- it was her husband's, she said -- but made another for me.
While my bovine lust, or whatever it was, manifested itself with these two breeds, it began to dawn on me that cattle of any sort standing out in whatever wide world I was driving through held a great appeal. A herd of dairy cows, a scattering of grazing beef cattle -- whatever the assemblage -- seemed to me at once familiar and mysterious. By any definition of rural America, cattle are an indivisible part of the terrain, but what exactly are they doing out there? Who owns them? What is their significance to a particular place, to its culture and economy? In the mid-1980's, I developed a somewhat casual course of study whereby I would try to determine the names of the breeds I encountered and to gain at least a thimbleful of knowledge about them and about cattle on their home ground.
This has not been easy. I have bookshelves full of guides to birds, bats, plants, snakes, trees, insects, historic sites, cities, restaurants, architectural wonders, but I have never come across a field guide to livestock. I find the dearth of information amazing, because a person traveling across this continent is much more likely to see a cow than, say, a whooping crane. Could it be that I am the only nonagrarian in America who cares to distinguish between a Guernsey and a Charolais?
There is now some information on the Internet. To see a Santa Gertrudis without driving to South Texas, you can beam one up via www.king-ranch.com. The best survey of livestock I've found so far on the Web is at www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle. I'm happy to have this information. It will suffice in the absence of facts bundled in a fashion I find more useful, i.e., in a book I can throw on the seat of my car.
For a couple of years I wandered around livestock exhibitions -- places like the Houston Livestock Show and Rodeo -- up and down aisles of gorgeous steers. I recall the hind ends of many huge purebreds, like chalk-white Charolais or burnished-red Limousin, being groomed by youngsters for the show ring. In 1985, a black baldy was chosen grand champion of the Houston show, a major arbiter of livestock, which at the time caused quite a stir. A black baldy would be a Hereford-Angus cross.
Black baldy is one of my favorite names because it actually gives a clue to what the animal looks like: typically it is jet black, like an Angus, with a Hereford's white blaze (hence baldy) on the nose. The win presaged a shift in cattle fashion from gargantuan steers like the Limousin, which had held sway through much of the 1970's and 80's, to more compact models like the black baldy. The shift actually had meaning in the real world of livestock production and market efficiencies: it takes too much time and feed to grow a giant steer.
Black baldies are a motley crew, which is another reason to like them. Because they are a crossbreed -- also referred to in the cattle business as a composite -- and because a producer will often throw other breeds into the mix besides Angus and Hereford, a bunch of black baldies standing out in a pasture can be quite varied in markings and coloration, a great display of genetic pyrotechnics.
Black baldies are still an industry mainstay, at least along the roads I'm driving these days. Thirteen years ago I moved from Texas to Minnesota, then six years later to Nebraska. Adios, Santa Gertrudis, bye-bye Brahman. My cow landscapes vastly changed.
IN Minnesota I lived in the southeastern corner of the state in a rented farmhouse surrounded by corn, soybeans and alfalfa. This was farm country, a quilt of small, discrete ownerships, decidedly more ordered than the cow country that makes up much of Texas. I drove around a lot in Minnesota, too, and in nearby Iowa, on birding trips or visiting remnant prairies or simply staring out the car window at what seemed to me a very exotic landscape.
People there either have small herds of beef cattle or keep dairy cows, of which the most vivid of all are the Holsteins. So bold, so black and white, so lovely standing on a greensward!
The main roads I travel now unfurl from urban Omaha into deeply rural terrain. It is a great base for a cow watcher. Omaha is four degrees east of the 100th meridian, the standard marker of where the West begins, which means it sits on the edges of two very different agricultural worlds. If I want cows in a Grant Wood landscape I go east; if I want something more along the lines of Remington or Russell, I go west.
A pleasant back road is Route 92, which heads east out of Omaha, over roly-poly hills straight into "Bridges of Madison County" country and the town of Winterset, birthplace of John Wayne. Though I seldom defend Interstates, I-80 between Des Moines and the Missouri River is quite splendid, and in winter it can be surreal. Everyone knows it's cold out here then, but few people appreciate how foggy it can get in December and January. When there is snow and fog, and the ground and sky are indistinguishable, it is the cows looming out in the corn -- most of them black baldies -- that provide a frame of reference.
When I head west it is usually into the Sandhills, an exquisite expanse of grass-stabilized sand dunes that occupies a large chunk of north-central Nebraska, via Highway 2 out of Grand Island. I am not the first person to remark that this is one of the most beautiful drives in America. For birding and cowing, there's nothing like a trip between April and June into the Sandhills, which combines an abundance of songbirds and waterfowl with an assortment of brown, blue-gray, brindled and brock-faced cows and calves.

LENGTH: 1101 words

HEADLINE: Goodbye to Momism

BYLINE: By Carol Tavris; Carol Tavris, a social psychologist, is the author of "The Mismeasure of Woman."

 BODY:

A MOTHER'S PLACE
 Taking the Debate About Working Mothers
 Beyond Guilt and Blame.
 By Susan Chira.
 318 pp. New York:
 HarperCollins Publishers. $25. 
 Although I am not an expert on motherhood, I am an expert on motherhood books. I have lived long enough to witness about a dozen cycles of contradictory advice -- work/don't work; day care is good/day care is bad; don't work for the child's first six months/six years/lifetime -- that clarify one's perspective on the mom business wonderfully.
But it's also why reading Susan Chira's splendid book was both pleasing and depressing. Pleasing, because Chira, the deputy foreign editor of The New York Times, makes an eloquent, well-documented case that motherhood does not require martyrdom and self-obliteration; that motherhood and outside work are not only compatible but also beneficial to mothers and children; that day care does not harm children (on the contrary, it often improves their social and intellectual skills); and that much of what passes as "expert advice" is biased opinion, which is why it changes so rapidly with changing political climates and economic conditions.
"A Mother's Place" is depressing, however, because it makes me feel like Rip Van Winkle, awakening to the exact same arguments about working mothers that modern feminists were raising in the 1970's -- and that their predecessors were in the 1920's. Do we really need to be shown again that time spent with children is not the ultimate measure of good motherhood? That stay-at-home mothers who are bored, resentful, punitive, depressed or anxious about finances aren't going to be so great for their kids? It seems so.
The need for this book means that one of the most important messages of contemporary feminism and decades-old research in the social sciences has yet to penetrate even the skin of American culture: namely, that a mother's working does not, in and of itself, harm children. A woman (or, increasingly, a man) may want to stay home and watch the children develop; she (or he) may want to give up the corporate rat race. But this decision is a matter of preference, not a requirement for raising healthy children. Yet this preference is supported by a society that is still deeply suspicious of mothers who wish to work, need to work, or, God help them, love to work.
Chira wrote this book, she says, because she kept hearing "that what I wanted was impossible -- to be serious about both my work and motherhood." In the 1960's, women began to dispute the "cult of domesticity" of the 1950's, vigorously advocating that women could and should do both. That was news then. By the 1980's, after the mass influx of women into the labor market, the news was the women who were giving up their careers. Today the new news (again) is that women can combine work and motherhood. Chira's book, along with "The Sacrificial Mother," by Carin Rubenstein, and "When Mothers Work," by Joan K. Peters, is part of the latest turn of the wheel.
This endless debate about "a mother's place" could occur only in a culture that gives mothers no help, provides no universal and reliable system of day care, and then blames mothers for whatever they do: work (if they are middle-class), not work (if they are on welfare), work too much (if they are ambitious), or work too little (if they aren't ambitious enough and gutlessly take the "mommy track").
I mustn't be too curmudgeonly, however, about women's continual rediscovery of the mother-work dilemma. Motherhood, like illness, is another country: If you haven't been there, you can't quite imagine it. You can read about it, sympathize with those who have crossed the border, fume about the inherent unfairness of its burdens, but nothing takes the place of experience. That's why childless women can delusionally believe that having children won't affect their lives. And it's why they desperately start looking to experts for help once actual children arrive.
So, setting aside my sense of deja vu when reading Chira's book, I wholeheartedly recommend it to politicians, pediatricians, fathers and especially working mothers who feel buffeted by incessant criticism. These are perilous times for mothers who work outside the home, as revealed by the speed with which the trial of Louise Woodward, the au pair found guilty of the death of Matthew Eappen, was transformed into a trial of the baby's mother.
The national antipathy toward Deborah Eappen for having the temerity to work -- even if it was only three days a week, even if she came home for lunch, even if she taught her au pairs CPR and child-care skills -- is reflected, Chira demonstrates, in custody decisions nationwide. Judges routinely reward fathers who take any part in child rearing, and they routinely punish mothers who aren't home with the kids full time. Of course, staying home often means a mother doesn't have money to contest an ex-husband who sues for custody on the grounds that he earns more money than she does. And it often means that women won't have enough money in Social Security or pension plans to provide for their old age. But, hey, aren't women supposed to be self-sacrificing?
Chira's book is a harmonious blend of her own experiences, interviews and research. Her concerns about leaving her children in the care of others, her jealousy when her children turn to their father instead of to her for comfort, and her insecurity about how to balance work demands with those of her family will resonate with many women. She wittily dissects the baby-care advice biz, pointing out the stay-at-home bias of modern gurus such as Penelope Leach. And she highlights what social science has reliably indicated for years -- that there is no one right way to be a mother, that kids do fine as long as they get love and attention, and that parents are not the sole influence on their children, regardless of how much time and money parents lavish on them.
As Chira shows in her brilliant last chapter, "Reimagining Motherhood," it is time to drop that tired, unanswerable question -- "does working harm children?" -- and move to the more important one: how can we make sure it doesn't? It is time to replace "does day care harm children?" with efforts to make child care available to all who need it. Until we do, mothers will continue to feel defensive about the choices they make and blame those who make different ones. Who benefits from this division among women, and from blaming women for whatever choice they make? Those who want women out of the workplace and out of politics. Who loses? Everyone.

HEADLINE: Yeltsin's Tax Reform

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Anders Aslund (Op-Ed, April 28) suggests that the Russian state is still too large and needs further shrinking. He says that the Government "collected 32 percent of Russia's gross domestic product last year, the same proportion that the United States does." This is somewhat misleading. 
 The Russian Government collected 11 percent of gross domestic product in revenues in 1997, while the United States collected 23 percent. On top of that, Russian regional and local governments collected another 15 percent, and off-budget funds for pensions, health and social security another 6 percent.
Certainly, Russia needs to reform its system of public administration. But the federal Government also needs to increase tax revenue -- to pay its employees decent wages on time and to complete projects like the dismantling of nuclear and chemical weapons that are important to the United States.
 
PETER RUTLAND
Middletown, Conn., May 1, 1998
 
The writer is an associate professor of government at Wesleyan University.

HEADLINE: Income Gap Widens

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "U.S. Economy Grew at Brisk Pace This Winter Despite Crisis in Asia" (front page, May 1): 
 Glowing reports on the economy obscure the struggle of the average worker and the widening income gap between the rich, the middle and lower classes. As of March 18, 1998, the average hourly wage according to the Department of Labor was $12.60 per hour, while in 1973 the average was $13.58 (in 1996 dollars). Since 1973 the average worker's salary has decreased in value, while corporations have experienced booming returns to the applause of Wall Street.
 
PATRICK LANGHENRY
New York, May 1, 1998

HEADLINE: Immigrants Moving Up

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While the Urban Institute's disaggregation of legal immigrants, illegal immigrants and refugees sheds some new light on the immigration issue (news article, April 30), the disaggregation stops short of a more sensitive fact: immigrants from some regions do better than immigrants from others. 
 The report concludes that after 15 years of residence, legal immigrants in New York as a whole make more money and pay more taxes than natives, although they have higher rates of welfare use as they move into the economic mainstream.
The Rand Corporation's 1997 report, "Immigration in a Changing Economy," concludes that the income of Chinese, Korean and Japanese immigrants substantially exceeds that of natives after 10 years in the United States, while the income of Latin American immigrants is significantly below average after much longer periods. Few people take comfort from this disparity, but it is a reality that needs to be addressed.
 
LAWRENCE E. HARRISON
Vineyard Haven, Mass., April 30, 1998
