HEADLINE: What Antitrust Is All About

BYLINE: By Robert H. Bork; Robert H. Bork, a fellow of the American Enterprise Institute, is representing Netscape in its efforts against Microsoft.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Rarely does a prospective antitrust case roil public passion. But since it became known that I represent a company urging the Justice Department to challenge certain of Microsoft's business practices, my mail has certainly livened up. One letter writer complained that I had sold my "sole." His spelling aside, that writer was at least kinder than the one who labeled me senile.
There seems to be a widespread impression that the Microsoft controversy should be resolved by an ideological litmus test: liberals are bent on punishing success, and conservatives must defend Bill Gates's company from any application of the antitrust laws. But the question is not one of politics or ideology; it is one of law and economics. And that is why an outspoken free marketeer like me can be found arguing against Microsoft. 
 Indeed, in Congress and among the players, liberals and conservatives, Democrats and Republicans are found on each side of the controversy. What, then, is the complaint of the many companies that are urging action by the Justice Department?
These companies -- customers as well as rivals of Microsoft -- challenge some of Microsoft's business practices as predatory, intended to preserve the company's monopoly of personal computer operating systems through practices that exclude or severely hinder rivals but do not benefit consumers. Microsoft's effort to maintain and expand a market dominance that now stands at 90 to 95 percent violates traditional antitrust principles. Specifically, it violates Section 2 of the Sherman Act, territory visited decades ago by the Supreme Court.
The case, from 1951, was Lorain Journal Company v. United States, and the Court's ruling is directly on point. The Journal, in the Court's description of the case, "enjoyed a substantial monopoly in Lorain, Ohio, of the mass dissemination of news and advertising." The daily newspaper had 99 percent coverage in the town.
"Those factors," the Court said, "made The Journal an indispensable medium of advertising for many Lorain concerns." A minor threat to The Journal's monopoly arose, however, with the establishment of radio station WEOL in a nearby town. The newspaper responded by refusing to accept local advertising from any Lorain County advertiser that used WEOL.
The Supreme Court called that an attempt to monopolize, illegal under Section 2 of the Sherman Act. There being no apparent efficiency justification for The Journal's action -- that is, no evidence that it resulted in an operation whose efficiency somehow benefited consumers -- it was deemed predatory. To those who say I have altered my longstanding position to represent an opponent of Microsoft, I'm happy to note that 20 years ago I wrote that the Lorain Journal case had been correctly decided.
The parallel between The Journal's action and Microsoft's behavior is exact. Microsoft has a similarly overwhelming market share, and it imposes conditions on those with whom it deals that exclude rivals without any apparent justification on the grounds of efficiency. In fact, the case against Microsoft is stronger, for there are many documents in the public domain that make clear that Microsoft specifically intended to crush competition.
We may not yet know all of the exclusionary practices, but we do know many. Here's a sampler:
* Microsoft's operating system licenses have forbidden "original equipment manufacturers" -- makers of personal computers -- to alter the first display screen from that required by Microsoft. Microsoft thus controls what the consumer sees. This restriction also hampers consumers' use of competing browsers to search the Internet or to serve as an alternative platform for other programs.
* Microsoft has restrained Internet service providers and on-line services, which are forced to deal with Microsoft because of its monopoly in the Windows system. For instance, it has forbidden service providers to advertise or promote any non-Microsoft Web browser or even mention that such a browser is available. Netscape and others are denied an important distribution channel to consumers.
* Companies that provide content on the Internet, to gain access to Microsoft's screen display, have been forced to agree not to promote content developed for competing platforms.
When a monopolist employs practices and makes agreements that exclude competitors and does so without the justification that the practices and agreements benefit consumers, the company is guilty, as was The Lorain Journal, of an attempt to monopolize in violation of Section 2 of the Sherman Act. When its own documents display a clear intent to monopolize through such means, the case is cold.
Netscape and the other companies seeking an end to these practices are not asking the Justice Department to take any action that would interfere in the slightest with Microsoft's ability to innovate. The department is simply being asked to stop Microsoft from stifling the innovations of others. The object is to create a level playing field benefiting consumers. That is what antitrust is about -- a view that should require no one to sell his "sole."

HEADLINE: Acquisition Set By Time Inc.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Time Inc. is buying the publisher of Mutual Funds Magazine and nine financial newsletters.
Time, a unit of Time Warner Inc., declined to disclose terms as it announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Institute for Econometric Research, which is based in Deerfield Beach, Fla. 
 The deal includes Mutual Funds Magazine, which was started in 1994 and has grown to a circulation of 750,000. as well as newsletters that include Mutual Fund Forecaster.
Time said the institute would continue as a stand-alone entity with its own editorial, sales and marketing staffs.
The institute's chairman, Glen King Parker; Mutual Funds Magazine's publisher, Edward C. Frey, and the magazine's editor in chief, Norman G. Fosback, will remain part of the management team, which will expand to include Time Inc. executives.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bump in Road to Euro May Signal Trouble Ahead
A messy political compromise that marred an agreement among European leaders to adopt a new single currency is likely to leave world markets more suspicious than before about the fledgling euro, financial analysts predicted. But few expect that when markets reopen today investors will react dramatically to the squabble, which involved naming a chief for the new European central bank. 
Over the longer term, however, the incident may contribute to a feeling among officials of the new central bank that they must err on the side of toughness and higher interest rates to demonstrate credibility. Page D2.
 
Journalism Turns Inward
While the 1970's may have been the "Me Decade," a new study of news coverage over the last two decades shows that journalism in the 1990's is far more oriented toward the personal than it was 20 years ago, when Tom Brokaw interviewed former President Gerald R. Ford. D8.
 
History Yields Mixed Lesson
The Freedom Forum's Newseum, which is dedicated to demystifying the news business, has mounted an impressive monument to the profession. An exercise in comparative history that brought journalists and news makers together at the Newseum to discuss press coverage in 1968 was impressive in its own way. Felicity Barringer: Press. D8.
 
Entertainment Option: Short Books
Series of short books, written by prominent authors, are coming from two big publishers who are hoping they can attract readers with the notion of works that can be read in a couple of hours. But critics wonder whether consumers will bite. D8.
 
Internet Shapes Curious Alliances
The Internet appears to be bringing together even stranger bedfellows than politics these days, with Bob Dole joining Ralph Nader in the fight against Microsoft, and Jack Kemp, long an opponent of government regulation, joining a freewheeling Internet telephony company. D4.
 
Data Pioneer Battles on New Front
An Internet pioneer who put S.E.C. data on line four years ago at no cost to computer users is now pushing the Government to make the nation's patent and trademark data base freely available. Carl Malamud says he will undertake the project himself as a guerrilla effort if the Government fails to respond. D6.
 
In Washington, meanwhile, Congress hopes to seize global leadership of the hotly disputed issue of protecting creative works in cyberspace. Legislators are completing work on a measure that would expand copyright protections to on-line material. D12.
 
A War Cry From the Cable Industry
Contending that they have lost some of the early public relations battles, cable operators plan to announce an organization to fight telephone companies over which industry will provide high-speed Internet access to people's homes. D9.
 
Ford Updating Advertising Theme
With the quality of American cars no longer the burning issue it was in the 1980's, Ford Motor has decided to jettison the commercial tagline it has used for the last 17 years, "Quality is job one." The new theme: "Better ideas. Driven by you." Advertising. D10.
 
Seat Belts Make Saddles Safer
A teen-age girl who once rode at the same stable as Christopher Reeve, the actor who was paralyzed in a riding accident, has patented a restraining belt that binds riders to their horses. Patents. D2.

HEADLINE: Better Public Housing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
If one person is unemployed and another person is earning minimum wage, and both live in poor conditions, should Federal housing policy punish the family of the person with a job? Your April 27 editorial suggests doing just that. Although the House and Senate are negotiating public housing reform, neither chamber's bill "redirects" assistance toward any group of residents at the expense of others. 
 The House bill lets authorities serve "working poor" families -- in which two people earn the minimum wage -- with vouchers. The Administration plan would force the working poor in many areas to compete for only 10 percent of the vouchers.
Our approach to public housing developments ends Federal preferences that resulted in the warehousing of the poorest of the poor. The real issue is whether this Administration and Congress are willing to make the rhetoric of mixed-income, healthy neighborhoods a reality for public-housing residents.
 
(Rep.) RICK LAZIO
Washington, April 29, 1998
 
The writer is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Housing.

HEADLINE: Chirac, the 'Bulldozer,' at the Birth of the Euro

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, May 3

 BODY:
If Europe gave out an award to politicians who shoot themselves in the foot, President Jacques Chirac of France might take the prize.
Two years ago, Mr. Chirac announced that France would like to rejoin the military structure of the NATO alliance 30 years after it pulled out. 
 Then he immediately made that impossible by demanding for France the senior NATO post in the Mediterranean, the Southern Command in Naples. It had always been held by an American admiral, since it would control the United States Sixth Fleet in wartime, and after Washington inevitably refused to give up the post, France decided to stay where it is: half in and half out of NATO.
Last year, Mr. Chirac -- whose conservatives controlled both houses of Parliament, the Government in Paris and most regional assemblies -- threw the electoral dice and called national elections in a gamble to win a mandate for austerity moves to get France ready for a common European currency.
The move was one of the most colossal blunders in French political history. Voters threw out Mr. Chirac's Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, and voted for a leftist majority in Parliament, forcing Mr. Chirac to share power with a Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin.
This year, the Gaullist parties that brought Mr. Chirac to the presidency three years ago have collapsed in recriminations about accepting support in regional assemblies from the far-right National Front. Even Paris, a Gaullist fief that Mr. Chirac ruled as Mayor for 18 years, is now in danger of falling to the Socialists in the next municipal elections in 2001.
The President has long been nicknamed "the bulldozer." Franz-Olivier Giesbert, a biographer, once wrote of him, "Jacques Chirac charges through politics without baggage or memory."
And when European Union leaders gathered here over the weekend to decide to start the new European currency next year, the bulldozer went into action again, with results that had even some French officials shaking their heads in disbelief when the rubble settled at about 2 o'clock this morning.
Only a few years ago, Mr. Chirac opposed the common currency as an unacceptable diminution of French sovereignty.
But for more than two years now, he has been telling his compatriots that Europe needed a strong new currency to face up to the dollar on world financial markets and end the virtual dictation of international trading terms by the United States.
Germany, which has the strongest European currency to lose when the euro replaces the German mark four years from now, was a bit uneasy about the bluster.
But Chancellor Helmut Kohl, battling for a fifth term in elections in September, needs to be able to reassure German voters that the euro will indeed be as sound as the mark, so he insisted on a European central banker with impeccable anti-inflationary credentials to run it: Wim F. Duisenberg of the Netherlands, which has pegged its currency to the mark since 1983.
Mr. Duisenberg was enthusiastically accepted as head of the new European central bank's predecessor institution in Frankfurt by all 15 European Union central bankers, including the President of the Bank of France, Jean-Claude Trichet.
But Mr. Chirac was furious at what he saw as an attempted coup d'etat by technocrats that would pre-empt him and his fellow European politicians from making the final decision. The Socialist Government, which wanted more political control over the independent European central bank anyway, supported him.
Mr. Chirac was also determined not to allow a candidate to be imposed by the Netherlands, a country that gave Mr. Chirac fits when he briefly resumed French nuclear testing in the Pacific in 1995.
The Dutch Prime Minister, Willem Kok, has also irked Mr. Chirac by demonstrating a lenient attitude toward marijuana and hashish in Amsterdam, where drugs easily find their way to France now that continental Europe has all but eliminated border controls.
Last year, Mr. Chirac nominated Mr. Trichet to run the new bank when it starts operations on July 1.
He maintained the nomination even after it became clear this year that only France among the 11 countries that will adopt the new currency was not prepared to accept Mr. Duisenberg for a full eight-year term.
Mr. Chirac bulldozed on even after Hans Tietmeyer, the head of the German central bank, Finance Minister Theo Waigel and other German leaders warned that his dissension was weakening the European central bank, and potentially the euro.
And he chugged into Brussels this weekend, his Socialist Finance Minister and Foreign Minister beside him, determined to force France's 14 European Union partners to agree to a compromise under which, if Mr. Trichet could not have the central bank presidency for the full eight years, he would at least have it for four.
On Saturday, Mr. Chirac was relentless in 12 hours of what a spokesman for Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain called "hard pounding" for the only solution France would accept: an accord to let Mr. Duisenberg have an eight-year term but agree to step down after four years and be replaced by Mr. Trichet.
Mr. Waigel and Mr. Kohl fought the move as a fatal weakening of the statutory independence of the central bank laid down in the 1992 European Union Treaty to protect it from precisely this kind of political interference.
But in the end, they gave in, accepting a declaration by Mr. Duisenberg about his wish to retire before the end of his term that sounded like the kind of confession prisoners of war have been known to sign after prolonged torture.
"I want to underline that this is my decision and only my decision," said Mr. Duisenberg's statement, which was greeted with incredulous laughter by French, German and other journalists when Mr. Chirac and Mr. Kohl read it to them.
French and Belgian officials attributed some of the fiasco to the way that Prime Minister Blair presided over the discussions. Britain, though not in the common currency, holds the rotating European Union presidency until July 1, and some Francophones thought perfidious Albion might have been trying to sabotage the euro before exhausted leaders finally proclaimed it in the wee hours this morning.
"It's not good at all for the European central bank to begin like that," said Jose Maria Gil Robles, the President of the European Parliament, one of many who warned that the credibility of the bank, and therefore of the euro itself, could be badly damaged by the battle Mr. Chirac waged to put a Frenchman at the bank's head after 2002.
Some economists argue that if Mr. Chirac had deliberately set out to weaken the euro and strengthen the dollar, he could not have found a better strategy. Time and the money markets will tell.

HEADLINE: Democrats Agree to a Tax Package Including Rebates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 3

 BODY:
Four months ago, Democrats in the Connecticut House of Representatives dismissed as little more than an election-year ploy a proposal by Gov. John G. Rowland to send rebate checks of as much as $200 to thousands of taxpayers. On Saturday, many of those same Democrats swallowed hard and voted for a tax package with a rebate proposal strikingly similar to the one that Mr. Rowland, a Republican, had suggested in February.
The Democrats, who hold the majority in the House, were not making some last-minute conversion to the social benefits of handing out money a few months before voters go to the polls. Rather, they were acknowledging that Mr. Rowland held the political upper hand, and that their resistance had already wrung all the concessions it could. 
 This surrender left United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, the likely Democratic challenger to Mr. Rowland in November, in an awkward spot, since she had argued that the rebate was politically motivated and a bad use of state funds.
Still, the decision to go ahead with the rebate can only help her fellow Democrats in the legislature, who also happen to be facing elections this November. "I think it's a very pro-incumbent document," said Representative Chris DePino, a Republican of New Haven and chairman of the state's Republican Party, speaking of the tax and spending plans that the state's House and Senate passed this weekend. Indeed, lawmakers from both sides of the aisle could hardly contain their praise for one another on Saturday.
What made fighting among the legislators so difficult was the projection that Connecticut would end the current fiscal year on June 30 with a surplus of more than $500 million, the biggest in state history. This would leave enough money for Mr. Rowland to achieve his top priority -- the rebate -- while also enabling Democrats to push for increased aid to cities, more money for public schools and greater property-tax relief.
The state passed a two-year budget in 1997, so this legislative session is supposed to address only modifications for the coming fiscal year. But the surplus made it possible to increase spending in both years as well as make additional tax cuts and rebates.
The difference of opinion over the rebate was between Mr. Rowland and Thomas D. Ritter, a Hartford Democrat who is House Speaker and a chairman of Mrs. Kennelly's campaign. The Democrats in the Senate did not object to the rebate.
In the horse-trading that occurred over the last month, the Democrats extracted sacrifices from Mr. Rowland. They won $40 million more for the state's Education Department, $12 million for job training for people being pushed off welfare; the Democrats also got tens of millions for a reserve fund to help the state through a future fiscal crisis. In total, the Democrats added about $67 million more in spending to the nearly $11 billion budget for next year.
The Democrats also stopped Mr. Rowland from making any further reductions in the income tax. Instead, Mr. Rowland agreed to increase next year the property tax deduction that people can take from their income tax to $350 from $285, a move that fits the Democratic goal of property tax relief.
"We got almost everything we wanted," said Mr. Ritter, adding that he could not let the politics surrounding the gubernatorial election affect his job in getting a budget passed. "The rebate was the Governor's priority, and he did everything he had to do to get it."
And it was difficult for Democrats to argue against it. The state had millions of dollars in surplus, and Mr. Rowland was broadcasting commercials insisting that taxpayers deserved to see some of it back.
Democrats whittled away at the proposal. They lowered the total being spent to $115 million from $125 million. They expanded the number of people receiving the rebate to 1.2 million from 800,000, a move that insured that more low-income people would get a check while lowering the maximum any individual would receive to $150. And the Democrats also moved up the date that the checks would be sent out from October -- just weeks before the election -- to July.
But ultimately, many Democrats in the House said, they had little choice but to yield to the Governor's will.
"You've got to understand that the Governor is the engineer who drives the train," said Representative Terrance E. Backer, a Democrat of Stratford. If the Democrats in the House had opposed the rebate, Mr. Backer explained, Mr. Rowland would have vetoed the budget, called them into a special session and attacked them for failing to give the people their money back.
Republicans praised the agreement this weekend as smart public policy. The money, they maintained, would reward residents who had seen tough times and give another boost to the state's booming economy.
Still, 19 of the 96 Democrats in the House broke ranks on the tax bill and voted against it. And in a unusual twist, they were led by the Democratic chairman of the legislature's tax policy committee, Representative Carl J. Schiessl of Windsor Locks, who delivered a half-hour speech against the measure.
"It may not be politically popular," Mr. Schiessl said of the rebate, "but I dare say there may be better ways" to spend the surplus. He said the money should be used to pay off state debt or pension fund liability, which ultimately would reduce spending in the future.
Whether that message will go over well with voters who get a check in the mail in July remains to be seen. But one thing is clear: Mrs. Kennelly cannot count on the Democrats in the legislature to deliver that message for her.

LENGTH: 1650 words

HEADLINE: The Stuff of Memories And Manic Wit;
A Comic Revisits Queens, the Source Of Material for His Broadway Show

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
John Leguizamo was back home the other day, in what he once called "the large intestine that was Queens." He cruised down Roosevelt Avenue in Jackson Heights, past the Mexican mango vendors and the hustler pitching the services of a storefront fortuneteller. He pointed to the pet shop where he had tried in vain to steal parakeets. "They put locks on those suckers," he muttered resentfully. Up ahead, he stared, bewildered, at the man in the mangy chicken suit waving menus at the passers-by. "Maybe it has Hong Kong bird flu," he ventured.
Then, around the corner from the No. 7 train roaring overhead, Mr. Leguizamo swung down to Denman Street. He was 7 years old, he recalled, when he played at the end of this rutted cul-de-sac, while his mother kept watch from a corner apartment two floors up. He got into his first fight here and, he remembered with a little remorse, broke his little brother Sergio's arm. 
 On this breezy afternoon, a small crowd gathered around, trying to catch a glimpse of the star, trying to see if they remembered him. "Man, I lived there 22 years and I never seen you around," said James Newbold, 32. "You must have changed."
That he has. Mr. Leguizamo, whose latest one-man show is inspired by the flotsam and jetsam of Queens, is a celebrity now -- one who seemed a bit shy this afternoon, behind his silver wraparound shades. Jackson Heights and its Denman Street, where he lived for just a year or two, are only a memory now, feeding the bitter humor of his stage ruminations.
From the time his family landed here in 1969, from Bogota, Colombia, they shuffled from one Queens apartment to another. Every other year, Mr. Leguizamo found himself at a new school, making new friends once again, fending off new enemies, telling new stories about himself.
"I hated my childhood," he said. "People talked about memories. I had none, because I was new all the time."
In his first solo show on Broadway, "Freak: A Semi-Demi-Quasi-Pseudo Autobiography," Mr. Leguizamo, now 33 and living among the more fashionable tenements of the Lower East Side, remembers with a vengeance. And while the tales are his own, the memories are recognizable to immigrants of all generations, from all over.
He remembers parents with a rabid sense of ambition and enterprise ("immigrant drive on crack" is how he described it the other day). He remembers the run-ins with hostile neighbors in a borough much less diverse and welcoming to newcomers in the 1970's than it is now. He remembers being a misfit at home and on the streets of Queens.
"What a confused mongrel I was," he said. "So needy, needing to belong so bad."
On stage, Mr. Leguizamo is a maniacal entertainer, bouncing, dancing and darkly funny, prattling on in the voices of a dozen loony characters. But this trip back to Queens provoked as many poignant recollections as goofy wisecracks. Indeed, he seemed a little bewildered by this place he once called home and more than a little envious of the latest generation of young Latinos here.
"It's so much easier for them," he said. "When you're by yourself and somebody calls you names, you believe it. I thought, 'We are the parasites of the universe.' "
In the 1990 Census, nearly 25 percent of all youngsters under 18 in Queens were Hispanic; in 1970, the year after the Leguizamos arrived, the Census had not even begun tallying people of Hispanic origin. Today, Roosevelt Avenue is packed with telefonereas offering discount rates to Quito and Karachi. Colombian restaurants sit next to Indian sweet shops and all-night Korean diners.
Back then, Jackson Heights, once a white, affluent suburb of Manhattan, was just becoming a gleam in the eyes of newcomers from Latin America and a few from Asia. And like generations of youngsters who have crossed the borders of New York's ethnic enclaves, Mr. Leguizamo found there were few neighborhoods where a Latino boy could safely wander. "If you went this way too far," he said, pointing west, to Irish-dominated Sunnyside, "or that way," pointing east toward Italian-ruled Corona, "it was trouble."
In "Freak," he remembers these confrontations with scathing impersonations: the band of truculent Irishmen who approach with curled upper lips after Mr. Leguizamo tries to "riverdance up to" an Irish girl at a Sunnyside bar; the Indian merchant in Jackson Heights who tries to sell him "curry candy"; the brutish Italian in Corona whom he taunts with "a book of Guido jokes."
In fact, after several stops in Jackson Heights, Mr. Leguizamo's family took a step up the economic ladder ("Beans don't stick to the pan," he noted) by moving to Corona, then an enclave of second- and third-generation Italian-Americans who had themselves stepped up from the tenements of Little Italy and were not altogether happy to see the likes of young John.
That, too, has changed; in the 1990 Census, more than half of Corona's 75,000 residents called themselves Hispanic, and in the first half of the 1990's, nearly 12,000 newcomers, the vast majority from Latin America, made Corona their first stop in America.
During this afternoon's tour, Mr. Leguizamo's musings on Queens, past and present, burst out despite his insistence that he would maintain complete silence. He said he wanted to save his voice for the evening's performance, and he had brought along a laptop computer, intending to type out his observations.
(He had also vowed not to eat -- again worried about his condition for that night's show -- but he quickly broke that promise, unrepentantly diving into a plate of plantains and pork at his favorite Roosevelt Avenue spot, La Pequena Colombiana. In an E-mail message a few days later, he wrote that he had not actually digested the pork, but had had it surgically removed. "They're using it to feed a family of four in Bolivia who live in a zapato," he said, using the Spanish word for shoe.)
As for his vow of silence, he seemed unable to resist a running commentary. He cruised past a quiet stretch of 32d Avenue and pointed to the site of his first robbery, stealing cupcakes in the dead of night from a parked lunch truck. He swung down 80th Street, past Junior High School 145, his alma mater, and the park down the street where he learned to smoke reefer and listened to the stories of the older bad boys of the neighborhood.
He recalled his best friend back then, a Brooklyn boy who belonged to the Latin Tops posse and in whose company John managed to score some attention from the girls. Mostly, though, he did not. "Only the ugly ones, the ones with braces," he said, adding that he could not exactly turn them down. "I was a desperate soul. Beggars can't be choosers."
Young John seems to have been a magnet for trouble, though. Perhaps as a way to compensate for how hard his parents worked, he worked extra hard to have fun. He was arrested twice -- once for jumping a turnstile and once for truancy. "Now this was ridiculous, because I had only seen that on 'The Little Rascals,' " he explained. "Me and about 20 other kids went to see our first porn movie, and I was arrested before I got to see the opening credits. I love that sequence. The names are so cool. Steve Tool. Rod James. Anyway, cuff, report, Family Court."
Exasperated, his parents shipped him back to Colombia -- just as today's immigrants often do when they cannot handle their American children -- where he stayed for a year with relatives. When he returned, he was sent out of the neighborhood again and enrolled in Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers in Manhattan.
He was already doing imitations at family parties, but his parents -- especially his father, Alberto, who after a variety of jobs eventually became a real estate broker -- didn't exactly encourage an acting career. His parents wanted him to go into accounting, "or some mundane, dull existence where I would surely have gone postal," Mr. Leguizamo typed during a lunch break, momentarily resuming his vow of silence.
A teacher in high school suggested that he try acting instead of acting out. He went on to study theater at New York University and dabbled in stand-up comedy before earning critical attention with his one-man Off Broadway shows, "Mambo Mouth" and "Spic-O-Rama." He played a cross-dressing diva in the film "To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything, Julie Newmar" and had a brief run on television with the Fox sketch-comedy series "House of Buggin'." (His work in the 1993 clunker "Super Mario Brothers" received less acclaim, he notes.)
"Freak," playing at the Cort Theater through July 4, is by far his most personal venture. He calls it his very own "emancipation proclamation."
"Even the ugly pain has some great redeeming qualities," he explained. "Because now, anything that happens to me can't be as bad as when I was growing up. I feel like I can survive anything, and I have. You saw 'Super Mario Brothers.' Oh well, maybe not."
His mother cried for days after seeing "Freak," Mr. Leguizamo said; he had neglected to tell her what it was about. "If I saw my son write a play about me, from his point of view, I'd be in tears," he conceded. "And then, I'd get a switch and beat his little Latin buttocks till they were lox-colored."
With his father, "Freak" worked a small miracle. The two men hadn't spoken in two years when Alberto Leguizamo -- excoriated on stage as a boozy and bitter man who won't stop drinking because "I'm not a quitter!" -- appeared backstage after the show recently, his face as lox-colored as a bad boy's bottom.
"The blood was rushing to his head, and it distorted his features," John Leguizamo recalled.
Later that night, father and son drove around the city, screaming at each other and crying over all that had not been said in life. "Now I'm closer to him than I have ever been," he typed feverishly. "We go to lunch. I bring my computer. I swear."

HEADLINE: Behind I.R.S. Hearings, a G.O.P. Plan to End Tax Code

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The taxpayer abuse hearings that Senate Republicans held last week were designed to show that the Internal Revenue Service is out of control. And with tales of tax agents in flak jackets storming houses and forcing teen-age girls to change their clothes at gunpoint not leavened by any testimony from the accused I.R.S. agents, the case seemed overwhelming.
But the hearings were just another step in a much larger strategy by Republicans in Congress who have vowed to replace the income tax system with a new tax code. 
 The Republicans want nothing less than "to pull the current income tax code out by its roots and throw it away so it can never grow back," Representative Bill Archer of Texas regularly tells audiences. Mr. Archer is the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, where tax bills originate.
In March, Senator Tim Hutchinson, Republican of Arkansas, introduced a bill, which quickly found many co-sponsors, that would repeal the Internal Revenue Code beginning in 2002.
The Republicans want to eliminate taxes on capital gains, dividends, rents, royalties and interest. Doing so, they say, would bolster savings and investment and help the economy. Opponents say eliminating such taxes would mainly benefit the wealthy.
The Republicans also want to eliminate the estate tax, which applies only to the richest 1 percent of Americans.
Polling has shown the Republicans that attacking the I.R.S. is their most effective tool to win votes in this election year and raise money. Mass mailings from Speaker Newt Gingrich and Steve Forbes, a magazine publisher who is seeking the Republican nomination for President in 2000, asking for donations to eliminate the I.R.S. and its abuses of power have brought in at least $3.6 million.
But even if the Republicans cannot find an alternative to the current income tax, the attacks on the I.R.S. provide political cover for them to make other changes in the tax code that, opponents say, directly benefit the wealthy.
A week ago Mr. Gingrich told an investment conference in Smyrna, Ga., that he will sponsor legislation to further cut the maximum tax on long-term capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent. Last summer the Republicans forced President Clinton to accept a cut in the long-term capital gains rate to 20 percent from 28 percent as the price for his education tax credits.
The Senate Finance Committee hearings demonstrated how the Republicans approach tax issues with what appears to be a clear strategy and policy objectives combined with marketing savvy that couches complex tax issues in plain language.
The Democrats, in contrast, remain in disarray on taxes, their public comments filled with the arcane lexicon of distributional equity and refundable tax credits.
Senator Phil Gramm of Texas and other Republicans on the Senate Finance Committee repeatedly described the I.R.S. last week as an agency with no checks or balances, ignoring laws that give the Justice Department control of all criminal tax prosecutions.
When Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, suggested that the hearings be expanded to investigate the conduct of the Justice Department and of the 90 United States Attorneys, who he noted are selected by senators, his remarks went nowhere.
Yesterday, two days after the hearings, Senator Moynihan said on the CBS News program "Face the Nation": "The I.R.S. is not out of control, it's just not under control. There is no management system." But Mr. Moynihan expressed confidence in Congress and in the agency's new director, Charles O. Rossotti, to create such a system.
The most significant testimony on tax policy came from three auditors who told of corrupt audits of large corporations in the Manhattan and Los Angeles tax districts.
In detail, but without naming companies or taxpayers, they explained how the system lets individual audit supervisors eliminate tax bills that can run to the hundreds of millions of dollars. They told of companies that had agreed to pay tax bills only to have those bills cut by audit supervisors who hoped to get lucrative jobs helping companies negotiate lower tax bills with the I.R.S.
One of three, Maureen O'Dwyer, an auditor who works on multinational companies based in New York, told of orders to purge audit papers that supported her findings of huge corporate taxes that were due. Ginger Mary Jarvis, another tax auditor in New York, gave details of influence peddling on behalf of rich individuals and corporations by former I.R.S. officials who now work in private practice. And Minh Thi Johnson told of orders to send unsophisticated companies bogus tax bills.
The Democrats complained that the hearings were one-sided and partisan. Mr. Moynihan noted that committee rules required that all senators receive copies of testimony a day in advance, but that Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is the chairman of the committee, kept the Democrats in the dark until testimony began.
Mr. Roth said he was trying to protect witnesses from reprisals by the I.R.S. His implicit criticism of the Democrats as allies of the tax agency went unchallenged by the Democrats on the panel.
Senator Bob Kerrey, a Nebraska Democrat and a key player in efforts to restructure the I.R.S., said that the one-sided nature of the testimony carried dangers for taxpayers who want help from Congress.
He said that the I.R.S. restructuring bill that the Senate is expected to vote on this week may not be enough to protect taxpayers. He called for holding the bill in abeyance until the Senate hears both sides of the stories told last week. Mr. Roth brushed aside the proposal.
Senator Kent Conrad, the North Dakota Democrat who was once his state's elected tax commissioner, issued a similar warning.
Despite these concerns, Mr. Moynihan said, the bill probably would pass the Senate unanimously.

U.S. Officials Pessimistic Over Middle East Talks
American officials continued to say they had little expectation for a breakthrough in the Middle East peace effort during meetings scheduled in London today. They suggested that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel was not prepared to accept American proposals for compromise and that he thinks he can withstand any political pressure that might result from public American disapproval of his position. A10

Sharing Power in Bosnia
The surprising new relationship between two war-time enemies who have now become Mayor and Deputy Mayor of a Bosnian town is a clear signal of the political changes that have taken place. The sharing of power seems to be the beginning of joint local administrations to replace those created during the war, which were almost always made up exclusively of officials from whatever ethnic group had seized control of the area. A6

Peace talks between the Islamic militants of the Taliban and its opponents to resolve years of bitter conflict in Afghanistan broke down and were "suspended indefinitely," said the United Nations representative at the negotiations. A5
 
British Uproar Over Book
Thirty years after 10-year-old Mary Bell strangled two little boys, becoming one of Britain's most notorious criminals, the revelation that she was paid to cooperate on a forthcoming book about her case has created a furor around the country. With some Britons demanding that the book be banned outright, and others calling for bookstores to refuse to sell it, Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he would seek to change the law governing criminals' ability to profit from their crimes. A6
 
Japan's Premier Under a Cloud
As the bad news on Japan's economy continues, the Japanese are expressing contempt for Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who started his term as one of the nation's most popular leaders. A poll issued last week by Mainichi Shimbun, one of Japan's leading national dailies, showed that Mr. Hashimoto's approval rating dropped to 24 percent, its lowest level since he took office in January 1996. A survey by Asahi Shimbun, another top daily, showed a majority of respondents calling for him and his Cabinet to be replaced. Mr. Hashimoto, however, has no opposition. A8

Greeks Heal Schism
A 27-year-old schism between 30,000 Greek Orthodox, who follow the old Julian calendar, and their 1.5 million brethren in the United States, who follow the Gregorian calendar, was healed over a couple of hours of celebration in Astoria, Queens. The reconciliation, approved on April 7, was simple. Neither group had to give up its method of counting the days. The Old Calendrist clergy were reordained last month. The sacraments that they had celebrated were deemed retroactively proper. B3

HEADLINE: Black and Hispanic Immigrants Lag in Housing Study

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
Black and Hispanic immigrants -- particularly those from the Dominican Republic -- continue to live in New York City's most dilapidated housing, pay among the highest percentages of income for rent and have the lowest rates of home ownership, according to a study commissioned by the Fannie Mae Foundation, an arm of the federally chartered home-mortgage provider.
The report, prepared by the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law and released Friday, found that European, Russian and Asian immigrants tend to live in far better housing, though Russians pay more of their income for rent than any other ethnic group. 
 "European and Asian households experience a far lower incidence of housing-related problems," said Michael Schill, director of the university's real estate center. "Indeed, they usually have lower rates of housing problems than even native-born minorities." The study was done by Professor Schill, Samantha Friedman of the real estate center and Emily Rosenbaum, a professor of sociology at Fordham University.
The report found that 34 percent of the Dominican households are in homes with three or more major deficiencies, like rat infestation or plumbing breakdowns, while the rate for native-born blacks is 27.2 percent.
The study also looked at households in the most seriously dilapidated buildings: those that do not provide safe and adequate shelter or that have problems that normal maintenance cannot correct. Immigrants from the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Latin America, other Caribbean countries and Africa top the list, followed closely by native-born blacks and mainland-born Puerto Ricans. (For statistical purposes, the study considered island-born Puerto Ricans as an immigrant group.)
The study said 47.2 percent of Russian immigrants pay half or more of their incomes for housing, followed by 40.3 percent of Dominicans.
Immigrants from the Indian subcontinent were found to be 12 times more likely than native-born whites to be living in overcrowded conditions, with Latin Americans 10 times more likely.
"We wanted to quantitatively document some of these conditions," said Patrick Simmons, a demographer for the Fannie Mae Foundation. He added, "It's important just to document which groups face which housing problems and, in particular, those groups like Dominicans who face problems across the board."
Factors like poverty, cultural differences and the propensity of immigrants to move into neighborhoods where their compatriots have already settled play a significant role in the substandard housing conditions they face. But Mr. Simmons said, "Even after you control for nativity, race makes a difference."
As Professor Schill said: "The proportion of Dominicans living in seriously deficient housing, 34 percent, is much closer to the 27.2 percent rate among native-born blacks than it is to any group of Asian or European immigrants. These data indicate that race and ethnicity play a much stronger role in influencing housing outcomes than merely being born in a foreign country."
Data for the study were taken from the 1996 New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey, which sampled 15,752 households, 5,933 of them headed by immigrants. The survey, conducted every three years by the Census Bureau under contract with the city, is considered the best source of housing data in the city.
Looking at costs, the study found that while more Russians pay at least 50 percent of their incomes for housing than any other group, black and Hispanic groups -- both native- and foreign-born -- rank second, third, fourth and fifth. For native-born whites, the rate is 20.1 percent.
Asked why Russians are at the top of the list, Dr. Rosenbaum said: "Russians move to predominantly white neighborhoods. In addition to Brighton Beach, they move to Forest Hills, which, of course, is more expensive than Washington Heights. So the costs of housing might present a heavier burden."
Indians, Pakistanis and Bangladeshis have the highest rate of overcrowding, at 28 percent, the study found. Overcrowding was defined as more than one person in one room, not counting bathrooms, hallways, unfinished basements and attics. Latin Americans are second in overcrowding, at 22.4 percent, and Dominicans place third, at 19.8 percent. Native-born whites have the lowest rate of overcrowding, 2.3 percent.
Dr. Rosenbaum said the high overcrowding rate among Indians, Pakistanis and Bangladeshis may reflect the fact that among those groups, more males than females come to this country. "These men live together to share costs," she said, "or may live with family members who are already here. And culturally, there is more of an emphasis on sharing space than among Americans, so it may not be viewed as onerous."
The study also found that Dominicans have the lowest rate of home ownership, 5.7 percent, followed by island-born Puerto Ricans, 11.6 percent, and mainland-born Puerto Ricans, 14.7 percent. The study found that 21.3 percent of native-born blacks own their own homes, as do 42.9 percent of native-born, non-Hispanic whites.
Dr. Reynolds Farley, vice president of the Russell Sage Foundation and a demographer who studies immigration, said, "What strikes me quite clearly, particularly when looking at housing deficiencies for Dominicans, Puerto Ricans, Caribbeans, Latin Americans and Africans, is that there certainly is the suggestion that the color line has something to do with housing opportunities."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Central Bank Chief Resigns in Thailand

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, May 4

 BODY:
The chief of Thailand's central bank resigned today after being linked to past mistakes that led to a plunge in Thailand's currency, the baht, depleting the country's foreign reserves by billions of dollars.
The official, Chaiyawat Wibulswasdi, said his resignation would take effect on Tuesday. The Finance Minister, Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda, said he would nominate Chatu Mongol Sonakul, the ministry's former permanent secretary, to the post. 
 The central bank said in a statement that the deputy governor, Jaroong Nookhwun, had also tendered his resignation.
Mr. Chaiyawat is the third governor of the central bank -- now riding out its worst economic crisis in decades -- to quit in three years. He was appointed to the job in July.
The findings of a Government panel investigating the central bank's performance linked Mr. Chaiyawat to past mistakes during a period when he was deputy governor.
The panel said several other senior finance officials shared the blame for the baht's plunge last year.
The panel also criticized the central bank for losing billions of dollars in loans to debt-ridden finance companies, 56 of which are now closed.
Mr. Tarrin said he was forming a panel of international experts to help revamp the central bank. Those approached about joining the panel include former officials of the United States Federal Reserve, the Bank of England and the Monetary Authority of Singapore, he said.

HEADLINE: Bush Appointee Announces Plans to Quit Central Bank

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
Susan M. Phillips, a member of the Federal Reserve Board since December 1991, said today that she would resign from the central bank on June 30.
Ms. Phillips's term expired on Jan. 31, but she had agreed to stay on while two new Fed governors, Roger W. Ferguson Jr. and Edward M. Gramlich, were taking up their positions on the seven-member board. She is leaving the Fed to become dean of the School of Business and Public Management at George Washington University in Washington. 
 White House officials said they hoped to have a successor to Ms. Phillips named by the end of June. The position requires Senate confirmation. The Administration had all but announced a selection for the post several months ago but had to begin the search again when the candidate, whose name was never publicly disclosed, backed out at the last minute.
 Ms. Phillips, a former finance professor, was appointed to the Fed by President George Bush. She helped lead the Fed's bank-regulation activities and took a particular interest in assessing the risks of complex new securities like derivatives.
But Ms. Phillips, who is 53, was never influential within the Fed on interest-rate policy. Analysts who watch the Fed said she tended to follow the majority opinion within the central bank's policy-setting committee, which has long been dominated by the chairman, Alan Greenspan.
In her resignation letter to President Clinton, Ms. Phillips called for the nation to update its banking laws to reflect the rapid changes brought to the financial world by technology and globalization.
The House is scheduled to vote on the first major overhaul of banking regulation in decades on Thursday, but the legislation's chances of passage have been clouded by disputes among banks, Wall Street, insurers and regulators over the powers the bill would allocate to each.
"Given the significant changes and integration of the world's financial markets and of market participants, I believe that significant revision in this country's banking laws are now required," Ms. Phillips said.
Separately, Mr. Greenspan and Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, sent a letter to Capitol Hill today urging the House to pass the proposed banking legislation. The bill, which would break down many of the remaining barriers between banks, securities firms and insurers, is opposed by most banks and appears likely to face strong objections from the Clinton Administration.
The departure of Ms. Phillips from the Fed means that aside from Mr. Greenspan, who was appointed to a third four-year term by President Clinton two years ago, the board will have only one Republican-appointed member, Edward W. Kelley Jr., who was first appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1987 and later reappointed by President Bush. The other four governors -- Mr. Gramlich, Mr. Ferguson, Laurence H. Meyer and Alice M. Rivlin, the vice chairwoman -- were named by Mr. Clinton.
So far there has been little to suggest any tilt in monetary policy as the board has been filled with Democratic appointees. Given Mr. Greenspan's clout within the Fed, in Washington and on Wall Street, there is unlikely to be any as long as he remains chairman. The most prominent of Mr. Clinton's appointees, Mr. Meyer, has proved to be even more hard line an inflation fighter than Mr. Greenspan is.
The Fed also announced today that its longtime spokesman, Joseph R. Coyne, would be replaced when he retires on June 1 by Lynn S. Fox, who is currently the central bank's deputy Congressional liaison.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Currency Markets Largely Discount Maneuvers Over Euro

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 4

 BODY:
World currency traders today largely disregarded embarrassing political squabbles among European leaders this past weekend over plans to introduce a common European currency on Jan. 1.
On the first business day after 11 European nations signed an agreement to adopt the euro, traders initially sold currencies such as the German mark but later bought them back at the expense of the dollar, leaving them little changed for the day. Many European stock markets posted big gains. 
 Both the London and Tokyo markets were closed for holidays, which may have helped exaggerate currency swings as trading was thin. But the reactions still suggested that currency traders remained confident about the euro's credibility and were not particularly concerned over the back-room machinations Saturday and early Sunday over the leadership of the new European central bank.
Indeed, if currency traders took any cue from the political contortions that preceded agreement on the euro, it was to bet on a more conservative monetary policy from European central bankers. who may feel increased pressure to prove their toughness.
In the past, anxiety about a potentially weak euro has prompted investors to sell German marks and French francs and buy dollars, British pounds and Swiss francs -- currencies that will remain outside the monetary union next January.
Today, despite scorching newspaper headlines about the compromises that European leaders struck in Brussels over who would head the new central bank, the mark maintained its resilience. Late in New York trading, the dollar sold at 1.7803 marks, little changed from a three-month low of 1.7799 marks late Friday.
Although the mark's recent ascent against the dollar may have little to do with the euro, it suggests that euro-anxiety has not increased as the point of no return drew closer.
"The reaction was really positive," said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt. "It speaks to the fact that the euro is now a reality, and that the economic fundamentals are present for a strong and stable currency."
After months of feuding over rival candidates to head the bank, which will control monetary policy under the new currency union, France and Germany reached a much-criticized agreement early Sunday morning to split the first president's term between the rival candidates. Economists and many political leaders complained that the deal could undermine the euro because it violated at least the spirit of laws intended to guarantee the new bank's political independence.
Wim Duisenberg, until recently head of the Dutch central bank, will take the job first and retire about halfway through his eight-year term and make way for the French candidate, Jean-Claude Trichet.
Financial analysts generally agreed today that the unseemly deal making, which stemmed primarily from France's dogged demands that a Frenchman run monetary policy, represented a bad start for the new central bank.
But they also said that the markets' potentially negative reaction had been offset by several factors. For one, proposals for a "gentleman's agreement" had been widely reported and debated for weeks and the outcome was therefore not a big surprise.
In addition, both Mr. Duisenberg and Mr. Trichet are respected hard-liners on monetary policy, and the bank's other voting board members are almost all conservative as well.
Indeed, analysts said investors may have taken the political skirmishes as a signal that monetary policy would become a bit tougher as European central bankers will feel more pressure to prove their credibility.
"One impact of this could be a slight loss of reputation for the European central bank," said Holger Schmieding, a Merrill Lynch economist in London, "but this also slightly raises the risk that the German Bundesbank will raise interest rates earlier than it might have planned."
The Bundesbank has been expected to nudge up German rates late this year, to bring them closer into line with the higher rates that prevail in countries like Spain and Italy. But Germany's central bank has been hostile toward the idea of splitting the term of the European central bank's first president, and investors suspect that it might raise rates earlier than originally planned to shore up the new currency's credibility.
Mr. Ramm of Commerzbank said both the possibilities of a soft euro and of a hard-line reaction by central bankers had been overestimated.
Analysts pointed out that almost all the board members of the new central bank were demonstrated hawks who had frequently imposed restrictive monetary policies to suppress inflation and stabilize their individual nations' currencies.
"These are all technocrats, and they will probably behave like technocrats in setting monetary policy," said Graham Bishop, an adviser on the euro to Salomon Smith Barney.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Booting Up Africa

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Jim Lowenthal is wiring Timbuktu.
Mr. Lowenthal runs a small Internet company based in Morocco that has an unusual contract from the U.S. Agency for International Development. His job is to go to the most remote African countries and establish Internet nodes in their capitals so that anyone there can make a local phone call and get on the World Wide Web. He's already helped bring Mali, Madagascar, Mozambique and Guinea on line, and is in the process of wiring Benin, the Ivory Coast and four others, as well as helping design Internet access for Timbuktu, in Mali -- the city that is a synonym for the most obscure spot on earth. 
 "Timbuktu is a small town, but in the 14th century its university was a center of learning for the Arab world, because it was a key crossroad for caravans traversing the Sahara," said Mr. Lowenthal. "It's now a town of sand and shrub but with amazing archives that are piled up and deteriorating. The Mali Ministry of Culture would love to share them with the world but they never had a way. The Internet gives them the way."
Projects like Mr. Lowenthal's highlight why globalization can leave one simultaneously optimistic and pessimistic about Africa. Globalization does two things at the same time: It increases the gap, further and faster than ever before, between those partaking of the information revolution and the global economy and those who are not. So the gap between the Rift Valley and Silicon Valley is growing exponentially.
But at the same time, globalization and the information revolution offer an escalator from poverty into the global economy that also moves further and faster than ever before for countries that get the basics right. Global investors are always looking for the next great opportunity, and Africa has the potential to be that.
"What U.S. A.I.D. is trying to do," says Mr. Lowenthal, "is broadly disseminate the basic information infrastructure that will allow African countries to move from one step to the other. And the great thing about the Information Age is that you can move from 0 to 60 much more quickly than in the Industrial Age, if you get the basic digital information technologies. I just came back from Guinea-Bissau. It has one of the least developed telecom systems in Africa, but two entrepreneurs there just put up a three-story building that is completely wired. They're now running a computer training center, an Internet cafe and a marketing business for next-generation information technology solutions. You should see the colorful web page designs now coming out of Africa by their own Webmasters."
Sure, it's just one building in a big continent, but that's how it starts. Americans don't realize that when they go to the doctor and get examined and the doctor dictates his notes from the examination onto a tape, that tape often gets shipped on the Web to a housewife in Ireland who transcribes it in her spare time for a fee and then sends the transcript back on the Web. There is no reason, with some basic English education and digital infrastructure, that Africans cannot get into this lucrative area of telecomputing and data processing.
No, the Internet will not solve the problems between Hutu and Tutsi in central Africa or cure AIDS in Kenya. And yes, power in Africa still resides with those with the guns, not those with the phones. Africa's tribal and economic problems will not be solved overnight or on line. But all of these problems are related to, or exacerbated by, chronic underdevelopment, and the Internet gives Africans a new tool to leapfrog back into the game.
In 1977 there was a movie, "Black and White in Color" about French and German army units that were caught in West Africa at the end of World War I, but because the local newspapers were six months old, they never got the news that the war was over, so they went on fighting while the Africans watched in amusement.
"If they made that movie today it would be about how Deutschtelekom and France Cable et Radio were competing over who will get to privatize the telephone system in Senegal by offering the most connections at the cheapest cost," argued Mr. Lowenthal. "If you don't factor the Web into your analysis of Africa, you're going to miss something. We're just two years away from large numbers of people in Africa being able to tell their own story, and that has got to impact politics there."

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Germans to Mourn Mark, The Symbol of Revival

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: BONN, May 3

 BODY:
Half a century ago, from the ration lines and ruins of defeated Germany, a new German mark was born. Like many a child of postwar occupation, the mother was German, the father a foreigner. The date was June 20, 1948.
But with the coming of a European single currency, its details agreed to at a heads of government meeting in Brussels this weekend, that 50th anniversary is likely to be much more of a wake. Among the 11 European nations ceding fiscal sovereignty as they shed marks, francs and pesetas for the euro, Germans will mourn the most. 
 Anyone seeking to understand why need look only at the tumultuous days when the mark was born -- not simply the new coinage of a fallen realm, but the infant emblem of Germany's regeneration as postwar Europe's economic colossus.
As the Brussels meeting got under way, the latest opinion survey here said 56 percent of Germans remained opposed to the new currency because its introduction, quite simply, meant the end of the mark that many people still associated with that first Volkswagen Beetle and that first postwar vacation in the sun -- the budding fruits of Germany's economic miracle.
"The Deutsche mark is the incarnation of 40 or 50 years of prosperity," said Prof. Klaus von Beyme, a political scientist at Heidelberg University. And as they contemplate a future without it, many Germans are reminded of a past in which inflation wiped out savings and left their parents and grandparents bereft. "Every monetary reform has been associated with a loss of money," Professor von Beyme said. "And people are afraid."
As of Jan. 1, 1999, the euro will be used in some electronic trading. By 2002, euro notes and coins will have banished not just the mark, but francs and many other currencies, in the one of the boldest financial adventures undertaken by a group of disparate lands.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl came under fire over the weekend for making a last-minute political deal with France to introduce the euro. Under the arrangement, Wim Duisenberg, a Dutchman favored by Germany, will step down voluntarily as head of the forthcoming European central bank after only four years on the job, to be replaced by a Frenchman.
Germany's opposition Social Democratic Party lambasted Mr. Kohl's maneuvering to placate France, asserting that the Chancellor had "lost trust over his foreign policy." Even allies of Mr. Kohl, including the Bavarian state premier, Edmund Stoiber, said the compromise had "thrown shadows over the start of the currency union."
The prickliness of Germans was perhaps not surprising, because in this country, the loss of the mark carries a lot more emotional freight than Europeans normally associate with pocketbook issues. Currencies, of course, are national totems -- just as the dollar is part of being American or the pound sterling, part of being British.
But the mark was always more than that -- an emblem of a new respectability after the horrors of Nazism, of success and prosperity and, above all, of stability.
As a measure of its meaning, consider, for instance, that the postwar mark -- the Deutsche mark in West Germany as distinct from the reichsmark of the Weimar and Nazi eras -- was born 11 months before the Bonn Government was created. It entered history on the front line of the cold war, at a time when many Germans were beginning to sense that postwar deprivation was coming to an end.
"After the war, there was nothing to eat, nothing to wear," said Erika Ritter, now a pensioner, who was 18 when the new money was introduced. "Everything was rationed and families would send their children into the food lines in relays, the queues were so long. We were given the new money with our ration cards, and the shops suddenly filled up with glasses, food, everything."
Indeed, a commentator, Michael Schmidt-Klingenberg, writing in the news magazine Der Spiegel, said, "The founding myth of the new state was not the Constitution, but the miracle of the store windows."
From its birth, with Americans and the other Western Allies as midwives, the mark molded postwar Germany as a land whose fortunes were intertwined with those of the West and of capitalism.
For 49 days from April 1948 onward, sequestered in an attic conference room near Kassel in central Germany, in a villa encircled by American barbed wire, a group of German financial experts, nudged forward by the Occupation powers -- the United States, Britain and France -- met quietly. As they met, rumors swirled about of an impending currency reform in a land that had no real currency.
And when on June 20, 1948, Germans in the west were permitted to exchange 40 old, virtually worthless reichsmarks for 40 of the crisp new notes (printed in Philadelphia), the Soviet occupiers of eastern Germany followed suit, issuing their own Ostmarks.
The dispute over which currency would be used in divided Berlin led to the Soviet blockade of the city, and to the beginning of the Berlin airlift. If ever there was an emblem of Germany's division, and a defining symbol for the split-up of Europe for decades to come, this was it.
Compared with some other European currencies, the mark has kept its strength: These days, one mark has 27 percent of the buying power it had in 1948. By contrast, the Italian lira has 4 percent of its 1948 value.
The fear of losing all that, perhaps, is why Chancellor Kohl has had some difficulty in persuading his compatriots that, as he frequently insists, the euro will be "as stable as the mark."

HEADLINE: Italy's Leader, Due on Visit, Praises U.S. for Backing Euro

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, May 4

 BODY:
Prime Minister Romano Prodi may well be the happiest man in Europe.
Only a year ago, Italy was disparaged as the biggest country least likely to qualify for membership in the European economic union. Two years ago, when the former economics professor was elected on a pledge to either get Italy into Europe or resign, he was widely dismissed as a hopelessly naive academic. 
 When he arrives in Washington on Tuesday for his first state visit, Mr. Prodi, 58, will be feted as the first European leader to visit the United States since he and his counterparts made the momentous decision on Saturday to go ahead with plans for the single currency, and as a statesman who, against all odds, led Italy into the euro. It was a remarkable feat and showed in Mr. Prodi political skills that rival those of President Clinton.
"Politics," he said with a convert's relish, "is beautiful."
In an interview today, Mr. Prodi beamed as he praised the United States for its "magnanimity" in supporting the euro, which, he warned, could soon rival the dollar as an international currency.
"Americans have been very, very generous," he said. "They have flashes of vision. Unlike Europeans, they have understood that long-term stability and simplicity should prevail over sectoral interests of the United States. The euro is in the long-term interest of the U.S., but we are building a competitor to the dollar, there is no doubt about that."
Mr. Prodi was so buoyant about Europe -- and Italy's up-from-behind inclusion in the euro -- that he could not help laughing at the dispute over the presidency of the European central bank, a tussle between France and Germany that largely overshadowed the historic drama of the weekend. "Given their grand and marvelous love-hate relationship, did we really expect the French and the Germans to say to each other, 'You first,' and 'No, no after you?' " he said, chuckling uncontrollably. "There is a folkloric aspect to the longstanding rivalry between France and Germany, which can even be entertaining."
He said he considered that the compromise reached at the Brussels meeting -- Germany's choice, Wim F. Duisenberg, the Dutch central banker, will split the eight-year term with France's central banker -- was by no means a serious problem. "Four years are a century!" Mr. Prodi said.
By Italian political standards, certainly, Mr. Prodi's two-year tenure is nothing short of a miracle. His coalition Government is the third longest-lasting in Italy since World War II, and his prediction that he can stay in power until the next parliamentary elections in 2001 no longer sounds so laughable to Italians. But having cut Italy's deficit, lowered interest rates and begun to reduce the staggering public debt to qualify for European membership, Mr. Prodi now faces a new host of challenges.
He must continue to cut Italy's debt -- which at 121 percent of gross domestic product is still double the European limit -- while addressing painful domestic problems like a 12 percent unemployment rate.
After holding their breath for the sake of European membership, Mr. Prodi's partners in his coalition, which is dominated by former Communists, are already grumbling about Government plans to cut Italy's bloated welfare state and demanding a 35-hour work week. Mr. Prodi, whose approval ratings rose to 60 percent earlier this month, said he was confident that he could lower taxes and unemployment rates during the next three years.
He said that Italians would continue to make the necessary sacrifices to reduce its debt, but that he was not expecting them to suffer unduly. "I've explained to the Italians that it won't be paradise," he said, "but a nice purgatory with air-conditioning and decent toilets."
Mr. Clinton is scheduled to see Mr. Prodi on Wednesday. Yugoslavia, and the crisis in the Serbian province of Kosovo, which is 90 percent ethnic Albanian, will be high on the agenda.
Italy, which has strong ties to Albania and commercial investment in Kosovo, recently was host to a meeting of the so-called Contact Group, six nations that monitor events in the former Yugoslavia. The group agreed in Rome to impose new sanctions if Serbia does not agree to negotiate a settlement in Kosovo.
Mr. Prodi said that Europe and the United States alike want to put pressure Serbian and Kosovan leaders to negotiate a peace settlement, but that they differed slightly on "tactics," most notably the American desire for tougher sanctions on Serbia if it rejects peace talks.
But Mr. Prodi, whose coalition nearly collapsed a year ago over his decision to send Italian troops to restore peace in Albania, said Italy had earned the right to speak its mind. "We are fulfilling our leadership role in the region," he said. "We couldn't say that a few years ago."
Diplomatic relations between the United States and Italy hit a low point in February, when an American military airplane sliced through the cables of a ski lift in the northern Italian town of Cavalese, killing 20 people. Italian officials said that despite warnings, American pilots had repeatedly flown recklessly low in training missions.
The four crew members involved in the accident will face a military legal proceeding in the United States, and Mr. Prodi said that while he intended to raise the subject with Mr. Clinton, he was fully satisfied with American efforts to bring the case to justice and prevent future incidents.

HEADLINE: Smoking Foes Battle the Industry's Specter of Smuggling

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 4

 BODY:
In fighting the anti-smoking legislation before the Senate, the tobacco industry argues that the current bill would lead to a black market in cigarettes and a crime wave that would rival the rum-running and gangsterism of Prohibition.
Children would no longer be buying cigarettes from convenience stores or "stealing them from their mother and daddy," J. Phil Carlton, a top industry lawyer, said in a television interview last month. "They're going to be out on the street dealing with drug dealers." 
 No one doubts the potential for smuggling cigarettes. But advocates of a strong anti-smoking bill believe that the problem can be controlled through regulations and law enforcement and that the importance of deterring teen-agers from smoking outweighs the threat of a black market.
Many influential lawmakers have adopted the industry's view on the likelihood of a serious contraband problem. At a Senate hearing last week, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, held up a blue pack of Chinese cigarettes and declared, "The real concern I have is that we're going to be flooded with this stuff."
But other senators agree with Senator John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, who characterizes the black-market argument as a "red herring."
At a hearing today, Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, called the cigarette makers' specter of a black market "as false and misleading as the industry's past assertions about addiction, health effects and marketing to kids."
Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told Congress last week that it was not groundless to fear that a black market could develop if cigarette prices rose steeply, as they would under a bill approved by the Senate Commerce Committee. But he said cigarette smuggling could be avoided if Congress enacted a rigid system of licensing tobacco wholesalers, exporters, importers and distributors.
Cigarettes, Mr. Summers said, should be stamped in such a way that law-enforcement authorities could tell at once whether they were smuggled. The rules would be similar to those now applied to alcoholic beverages. Government officials say that because of the regimen of licensing and policing, no serious black market in wine and spirits exists in the United States.
The Senate is tentatively scheduled to vote on the Commerce Committee's bill the week before Memorial Day, but Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, raised some doubt today about whether the schedule could be met. Mr. Lott and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, agreed that the prospects of getting tobacco legislation through the Senate were slim if it did not happen before Memorial Day.
It was unclear whether Mr. Lott seriously intended to postpone action on the tobacco bill or was using the threat to prevent Democrats from tying up the bill now before the Senate that would overhaul the Internal Revenue Service.
The potential for cigarette smuggling when prices rise steeply is apparent. Last month Sweden, which had one of the highest tax rates in the world on cigarettes, cut its tobacco tax by more than 25 percent to stop trafficking.
In 1994, Canada reduced its cigarette tax in the face of widespread smuggling. The Canadian experience is offered by opponents of the Senate legislation as the prime example of the threat of a black market in the United States.
Increased taxes imposed by the Canadian Government and the provinces had pushed the average price of a pack of cigarettes, in 1994 Canadian dollars, to $5.65 in 1993 from $2.64 in 1984.
By 1993, more than 60 percent of the cigarettes smoked in Quebec were contraband. Organized criminals had purchased Canadian-made cigarettes that had been exported to the United States and were not subject to Canadian taxes, smuggled them back into Canada and sold them at a discount. From 1990 to 1993, United States imports of Canadian cigarettes increased more than tenfold.
After the Canadian taxes were reduced in 1994 and a new tax was levied on cigarettes exported from Canada, the black market ceased to exist.
But that chronology does not tell the whole story. First, according to David Sweanor, a lawyer in Ottawa who works full time on anti-smoking campaigns, the number of cigarettes smoked per capita fell by 40 percent in Canada during the years the high taxes were in effect, half again as much as the decrease in the United States. The prevalence of daily smoking by Canadians 15 to 19 years old fell to 16 percent from 40 percent.
Moreover, the Canadian tobacco companies, affiliates of American and British companies, were complicit in the black market. When the Canadian tax was lowered in 1994, Prime Minister Jean Chretien said, "The fact is that the Canadian tobacco manufacturers have benefited directly from this illegal trade."
In the United States, the source of cigarette smuggling would most likely be Mexico, where cigarettes cost less than $1 a pack. Under the Senate bill, the average price in the United States, now about $2 a pack, would rise to at least $3.50 by 2003, taking account of inflation, and as high as $5 by some industry and Wall Street estimates.
The authorities are concerned because two American tobacco companies, Philip Morris and Brown & Williamson, have recently bought interests in companies that make cigarettes in Mexico.
One way to prevent a black market in the United States, Mr. Summers testified, would be to make sure that the law penalized American tobacco companies if evidence of smuggling arose.
Smuggling cannot occur, Mr. Summers said, "without the complicity of those who are involved in the industry."
