HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Sets Record, With Gains Mostly in a Few Companies

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Investors propelled stocks further into record territory yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average posting a new high.
But analysts offered mixed views of the market's rise. Although some pointed to optimism about the continued prospect for low interest rates, based on economic data released last week, others discounted the gains, which came in only moderate trading volume and were concentrated among a few large companies. 
 "This move is not as significant as other highs," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore.
"You're not seeing that broad conviction," Mr. Cripps added, noting that the Nasdaq composite index, which had been leading the market higher in recent weeks, had only modest gains.
Yesterday's gains may not have resulted from any strong belief about the prospects for companies and expectations of strong future earnings growth, analysts said.
"There's a big fear of missing the next leg up," said Jim Benning, a vice president and trader at BT Brokerage in New York. "It's more like a defensive kind of buying. I think they're more afraid of missing the upside than getting caught on the downside," he said, noting that traders who bought shares after last Monday's plunge of nearly 147 points saw the Dow rebound to end last week up 82 points.
After rising more than 114.25 points yesterday, the Dow lost more than half those gains, closing up 45.59 points at 9,192.66. That was still enough to allow the average to eclipse its previous record high of 9,184.94, reached April 21. Two stocks, Union Carbide and Eastman Kodak, accounted for half of the average's gains.
A computer-generated sell program erased 46 points from the blue-chip average in the final 30 minutes of trading, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. In total, computer buy and sell programs shaved a total of 38.63 points off the Dow and 5.06 points off the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, a Birinyi official said.
The S.& P. 500 inched up 1.07 points, to 1,122.07, led by Philip Morris. The Nasdaq composite index, added 5.42 points, to 1,878.86. Despite the limited rise, Internet-related shares, including America Online, Excite, K-tel International and Lycos, again had strong gains.
As stocks wound modestly higher, Treasury securities were virtually unchanged, after two days of gains, as investors turned cautious ahead of Friday's employment report.
"It looks O.K. for a while, but I wouldn't stray too far from the door," said Peter J. Canelo, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York.
Although Mr. Canelo forecast that the Dow could rise as high as 9,500 to 9,600 before late summer, a number of factors, including an increased amount of cash flowing into investments and continued strong economic growth, could push the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to curb growth, he cautioned.
"This economy is just too strong -- there's no visible slowdown," he said. "All that this does is postpone the moment of truth until sometime in the summer."

HEADLINE: Union Upholds Trusteeship For School Workers' Local

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A union's appeals board has upheld a decision to put the local representing 22,000 New York City school cafeteria workers and crossing guards into trusteeship, finding that its president improperly took $1.1 million.
The ruling against the local's longtime president, Charles Hughes, was disclosed yesterday by Jean Nolan, a spokeswoman for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. Mr. Hughes was suspended by the union's national leaders on Feb. 3. 
 Mr. Hughes, who is one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's closest union allies, has repeatedly asserted that he was owed the $1.1 million as overtime and expense reimbursements.
But the parent union's appellate board found on April 23 that Mr. Hughes was wrong to take the money because he did not provide documentation that it was owed him and there was no proof that the local's board had approved the payments.
Lee Saunders, a senior aide to the national union's president, will run the local until the financial situation has been cleaned up.
Local 372 is one of the largest in District Council 37, the umbrella group composed of 56 locals and representing 120,000 municipal employees. Local 372 has long been a political powerhouse because of its campaign contributions and phone banks. During last year's mayoral campaign, Mr. Hughes appeared in a commercial for Mr. Giuliani and held a fund-raiser for him.
The appellate board's decision comes as Mr. Hughes's local and seven others in District Council 37 are being investigated by the Manhattan District Attorney or the United States Attorney in Manhattan.
The appeals board also found that under Mr. Hughes, the local's funds were quickly dwindling.
"The board found that the funds of 372 were being dissipated in a very rapid and increasing rate," Ms. Nolan said. "It determined that there was every reason to believe that this spending would continue at a rate exceeding the local's ability to pay."
In an interview in February, Mr. Hughes denied receiving any improper reimbursements. He said he had forgone a salary increase in the early 1970's and was thus owed 26 years of payments at $12,000 a year, with 8 percent compound interest added. Mr. Hughes, whose salary last year was $241,000, said he was owed hundreds of hours of overtime and compensatory time because he often worked more than 35 hours a week.
Mr. Hughes's lawyer, Robert Schmukler, said he might appeal the board's decision. "I'm saying Mr. Hughes did not improperly take that money," Mr. Schmukler said. "As far as I know he didn't get any more than he wasn't entitled to."
Mr. Schmukler insisted that District Council 37 was in part at fault because it wrote $1.1 million in checks to Mr. Hughes after the union leader had requested the payments.
"If they're entrusted with the money obtained by dues checkoff and they don't keep sufficient control, don't they have some fiduciary responsibility?" Mr. Schmukler said.
Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37, said it would be irresponsible to respond to Mr. Schmukler's criticisms, because "there are judicial processes that are going on."
In January, Mr. Hill asked the parent union to suspend Mr. Hughes and create an emergency trusteeship because Local 372 was $8 million in debt and had not paid rent to District Council 37 for 27 months.
The case has been an embarrassment to Mr. Hill as well as to Mr. Hughes. Some union members have criticized Mr. Hill for waiting until Local 372 was $8 million in debt before moving against Mr. Hughes and for having District Council 37 guarantee a multimillion-dollar bank loan made to Local 372.
Although Mr. Hughes has been criticized for a life style that includes a BMW automobile and a luxurious house in Georgia, Mr. Schmukler said Local 372 members were in no rush to have Mr. Hughes pushed out. Mr. Schmukler said Local 372 was one of the few locals comprised mainly of part-time workers to obtain pensions for its members.
"Charlie Hughes has been president of this local for 30 years," Mr. Schmukler said. "He built it into a force to be reckoned with politically. Charlie Hughes gets people out there to work for politicians and then gets them to work for his members."

HEADLINE: Roukema Again Has Conservative Challenger in Primary

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 4

 BODY:
"Why are they doing this to me?" Representative Marge Roukema asked with a laugh of mock despair. "I can't explain it, and I am completely confounded."
But not too worried: On June 2, with 18 years in Congress from her Bergen County district behind her and the kind of seniority that makes most incumbents immune to challenge in a party primary, Mrs. Roukema, a moderate Republican on issues like abortion, crime and welfare, will again face a challenger from the conservative wing of the Republican Party. It is the fourth consecutive primary she has had to fight, and the fifth in seven elections. 
 Mrs. Roukema's race in the 5th District is one of only two primary contests to draw much party attention in a year when New Jersey politics has been dominated by state issues like auto insurance and school finance reform, and in which Congress has not made much news.
The other race is in central New Jersey's 12th District, where two Democrats are battling to face Michael Pappas, the only freshman on the 13-member state delegation. Republicans hold 8 seats, the Democrats 5.
If the past is any indication, Mrs. Roukema will beat State Assemblyman E. Scott Garrett with the same ease with which she dispatched the last four party challengers she faced. But in a New Jersey election year that seems otherwise to lack any dominant political or ideological theme, the fact that Mrs. Roukema is again the only incumbent with a primary race underscores the almost open warfare that continues among Republicans over the fulcrum issues of taxation and abortion.
"It's the right wing of the party going after someone they think is vulnerable," a moderate Republican said of Mrs. Roukema, speaking on condition of anonymity. "She keeps winning, but they keep coming back."
Mr. Garrett, a trial lawyer from wealthy, conservative Morris County, with eight years in the Assembly, says his polling shows that Mrs. Roukema is too liberal for the 5th District. As to why she has always been re-elected, he said, "Marge has been the incumbent for 18 years and has never had a solid challenger in all that time."
He is emphasizing three elements of his Assembly record: that he was part of the successful vote to override Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's veto of a bill outlawing partial birth abortions, that he was the sponsor of a measure -- still locked in committee -- to outlaw homosexual marriage in the state and that he supported a bill to create a charter school in each district.
Mr. Garrett said he had never voted for a tax increase, and he attacked Mrs. Roukema's success in bringing Federal highway money to her district. "My view is that we should not be taxing at the Federal level for the things that New Jersey can do for itself," Mr. Garrett said. "New Jersey has done very poorly under Marge for the last 18 years, because we send more money to Washington than we get back."
Mrs. Roukema has countered Mr. Garrett's campaign by emphasizing that she is as conservative as Mr. Garrett on fiscal matters. But on the issue of abortion, Mrs. Roukema is unbending.
"If we're talking about people having a choice and not being controlled by the Government," Mrs. Roukema said, "this is so clearly an issue that should be strictly between the woman and her doctor and her religious counselor -- not the Government."
The strength of the conservative wing among the state's Republicans is also an element in the 12th District, which Mr. Pappas won two years ago even as President Clinton carried the district.
This year, even though the state Democratic Party did not bother to nominate candidates for Congressional races in the strongly Republican 2d and 3d Districts, the Democrats believe that they can field a winner against Mr. Pappas, who is campaigning against inheritance taxes and for a flat income tax.
"The 12th is the one where we would say all of the evidence is most conducive to our picking up a seat," said Rick Thigpen, executive director of the state Democratic Party. "Pappas is a little to the right of the voters in the district, he doesn't enjoy strong Republican support and we think he's vulnerable."
Mr. Pappas, in response, said he remained confident. "But I run scared in every election that I run in," he said. "I did that in the primary two years ago, that most people thought I couldn't win, and I won the general election even though the President carried the district."
But before facing Mr. Pappas, the Democrats have to get through a potentially bruising primary fight of their own between Rush Holt, a physicist and party favorite, and Carl Mayer, a wealthy maverick and one-term Princeton Township Committeeman who is running in his fourth primary race for a Congressional nomination. Mr. Holt beat Mr. Mayer for the party nominations from the five counties that make up the 12th District, and Mr. Mayer's persistence has created some ill-concealed dismay among party leaders.
"There is a grand opportunity out there for us to win against Pappas, but unfortunately we Democrats too often find ourselves circling the wagons and shooting at each other," said Alan Karcher, a lawyer and chairman of the Democratic Committee of Mercer County, which has the largest voting bloc in the 12th District.
Mr. Mayer contributed nearly $1 million of his own money to his campaign in the first three months of this year. He has rented office space and hands out professionally prepared brochures and campaign videos. Mr. Holt, who until October was the assistant director of Princeton University's Plasma Physics Laboratory, raised $114,000 in the same period. He said the 12th District, which was drawn by Republicans to skirt the region's Democratic-voting cities, represents the future.
"If the Democrats are ever going to regain control of the House of Representatives, it will be in districts like this one," Mr. Holt said. "This is where America lives, and this is where the issues that motivate Americans are -- education, the environment, will Social Security be there when you retire."
Mr. Mayer, who beat Mr. Holt in a three-way primary in 1996 but came in second to David M. Del Vecchio, said that his three years on a township committee trump Mr. Holt's lack of any elected office.
"I think the issues of the quality of suburban life cut to the core of this district," Mr. Mayer said. "The people here pay the highest auto insurance rates, they pay the highest property taxes, they pay the highest electric rate, they sit in traffic -- you can't say that the economy is doing well and nothing else matters when people are dealing with issues like that."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The New World Order

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
April 30 -- U.S. approves another $1 billion in aid to Indonesia as part of the international $40 billion economic bailout. President Suharto refuses to break up the multibillion-dollar monopolies controlled by himself, family and friends. He says no political reforms until 2003, at earliest. Police break up student protests.
May 1 -- Washington Times and A.P. say C.I.A. reports China has nuclear missiles targeted at U.S. 
 May 3 -- President Clinton's June visit to China will include welcome ceremonies at Tiananmen Square. Washington preparing to allow U.S. companies to sell nuclear reactors to China.
May 4 -- Human rights workers report continued oppression in China and Indonesia; more executions in China than in all the rest of the world.
The U.S., its democratic allies and major dictatorships are rapidly building a new world order -- not quite finished yet but already a central part of international life and values.
Its ideology, powers, rewards and punishments are supplanting those that prevailed internationally until 1994, when President Clinton joined the new order. If it continues, it will be the most important new international concept since the end of World War II.
The order was created without formal parliamentary approval by its sponsors, or any treaty. But every week, sometimes every day, the underlying tenets are revealed, in action. See above.
The following description of objectives and goals of the new order is so different from principles recently assumed in the West, though not always followed, that it may read as satire. It is not.
The fundamental change, demanded by the dictatorships and agreed to in practice by the democracies, is that the internal policies of persecution by the rulers, and the rights of the governed, are not a primary moral or economic consideration of the world.
The democracies, under these values, can protest some internal acts of the dictatorships -- torture and such. But they must do so quietly, not allowing these acts, or often even security interests, to damage the new overriding value of the democratic leaders.
That value is the trade and investment with the dictatorships that the democracies believe important to their national economies -- which are sometimes called jobs, but usually interpreted as corporate profit.
In exchange, dictatorships allow democracies to invest and trade in enterprises the capitalists consider profitable to their corporate strength, although not necessarily to their own employees or the national economic health of their countries.
If the dictatorships, or authoritarian governments as some are known more pleasantly, find their economies collapsing through the corruption generic to such societies, the International Monetary Fund and individual democracies rush to arrive with bailout.
The explanation given is that otherwise the dictatorships' economies would disintegrate, bringing revolution. Now, the people of the dictatorships may long for revolution. Obviously that cannot be allowed to overcome saving the dictatorship and thus rescuing the money invested by nationals of democracies.
Accepting these values, the events dated above become understandable, and even neatly logical.
The Indonesian dictator, for instance, was installed by the army 33 years ago and has been in power ever since. Now he needs scores of billions with which to overcome his own ineptitude and family corruption, and do the right thing by his foreign investors. Who can deny him?
The U.S. gets to sell strategic material to China, offering as an extra a visit by the U.S. President to honor the Communist leaders and expand their power and political life span.
Religious and political mavericks in the totalitarian partners of the new world order get prison, or death, often both.
The press of the democracies gets to write stories about the growth of order in the new order. Other citizens of the democracies get to say costs of imported goods are down, how nice.
Americans and Europeans may come to object for political or moral reasons, or because the new world order may after all cost them their jobs. But they will never be able to say they never knew; see above.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Friendly $3.6 Billion Bid Could End Brawl for Echlin
Dana made a friendly $3.6 billion stock offer to acquire Echlin, a smaller rival in the auto parts industry and the target of a hostile $3.1 billion bid of cash and stock from SPX. Echlin shares rose 8.4 percent and Dana fell 5.2 percent. The bid could end a takeover battle that began nearly three months ago.
Echlin would, in effect, become a seventh business unit at Dana. Echlin's chairman and president, Larry W. McCurdy, would be named president of the Echlin Strategic Business division and would lead Dana's entry into the aftermarket, where Dana has little presence. Page D2. 

Dow Hits Record in Cautious Market
The Dow Jones industrial average posted a new high of 9,192.66, up 45.59 points. But some analysts were not impressed, noting that volume was moderate and that the gains came mainly from a handful of blue chips, notably Union Carbide and Eastman Kodak. D12.
 
The Treasury market ended its two-day rally, as investors grew wary ahead of a jobs report due Friday. The yield on the long bond was unchanged at 5.93 percent. D12.
 
ARCO in $2.47 Billion Deal
Atlantic Richfield, which has been under pressure to find new oil reserves, said that it would acquire Union Texas Petroleum Holdings, an independent oil company based in Houston, for $29 a share, or $2.47 billion in cash, plus the assumption of debt and preferred stock. D4.
 
Merrill Settles Discrimination Suit
Merrill Lynch and lawyers for female brokers who sued the nation's largest securities firm for gender discrimination reached a settlement that awards the plaintiffs $600,000 and abolishes Merrill's mandatory arbitration process. The settlement affects 2,500 of the firm's current or former brokers. D11.
 
Fed Governor Resigning
Susan M. Phillips, a member of the Federal Reserve Board since 1991, said she would resign from the central bank on June 30. Aside from Alan Greenspan, the chairman named to a third four-year term by President Clinton two years ago, the Fed will then have only one Republican-appointed member, Edward W. Kelley Jr. D2.
 
Tobacco Suit Settlement Sought
Tobacco companies and an insurer have stepped up talks to settle Minnesota's lawsuit against the tobacco industry, lawyers with direct knowledge of the talks said. The state would receive $500 million to $1 billion more than the $4 billion it would have collected under last June's proposed $368.5 billion deal between the industry and 40 states. A28.
 
Traders Dismiss Euro Rancor
World currency traders largely disregarded embarrassing political squabbles among European leaders over plans to introduce a common European currency Jan. 1. European central bankers are expected to face increased pressure to maintain a conservative monetary policy to defend the euro's credibility. D6.
 
Price Shock in Indonesia
President Suharto's Government said it would raise the price of fuel and electricity by as much as 70 percent. The announcement, which shocked many Indonesians, was clearly timed to coincide with the I.M.F.'s decision to restore $1 billion in aid to the country. A6.
 
China's exports and foreign investment surged in the first quarter, defying predictions of harm from neighboring economic crises. D7.
 
Thailand's central bank chief resigned over mistakes that led to the baht's plunge. D6.

HEADLINE: Clinton Unveils Plan to Help Households in U.S. Use Less Fuel

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 4

 BODY:
President Clinton today announced a Government-industry initiative to reduce the gases that contribute to global warming by making homes in the United States more fuel-efficient.
The goal of the program is to cut household energy use in new homes by 50 percent by 2010 through better windows and insulation, energy-saving appliances and more efficient heating and cooling systems. 
 The plan would also help owners of 15 million existing homes cut their energy use by 30 percent by 2010.
The program needs little new money, relying instead on existing tax credits and Federal research money to help spur the development and use of more efficient building technology. The plan is part of the Administration's five-year, $6.3 billion proposal to help the United States reach greenhouse gas emission targets set at the environmental conference in December in Kyoto, Japan.
That plan faces stiff opposition from business groups and Republicans in Congress, many of whom believe the alarms over global warming are overblown and think the proposed solutions will cost businesses billions of dollars and will slow economic growth.
Speaking at a San Fernando Valley site where 186 energy-efficient homes are to be built, the President said that there was "virtual unanimity" among scientists that greenhouse gas emissions were rising at a dangerous rate. He said that while vehicles and industry account for two-thirds of global warming, residential housing contributes 20 percent of the total emissions.
The President said the new program, the Partnership for Advancing Technology in Housing, or PATH, would save consumers as much as $11 billion a year in home energy costs and reduce annual carbon emissions by 24 million tons. That represents about 5 percent of annual carbon emissions in the United States, officials said.
"It will be the most ambitious effort ever to help private home builders and homeowners make cost-effective, energy-saving decisions that will pay big dividends throughout the 21st century," Mr. Clinton said.
Earlier today, Mr. Clinton spoke against a California ballot initiative that would limit unions' ability to use dues from members for contributions to candidates or other political activities. The proposal would require unions, as well as corporations, to get employees' consent in writing each year to use payroll deductions or union dues for political action.
Republicans in Congress argue that such a requirement should be part of any Federal campaign finance legislation. But since little appears to be happening in Washington, opponents of unions' political spending are pushing the issue in several states.
The California measure, Proposition 226, is backed by business groups and Republican politicians, including Gov. Pete Wilson. It also has support from union members, according to California polls.
The Clinton Administration and labor leaders oppose the measure, saying it would limit the ability of unions to match business groups' political spending.
"This is just an attempt to put unions at a disadvantage to other organized groups in the political marketplace and thereby to diminish the voice of working men and women," Mr. Clinton said at a breakfast to raise money to fight the measure.
Mr. Clinton returns to Washington tonight, after a stop in Chicago to raise money for the re-election campaign of Senator Carol Moseley-Braun, Democrat of Illinois.

HEADLINE: A Plot on Castro Spotlights A Powerful Group of Exiles

BYLINE: By ANN LOUISE BARDACH and LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R., May 3

 BODY:
When the Coast Guard approached the cabin cruiser La Esperanza near Puerto Rico last October, the four Cuban exiles aboard said they were on a fishing trip.
But the only fishing gear on the boat was still in plastic wrappers, and the men said they had sailed the 900 miles from Miami in a single day -- a nautical improbability in their vessel. 
 Suspicions aroused, the Coast Guard escorted the boat to shore, searched it, and found beneath a throw rug a secret compartment built into the stairs leading to the cabins. Inside was an arsenal of weapons, including nightscopes and two high-powered sniper rifles.
With that, one of the men aboard blurted out an explanation that prompted their immediate arrest.
"These weapons are mine," Angel Alfonso Aleman was quoted as saying by a United States Customs investigator who searched the ship and later testified in court about the remark. "The others know nothing about them. I placed them there myself. They are weapons for the purpose of assassinating Fidel Castro. "
The incident touched off a widening Federal investigation that Government officials say has led authorities to one of the most powerful lobbying organizations in the United States, the Cuban-American National Foundation.
The group, which has raised more than $1 million for both Republicans and Democrats, has publicly advocated nonviolent approaches to foment change in Cuba and has forged close ties to every President since Ronald Reagan.
Its combative chairman and founder, Jorge Mas Canosa, was the behind-the-scenes architect of America's hard-line policies on Cuba before his death last year from lung cancer.
President Clinton met privately with two of the foundation's leaders at a fund-raiser in Miami last year, shortly after Federal investigators had begun to examine the group's possible role in a plot to kill Mr. Castro.
Investigators began scrutinizing the foundation shortly after the discovery of the weapons aboard La Esperanza.
The navigational coordinates aboard the boat were set for Margarita Island off Venezuela, where Mr. Castro and other Latin American leaders were to meet for a summit meeting in early November.
One of two .50 caliber Barrett assault rifles seized on board turned out to be registered to Francisco (Pepe) Hernandez, president of the the foundation, according to an F.B.I. report. The tan 46-foot cabin cruiser itself, Florida state records show, belonged to a company owned by Jose Antonio Llama, a member of the foundation's executive board. The boat set sail from Coral Gables, Fla., from the private dock of another foundation member whose business partner is the group's treasurer.
 
Two Are Notified They Are Targets
Since then, according to lawyers involved in the case, both Mr. Hernandez and Mr. Llama have been notified that they are targets of a Federal investigation, a formal step prosecutors take when they are seriously considering an indictment. Neither man was aboard the boat.
Ninoska Perez, a spokesman, said the foundation and its leaders had no comment on any aspect of the case.
"You can publish whatever you want, but we're not going to make any comment whatsoever," Manuel Vazquez, a Miami lawyer who represents Mr. Hernandez, said in response to a request for his client's version of events.
Jose Antonio Pagan, who represents Mr. Llama, acknowledged that his client owns the company that owns La Esperanza and that he was asked to supply fingerprint and handwriting samples to the F.B.I., but that he "definitely denied" he had sought to kill the Cuban leader.
The lawyer representing Mr. Alfonso, Ricardo Pesquera, warned in an interview that should the Justice Department try his client, "we will go after the Government very strongly" and "attack their hypocrisy." Brandishing a sheaf of declassified C.I.A. documents about Government efforts to overthrow the Cuban leader, he complained that "for 30 years they tried to kill Castro and now they say others can't do the very same thing they were doing."
The only charges brought in the case thus far were against the four men arrested aboard La Esperanza, who have been accused of conspiracy to commit murder, weapons smuggling and making false statements.
At a pretrial hearing, defense lawyers persuaded a judge here to dismiss the conspiracy charge on the ground that the evidence was insufficient. But defense lawyers and Federal investigators say they expect the conspiracy charges will be reinstated in a more detailed indictment. And one investigator predicted that the case would expand.
"You don't go out on a fishing expedition with .50 caliber weapons," said Hector M. Pesquera, chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's office in San Juan. "It doesn't compute. We have got to pursue this. Most likely, additional defendants and counts will be added."
In those circumstances, he continued, "there could be foreign policy implications." He added, "We are not ruling anything out."
 
A Leader's Death Leaves a Vacuum
The inquiry comes at an especially delicate and troubling time for the Cuban-American National Foundation.
Since its founding in 1981, the group has argued to America's 1.5 million Cuban-Americans that the most effective way they can undermine Mr. Castro is through lobbying and legislation in Washington.
In August, the foundation startled some in Miami when it declined to condemn a string of bombings ofhotels and restaurants in Cuba.
The death of Mr. Mas Canosa has left it with a leadership vacuum that remains unfilled.
In addition, Miami-Dade County is now investigating irregularities and possible overcharges in a $58 million contract awarded to the Mas family business, and Congress is considering new legislation that would somewhat loosen the 36-year economic embargo against Cuba that the foundation vigorously supports.
If the Federal inquiry establishes that its leaders supported commando activities against Mr. Castro or the Cuban Government, that would weaken the organization's credibility on Capitol Hill and leave an opening for those who favor a less confrontational approach to Cuba.
Among the items Customs and Coast Guard officials found aboard La Esperanza were seven boxes of ammunition, military fatigues, six portable radios, a satellite telephone, night vision goggles, nightscopes and the two assault rifles, which sell for about $7,000 apiece and can hit a target more than mile away. Extra fuel tanks holding an additional 2,000 gallons of fuel had also been built into the vessel.
Shortly after the boat's seizure on Oct. 27, numerous news organizations in Miami received anonymous telephone calls or letters asserting that the assassination plot against Mr. Castro was an attempt to grant Mr. Mas Canosa a deathbed wish.
 
A Man's Self-Portrait: 'A Cuban Patriot'
In a series of interviews at his home in Union City, N.J. and here, Mr. Alfonso said that, on his lawyer's advice, he could not discuss the statements that Government officials have attributed to him. But he made no secret of his loathing of Mr. Castro and his admiration for Mr. Mas Canosa, whom he described as "a true leader who dedicated his life to the struggle."
"I am a Cuban patriot," said Mr. Alfonso, who now works at a textile company in Union City. Referring to his fight against the dictatorship of Fulgencio Batista, he added: "I was a revolutionary, and I am a revolutionary. But I was not a Fidelista."
Mr. Alfonso, 57, who is an active member of the Association of Former Prisoners, a fraternity of some 300 veterans of Cuban jails, said he had visited the White House on four occasions, "once with Reagan, once with Bush, and twice with Clinton."
With pride, he produced a photograph of himself alone with Mr. Clinton, as well as other pictures that show him with Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey; Mr. Mas Canosa, and Felix Rodriguez, the C.I.A. agent who captured Che Guevara and later became embroiled in the Iran-contra affair. The photo with the President was taken two years ago at a White House ceremony for the signing of the Helms-Burton Act, which expands the American embargo against Cuba.
A passionate, voluble man with courtly manners, Mr. Alfonso scoffed at the notion that he was acting on behalf of Mr. Mas Canosa or anyone else. "Nobody can use me," he said. "I think for myself."
He said that he first met Mr. Mas Canosa in Miami in 1980, just before the Cuban-American National Foundation was founded, and last saw him about six months before his death, when Mr. Mas Canosa visited Mr. Alfonso's group in Union City.
Because of his anti-Castro activities, Mr. Alfonso served 18 years in Cuban prisons, where he first met Francisco S. Cordova, one of the men arrested with him aboard La Esperanza. Mr. Cordova, in turn, told F.B.I. investigators that he had been a friend since childhood of Angel Hernandez Rojo, the captain of the vessel, and knew Mr. Llama, the owner of the boat, through what an F.B.I. document described as "casual social contacts."
Both Mr. Hernandez Rojo and Mr. Llama took part in the C.I.A.'s Bay of Pigs operation in 1961.
 
12 Mysterious Bullets: Where's the Gun?
According to an F.B.I. report, Mr. Cordova, 50, a fisherman who lives in the Florida Keys town of Marathon, said he was on the trip to sell the vessel on the Caribbean island of St. Lucia and was unaware of the arms on board.
He was quoted as saying that had he known, "he would have discarded them overboard" when approached by the Coast Guard, "a technique," the report said, "commonly utilized by Cuban exiles when confronted by law enforcement on the high seas."
In fact, investigators are puzzled by the presence on the boat of 12 rounds of .357 bullets with no corresponding pistols, and suspect that at least one gun may have been tossed overboard.
All four men were eventually released on bail. Mr. Alfonso said his $50,000 bail and a $50,000 retainer for a lawyer "was paid by Cuban exile groups and individuals" in the United States, though he declined to be more specific.
As part of their investigation, Federal agents have been looking into the flow of money in and out of a Miami bank account in the name of Juan Bautista Marquez, 62, a former merchant marine who runs a boat rental business in Cancun, Mexico, and was the fourth man aboard the vessel. Investigators have submitted those records to the grand jury here, focusing on a $2,000 transfer into the account in July 1997, court documents show. The source of money has not yet been publicly identified.
Mr. Marquez's lawyer, Juan Massini, said his client was asked by an acquaintance he knew as "Mr. Otero" to sail the boat for Mr. Llama for a fee of $2,000. Mr. Marquez, who was retained to be the navigator, knew both Mr. Hernandez Rojo and Mr. Cordova, Mr. Massini said, but had never met Mr. Alfonso before La Esperanza set sail.
The seriousness that the Government attaches to the case can be measured by the number of agencies collaborating in the investigation. Government officials say these include the United States Attorney here, Customs, the Coast Guard, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, the Maritime Enforcement Agency, the C.I.A., the F.B.I. and the State Department. The prosecution is being directed by Miguel Pereira of the division of violent crimes and terrorism at the Justice Department's Washington headquarters.
 
Two Different Accounts Of the Boat's Voyage
Government investigators acknowledge that the case began by sheer chance. The Coast Guard cutter Baranof was making a routine patrol off northwestern Puerto Rico when it spotted La Esperanza. Only after the captain gave an incorrect registration number and asserted that La Esperanza had sailed from Miami in a single day was it decided to board the vessel.
Initially, the captain, Mr. Hernandez Rojo, said that the purpose of he and the others "was to go fishing," but that they had run into bad weather and were turning back because a pump had failed and they were taking on water. However, when investigators contacted Mr. Llama, the boat's owner, in Miami, he told them the four men were on their way to Venezuela to sell the vessel.
"They were looking for drugs, frankly," one official said of the Coast Guard "When four men on a boat in trouble tell you a funky story, we look for drugs."
Once the arms cache was found, Mr. Alfonso, described as visibly agitated, also acknowledged a Venezuelan connection. "I have a contact on Margarita," Federal agents said he told them, referring to the island where Mr. Castro and leaders of more than 20 other countries were scheduled to meet on Nov. 7-9.
"Look at all the entries in my passport going to Venezuela," the agents testified that Mr. Alfonso also said. "Do you think I went there on vacation?"
After the arrest, the Venezuelan Government made an unusually thorough security sweep on Margarita Island. All Cuban exiles found on the island were taken into custody and forced to leave, though the reason for those actions was never made public.
As for Mr. Alfonso, the incident does not appear to have diminished his devotion to the anti-Castro cause.
"I love life, I love my children," he said. Then, pressing his hand to his heart, he added: "But the most important thing are my principles, and for these I am prepared to sacrifice everything and return to jail. I am not afraid. I am at peace with my conscience."

HEADLINE: COLLEGES;
Assistant Coaches Win N.C.A.A. Suit; $66 Million Award

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
A Federal jury in Kansas awarded more than $66 million yesterday to 1,900 assistant college coaches whose salaries were found to have been illegally restricted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The penalty, which included more than $22 million in back wages, penalties and legal fees that were tripled under Federal antitrust law, was by far the largest court assessment against the association, which regulates and administers major intercollegiate sports.
The verdict came after five years of often tortuous legal wrangling, in which the coaches contended that a blanket rule imposed by the N.C.A.A. in 1992 to restrict the salaries of certain assistant coaches to $12,000 for an academic year had stifled competition and deprived them of fair market wages. 
 The N.C.A.A., which said yesterday that it was considering appealing the award, had established the salary limit for certain assistant coaches at the 300 major athletic programs that make up Division I college sports as a way of containing costs.
The N.C.A.A. likened the lower-tier assistant coaches to graduate student teaching assistants in history or math, who traditionally work long hours for low pay and valuable experience.
In effect, the jury agreed with the contention of the coaches that the millions of dollars generated by college sports made any comparison to teaching History 101 misplaced.
The coaches had sought $30 million, basing their claim on estimates of what they would have earned in a fully open market. The $12,000 cap, the coaches said, often amounted to less than a third of what others who did similar work at major universities were paid.
"We didn't want it to come to this," said Andy Greer, an assistant men's basketball coach at Northern Illinois University. "They made a mistake and now they're learning a very painful lesson -- that when people in your organization have concerns, you need to take some time and listen."
The N.C.A.A. has said the policy limiting salaries for the assistant coaches was lifted in 1995 after United States District Judge Kathryn H. Vratil ruled that the restrictions violated antitrust law. The judge's ruling was appealed by the N.C.A.A. and affirmed by a Federal appeals panel in Denver earlier this year.
Yesterday's monetary penalty was the second major blow to the association this year, and another in a series of rulings that curtails its authority. In March, the N.C.A.A. agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle a long-running and highly publicized lawsuit by Jerry Tarkanian, the head basketball coach at Fresno State University, who had contended that the association had persecuted him in applying its rules.
The chief attorney for the association, Elsa Cole, said the judgment would almost certainly be appealed. Ms. Cole said that financial reserves at the association, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., were inadequate to the penalty assessed, and that revenue payments to schools for sports programs would have to be reduced if the order stands.
"It was designed to create opportunity for new coaches and not hurt anybody," Ms. Coles said of the salary limit. "This verdict far exceeds fair compensation, and we cannot pay a judgment that in our judgment unjustly enriches plaintiffs."
Neither the coaches who were involved in the suit nor the N.C.A.A. said they expected any immediate impact from today's award, either in back pay or in some diminished level of collegiate sports financing. Several of the coaches who sued said their salaries had since risen to a level of parity with other assistant coaches, and that money was apparently found to pay them without reductions in coaching staffs.
The rule restricting salaries, approved by the N.C.A.A.'s board at its national convention in 1991, took effect in August 1992. It was aimed at controlling costs, but also, the association said, at providing a career ladder for beginning coaches. The new rules eliminated one coaching position from Division I rosters, cutting the number of assistants to four from five, and capped the salary of the fourth and lowest member of the staff.
The suit, while originally filed by a group of men's basketball coaches, was expanded when it became a class action case to include assistant coaches in men's baseball and in other sports. While the suit was filed on behalf of 1,900 coaches, hundreds of additional assistant coaches could receive compensation under the award, lawyers said.
The jury, which calculated the monetary award after hearing testimony from economists from each side, awarded $11.2 million to the basketball coaches, $1.6 million to the baseball coaches and $9.5 million to coaches in all the other sports -- all tripled. The N.C.A.A. was also required to pay the legal fees and costs of the plaintiffs, which some lawyers said could total another $5 million or more.
Ms. Cole said she would advocate two potential appeals -- a review of the jury's financial award, and of the separate ruling by Judge Vratil. Since the judge's ruling had already been appealed unsuccessfully, another appeal would have to be pursued with the United States Supreme Court. An appeal of the jury's award would go to the circuit court appellate level, where it could take perhaps a year or even two for a resolution, Ms. Cole said.
In the meantime, she said, the association would implore its member colleges not to retaliate against the coaches involved in the suit. Some coaches said they were nonetheless afraid that the N.C.A.A. would retaliate in some way, either against them or with cuts in revenue for certain sports.
"For a while there is going to be a little fear," said Mike Jarvis Jr., another plaintiff, who is an assistant men's basketball coach at George Washington University and the son of the team's head coach, Mike Jarvis. "But hopefully we can get it resolved soon so that everybody can move on."
Mr. Greer and other coaches said they had a hard time believing the association's claim that it could not afford the jury's award. The N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament alone is worth an average of $215 million, for example, under an eight-year contract with CBS signed in 1994.
But the coaches also said the suit was always about more than money.
"The coaches came together and pulled as a group, united as one -- that's as big a thing as anything," Mr. Greer said.
 "But this is something they chose to happen," he added, referring to the N.C.A.A., "not the coaches."
Murray Sperber, a professor of English and American studies at Indiana University and an expert on the N.C.A.A., said: "Very few Americans believe that college basketball and football are really amateur sports anymore.
"Today the jury basically said, 'No, it's a professional organization and the market should rule.' "

HEADLINE: Jolting Its Citizens, Indonesia Sharply Raises Energy Cost

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 4

 BODY:
Just hours before the International Monetary Fund unanimously approved restoring financial aid to Indonesia, President Suharto's Government announced plans today to raise the price of fuel and electricity by as much as 70 percent.
The announcement, fulfilling commitments to the I.M.F. that the Government has long resisted, left many Indonesians shocked, and they lined up by the thousands at gas stations here to buy a last tank of cheap gasoline. President Suharto clearly timed today's announcement to coincide with the I.M.F.'s approval of $1 billion in emergency aid to his ailing country. 
 In Washington, the United States, which holds enormous sway within the I.M.F., said on Monday that it approved the I.M.F.'s moves. Officials declared that Indonesia is finally enacting a number of major economic reforms after months of delay. But they said they insisted that Mr. Suharto's progress must be evaluated month by month. Officials praised Indonesia's progress in tightening credit, restoring discipline over the central bank, beginning to deal with insolvent commercial banks and negotiating with overseas creditors, who are owed about $70 billion.
 "We are under no illusions that everything will be smooth sailing from now on out," Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official at the fund, said at a news conference. "We will follow it very closely. There really is not much room for slippage."
Responding to sharp criticism from the I.M.F., the Suharto Government also announced plans to dismantle a vast monopoly in cloves. The continuing monopoly -- despite past commitments to dismantle it -- had been another major sticking point with the I.M.F. It is controlled by Mr. Suharto's youngest son, Tommy, and epitomizes the crony capitalism that has weighed down Indonesia's economy.
Last week Indonesian officials were already insisting that the monopoly had been broken up. But in interviews, people involved in the Indonesian cigarette trade, in which the cloves are used, said that Government officials were not providing the stickers necessary to sell cigarette packs unless the companies were buying their cloves from the younger Mr. Suharto's business.
The I.M.F.'s effectiveness in breaking up the Suharto family empire, which dominates business here, is clearly one of the most important yardsticks of progress to Indonesians who are protesting the 76-year-old leader's rule. In central Indonesia this weekend, protesters broke into a showroom and burned a car produced by the national car company, which Tommy Suharto also controls.
Other disputes have centered on a cartel in the plywood industry, which was controlled by one of Mr. Suharto's closest friends, Bob Hassan. Mr. Hassan is now Minister of Industry and Trade.
But the I.M.F., which has made Mr. Suharto's industrial monopolies a clear target, has clearly decided that the best way to deal with Mr. Suharto is to praise his moves toward reform, and reward them with relatively small injections of cash from the $43 billion bailout package.
In Singapore today, the director general of the I.M.F., Michel Camdessus, commended Indonesia for taking steps toward reform.
But for Indonesia's citizens -- who are already struggling with rampant unemployment, spiraling inflation and a devalued currency -- economic reform seemed just another word for misery.
"It's always the common people who get hurt," said Nana, a 45-year-old driver, as he sat in a two-hour traffic jam on a sweltering side street to fill up his van. "I oppose the Government's policies, but what am I going to do about it?"
The bigger threat to the Suharto Government comes from students, who have staged increasingly violent protests in recent days and stridently oppose increases in fuel and electricity prices. Students clashed with the police again today in Medan, a city in northern Indonesia, and there were scattered protests on campuses in Jakarta and Surabaya. A mob of more than 1,000 people in Medan burned a police post and a shopping mall and damaged dozens of small shops during a riot on Monday night that lasted into the early hours of Tuesday before the police broke it up, Reuters reported.
One student leader hinted that the students would organize a major demonstration in Jakarta later this week to protest the higher prices.
"The Government's policy is counter-productive," said Rama Pratama, chairman of the Student Senate at the University of Indonesia in Jakarta. "The rising price of fuel only makes matters worse for people."
Economic hardship and politicized students are a volatile mix in Indonesia. Today Indonesia's Defense Minister, General Wiranto, warned that the military would take "stern action" against any demonstrations that moved outside campus gates. But the price increases will provide fresh ammunition for students who have been calling for President Suharto to step down.
Indonesian officials acknowledged at a news conference today that the decision to raise prices was difficult. But they noted that the Government was spending more than $3.5 billion a year to subsidize fuel and electricity -- money that could be better spent on medicine and food. The level of subsidies exploded after Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, collapsed last fall, which made imported petroleum more costly.
The price increases will also ripple through the transportation industry, making buses, trains and taxis more expensive.
The I.M.F. originally demanded that Indonesia scrap the subsidies by April 1, but the Suharto Government negotiated a one-month reprieve. The I.M.F. also backed away from its earlier insistence that it immediately end subsidies on major food products and that the Government-controlled food monopoly be broken up. The monopoly controls the food distribution system, and without it, officials feared, food riots would quickly spread around the country.

CORRECTION-DATE: May 9, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about Indonesia's decision to raise prices for fuel and electricity referred incorrectly to the youngest son of President Suharto. His name is Hutomo Mandala Putra, not Tommy Suharto. (Tommy is his nickname.)

HEADLINE: New Operators Likely for Rainbow Room at End of Year

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Seeking to garner even more revenue from the Rainbow Room, which paid $3 million in rent last year, and to update its image, the landlord of the famous tourist destination said yesterday that it would be turned over to new owners when its lease expires at the end of the year.
"The restaurant will change hands," said Jerry T. Speyer, the president and chief executive of Tishman Speyer Properties, which is both a part-owner and the manager of Rockefeller Center. 
 On the 65th floor of 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the 1930's-era Rainbow Room -- known for its sweeping views, 12-piece orchestras and slowly revolving dance floor -- is the second-highest-grossing restaurant in the nation.
Recently, after weeks of heated negotiations, the current operators, Joseph Baum and David Emil, agreed to join forces with Drew Nieporent, the restaurateur, to spice up the Rainbow Room. But they refused to accept the financial terms that Mr. Speyer had set for renewing their lease.
Under those terms, the restaurateurs would have paid about $4 million a year in rent, said by real estate experts to be the highest in the industry. Mr. Baum and Mr. Emil decided against the new lease because it would not allow for a rent reduction if the economy soured.
"Our negotiations with the Baum-Emil group terminated approximately two months ago," Mr. Speyer said. "We do not expect to resume those negotiations."
Now, Tishman Speyer is talking about leasing the Rainbow Room to the family that owns Harry Cipriani, a restaurant at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel on Fifth Avenue. "We are hoping we can take over by the first of the year," said Jeffrey S. Vasser, the chief financial officer for the Ciprianis, who are planning to open a luxury hotel and banquet hall at 55 Wall Street and another restaurant at Grand Central Terminal.
The Ciprianis also own the renowned Harry's Bar in Venice, but they have never operated a restaurant on the scale of the Rainbow Room, where up to 700 meals are served on a busy Saturday night.
As late as Friday, a person connected to Tishman Speyer who insisted on anonymity said the Ciprianis were close to reaching a deal. But late yesterday, he said that some "sticking points" had materialized that could derail the negotiations.
Mr. Vasser said he knew of no obstacles. "What I'm hearing is that everything is moving ahead," he said.
After first being hired as consultants, Mr. Baum and Mr. Emil assumed control of the Rainbow Room in 1985, spending $20 million to renovate it and increasing its gross income to $32 million from about $8 million.
Last month, a trade publication, Restaurants and Institutions, ranked the Rainbow Room as the second-highest-grossing restaurant in the nation, after the Tavern on the Green in Central Park. (In January 1997, after a new chef, Waldy Malouf, was hired, Ruth Reichl, the restaurant critic for The New York Times, awarded the Rainbow Room a three-star rating.)
Even so, Tishman Speyer apparently decided that the restaurant lacked one ingredient to earn even more revenue: a trendier image that would draw more New Yorkers as customers. Since the rent for a restaurant is usually based on a percentage of the gross revenue, more business would mean more income for the property owners.
One person close to the negotiations who insisted on anonymity said Mr. Baum and Mr. Emil were told that their restaurant catered to a "fuddy-duddy" clientele. But Steven Rubenstein, a spokesman for the landlord, denied that such a characterization had been made.
With the expiration of the lease little more than a year away, Tishman Speyer invited proprietors of several of the city's more glamorous restaurants to apply to take over the Rainbow Room.
Among those approached was Mr. Nieporent, the owner of such chic TriBeCa spots as Nobu and Montrachet. He was tempted, he said. "Getting the Rainbow Room is like someone saying, 'Would you like a piece of the New York Yankees?' " Mr. Nieporent said.
Instead of submitting his own bid for the restaurant, however, Mr. Nieporent chose to remain loyal to Mr. Baum, who has been in the restaurant business for nearly half a century, and become a partner. "Joe Baum is one of the people I patterned my own career after," Mr. Nieporent said.
The addition of Mr. Nieporent enhanced the team's prospects of holding onto the restaurant. After what some people in the restaurant business described as a "bakeoff" to secure the lease, the Baum-Emil-Nieporent team beat out two other finalists: Alan Stillman, the owner of Smith & Wollensky, and Warner LeRoy, the owner of the Tavern on the Green.
Included in the winning proposal was a plan to turn a storage area two floors above the Rainbow Room and another space adjacent to the main restaurant into a second restaurant, with a chef hired by Mr. Nieporent. David Rockwell, who designed Nobu, would spruce up the Rainbow Room's Art Moderne interior.
By opening the restaurant for lunch and adding new space, Mr. Baum and Mr. Emil estimated that the restaurant would eventually gross $40 million, and the rent was set to take that increased revenue into account.
But the deal foundered in February when lawyers for Tishman Speyer drafted a lease agreement that would not allow for a reduction in rent if the economy soured. Mr. Nieporent said these terms were too onerous and placed too much of a burden on his shoulders.
Mr. Baum and Mr. Emil decline to discuss the stalled negotiations publicly. "We've always been proud to run the Rainbow Room, and we would like to continue," Mr. Emil said.
Mr. Rubenstein said that Tishman Speyer had been eager to renew the lease with them. "They wanted Joe Baum to remain a part of the Rainbow Room, while reinvigorating it with Drew Nieporent," he said.
Other restaurateurs said they doubted that the Rainbow Room would be turned over to the Ciprianis. "It would surprise me that they would consider anyone who didn't have that kind of experience," Mr. Stillman said.
Like several other restaurateurs, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, the owner of the hot new restaurant Jean-Georges, expressed warm support for Mr. Baum and said he saw no reason to change a winning format. "The food shouldn't be too serious," he said. "It should be simple and straightforward, and that's what it is now. It's a big place. To do really precise food would be a mistake."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 4, 1999, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 5 about the decision to turn over the Rainbow Room to new operators misidentified the restaurant consultants who planned its renovation in the mid-1980's. In addition to Joseph Baum, they were Michael Whiteman and Dennis Sweeney, not David Emil.
The article also referred incorrectly to the ownership of the company that assumed control of the restaurant in 1987. Mr. Baum and Mr. Emil were among the owners, but were not the only ones.

HEADLINE: Wine Talk;
Beaujolais That Ages As Well as Burgundy

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
IT was in the dead of winter some 20 years ago, and the dining room at La Pyramide was half empty. The glory days of the famous restaurant in Vienne, 20 miles south of Lyons, where Fernand Point once reigned, were long past, but there was a feeling about the place -- that at one time great things had happened there.
In an effort to bring back that time, if only for a few minutes, I let the elderly sommelier pick our wines. It was a mistake. Not that his choices -- a St.-Joseph to start and a Cote Rotie from Ampuis, just across the river -- were bad. These are classic wines of the region. 
 But halfway through the meal, I began browsing through the wine list, something I should have done earlier. Among the rare and reasonably priced wines I discovered a small cache of old Beaujolais. Reluctantly pushing the Cote Rotie aside, I ordered a 1937 Morgon.
What a revelation. It was old but still strong and well structured. It had Burgundy characteristics, but it was a gamay wine. A great treat, probably never to be duplicated. Then again, as someone once put it: never say never. There are Beaujolais around that just might have that kind of longevity.
A year ago, The International Wine Cellar, a reputable newsletter, printed an article titled "Real Beaujolais for Real People." There is a lot of good Beaujolais to choose from, the article said, but most people's experience is limited to nouveau, the young wine that appears around Thanksgiving, and to the wines of "the ubiquitous Georges Duboeuf."
Mr. Duboeuf is a negociant, or shipper, who buys his wines from hundreds of small producers in the Beaujolais region. His success in the United States and worldwide is incontestable. Year in and year out, his Beaujolais Villages sets the standard for what a fine commercial wine should be, and his smaller bottlings, like the Jean Descombes Morgon and the Domaine des Rosiers Moulin-a-Vent, rank among the best fine-wine bargains.
So it is no criticism of him or his wines when people whom he has introduced to Beaujolais choose to expand their horizons. In that light, here is a primer for Beaujolais fans.
The Beaujolais region runs from just outside Lyons some 35 miles north to Macon and produces 15 million cases of wine a year. Most of it is called Beaujolais or, if it is a little better stuff, Beaujolais Villages. Some small areas that produce particularly good wine can use the local name. They are Brouilly, Cote de Brouilly, Chiroubles, Chenas, Julienas, Fleurie, Regnie, Morgon, Moulin-a-Vent and St.-Amour. All Beaujolais is made from the gamay grape. There is also a little white Beaujolais made.
The Moulin-a-Vent (which means windmill) from Jacky Janodet is a good example of what smaller winemakers can do. This intense, concentrated wine comes from 65-year-old vines, is dark garnet in color and needs an extra five years in bottle.
In Paris a few months ago, I had a Fleurie from Yvon Metras. It was a beautiful wine but, I thought, available only in France. No longer. Kermit Lynch imports it and, hopefully, doesn't keep it all for his shop in Berkeley, Calif.
Alain Michaud, a producer in Brouilly, makes four versions of his wine. The first, from young vines, is sold to one of the big shippers. The second is a blend from young and old vines; the third is from old vines, and the fourth, from vines more than 90 years old, is made only in the best vintages and, Mr. Michaud says, should be aged eight years.
The felicitously named Louis-Claude Desvignes produces two Morgons, Javernieres and Cote de Puy, from very old vines. These are concentrated wines that will surprise anyone who thinks Beaujolais must taste like strawberry jam.
What will not surprise is that these small-batch Beaujolais are relatively expensive. Some are more than $20 a bottle, where most of the more commercial Beaujolais sell for $7 to $10. The small-producer wines cost more because the gnarled old vines produce less fruit, because the wines get individual care and because the economies of scale available to shippers like Duboeuf elude mom-and-pop winemakers.
Not that all these alternative styles are produced in cottages. In 1996, Louis Jadot, the prominent Burgundy shipping and winemaking firm, purchased the 69-acre Chateau des Jacques, an estate in Moulin-a-Vent that produces wines from five separate vineyards. Two of them tasted recently, the Clos de Rochegres and the Clos de Grand Carquelin, both from 1996, were exceptional Beaujolais in the big style. Both could have used another three to five years in the bottle.
Henry Fessy makes a full-bodied Chiroubles, Cuvee Payraud, that will distinguish anyone's cellar.
Then there is Georges Duboeuf. Along with his separate bottlings like the Descombes Morgon, the Domaine des Rosiers Moulin-a-Vent and his praised Fleurie, Chateau des Deduits, he at times releases older wine, purchased from one of his suppliers or set aside in his own cellars.
These are extremely limited wines and usually will not show up in your local wine store. The Burgundy Wine Company, a retailer in New York, has a few of them. Recently it offered a 1989 St.-Amour at a modest $12.50 and a 1990 Moulin-a-Vent for $29.50, definitely not a hamburger wine.
 
Tastings
Rounded Blend
Lambert Bridge Winery, Crane Creek Cuvee 1994. Dry Creek Valley, Sonoma County, Calif. About $28.
 
THIS is the initial release of Crane Creek Cuvee, a proprietary wine from Lambert Bridge. Proprietary wines are blends, and this one is made of 67 percent cabernet sauvignon, 22 percent merlot and 11 percent cabernet franc. The blend will change from vintage to vintage to achieve a desired style, much the way it is done in Bordeaux. In this case, the wine is unmistakably a cabernet blend, with the signature cassis taste in evidence. The merlot adds roundness and the cabernet franc a touch of austerity. The wine has spent 20 months maturing in French oak, but could easily use two or three more years' time in the bottle to be at its best.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 4; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk
