HEADLINE: For Passionate Home Cooks, It's a Magnificent Obsession

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
WHEN dusk gathers and the dinner hour approaches, New Yorkers quietly divide into two tribes: the consumers and the creators. They look the same. By demographic, ethnic, religious and nearly every other measure, they are indistinguishable. But when it comes to food, they lead different lives.
The consumers eat out, or they buy out. They keep the city's innumerable restaurants afloat. They have made Chinese takeout an internationally recognized symbol of life in New York. In a pinch, the consumers can operate a microwave or give orders to a caterer. They don't like to get too near a stove. 
 The creators cook. They entertain. They shrug off the obstacles posed by tiny kitchens, and make time in a city that gives them none. And New York being the highly competitive, food-obsessed place that it is, the creators firmly believe that they can turn out meals that hold their own with the best restaurants in town. Their guests agree. The creators may not be famous, but they have reputations. Their names get around. They are the ones whose dinner invitations do not get turned down.
On a recent evening, with spring showing signs of serious intent, Deirdre Livingstone organized her first affair of the season, a dinner for her brother, his fiancee and a half-dozen friends.
Ms. Livingstone, a Scotswoman who works as a marketing manager for the British Tourist Authority, started with bite-size portions of haggis piped into phyllo pastry cups that had been lined with turnip mousseline. A pea, pear and mint soup followed. The main course was a steak and kidney pie made with Yorkshire ale, served with sugar snap peas, roasted carrots and parsnips, and funny potatoes carved to look like poached pears. (One baffled guest, insisting that he loathed poached pears, put up fierce resistance but in the end took a tentative bite.) Dessert, another invention, was pecan-whisky-ginger ice cream.
All in all, it was the sort of meal that Ms. Livingstone produces every six weeks or so at her house in Weehawken, N.J., almost as a matter of course. "I don't think of it as work," she said. "I genuinely enjoy the process, which is creative. I also think it's more intimate to entertain or be entertained at home. I miss that eating in a restaurant."
Two nights earlier, and two rivers away, Gordon Churchwell, a writer, was bent over a small, rather battered-looking stove in Park Slope, Brooklyn. A small party of friends seated around his kitchen table had already made quick work of the steak tartare and the silky homemade gravlax. Now, the magic stove was starting to yield a profusion of dishes. Four cats, sensing important developments, filed in through an open window from the backyard.
Mr. Churchwell, who is half Korean, had devised an Asian menu. Pork and beef dumplings in a rich, savory broth. Braised and marinated short ribs with chestnuts, accompanied by homemade kimchee. Spicy, garlicky bulgogi, sizzling on the backyard grill. Sea bass marinated in three misos and accompanied by braised kale and kochijang, Korea's national hot sauce. Mr. Churchwell's wife, Julie Metz, pitched in with a pear tart festooned with a bit of rosemary.
Mr. Churchwell brooded a bit over the gravlax. "I think it could be too subtle," he said. The kimchee bothered him, too. "It really needs another couple of days to ripen," he said. The guests were not complaining. Besides, they were used to Mr. Churchwell's obsessiveness.
"He once called me up and said, 'I think you'd better come over, because I just made 300 dumplings,' " said Jill Herzig, an editor at Glamour magazine and a devotee of Mr. Churchwell's cooking. "Then there was the time we were all supposed to go to a restaurant and celebrate his birthday, but he changed his mind at the last minute and made dinner for 14. I came over and he was in the backyard, grilling more varieties of meat than I've ever seen in one place before."
Food lust in New York is usually measured in phone calls per hour to Balthazar or Le Cirque 2000. But even as untold hours are spent speed-dialing the city's top restaurants, a dedicated population of gifted amateur cooks roam the markets, sniffing fruit, staring fresh fish in the eye and plotting grand culinary adventures. When they eat at restaurants, they tend to be thinking about how they can lift a few ideas from the chef and bring them home to the kitchen.
"I think the joy of food is the adventure of preparing it yourself," Mr. Churchwell said. "The latest restaurant and the latest chef -- that's not where it's at."
The passionate amateurs are a varied bunch who discovered a love for cooking in all sorts of ways. Cheryl Tenia, a nanny from Trinidad, took over the cooking in her family after her mother died. Now, every Sunday, she has as many as 20 friends and relatives over to her house in the Flatlands neighborhood of Brooklyn for dishes like oxtail and beef stew, kingfish or shark stew, callaloo, and macaroni and cheese pie.
Steven Powers of Greenwich Village, an antiques dealer, discovered cooking after becoming a strict vegetarian soon after high school. He picked up a few vegetarian cookbooks but found them long on virtue, short on flavor. "They seemed too countercultural to me," he said. "I'm not a crunchy vegetarian -- too bland."
To please himself, he began developing his own vegan interpretations of classic dishes, like a shepherd's pie made with a Guinness broth, or a lasagna layered with hamburger substitute, portobello mushrooms, spinach and carrots.
Charles Michener of the Upper West Side, an editor at The New Yorker, fumed when his father would parsimoniously divide scrambled eggs for the family. He begged his mother to give him an omelet pan for Christmas. As a teen-ager, he banded together with two school friends and formed a gourmet club, hoping to attract girls by inviting them over for fancy meals. It worked.
The connecting thread that unites these very different people is an almost carnal desire for good food, scant regard for printed recipes, strong organizational skills and more than a dash of hubris.
"I can master some supposedly pretty difficult stuff," Chantal Meyers said. "Not stuffed pig's head yet, but I try to make things that guests would not order out. I'm not intimidated or insecure. When it's good, it's good and I know it."
Like her colleagues in the amateur food fraternity, Ms. Meyers simply loves to entertain, to round up a good-size group, put them together and cut loose. "I can cook all day," she said. "For me it's not a slog, it's an outlet."
Often, she organizes dinners around an ethnic theme. Last month, it was Moroccan night at her Upper West Side apartment, where 16 guests -- "if you have 8, you might as well have 16," she said -- worked their way though a bisteeya with squab, a lamb and prune tagine, chicken with olives and preserved lemon, and couscous.
The meal had a soundtrack, which Ms. Meyers described as "Frenchy funky African." She said: "I like to theme the music. I go out, pick up six or seven CD's, and just blast it."
In the same way that stylish people simply know how to put an outfit together, breaking rules when they feel like it, good amateur chefs work with a free hand. They rummage through cookbooks for ideas but do not feel obliged to follow them exactly. They plagiarize restaurant chefs if they like an idea, or they come up with their own inventions.
"I make it up as I go along," said Usha Cunningham, a physical therapist from Bombay, who routinely gives dinner parties on the Upper East Side for 20 guests. "I don't hesitate to mix Indian and Western spices. I'll mix coriander and tarragon in the same dish. It's never a problem. If I happen to have both I'll use both."
The relaxed approach to flavors, rules and boundaries between cuisines can mask a sometimes ferocious culinary drive, the kind that causes an otherwise rational cook to make 300 dumplings for no apparent reason. At times, the amateurs can sound like the fussiest of fussy French chefs.
"I'm an obsessive maniac," said Howard Adler, a lawyer who learned to cook after his mother, a home economics teacher in the city school system, died when he was 13. "I'm fussy, picky, crazed if I can't find exactly what I want. I'll go to 10 different places to do my shopping. It makes up a large part of my life."
There are strong indications that Mr. Adler, who entertains at the drop of a hat, does not quite know when to stop. He built and installed a wood-burning brick pizza oven in his country house, for one thing. And when 10 guests sat down to dinner last week at his apartment in SoHo, a printed menu lay on each plate.
It's not surprising that most of the amateur chefs describe a similar path of development: initial fumbling efforts, followed by a manic experimental phase, followed by a relaxed simplicity, which is as much a survival tactic as an esthetic choice. The trick to cooking for a dozen guests, they say, is to zero in on dishes that can be prepared either in advance or in stages over several days. Because a fancy dessert can consume precious hours, and there's far less room for error, many of them just buy it.
"We used to have these dinners where we'd just shoot for the moon," Mr. Churchwell said. "You know, things like porcini-mushroom-and-truffle risotto for 18, or a pork roast marinated for five days in a dry rub. That one almost killed me. I worked like an animal and didn't get to enjoy anything."
Rose Marie Morse, the head of Morse Partners, a public relations agency, began cooking as a 16-year-old out of frustration at the small portions her mother served. "She thought eating a lot was vulgar," Ms. Morse said. "I thought it represented abundance and warmth."
In the early 1970's, Ms. Morse said, she entered a manic phase, spending long hours deboning entire chickens for galantines, making puff pastry, baking the tricky meringue cakes known as Windtortes. Eventually, she came out the other side. "Now I've adopted the philosophy that you can judge a cook by how well they roast a chicken," she said. "I make more consoling food now. But delicious. The standard is that it has to be delicious."
Supposedly, one should eat to live, not live to eat. For some New Yorkers, it's not that simple. If you are not eating, or cooking, or planning to cook, can you truly be said to be living? It's all well and good to order from a menu, but where is the sense of satisfaction in signing the check for a meal?
"If people weren't afraid to cook, they'd be much more willing to have people into their homes, and that would affect the rest of their lives," said Martin Fisher, a Manhattan real estate broker, who grew up working in his family's wholesale grocery in Brooklyn. "It leads to friendships and relationships. There's a great social purpose here."
 
PAPPARDELLE AND SHIITAKE MUSHROOMS IN SAFFRON CREAM SAUCE
Adapted from Rose Marie Morse
Time: 30 minutes
 
 Salt
 2 tablespoons light olive oil
 10 large shiitake mushroom caps, cut into thin strips
 1 large tomato, cut into small dice
 2 yellow bell peppers, cut into thin strips
 1 1/2 teaspoons minced garlic
 20 ounces pappardelle or large bow-tie pasta
 1 1/2 pounds rock shrimp (or other small shrimp), peeled and deveined
 1/2 cup white wine
 1/4 cup fish stock or bottled clam broth
 1/4 cup chicken stock
 1 1/2 cups heavy cream
 2 large pinches saffron
 Freshly ground black pepper
 2 tablespoons butter (optional)
 3 tablespoons chopped chives (cut into 1/2 inch lengths).
 
 1. Place a large stock pot (8-quart or larger) of lightly salted water over high heat, to bring to a boil for the pasta. In a large nonstick or well-seasoned saute pan over medium heat, heat 1 tablespoon olive oil and add mushroom slices. Saute until mushrooms are limp, about 2 minutes. Remove from pan with a slotted spoon, and set aside in a bowl.
 2. Add diced tomato to the pan. Saute until heated through, about 1 minute. Remove with a slotted spoon, and place in a bowl.
 3. Add 1/2 tablespoon of the remaining oil to the pan. Add yellow peppers, and saute until limp, about 3 minutes. Remove to a bowl. Add garlic to the pan and saute lightly; do not brown. Remove to bowl of peppers. Place pappardelle in pot of boiling water, and cook until al dente, about 8 minutes.
 4. While pasta is cooking, add remaining 1/2 tablespoon oil to the saute pan. Increase heat to medium-high, and add shrimp. Saute until shrimp are pink but not fully cooked, about 2 minutes. Remove with a slotted spoon, and place in a bowl.
 5. Reduce heat under pan to medium, and add wine, fish stock or clam broth, chicken stock and any juices collected in the bowls of mushrooms, tomatoes, peppers and shrimp. Stir well with a wooden spoon, scraping the bottom of the pan. Add the cream and saffron, and bring to a simmer. Cook, stirring, until sauce thickens and turns yellow from the saffron, about 3 minutes. Add the reserved vegetables and shrimp. Heat through, and add salt and pepper to taste. Add butter, if desired, and stir gently until it has melted. Add chives, reduce heat to very low, and cover pan.
 6. Drain pasta well, and transfer to a warm serving bowl. Add saffron cream sauce, and toss gently to mix well. Serve immediately.
 Yield: 6 servings.
 
KALBI-CHIM
Adapted from Gordon Churchwell
Time: 5 1/2 hours

 3 pounds beef short ribs, or other meaty ribs cross-cut into two strips
 1 1/2 tablespoons sugar
 1 tablespoon sesame oil
 4 large cloves garlic, minced
 6 scallions, chopped
 2 tablespoons minced fresh ginger
 3 tablespoons dry sherry
 4 tablespoons tamari (Japanese soy sauce)
 3 tablespoons mirin (sweet rice wine)
 2 tablespoons peanut oil
 1 onion, chopped
 2 carrots, one minced and the other cut into 1-inch chunks
 3/4 cup chicken or beef broth
 1cup red wine
 10 to 12 dried shiitake mushrooms
 12 fresh chestnuts, peeled, or 12 dried peeled chestnuts, soaked in water for 2 hours, or 12 jarred peeled chestnuts
 1 pear or apple, peeled, cored, chopped.

 1. Score ribs diagonally, and place in a large bowl. Add sugar, and rub into the meat. Rub sesame oil into the meat, and let rest for 15 minutes. Add garlic, scallions, ginger, sherry, tamari and mirin. Rub into meat, and marinate, refrigerated, 2 to 3 hours.
 2. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a Dutch oven or other covered pan large enough to hold ribs in one layer, heat 1 tablespoon peanut oil over medium heat; add chopped onion and minced carrot. Saute until vegetables are tender, 5 minutes. Place ribs on vegetables, meat side down. Add marinade, broth and wine. Bring to a boil on top of stove; cover and place in oven for 1 hour.
 3. While meat is in oven, reconstitute mushrooms by adding boiling water to cover and soaking until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain, pat dry with paper towels and slice thinly. In a small skillet over medium-low heat, heat remaining tablespoon peanut oil, and add mushrooms slices. Saute until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Set aside.
 4. Remove pan from oven, skim fat, and turn ribs meat side up. Add mushrooms, carrot chunks, chestnuts and chopped pear or apple. Cover, and return to oven 1 1/2 to 2 hours, until liquid is almost evaporated.
 5. Before serving, skim fat from liquid in pan. Accompany with rice, kimchi and other Korean condiments and side dishes. Kalbi-chim improves with rest, and may be made the day before, refrigerated and reheated for about 10 minutes in a 350-degree oven.
 Yield: 4 servings.
 
SINGLE MALT WHISKY, CRYSTALLIZED GINGER AND PECAN ICE CREAM
Adapted from Deirdre Livingstone
Time: 20 minutes, plus freezing time
 
 8 tablespoons butter
 1 cup chopped pecans
 Pinch salt
 2 large eggs
 3/4 cup sugar
 2 cups heavy cream
 1 cup milk
 1 cup chopped crystallized ginger
 2 tablespoons single malt whisky.
 
 1. Have ready an ice cream maker with a frozen bowl, or whatever equipment will be needed for freezing the ice cream.
 2. In a small heavy skillet or saucepan over very low heat, melt butter and add pecans and salt. Saute pecans until they begin to darken, 5 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer them to a plate. Reserve butter.
 3. In a large mixing bowl, whisk eggs by hand for 1 minute. Gradually add sugar, and whisk until blended, 2 minutes. Add cream and milk, and blend. Add melted butter; whisk until smooth and thoroughly blended.
 4. Pour mixture into ice cream maker, and freeze according to manufacturer's instructions. When ice cream is stiff and about 2 minutes from finished, add pecans and chopped ginger while the drum is still turning. When really stiff and frozen, add whisky, and blend until whisky is incorporated. The ice cream will soften slightly with the addition of whisky. Transfer to an airtight container, and store in freezer until serving.
 Yield: 1 quart.

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Rose 0.2% in March

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
Strong stock market gains helped push an important gauge of future domestic economic growth ahead in March, the Conference Board said today in a report suggesting the economy will expand steadily.
The group's index of leading indicators, which combines 10 measures of economic activity into one index, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March after increases of four-tenths of 1 percent in February and one-tenth of 1 percent in January. 
 Five measures were higher in March, led by stock prices and money supply, according to the Conference Board, a private research group based in New York. Four fell, notably consumer expectations and the length of the workweek. One, weekly unemployment claims, was unchanged.
The latest data supported the view that the domestic economy remains vibrant despite economic turmoil in Asia.
Michael Boldin, director of the Conference Board's business-cycle research, said it was a positive sign that money supply and stock prices were driving the leading indicators up and suggested they could be signaling continued growth.
"Because these financial series have historically proven to be some of the best predictors of growth, not only is the risk of a recession in the foreseeable future almost nil, but the economy is likely to expand at a brisk pace throughout 1998," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Overseas airlines are following the lead of United States carriers in cutting fares for slow periods.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
UNITED STATES airlines have become skillful at offering periodic low fares and special deals designed to fill seats during slow periods. Foreign airlines have wasted little time following this lead, and at the moment, carriers from three different continents are offering substantial reduced fares -- with the usual restrictions.
Tomorrow only, Britain's Virgin Atlantic is offering a free companion ticket for anyone buying a round-trip economy-class ticket between London and any of the carrier's eight United States gateways: New York; Newark; Boston; Washington; Miami; Orlando, Fla.; Los Angeles, and San Francisco. The one-day sale is to commemorate the cameo appearance tomorrow night of Richard Branson, Virgin Group's chairman, on NBC's "Friends." Fares, depending on the city, range from about $720 to $970. Travel must begin before June 1 and be completed no later than June 15. 
 Those who buy two round-trip adult tickets before June 1 on Air New Zealand for nonstop travel between Los Angeles and Sydney, Australia or Auckland, New Zealand, will get a three-night cruise for both passengers (double occupancy) between Los Angeles and Encanada, Mexico, on Royal Caribbean's Viking Serenade. Air travel must begin before Aug. 16, while cruises must begin before Dec. 14.
And travelers who buy a first-class or business-class ticket for travel by June 30 on Lan Chile Airlines between Miami and any of three South American cities -- Bogota, Colombia; Guayaquil, Ecuador, or Caracas, Venezuela -- will receive a free ticket for a companion flying the identical itinerary.
In other airline news, Delta Air Lines is offering double frequent-flier miles for travel in first class or business class between June 15 and Sept. 1. That is in addition to the usual 50 percent mileage bonus for first-class passengers and 25 percent for business class.
Last Friday, AMR's American Airlines became the first United States carrier to install on a domestic aircraft enhanced medical kits, plus an automatic external defibrillator to treat heart problems.
American has had such equipment on its trans-ocean fleet since last year, and expects to install them in all its 649 jets by the end of this year.
Meanwhile, Varig Brazilian Airlines recently equipped its fleet with the defibrillators and separate handheld electrocardiogram monitors, which the airline said minimized the danger of exhausting batteries in the defibrillators.
 
Delayed Maiden Voyages
Add the 2,600-passenger Grand Princess to the list of new ships that have been delayed this year. The Disney Magic was delayed twice, at a cost of 15 voyages, and is now scheduled to sail July 30, while delay of the Sun Princess resulted in three canceled cruises. Because of what a Princess spokeswoman described as the need merely to "fine tune" the Grand Princess, its maiden voyage will be delayed 12 days, until May 26, when it sails from Istanbul, Turkey, to Barcelona, Spain. Passengers who had been booked on the canceled voyage will receive a full refund plus a 25 percent discount on any future Princess cruise, depending on space available. Princess ships are owned by the Peninsula and Oriental Steam Navigation Company.
 
A Limited Strike
The strike called against Air France for today will have no effect on long-haul flights, the airline said, but could disrupt medium-haul and domestic flights.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
4-Day Rally Comes to Halt On Fear of Rate Increases

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
A four-day rally in stocks fizzled yesterday amid renewed fears that strong economic growth may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
Investors received little consolation from the latest economic reports -- the March index of leading economic indicators and a monthly retail sales report -- which showed further evidence of the robust growth that was glimpsed in last week's reports. 
 The data added to concerns that April's employment report, due Friday, will continue that trend.
"The perception of our market is that this is the last major piece of information before the Federal Open Market Committee meeting that could sway the Fed" to act, said Robert J. Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Scudder Kemper Investments, of the Fed's meeting scheduled for May 19.
Despite the strong evidence of economic growth, Mr. Froehlich and some other analysts believe that the Fed is unlikely to take any action then. "A strong economy isn't enough to get them to act," said Barbara Marcin, senior equity portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management.
While Asia's economic turmoil has had a muted impact on domestic growth thus far, both Mr. Froehlich and Ms. Marcin believe the Fed will not act until it has a clearer indication of how much American corporations will be hurt by the slowdown.
"Until we can get that quantified, they're not going to run the risk of slowing down our economy," Mr. Froehlich said. "There are too many mixed signals and uncertainty."
In the current environment, Ms. Marcin continues to favor financial services stocks, including brokerage firms, insurance companies, asset management firms and banks. Those companies will continue to benefit from the industry's consolidation wave, which may expand to include domestic and international combinations, she said.
Mr. Froehlich suggests investors diversify among various assets and investment strategies, putting some cash into growth and value-oriented investments, for example. Sectors he likes include health care, beverages, and pharmaceuticals, as well as furniture and appliance companies.
After posting a new closing high Monday, the Dow Jones industrial average gave back almost all of those gains yesterday, falling 45.09 points, to 9,147.57. Large, multinational issues such as American Express, General Motors and Eastman Kodak led the declines.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 6.57 points, to 1,115.50. The Nasdaq composite index fell 13.95 points, to 1,864.91.
Among individual stocks, the Cendant Corporation barely nudged yesterday, closing at 24 9/16, down 15/16 after the company reported preliminary first-quarter earnings of 26 cents a share, in line with analysts' forecasts. Cendant fell 46 percent April 16 after the company disclosed accounting irregularities in one of its units. In the health care sector, Pfizer slipped 1 1/16, to 111 5/8, after news Monday that eye doctors and surgeons of the American College of Ophthalmology warned that the Pfizer's potence drug, Viagra, might cause vision problems.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Fall for Second Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities declined for a second day yesterday, as investors await Friday's jobs data and ponder the probability of an increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Prices were also weighed down by a meeting between President Clinton and the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan. 
 The 30-year bond dropped 21/32, to a price of 102 1/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.98 percent, from 5.93 percent on Monday.
Many moves in the bond market come on speculation alone and yesterday's meeting at the White House was no exception. The meeting in all probability was to update the President on all of the nuances of the current economic and inflation picture. Some of the downward price pressures came as some market participants began speculating that the meeting might mean something else: for instance, that the Government was giving the central bank permission to raise interest rates.
"News tape items by Fed officials, speculation about a meeting between the White House and Chairman Greenspan, and other assorted sundry tidbits of market gossip and innuendoes generally kept bond prices within a relatively contained range in thin trading," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst for Chase Asset Management.
He said market reaction to economic data released yesterday was barely perceptible. The index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, an expected outcome as a result of increases in stock prices and money supply.
The employment data for April will be released on Friday and market attention will be focused on the payroll number in order to interpret the trend. Mr. Fine said that the number of new jobs added to the economy averaged 205,000 a month in the first quarter, which he thought was a relatively small number compared with recent economic growth. Most analysts expect a gain of roughly 250,000 jobs for April.
Elsewhere, in the corporate market the AT&T Capital Corporation sold $1.05 billion through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities. The debt offering was broken down into $750 million of three-year notes priced to yield 6.269 percent, or about 63-hundredths of a percentage point more than a three-year Treasury, and $300 million of seven-year notes, yielding 6.614 percent, or about 88-hundredths of a percentage point over the seven-year Treasury note.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Clinton Sees Greenspan; No Word on Rates

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
President Clinton held his first official meeting in 16 months today with Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, in what the White House described as wide-ranging talks that had not been prompted by any specific economic policy issue.
There was no word from either the President's staff or the central bank as to whether the talks had touched on the future direction of domestic interest rates. The meeting lasted about an hour and had earlier been characterized as routine. 
 The session, also attended by Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin and by Gene Sperling, the head of Mr. Clinton's team of economic advisers, had been requested by the Administration.
Advance word of the talks contributed to speculation in financial markets today that Mr. Greenspan might have been seeking to prepare the President for an impending increase in interest rates.
The last official meeting between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Greenspan came in January 1997, two months before the Fed's most recent rate increase. The central bank's policy-making committee will next meet on May 19 and again on June 30.

HEADLINE: Jumping On America's Hospitality Bandwagon;
Foreign Students Choose U.S. for Studying Tourism

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

 BODY:
Nothing is fueling the world's economy quite like its inhabitants' wanderlust. Within the next decade, the global tourism industry is expected to triple in size, to almost two billion travelers spending $1.83 trillion a year, or $5 billion a day. All that growth could create as many as 100 million jobs.
So where is the world turning for guidance on how to handle the crush of visitors? To the Europeans, famed for their grand old hotel schools? Or to the Asians, renowned for their skill at pampering the road-weary? Guess again. It is turning to those masters of nuts-and-bolts business management and McDonald's-style mass marketing -- Americans. 
 Foreign students, many subsidized by governments desperate for more tourism dollars, are flocking to tourism schools across the United States. "We have over 1,000 international students from more than 85 countries this year, 54 percent majoring in hospitality or tourism," said Ana Roche, director of the International Student Center at Johnson & Wales University, which specializes in those trades. "Both those figures are up 75 percent just since 1993."
Statistics on foreign students studying hospitality and tourism in this country do not exist, but the number is thought to be well in the thousands -- and climbing rapidly. Surges similar to that at Johnson & Wales have been recorded in recent years at scores of other American institutions of learning, including George Washington University, Florida International, the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, the University of Houston and Northern Arizona University.
"Twenty-five years ago, about 20 schools in the U.S. had four-year programs for hotels, restaurants and tourism," said Lee Dickson, associate dean of the School of Hospitality Management at Florida International in North Miami, which attracts many students from the Caribbean and Latin America. "Today, at least 160 schools have them."
Aspiring hotel administrators, restaurant managers, casino executives, tour organizers, theme park directors, resort developers and candidates for all the other myriad positions opening up in the industry are streaming to the United States from every continent. And despite tourism's reputation as a source of mostly low-wage jobs, many are making great personal sacrifice for the chance to join the business.
Bridget Mavuma, 26, for example, left her two young children in Botswana two years ago to earn degrees in travel and tourism management here. She misses her children every day, she said, but they are well taken care of by her husband, who was reluctant to trade the African warmth for Rhode Island winters, and by their extended African family. Furthermore, she is confident the sacrifice will pay off after she returns.
"Before, when my country limited the number of tourists, we would study tourism in the U.K., because we're a protectorate of the British Isles," Ms. Mavuma said. "But now, our Government wants more tourists, so they want us to study the U.S. educational system to learn how to do it." Those who do learn, she added, will have the inside track for the best new jobs that will become available.
Andrea de Freitas, 31, of Sao Paulo, Brazil, was also eager to study in America, but did not want to leave behind her 7-year-old son -- so she brought him along to Johnson & Wales. They live in an apartment in nearby Greenville, where the boy is enrolled in a public school, learning English and playing soccer.
Ms. Freitas is looking for part-time work while she attends college, but meantime is sanguine about the future. "When I go back home with my degree, I'll be able to choose whom to work for," she said, adding that her sights are set on an international hotel under construction in Bahia in Northeast Brazil. It should be just about ready to open by the time she returns.
The sudden popularity of American mentoring is largely a reflection of the United States' economic ascendancy in the 1990's. With the nation leading the way into the global economy, even as Japan stagnates and Europe struggles to unify its currencies, American management and marketing techniques are being imitated everywhere as the path to business success.
"There are good, inexpensive schools in Europe," said Donald Hawkins, chairman of the department of tourism and hospitality management at George Washington University in Washington, "but students coming to study in the U.S. want to learn about hospitality and tourism from the world leader." At George Washington, the biggest number of such students in recent years has come from China.
John J. Bowen, the president of the main campus of Johnson & Wales (which has branch campuses in Charleston, S.C.; North Miami; Norfolk, Va., and Vail, Colo.), says the difference between European and American educational priorities is stark. "My European hotel school director friends say, 'We understand service; you understand management and profits,' " Mr. Bowen said.
And if it is a choice between knowing how to deliver good service or making a hefty profit, few tourism industry leaders-in-training hesitate. "We were shocked when our international students told us that American hotel work experience is a more highly valued commodity than European experience," said Moira Oliver, director of human resources at the Hyatt Orlando hotel. Not only does the Hyatt Hotels Corporation hire hundreds of interns each year, its sister company, Hyatt International, often sends fast-track employees to the United States for as much as a year, Ms. Oliver said, to acquire the experience necessary to advance through Hyatt International ranks.
It isn't just a yen for American knowledge and skill that draws so many foreign students to these shores. The fact is, there just are not that many slots open anywhere else. Despite an unprecedented boom in the construction of hotels, resorts, entertainment parks and other tourist attractions worldwide, few foreign colleges have degree programs to teach the necessary management and financial skills to the people who will run them.
For example, Switzerland's highly regarded Ecole Hoteliere de Lausanne, founded in 1893 and the world's oldest hotel school, did not offer a four-year university-level program until 1996.
"We have schools in my country," said Nava Singam, a Malaysian who is studying for a master's degree at the School of Hotel and Restaurant Management at Northern Arizona University in Flagstaff. "But they only offer a two-year diploma. That wouldn't take you beyond middle management with the international hotels, and I always had a vision to do better than that."
An American education can also be a short cut to a career with one of the giant American hotel chains or entertainment conglomerates that straddle the globe. In addition to Hyatt, American Express Travel Services, Inter-Continental Hotels, Universal Studios, Wyndham Hotels and Resorts and assorted cruise lines have recently hired foreign graduates of American schools.
"Experience is important," said Yap Che Che, an ebullient 20-year-old junior from Kuala Lumpur. "But most of the international hotels in Malaysia are American, so it's important to learn American standards and the American system."
Going to school in the United States has the added bonus of familiarizing foreigners with American culture -- handy knowledge when they take up jobs with their government or their country's domestic tourism industry.
"If these countries want to capture the American market, and they do," said Patti Shock, head of the tourism and convention department at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, "they have to learn what Americans want and expect, as well as their idiosyncrasies."
The course work at most American schools centers on marketing, accounting and management. But it also covers such topics as the economics of tourism, managing meetings and conventions, food and beverage operations, travel agency procedures and administration of amusement parks and cruise ships. Courses in tourism range from so-called eco-tourism (a discipline that covers everything from game parks in Africa to protecting local flora) to packaging the historic sites of a city or region in order to attract visitors -- preferably overnight visitors.
"The hands-on approach is important," said Prof. K. S. Chon, who specializes in tourism and hospitality marketing at the University of Houston, "but today you also have to learn marketing, accounting and managerial skills."
After a class in eco-tourism, which on this particular day focused on acid rain formation and ozone depletion, Helena Lofroth, 30, a senior from Skelleftea, Sweden, said, "A lot of people talk about preserving the environment, but it's important for everybody involved in the tourist industry to understand the relationship between nature and tourism."
The economic potential is enormous. Every year, the number of travelers grows by the tens of millions. Yet, some parts of the world have barely begun to build the infrastructure to receive them.
Last year, for example, the entire African continent counted a paltry 23 million visitors who spent $8.7 billion -- compared with 30 million visitors who poured $9.9 billion into Las Vegas alone.
Even wealthy industrialized countries see opportunities to expand. While tourism already accounts for some 200,000 full- or part-time jobs in Sweden, which has a population of 8.9 million, the Government is investing in small tourist businesses in the hopes of creating more jobs. Margareta Winberg, the Swedish Labor Minister, said the Government is counting heavily on tourism to meet its goal of reducing unemployment to 4 percent by 2000 from 6.7 percent today.
Indeed, the second-biggest foreign contingent studying hospitality and tourism at Johnson & Wales (trailing only the 106 students from Thailand) are the 96 students from Sweden, many of whom studied tourism at home before deciding they needed a degree from the United States.
The American economy, too, gets an enormous boost from the travel-and-tourism industry, which accounts for 15.8 million jobs, or one of every 17 working Americans, according to the Travel Industry Association of America.
If a meeting of hotel school directors from some 30 countries here three years ago was any indication, the Europeans and Asians can learn something about responsive service, too.
According to Mr. Bowen, the school's president, the coffee served at the receptions on the first day of the conference tasted weak to most foreign delegates, who were used to the potent concoctions served back home. The next day, after Johnson & Wales doubled the amount of coffee used in brewing, conference participants were astonished.
"Several of them told me if that happened in their country," Mr. Bowen said, "it would have taken a week to change things."

HEADLINE: Public Lives;
On Writing Well and Teaching Even Better

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
William Zinsser is the author of "On Writing Well," a quiet how-to bible that has sold nearly a million copies in 22 years. At 75, he has come to see the teaching of writing as his ministry. Here are some things Mr. Zinsser has told his flock:
Clutter is the disease of American writing. Never use "quotidian" for "daily" or "venue" for "place." Be economical with the semicolon, unless you want to sound like Thomas Hardy. (Maybe you do; Mr. Zinsser himself uses the semicolon more often these days.) The dash -- unfairly considered "a bumpkin at the genteel dinner table of good English" -- will get you out of tight corners. 
 Above all, remember that writing well is lonely and hard, and that all writers are vulnerable and tense.
"They're always going to be vulnerable and tense," Mr. Zinsser said the other day. "And so am I." But try to enjoy yourself, he said. Good writing should entertain. It should also tell readers why an article is being written, and get to the point.
So. Next week Mr. Zinsser is donating his papers to the Fales Library of New York University. There will be a party on Tuesday to celebrate, and also to mark the publication of the sixth edition of "On Writing Well," which Mr. Zinsser updates whenever he learns something new. "I'm still learning stuff that I didn't know five years ago," he said. "No one comes to you in the mid-Medicare years and says, 'That's it! You got it!' "
Mr. Zinsser spoke in his office on East 55th Street, a sparse fourth-floor room rented from a near-bankrupt ad agency, as he luxuriated in the noise of buses groaning down Lexington Avenue. "I love it," he said. Mr. Zinsser grew up in Great Neck on Long Island, now lives on East 62d Street and since the 1970's has worn sneakers with his jackets and ties. He is the courtly offspring of a "very tidy WASP family" -- specifically, a mother who clipped funny newspaper articles for him as a child and a father who was sad when Mr. Zinsser rejected the family shellac business for the wonders of the old New York Herald Tribune. It was, of course, a gentle rebellion; no one has ever called Mr. Zinsser a revolutionary. But dignified and principled, yes.
Mr. Zinsser has had many jobs over the years (chief movie critic of The Herald Tribune was among the best), but the one he cherishes most is teacher. From 1970 to 1979, Mr. Zinsser taught a nonfiction writing course at Yale that grew into his book.
SOME of his students became professional writers, Christopher Buckley and Mark Singer of The New Yorker among them, but many more were civilians who became doctors and lawyers. Mr. Singer has solicited testimonials from them for Mr. Zinsser's party, and judging from the quality of their E-mail, they know, mostly, how to whack through verbal weeds. Mr. Zinsser will be pleased.
"My dad thought that Mr. Zinsser was great, though he never met the man," wrote a succinct Steve Ballou, a family doctor in northwest Quebec. "Of all the work I brought home from Yale, it was my creative-writing papers, and especially the profuse comments in the margins, that interested him. My dad said that he really felt he was getting his money's worth."
Irwin Popowsky, the less succinct Consumer Advocate of Pennsylvania, wrote that Mr. Zinsser's course "had a greater impact on my life" than any other at Yale, and that full sentences from "the best thing" he ever wrote -- a brief for a case he argued before the Supreme Court -- made their way into the court's decision, written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. In other words, the provenance was Mr. Zinsser, and from there the good writing found its way into the language of Mr. Rehnquist, affecting the lives of us all.
Mr. Zinsser has spent a lot of time this past year pulling together what New York University calls the William Zinsser Papers. Since he hates pomposity, written and spoken, he is quick to say that his "papers" consist of his newspaper and magazine articles, as well as 15 books he wrote and 6 he edited. He also has letters from readers and students.
How has he organized it? "Well," he said. "What you do is get new manila envelopes." He gestured to his office bookshelf, where the envelopes were neatly filed, and to a few cardboard boxes on the floor. "My entire life is in this corner," he said. Inside one of the envelopes was a 1963 article from The Saturday Evening Post on a promising new comic, Woody Allen -- one of about 200 magazine articles Mr. Zinsser wrote in a decade as a freelancer.
"I look back on it as being a lonely period," he said. "In fact, my children were born and then they went off to nursery school and I was the only one left at home." Mr. Zinsser's two children are now grown. His wife, Caroline, former director of the Bank Street School, is the program officer for education at the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. They have a weekend house in Connecticut, where Mrs. Zinsser gardens and Mr. Zinsser does not. "I just sort of bicycle around looking for people to talk to," he said cheerfully. "I am not that self-amusing."
Mr. Zinsser went to Princeton and teaches writing at the New School, but is giving his papers to N.Y.U. because the school wants them. Besides, he likes the idea of having the record of his entire professional life in New York.
And he doesn't mind parting with them?
"Well," he said slowly, "I do. But I can get on the No. 6 train and go down and see them."

HEADLINE: Preservationists Criticize Rockefeller Center Renovation Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
Rockefeller Center's plan to accommodate large-scale retailers by expanding its jewel-box Fifth Avenue shopfronts came under criticism yesterday from preservationists who worried that the commercial gain would come at the expense of mid-Manhattan's architectural soul.
At a hearing before the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, whose approval of the plan is required, the owners of the landmark center also parted the curtains slightly on what would be one of the biggest stores in the complex: a two-level NBC retail and entertainment center across 49th Street from Studio 1A, home of the network's "Today" show. 
 The commission will not vote on the proposal until next month. Yesterday, the panel listened to the owners and their architects, Beyer Blinder Belle, and then to private preservation groups that were generally, though not unanimously, opposed to the plan and concerned about how the gilded Prometheus would look in a reconfigured Lower Plaza.
How one views the renovation depends on how one sees the center: as an enormous sum or as many fine parts, as a superbly preserved esthetic masterpiece or as an ever-evolving commercial enterprise.
"Rockefeller Center, since the beginning, has been a dynamic landmark," said Geoffrey P. Wharton, a managing director of Tishman Speyer Properties, the part owner and operator of the center. He said the center "has not, throughout history, successfully addressed itself to Fifth Avenue."
Among many changes contemplated at the center, Tishman Speyer would convert the one-story showcases along Fifth Avenue into two-story storefronts with much more glass and larger signs.
The change would affect the British Empire Building, Maison Francaise, Palazzo d'Italia and International Building North, between 49th and 51st Streets, as well as the Atlas Court.
"Carrying out this significant change would alter the entire architectural arrangement of the Fifth Avenue facades," Charles A. Platt, the chairman of the preservation committee of the Municipal Art Society, wrote in a letter that was read aloud at the hearing.
Replacing the second-story office windows with display windows would have a "particularly disturbing effect on the beautifully executed existing entrances," Mr. Platt wrote.
David Garrard Lowe, the president of the Beaux-Arts Alliance, went further. "It absolutely destroys that facade," he said, "to go from the great, 1930's sophisticated Art Deco to a banal storefront that could be in Ho-Ho-Kus. Wherever that is."
"New Jersey," someone in the hearing room volunteered.
Preservationists also took issue with the proposal to create new entrances from the Lower Plaza to the underground shopping concourse on either side of Paul Manship's statue of Prometheus.
To accomplish this, the red granite backdrop behind Prometheus would be reduced 5 1/2 feet on either side and a new semicircular basin would be constructed, which Mr. Lowe likened to a soap dish.
The most striking objection came from Gene A. Norman, who was chairman of the landmarks commission in 1985 when Rockefeller Center was designated. Former chairmen rarely testify in public on applications before the commission.
Describing Prometheus as an identifying icon of the center, Mr. Norman said, "To change the relationship between the statue and its surroundings I believe to be a mistake."
Referring to Prometheus's mythological role, Christabel Gough, secretary of the Society for the Architecture of the City, said, "Bringing fire from the gods is an activity that requires a little latitude."
Not every preservationist at the hearing spoke against the renovation plan. In fact, the influential New York Landmarks Conservancy offered its support "enthusiastically," said Roger Lang, the director of community programs.
"The best way to preserve landmark buildings is to insure that they're economically viable," Mr. Lang said. "Merchandisers now need larger spaces at many levels to compete."
Like the opponents, however, Mr. Lang urged the commission to reject the proposal for a large granite NBC peacock set into the pavement of Rockefeller Plaza, the three-block private roadway, in front of Studio 1A.
The corner of Rockefeller Plaza and 49th Street would be dominated by NBC if the network signs a lease for 20,000 square feet of space in the base of the G. E. Building. It would build a store whose working name is the "NBC Experience," not only to sell television-related merchandise but to supplement the popular studio tours.
Rockefeller Center has been owned since 1996 by the Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. Trust, which includes Tishman Speyer, Goldman, Sachs & Company, David Rockefeller (who watched the center being built from his bedroom on West 54th Street), and members of the Agnelli and Niarchos families.

HEADLINE: Mayor Proclaims Arts Week To Showcase Student Talent

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
With schoolchildren at his side literally singing his praises for providing money to help restore arts education in some city schools, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday declared May 18-22 Arts Education Week.
Organized by the New York International Festival of the Arts, the event will allow 485 schools, almost half of the schools in the system, to showcase their glee clubs, bands, student artwork and other offerings with special performances and presentations at their schools and elsewhere. 
 The 129 cultural institutions that now assist schools with visiting artists and field trips will also participate as will about 40 professional artists, from the cellist Yo-Yo Ma to the guitarist Vernon Reid, who are scheduled to visit schools.
"New York City, which is truly blessed with boundless treasures of art and culture and is filled with millions of the most talented and creative people on the planet, should have the best arts education in the world," Mr. Giuliani said at City Hall.
Shortly thereafter the "Mosaic Minstrels," a troupe from Public School 254 in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, serenaded the Mayor and other officials with a song promising that "New York will have a treat, come May 18" with all the singing and dancing.
"Oh, the Mayor, Chancellor Crew, our love to you," the children sang as Mr. Giuliani and Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew smiled and chuckled.
The cheery song and laughter reflected the sunnier mood these days among many arts educators. After a fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's and a recession in the 1980's, thousands of teachers were laid off and programs cut, with music and art often the first to go. But over the last few years, initiatives financed by the city and the private Annenberg Foundationhave sought to revive the arts.
The city provided $25 million last year to the Board of Education for Project ARTS (Arts Restoration to the Schools) and has earmarked $50 million for next year. So far, it has reached 438 schools and has led to the hiring of 486 full-time teachers, school officials said.
The Annenberg Foundation has provided $12 million toward a $36 million effort in which 61 schools have been linked with an array of cultural organizations to develop arts-related curriculums over five years.
But many schools still do not have full-time art or music teachers and only limited arrangements with outside artists that often do not involve all students in the school.
Indeed, P.S. 254 in Brooklyn has one music teacher for 570 students and no visual arts teacher. The school, with pupils in kindergarten through fifth grade, did not receive Project ARTS money this year but is scheduled to next year, said the principal, Pearl Glassberg.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Decline on Fears Of Higher Interest Rates
A four-day rally in stocks ended amid renewed fears that robust economic growth may prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. As a result, the Dow Jones industrial average, Standard & Poor's index and Nasdaq composite all declined.
Investors are also waiting for Friday's employment data for April and a clearer indication of just how much American corporations will be affected by the economic turmoil in Asia. Page D10. 

Prices of Treasury securities declined for a second day, sending the yield up to 5.98 percent, from 5.93 percent on Monday. D10.
 
Shares of Donna Karan Soar
Shares of Donna Karan rose nearly 12 percent after the fashion house said first-quarter earnings had more than doubled. The company attributed the increase to its decision to license large parts of its business and the hiring of a new chief executive, John D. Idol, who has cut costs. Donna Karan went public in June 1996 at $24, but its stock has disappointed investors since then. D2.
 
Merrill Case Could End System
A proposed settlement of a discrimination suit filed by women brokers against Merrill Lynch could lead to the end of Wall Street's system for dealing with employee cases through mandatory arbitration. Market Place. D9.
 
Cox Buying Las Vegas Cable System
Cox Communications is buying Prime South Diversified, the cable television system that serves Las Vegas, Nev., as part of a larger deal valued at $1.33 billion. D9.
 
Violence Threatens Indonesian Aid
The International Monetary Fund, with the backing of the Clinton Administration, has sent $1 billion in aid to Indonesia, rewarding the nation for beginning to enact long-promised economic reforms. Yet escalating violence could quickly sink the effort to stabilize the economy. A12.
 
Leading Indicators Climb 0.2%
The Conference Board's index of leading indicators, which combines 10 measures of economic activity into one index, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March. Half of the measures, including stock prices and money supply, increased, while four fell, notably consumer expectations and the length of the workweek. Weekly unemployment claims were unchanged. D3.
 
Vote Postponed on Financial Bill
Voting on a bill to revamp laws governing the financial services industries will be delayed until next week, the House Republican leader, Representative Dick Armey, announced. D2.
 
Cendant Earnings Top Expectations
The marketing and franchising company Cendant, which reported accounting problems last month, said it earned $230 million, or 26 cents a share, in the first quarter, slightly beating Wall Street expectations. The results, however, may be revised because of the investigation of the accounting irregularities at one of its units. D2.
 
Investigation Focuses on Allstate
Federal investigators are looking into allegations that Allstate Insurance doctored documents to reduce policyholders' claim amounts following the 1994 earthquake in Northridge, Calif. D9.
 
Microsoft Lobbies for Windows 98
Microsoft and computer industry executives urged Federal and state antitrust officials to permit the scheduled May 15 introduction of Microsoft's newest personal computer operating system, Windows 98. D2.

HEADLINE: A Huge Building Honors A Foe of Bigness: Reagan

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
They have short memories inside the Beltway.
Ronald Reagan, you may recall, was the President who abhorred big Government, cost overruns and busybody Federal regulators. He made that clear as soon as he hit town, declaring in his inaugural address in 1981: "Government is not the solution to our problem. Government is the problem." 
 And he kept right at it. Once he told a crowd in Montana: "The source of our economic problems is finally beginning to dawn on the bafflegabbers and those fancy dudes in Washington: Government is too big and it spends too much."
Well, nobody as much as breathed such ideas today, at least in public, when some of the capital's fanciest dudes turned out to help dedicate the second-biggest United States Government building ever constructed (after the Pentagon). It came in at $816 million, a mere $448 million more than Congress projected in 1987. It will house, among others, a large contingent from the Environmental Protection Agency, which President Reagan cordially loathed.
But the Gipper's name is chiseled into the limestone facade anyway. The Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center joins a medical institute at George Washington University, the Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport across the Potomac River in Virginia, a bridge in Illinois, a freeway in California, a turnpike in Florida and a state office building in Los Angeles on the long list of tributes to the nation's 40th President.
Standing in the building's soaring atrium, President Clinton said that he sensed "the essence" of Mr. Reagan in "this incredible space." Standing in for her husband, now 87 and ill with Alzheimer's disease, Nancy Reagan hailed the sprawling, L-shaped, sort-of-modern structure as "magnificent."
Magnificently big, without question; the concrete used in the building would pave 106 miles of two-lane highway, the floor space exceeds that of the Empire State Building and the exterior contains 42,000 slabs of Indiana limestone. There are no fewer than 13,000 doors and 21,000 light fixtures inside.
Designed by James Ingo Freed, the building completes the Federal Triangle, a complex of Government properties authorized by Congress in 1926 to replace a shabby neighborhood along Pennsylvania Avenue, a few blocks from the White House.
The style of the structure is severe. Unlike the 1908 John Wilson building that nestles within its "L," its columns have no fluting, its capitals have no carving and its facade is bereft of swags, shields and moldings. It looks like a neo-Classical building waiting for the stone carvers to show up.
The idea was to complement but not to mimic the academic style of its neighbors. In that it succeeds, but it has none of the freshness or clarity of Washington's most celebrated modern building, the angular East Building of the National Gallery, farther down the avenue. That was designed by Mr. Freed's partner, I. M. Pei.
Eventually, the structure will house 7,000 Federal workers, a 980-seat food court, restaurants and a privately run trade center that includes office space, a 650-seat auditorium and extensive exhibition spaces.
For his part, Mr. Clinton used the occasion to recall Mr. Reagan as an internationalist and to urge Mr. Reagan's Republican followers in Congress to honor his legacy by providing money for the International Monetary Fund and the United Nations.
"President Reagan once said we had made what he called 'an unbreakable commitment' to the I.M.F., one that was unbreakable because in this age of economic interdependence, an investment in the I.M.F. is simply an investment in American prosperity," Mr. Clinton said today.
Then he quoted Mr. Reagan as saying in 1985: " 'The U.N. stands as the symbol of the hopes of all mankind for a more peaceful and productive world. We must not disappoint those hopes.' We still must not disappoint those hopes."
There is almost as much disagreement over the building as over international spending. Some find it dignified and impressive; Benjamin Forgey of The Washington Post called it "brilliant." But Deborah Dietsch, former editor of Architecture magazine, said its "watered-down classicism" was "neither fish nor fowl."
Michael Reagan, the President's eldest son, derided it last year as Mount Wastemore.
Representative John J. (Jimmy) Duncan Jr., a Tennessee Republican who has been one the project's most persistent critics, said: "It's one of the biggest boondoggles ever seen in Federal construction.. We will wind up with a beautiful, well-constructed building, but one that will cost twice what it should have."
Washington is like that, as Ronald Reagan himself discovered. Things grow. When he took over from Jimmy Carter, the Federal deficit stood at $73.8 billion. Eight years later, as George Bush took office, it stood at $155 billion.

HEADLINE: The Indonesian Tangle: How It Enmeshes the U.S.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 5

 BODY:
In the last few days, President Suharto has ruled out any significant expansion of political freedom in Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation, until 2002, if not later. And his military chief has warned that protests could grow into anarchy, and promised "stern action" to quell student unrest.
Inside the Clinton Administration, those announcements signaled the possibility of enormous trouble ahead, as it worried that repression would only worsen the unrest. 
 On Monday, thousands of people angry about price increases rampaged in the worst outbreak of violence in Indonesia since its economy buckled last year. At least 94 people were taken into police custody.
Unlike student protesters, the rioters focused primarily on economic problems.
Officials in Washington worry that it is not possible to reverse Indonesia's flight of investors if they are fretting that the country is about to descend into chaos. And without the return of investors, the economy will worsen further.
So even as the State Department was expressing "extreme concern" about reports of escalating violence and the kidnapping of dissidents, the Clinton Administration on Monday voted through the International Monetary Fund to restart aid to Indonesia.
As it has since the Indonesian crisis began, the Administration once again put the top priority on economic stability. The fund, rewarding Indonesia for enacting some long-promised economic reforms, sent $1 billion and promised that more would follow if reforms continued.
As Administration officials readily concede, this could be their year of living dangerously with Indonesia. The entire economic rescue, a top official noted recently, "goes down the tubes if the place erupts," in a vicious cycle of economic and political collapse.
This was not a problem in South Korea and Thailand, the other Asian countries receiving I.M.F. aid, which were strengthening democratic institutions at the same time as they were undergoing economic reforms.
In recent days, in conversations with Indonesian officials here and in Jakarta, Administration officials have repeatedly warned that growing violence is undermining the confidence of the markets, just as President Suharto is desperately trying to raise the value of the country's currency.
In short, they are suggesting that the markets may accomplish what Washington cannot compel: meting out punishment if Indonesia cannot avert growing instability and a political crackdown.
And yet, in public at least, the Administration continues to maintain that questions of human rights and economic stability are divorced from each other. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin's priority throughout the Asian crisis has been to contain economic contagion -- keeping what ails Indonesia from re-igniting a crisis elsewhere in Asia.
And at the I.M.F., officials note that their charter prohibits them from delving into a nation's political life when setting conditions for economic bailouts.
That sounds fine, but in Indonesia's case, it is an impossible line to draw: there is nothing more political than dictating whether a country can subsidize food, or whether it must break up a monopoly owned by the President's family.
Yet the Clinton Administration has insisted that it is economic reform that will determine its vote on whether to turn the fund's aid on or off.
Asked about how the Administration was squaring its concern about political repression with its votes at the I.M.F., Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today, "We are aggressively pursuing these issues on parallel tracks."
Michael D. McCurry, the White House spokesman, tried a somewhat different formulation, reaching to celestial geometry. "We are working in separate orbits that intersect," he said, pursuing economic reform at the Treasury and I.M.F. and raising concerns about political stability and human rights through the State Department.
Mr. Rubin tried to align the planets a little differently, declaring, "The best protection against a political breakdown is the restoration of financial stability."
Administration officials involved in the hours of meetings over how to deal with the possibility of economic implosion or violent political upheaval in a country of 200 million say there has been little doubt that continuing aid is needed.
The State Department is clearly worried that if it does not provide some kind of economic aid it will be cut off from any kind of dialogue with the 76-year-old Mr. Suharto. "This puts him in the position of needing us and needing to engage with us," a senior official said, while admitting that Mr. Suharto has ignored much of the advice he has received. Cutting off the aid, the official argued, would "worsen the economic crisis, and probably precipitate a deeper political crisis."
Nonetheless, there is no way to provide aid to a country without appearing to strengthen its leader. That leaves Mr. Clinton in the position of doing exactly what he accused George Bush of doing during the 1992 Presidential debates: propping up dictators in the name of trade and stability.
Mr. Clinton's advisers do not deny that in stabilizing the Indonesian economy, they may also be stabilizing Mr. Suharto's hold on power. But the alternative, they say, is to imperil the lives of Indonesians and risk a new eruption in Asia just as the last one appears tamped down, at least for now.
"The Indonesian people -- particularly the poorest -- have a tremendous interest in seeing financial stability restored," said David Lipton, the Under Secretary of Treasury for International Affairs. "And so do we."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Race for California Governor Is Not Necessarily the News

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 5

 BODY:
California's closely contested race for governor took a significant turn the other day: a new poll showed that for the first time in months, Lieut. Gov. Gray Davis, a phlegmatic 20-year veteran of state politics, had edged ahead of his richer, flashier rivals for the Democratic nomination.
The local CBS television station reported that development on its evening news, but only after its accounts about a rash of freeway shootings, a case of suspected child abuse, a veterinarian accused of torturing cats, pirated "Titanic" videos, a new kind of lie detector, a new car alarm that shocks would-be thieves, the Lakers, the weather, Monica S. Lewinsky and a wave of rattlesnake sightings induced by El Nino. 
 The sole mention of Mr. Davis in the first half of the hourlong newscast was a 30-second paid commercial, about his support for education. And this was on a station, KCBS-TV, that local political professionals credit with doing among the best reporting about their business.
Here in the state that gave the nation the tax revolt, managed health care, the explosion of the ballot initiative and the rise of environmentalism, another phenomenon has been introduced: the all-commercial political campaign.
In a primary election on June 2, the nation's most populous state will begin choosing a new leader for the world's seventh-largest economy. But except for the millions of dollars in paid advertising that floods the airwaves day and night, hardly anyone would know it. The campaign is all but invisible on television news and only sporadically gets front-page newspaper coverage.
"You're looking at the epicenter of complete disinterest in politics," said Douglas Sosnik, senior adviser to President Clinton and former White House political director, who noted that Los Angeles was the only market in the nation where even a Presidential visit did not automatically draw notice on the local news. "It's the toughest media market in the country to break through. You have to buy time to break through."
That is an old complaint from scholars and political professionals, and one that is echoed, to a lesser degree, in other big media markets at a time when the economy is strong and the public not seized by consuming conflicts like the cold war or the civil rights struggle. But longtime veterans of California politics agree that this election year marks some kind of new low in a state where politics has often been much less of a spectator sport than in places with more combative partisan traditions, like New York or Illinois.
A recent statewide poll by the Public Policy Institute of California found that just 6 percent of voters were following news coverage of the campaign very closely, roughly half the levels reported at comparable periods before recent primary elections for governor in New Jersey and New York.
The news gap here is part of a broader fragmented political culture. This state is so big and diverse, and with such distinct regions, that it actually amounts to three or four good-sized states thrown together. Distances are vast, cities lack a single unifying core, and the gulf between California's population (increasingly young, diverse and nonwhite) and its electorate (increasingly older, white and conservative) has been growing for years. There are, in short, other reasons why campaigns here seem so distant, and at times surrealistically disconnected, from daily life.
All that said, veterans of politics say California's lack of news coverage plays a big part.
"It's pathetic," said Josh Mankiewicz, a former political reporter for WCBS-TV in New York, who moved to Los Angeles in 1991 to cover politics for KCAL, an independent station, and is now a network correspondent for "Dateline" on NBC. "In New York, being a political reporter's a big deal; in L.A., it's a backwater."
The absence of much coverage of the current campaign is exacerbated by timing: the June 2 primary immediately follows the May television ratings "sweeps" period, when local newscasts run all sorts of sensational stories and series intended to increase viewership. Until two weeks ago, Bill Carrick, the chief strategist for one of Lieutenant Governor Davis's rivals, Representative Jane Harman, had not received a single query about the campaign from a local television reporter. Then one called to say that coverage could begin in earnest at the end of May, after the sweeps ended.
"There is a sense here among local news people that people do not care about politics, and it has to do with ratings," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst at the Claremont Graduate School who provides commentary for KCAL. "If there was a debate held on a freeway that could be covered by helicopter, then we might get some coverage."
The news director at KCBS, Larry Perret, said viewer surveys repeatedly showed that Californians "just don't seem to have a keen interest in following politics."
"In Chicago and Boston, we covered politics as sports," said Mr. Perret, who worked in both cities before returning to his native California a decade ago. "The figures there seem more colorful; they come out swinging. Here people just don't do that as much."
That is true enough, and the perpetual joke about Gray Davis among politicians is that he is aptly named.
But his campaign manager, Garry South, complains that the last time Mr. Davis even got the chance to make much of a splash on television was 16 months ago, when Gov. Pete Wilson was out of state and Mr. Davis, as Acting Governor, offered a reward in the killing of Bill Cosby's son, Ennis. "If what you're saying or proposing does not have a nexus with some extremely hot issue, like crime or a car chase or a beheading or child molestation, it's just not news," Mr. South said.
Is lack of public interest driving the lack of coverage, or the other way around?
"The public's interest is not the issue," said Patrick Caddell, who was Jimmy Carter's pollster and political strategist and has lived here for a decade. "It's a circular argument. How can you be interested in politics if there's no coverage of it?"
Mr. Caddell said he was considering suing one or more of the local network-owned and -operated stations to have their Federal licenses revoked on the ground that they had failed to fulfill their public service obligation.
The current state of affairs "reduces politics to nothing but commercial television, and to the question of who has money and who can get on TV," he said. "It creates an artificial political atmosphere."
The issue is especially acute this year, because one Democratic contender for governor, Al Checchi, former co-chairman of Northwest Airlines, who is worth three-quarters of a billion dollars, has already spent more than $25 million of his own money on the race -- most of it for advertising -- and is poised to break all election spending records for a non-Presidential contest. Ms. Harman is also wealthy, but she and Mr. Davis can barely begin to match Mr. Checchi's spending and must depend more on news coverage.
Ms. Harman's campaign manager, Kam Kuwata, said she had made a splash on statewide television only once during the race, when stories surfaced that she might have illegally employed a British immigrant as a nanny for her children nearly a decade ago. On the day she declared her candidacy in March, Mr. Kuwata said, no radio stations covered the speech, and they even declined the campaign's offer to have Ms. Harman call in to talk-show hosts.
Paid television advertising so dominates the discourse that Mark H. Willes and Michael Parks, the publisher and the editor of The Los Angeles Times, decided that the paper should sponsor a candidate forum next week -- a step it had not generally taken in the past -- where the contenders could talk in a setting with time for more than slogans and sound bites. All three Democrats and the certain Republican nominee, State Attorney General Dan Lungren, have agreed to participate, in what seems likely to be the sole face-to-face encounter of the campaign.
Students of California agree that part of the reason for the apathy about politics here lies in the state's progressive past, in which strong partisanship never played quite the role it played in Eastern and Midwestern cities. Another factor is the rise of the ballot initiative, in which controversial matters are decided directly by voters, thus minimizing the leeway that the Governor and the Legislature have over taxes, spending and major policy issues.
"We've so tied down representative government that there's less and less action by elected officials, and the people don't focus on it," said Peter Schrag, who recently retired after nearly 20 years as editorial page editor of The Sacramento Bee and has just published a book on California's political culture, "Paradise Lost: California's Experience, America's Future" (The New Press).
And, Mr. Schrag added, "I don't know of any time when it's been as bad as it is now."
Until a decade ago, the network-owned and -operated stations in Los Angeles had Statehouse bureaus in Sacramento. Then they closed them, in a cost-saving move, although Mr. Perret of KCBS said his station was considering stepping up its Statehouse coverage once again.
There may be an appetite. Mark Baldassare, a senior fellow at the Public Policy Institute of California, who conducted the recent statewide poll that found scant public following of the campaign, said a separate series of focus groups with 140 voters in six regions throughout the state had shown wide dissatisfaction.
"We heard over and over again that people were really tired of getting their information through TV ads and were looking for better sources of information," Mr. Baldassare said. "People were very clear about how few opportunities they had to judge the candidates side by side. They know they're making their choices based on television advertising alone, and they're very unhappy about it."
