HEADLINE: Connecticut Ties Early Release From Prison to Frequent Drug Testing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
In an effort to trim its overcrowded prisons and stop drug-using felons from committing new crimes, Connecticut's Legislature passed a bill this week that will drastically cut prison time for nonviolent offenders on the condition that they undergo frequent testing for drug use.
The offenders may be tested as often as three times a week, and every time their urine test proves positive, they will be detained for two days in a spartan halfway house that falls just short of being a jail. If they fail the test repeatedly, they can be sent back to prison. 
 Although Maryland was the first to pass such a law, Connecticut, with a single state judicial system instead of many county courts, will likely be the first to put it into place statewide.
If they succeed, other states may look to follow their lead. Next year, the Federal Government will require states to have a plan for regularly testing prisoners and parolees to qualify for Federal funds to build new prisons.
Keeping an inmate behind bars costs about $25,000 a year. But Connecticut Representative Robert Farr, a Republican from West Hartford, who proposed the bill, estimated that the drug-testing program would cost $3,000 per person a year, plus probation costs.
The bill would make nonviolent prisoners eligible for this type of parole after serving at least half of a two- to four-year sentence. Typically, prisoners in Connecticut served at least two-thirds of their sentence before parole, and, although they could be tested for drugs while on parole, such tests have been random and infrequent.
The bill sailed through both houses unanimously; the State House of Representatives passed it on Saturday and the State Senate on Monday night. Lawmakers said that they expected Gov. John G. Rowland to sign the bill.
Republicans embraced the notion of a "zero-tolerance drug supervision program," as the bill is titled, while Democrats welcomed the alternative to long prison terms for addicted offenders.
The bill does not provide any extra money for drug treatment, although Connecticut is in the advantageous position of having enough treatment slots for drug abusers who want to quit. The problem had been in motivating them to do so.
But Representative Farr, the ranking Republican on the Judiciary Committee, said that the threat of repeated short-term confinement provided an incentive for an addicted criminal to find treatment and take personal responsibility for his or her rehabilitation.
"In our prison and parole programs, a substantial number of our people are using drugs," he said. "Now for the first time, we're saying there will be consequences."
Nationwide, four out of five prisoners behind bars are there because of some direct or indirect involvement with drug or alcohol abuse, according to a recent study by the National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University.
The study, released in January, also found that half the people who committed a new crime while on parole or probation were under the influence of drugs or alcohol.
The drug-testing program that Connecticut is planning has no large-scale precedent, though Washington, D.C., and Lansing, Mich., saw success with smaller pilot programs.
In a trial program last year in Coos County, Ore., the number of drug offenders who tested positive dropped from 40 percent in the first month to 10 percent by the sixth month, according to Mark A.R. Kleiman, an expert on drug policy who presented the testing concept to some Connecticut lawmakers late last year.
Professor Kleiman, a professor of policy studies at the University of California at Los Angeles, has promoted frequent drug testing for offenders on probation and parole, who he said account for 60 percent of the cocaine consumed in the United States.
"This program will encourage people to go into treatment if they need it, will encourage them to stick with it and will encourage them to succeed," he said in a telephone interview yesterday. "This is the single best shot we have at reducing hard-drug use and shrinking prison populations."
Representative Michael P. Lawlor, co-chairman of the Judiciary Committee of Connecticut's General Assembly, described the bill as a saner way to handle addicts who keep committing crimes to buy their drugs.
"Our policy has been a huge failure," Mr. Lawlor said. "We need to measure its effectiveness rather than its sexiness at election time."
He said that drug-related crime helped swell Connecticut's prison population to nearly 16,000 at the end of March, from 3,600 in 1980, and that one-quarter of the imprisoned were locked up for selling or possessing narcotics. Like many other states, Connecticut now finds itself spending more on its prisons than on its public universities and colleges. Mr. Farr estimated that there were about 20,000 regular drug users on probation or parole.
A program of coerced abstinence does not look likely to be implemented in New York or New Jersey soon. New Jersey tests selected parolees for drugs. In New York, state prisons held 23,510 drug offenders -- one-third of the total population -- including 5,724 locked up for possessing illegal drugs, as of the end of 1996. Republican lawmakers representing rural constituencies that benefit economically from new prisons have opposed relaxing the state's tough mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses.
And treatment centers in New York State are hard put to provide help to everyone who needs it. John J. Coppola, executive director of the New York State Association of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Providers, said that "when the person is leaving prison and going back to their community, if they're not in touch with a treatment provider, they're left to their own devices."
Connecticut's drug offenders who opt for parole or probation would likely be tested three times a week at first, then less often if they come up drug-free. Representative Farr said the routine of testing and sanctions could be phased in by this autumn. He envisioned starting with 10 beds for violators and expanding gradually to more than 300 slots.
"We have to start small, we have to start slow," he said. "We don't have any experience running this program."
Connecticut's new state budget includes an initial appropriation of $420,000 for three more probation officers, drug tests and a halfway facility to start the program.
Last year, the General Assembly voted down a broader package of legislation that treated drug abuse as a public health problem rather than a criminal justice issue.
No such antipathy has been expressed toward the tough-sounding program of zero-tolerance drug supervision. Representative Richard D. Tulisano, a Democratic majority whip who represents Hartford's southern suburbs, said the bill should be used as a tool to turn drug users into productive citizens.
"We know that addicts fail," he said. "That's got to be built into this. One failure in two or three years is different from one failure every week."

HEADLINE: A Monet Leads a Modest Auction

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Even in today's market, with buyers hungry for good material, few were tempted by the unsavory and in some cases overpriced offerings at Christie's sale of Impressionist and 19th-century art last night.
Of the 44 works up for sale, only 31 found buyers. The sale totaled $35.6 million, far below its low estimate of $62.9 million. Not since the art market took a nose dive in the early 1990's has Christie's has seen such poor results. 
 The salesroom was by no means overflowing, as it usually is at important evening sales of Impressionist art. The scarcity of works fresh to the market may have been one factor; classification was another.
Last night, Christie's broke away from the traditional categories, pairing top-flight 19th-century works by artists like Bouguereau and Boldini alongside those by masters like Monet and Degas. Christie's experts said they felt the change reflected their clients' buying patterns. (Sotheby's has not followed suit.) While many 19th-century paintings performed well, in some cases better than they might have if they had been in a strictly 19th-century sale, the combination may have turned off buyers of Impressionist and modern art.
The date may also have been a negative factor. The sale came a week before all the other big evening sales: Sotheby's auction of Impressionist and modern art, its sale of contemporary art and Christie's sale of 20th-century art. Many European and Asian collectors who usually fly to New York to attend all the sales had to make a choice, and they didn't choose Christie's. "Some lots were ambitiously estimated, but the sale was not of the quality of the last two years," said Christopher Burge, chairman of Christie's in America, who was the evening's auctioneer. "It was an anticlimax from last season."
Mr. Burge pointed out the lack of estate property available this spring, which accounted for the slim sale. Moreover, given today's strong economy, collectors interested in selling weren't willing to part with their art, believing the market hasn't reached its peak.
Certain paintings, however, brought strong prices. Monet's "Waterloo Bridge in the Fog" (1903), a pale, hazy painting, had several bidders interested. It finally sold to an unidentified telephone bidder for $5.2 million, just above its low estimate of $5 million. One reason for its success, Mr. Burge said, was that last fall, another Monet of the same series and the same date, "Waterloo Bridge in the Mist," brought $8.2 million, well over its high estimate of $6 million.
(Final prices include the auction house's commission, 15 percent of the first $50,000 and 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
Another high price for a popular painting was the $2.2 million paid for Courbet's "Gust of Wind or the Approaching Storm," a dramatic 56 1/2-by-90-inch landscape painted in 1855. It set a record for the artist when Bruno Meissner, a private dealer in Zurich, bought it for $2.2 million, nearly twice its high estimate of $1.2 million.
"We had very strong bidding on this picture coming from traditional Courbet buyers and collectors of Impressionist paintings and even 20th-century works of art," said Franck Giraud, who runs Christie's 19th- and 20th-century art departments in New York. "It is the best Courbet landscape to come on the market in memory."
But the Courbet was one of the evening's few bright spots. The sale included seven Renoirs, and many went unsold. The painting with the evening's highest estimate, Renoir's "Young Girl Holding a Bouquet of Tulips," an 1878 profile portrait, was estimated at $15 million, but there were no takers at that price. When bidding stopped at $11.5 million, gasps reverberated around the salesroom. By the time many of the artist's fleshy nudes came on the block, no one blinked when they went unsold.
Much of the property up for sale last night came from Europe. Many European sellers are shipping art to New York for sale, given the advantage of avoiding large import taxes now imposed on works coming into European Union countries and the depressed economies of countries like France and Italy. Sellers also believe America is where the big money is spent. Last night, they were wrong.
Degas's "Dancers in a Studio" (1900-05), for example, came from a private collector in Switzerland. But it failed to elicit a bid of more than $4 million, $1 million short of its low estimate, and went unsold.
One of the best works in the sale, van Gogh's "Boats on the Beach at Saintes-Maries-de-la-Mer," an exquisite pen-and-ink drawing from 1888, was thought to have many interested bidders. While there were several, no one was willing to overspend. The drawing was sold to an unidentified private collector for $5 million, just at its low estimate.
Many works came from Japan and had been bought in the height of the market in the late 1980's by Japanese businessmen who were in financial trouble just a few years later. Last night, the sellers were in many cases creditors who wanted high prices that the market was simply unprepared to pay.
"There was too much lackluster material, which brought lackluster prices," said Guy Stair Sainty, a Manhattan dealer. "Auction houses experts were so desperate to fill these sales they had to promise sellers big prices, which in the end they couldn't get."

HEADLINE: TV Notes;
'Lolita' Reaches A U.S. Audience

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
Showtime announced yesterday that it had acquired the rights to Adrian Lyne's much-debated new film, "Lolita," which means the $58 million movie, based on the Vladimir Nabokov novel, will be seen on American television without a prior release to theaters in this country. "Lolita" is the most expensive film ever to go directly to television.
The deal, which was months in the works, was completed after Showtime agreed to buy all United States rights to the film, including any future theatrical release and videocassette sales, and to give it additional exposure on the Sundance Channel, which is devoted to independent films and is programmed by Showtime. The film will have its American premiere in August on both channels, with Showtime running a standard format and the Sundance Channel showing the film in the letterbox format (a wide frame with black borders on the screen) that Mr. Lyne, the director, preferred. 
 "It's a huge relief," Mr. Lyne said yesterday by phone from his home in France. "I'm very happy. I'm excited the film will finally be seen in America after all the nonsense and lies that had been told about it."
Mr. Lyne's "Lolita" had been searching vainly for a theatrical distributor in the United States since it was completed more than a year ago. "Lolita" was first made into a film in 1962, but the new movie's presentation of the subject matter -- the love affair of a man in his 40's, played by Jeremy Irons, and a pre-teen-ager, played by a newcomer, Dominique Swain -- was clearly deemed too risky for conventional film distributors.
Showtime entered the negotiations for "Lolita" several months ago, but Mr. Lyne was still hoping to gain some initial release in American theaters. The deal yesterday closed out that hope, although Showtime did make a commitment to seeking a release in theaters after "Lolita" plays its initial five or six runs on Showtime and the Sundance Channel.
Jerry Offsay, the president for programming for Showtime, said he had held discussions with several distributors. "It's my expectation that the film will get a theatrical run, if the economics makes sense," he said. He added that film distributors had shied away from the film because of its content and the costs of promotion and advertising, which might have run as much as $15 million. But after a release on Showtime, with all the publicity that it is expected to generate, there may not be as much need for expensive promotion, Mr. Offsay said.
He did not disclose what Showtime paid to acquire "Lolita," but said it was "not an unusual price" for the television showings. What made it unusually high, he said, was Showtime's agreement to buy all American rights to the film. "That clearly made it a higher-cost deal," Mr. Offsay said, adding that Showtime was pleased to deliver a much-talked-about film to the public.
"Our job is to put on the best programming available," Mr. Offsay said. "This is a terrific film. If there's a terrific film out there, it's our job to get it in front of people."
Last year, Showtime purchased the rights to "Bastard Out of Carolina" which had been rejected by the cable channel TNT because of concerns about its content. (A child was raped in the film.) Mr. Lyne said he had been impressed with how Showtime handled "Bastard Out of Carolina," which was later nominated for an Emmy as the best film of the year. BILL CARTER

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dominique Swain and Jeremy Irons in "Lolita," which will be shown on Showtime in August. (Peter Sorel)

TITLE: LOLITA (MOVIE); LOLITA (MOVIE)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); FRANCE (55%);

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Sales Tax Exemption Is Proposed for Film Work

DATELINE: WEST ORANGE

 BODY:
In an effort to help New Jersey's growing movie industry, lawmakers plan to unveil legislation tomorrow that would exempt from the state's 6 percent sales tax purchases related to the production of films. 
 The tax break would apply to hotel rooms, catering fees and other purchases by film production companies that would ordinarily be subject to sales taxes. The break would cost an estimated $1.2 million to $1.4 million in tax revenues, but could help generate much more than that in economic activity, said State Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos, a Republican from Middletown, who is a co-sponsor of the bill with Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, a Republican from Scotch Plains. The two Senators are to announce the measure at the Edison National Historic Site in West Orange, home of the Black Maria, considered the first film studio.

HEADLINE: April's Auto Sales Prove Unexpectedly Strong

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 5

 BODY:
The auto industry turned in unexpectedly strong April sales results today, the first month this year in which customers bought more cars and trucks than they did during the same period of last year.
The sales spurt came as heavy mortgage refinancings in the first quarter of the year gave buyers extra money to spend on monthly car payments while hefty rebates drew them to showrooms. 
 Industry sales rose 6.3 percent in April, compared with April 1997. Sales hit a brisk seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.5 million, above the 15 million rate in March and well up from the 14.5 million pace in April 1997.
The General Motors Corporation turned in particularly strong results today, double some analysts' expectations. Its sales last month rose 8.5 percent, with car sales edging up seven-tenths of a percent and sales of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans rising 18.9 percent compared with April 1997.
Most Wall Street analysts were expecting a sales decline at the Ford Motor Company, but again, their estimates turned out to be too pessimistic. Ford sales rose 1.6 percent, with car sales up 2.3 percent and sales of light trucks up 1 percent.
"Everybody came in with numbers better than we were looking for," said Nicholas J. Colas, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in New York. The industry's results were pushed up by G.M.'s strong showing, which in turn was the result, he said, of "cash on the hood."
In addition, a boom in home mortgage refinancings in January and February left many consumers with more money to spend on car payments. "We're starting to get payoffs to mortgage refinancing activity," said Diane C. Swonk, an economist at the First Chicago NBD Corporation in Chicago.
In mid-March, G.M. began offering more generous rebates and discounted lease deals, and in late April it ignited an industry price war by piling on additional discounts by sending coupons to tens of millions of previous G.M. buyers. Those loyalty rebates were matched late last month by Ford and the Chrysler Corporation, which agreed to accept G.M.'s coupons for their vehicles, too.
G.M. estimated today that the loyalty coupons won it about 9,000 additional sales in April, but predicted those rebates would have a more dramatic effect this month. April's strong sales were the result of G.M.'s earlier increased rebates and financing discounts, strong sales from the Chevrolet division and better supplies of trucks with popular V8 engines and four-wheel-drive capability, said Michael C. DiGiovanni, G.M.'s director of market research and forecasting.
Some analysts said the higher rebates offered by the Big Three American auto makers would spur sales this month and later this year by changing price dynamics for the least expensive cars and trucks. "The coupons on top of the incentives already out there are making the new cars more competitive with used cars," particularly for small cars and small pickups, said Wendy Beale Needham, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. Earlier this year, it tended to be cheaper to buy a two-year-old midsized car coming off lease than to buy a new small car or pickup, but the rebates have reversed that equation, she said.
Most other auto makers reporting sales this week posted strong results. Volkswagen A.G. sales jumped 58.7 percent; Porsche A.G. sales increased 59.3 percent; BMW A.G. sales rose 12.2 percent, and A.B. Volvo sales climbed 8 percent. But, Hyundai sales fell 37 percent and Mazda Motor Company sales declined 5.4 percent.
On Friday, other large auto makers said their sales were strong. Chrysler sales rose 8.2 percent, Toyota sales jumped 10.5 percent and Honda sales increased 12.5 percent.
Among big auto makers, the only dismal results in April were reported by the Nissan Motor Company, which is the sixth-largest seller in the United States market after G.M., Ford, Chrysler, Toyota and Honda. Nissan announced Friday that its sales plunged 24.2 percent last month, and were down 29.5 percent for the first four months of this year compared with the corresponding period last year.
The Japanese auto maker notified employees today that its huge factory in Smyrna, Tenn., will be closed every Friday through Oct. 2. Factory workers will be given a choice of taking vacation time on those days or receiving half pay.
The Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. has repeatedly replaced senior sales and marketing executives over the last several years, with little success so far. Nissan is suffering from what the company now describes as a failed experiment in improving its long-term brand image by running abstract advertisements that won praise in the advertising industry but complaints from dealers because the ads said little about Nissan's cars.
"We focused on 2005 and 2010 and forgot to focus on 1997 and 1998," said Michael J. Seergy, the new general manager for Nissan cars and trucks. The company changed ad strategies this spring and has now returned to the industry tradition of emphasizing vehicles' features.
Nissan has also suffered from the withering of the small-car market in the United States and the company's own slowness in moving into faster-growing market segments. While the Toyota RAV-4 and Honda CR-V small sport utility vehicles have sold briskly for more than a year, for example, Nissan does not offer a small sport utility vehicle. Its small sport utility vehicle is due next year.

LENGTH: 1507 words

HEADLINE: High Point Rejoices as Furniture Sales Climb

BYLINE: By LIZ SEYMOUR 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C.

 BODY:
MODERNISM steamed into the International Home Furnishings Market, the world's largest wholesale furniture exposition, with all flags flying.
After several seasons of cautious experimentation with cleaner looks, the American furniture industry embraced 20th-century design with a fervor that took even longtime market goers by surprise. 
 The most startling symbol of High Point's sea change rose four stories in the middle of town. Natuzzi, the giant Italian leather producer, commissioned the Italian architect Mario Bellini to design its sleek 110,000-square-foot showroom and American headquarters with a skyward-jutting glass and bronze prow.The building evokes an ocean liner, but it could have been the Good Ship Lollipop, judging by the benign mood of buyers and sellers at this market, which ended on May 1.
In sharp contrast with the last few years of sluggish business, many companies were reporting double-digit sales increases.
"This could turn out to be the biggest market in history," said Carl Levine, an industry consultant and former home furnishings merchandise manager for Bloomingdale's. "In more than 30 years, I have never seen such complete enthusiasm and excitement from retail buyers."
The furniture industry was, in fact, finally getting its share of a five-year trend toward greater spending on home furnishings in general. The retail analyst Kurt Barnard noted in the April issue of his newsletter, Barnard's Retail Trend Report, that since mid-1996, Americans have been spending more on items for their homes -- everything from sheets and towels to paint -- than on apparel. Based on his own research and on figures from the United States Commerce Department, Mr. Barnard pegged home spending at $296.3 billion in 1997, compared with $277.9 billion on apparel. "It's partly a function of demographics," Mr. Barnard said. "People are less concerned with preening and a lot more concerned with enhancing their home environment."
With designers like Todd Oldham using upholstery fabric on the runway and Donna Karan and Calvin Klein designing home and apparel collections simultaneously, interiors are becoming a fashion force. "They can see what's happening," said Catherine Stein, the founder of the Color Council, a trend forecaster. "If you follow the money trail, home is where the action is."
A survey by the Home Furnishings Council and Hearst Magazines showed that 62 percent of single consumers under 35 bought a piece of furniture in the last year and that younger consumers were the ones most likely to agree with the statement "I like to shop for furniture."
There was no denying that the stock market deserved a lot of the credit for High Point's optimistic mood. "Five years ago, our biggest competition was with savings for retirement," said Jay Reardon, the president of the Hickory Chair Company. "Now, people are feeling that they've taken care of the future and they're ready to spend."
But there was also a sense that the industry was finally addressing some of its internal problems, from styling to quality to delivery times.
Buyers shopping the market -- the actual furniture will reach stores in the fall -- seemed particularly eager to connect with sleek, mid-century style. The Bernhardt Furniture Company reported that its 1930's-style Paris group, introduced last year, had been a best-seller; so it followed up in the same vein this time with a collection of streamlined tables. Larry Laslo's new collection for Bexley Heath invoked the spirits of Emile-Jacques Ruhlmann, Jean-Michel Frank and Andre Arbus. Ralph Lauren weighed in at Henredon with his Penthouse line, a beautifully proportioned group in mahogany veneer and with silver-plated hardware. The New York designer Vicente Wolf split his new Art Deco-style collection between two mid-price companies, Carsons and Casa Bique.
"Retailers are starting to understand that they're losing a lot of customers to Pottery Barn," Mr. Wolf said. "People are just not buying that old Shinola anymore."
In fact, the big mainstream furniture companies were taking the success of stores like Pottery Barn, Crate and Barrel and Restoration Hardware very much to heart. Pale wood, brushed nickel, frosted glass, the hybrid Shaker-Mission-contemporary style that the industry newspaper Furniture Today has dubbed "boomer casual," was everywhere, from small designer-owned companies to industry giants like Thomasville, Stanley, Bassett, Broyhill and Pennsylvania House.
Perhaps with that shopaholic apartment-dwelling Generation X buyer in mind, storage and multi-functional pieces were important elements in many new collections. One of the cleverest introductions was Normand Couture's Cameleon at Shermag, which goes from daybed to sofa with the addition of interchangeable arm and back pieces.
Even more adventuresome modern style -- long anathema to most High Point fair buyers -- showed surprising strength. Exhibiting back-to-back at the Milan fair and High Point, the Italian company Zeritalia introduced a brightly colored bent glass shelving system and painted glass tables. "We've been surprised by the people who have come in here," said Keith Derose, the company's American sales manager. "Everyone seems to be more design conscious, more fashion conscious all of a sudden."
Alexander Chan and Shelly Wong, the young husband-and-wife team who founded Sitcom, an Oakland, Calif., company, found themselves nudged toward a crisper modern by their customers. "We have a table that started out pretty conservatively, with clear glass and brushed steel," Ms. Wong said. "The buyers from Spiegel came in and asked us to do it in frosted glass and chrome legs with industrial wheels. Suddenly, it's modern."
All that contemporary segued easily into Asian looks. Traditional chinoiserie was out, and a kind of spiritual spa-style Asian -- clear finishes, clean lines -- was in. Shermag developed an Asian-inspired bedroom group called Now and Zen in cooperation with Federated Department Stores, for instance.
But Asia seemed to be more a state of mind than a pure style. The Henredon showroom had an opium den-like corner where chairs upholstered in Chinese patterns posed against walls that were papered in bright red embossed lizard skin. Others, however, hewed closer to true Asian style -- notably Drexel Heritage, which evoked Southeast Asia in its extensive new Mandalay collection, and Century, which brought out some Chinese-inspired tables and a wedding chest-style armoire.
The market's other accent was decidedly French. Many of the Art Deco-style pieces were inspired by what has come to be called the French flea-market look, of which the leather club chair is still the ne plus ultra. Almost as strong was straight-down-the-middle French Provincial.
Some of the most exciting introductions at the market, however, will be visible only on the bottom line. Over the last few years as the American economy has improved, weaknesses in the furniture industry became glaringly obvious: consumers chose to dispose of their disposable income elsewhere. Heeding the wake-up call, furniture makers have revamped everything from production equipment to employee relations in an effort to get delivery times down to 8 weeks from 12.
"It's remarkable how fast the hurdle is being raised in operation," said George Revington, the president of Universal. "We're not even looking at furniture manufacturers -- we're benchmarking ourselves against other industries now."
As consumers demand better communication and quicker deliveries, the fashion hand-off from apparel to home design is becoming lightning fast. "I can remember when we would see something in ready-to-wear and it would be two years before it had an impact on furniture," said the manufacturer Mitchell Gold, who showed some jaunty round ottomans covered in shiny Prada bag-style fabric. "Now we see something in December, we've got it in April and it's on the retail floor by July."
A few designers have started building couture shows into their itineraries. "I don't even decide on color until I've see what's on the runways," said Mr. Laslo, who settled on bronzy leather, white linen and a shade of purple he called "chicken soup with beets" for his collection of upholstered pieces for Directional.
There were hints of a more John Galliano-esque extravagance waiting in the wings. Sheer fabrics were stitched into pillow coverings at Susan Sargent. At MU/H (pronounced MOO-ha) some buyers were wrapping themselves in the silk throws.
Certainly the crossover minimalism of the Calvin Klein and Donna Karan apparel and home collections (neither of them show in High Point) had an influence. But buyers were not quite ready for total minimalism: Jean-Paul Drovet, the Swiss architect hired to design the Preview company's new showroom, spent the last hours before market hanging art on his strikingly curved walls. "I wanted it very clean, very European," he said with a shrug. "But they tell me I am in America now."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
What's a good word for updating one's competitive position? At Burnett, it's Vigilante.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A GIANT agency company that usually plays by the book is now trying to rewrite one: the dictionary, to redefine "vigilante."
Vigilante is the name of a specialty shop opened in New York by the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago, which is revamping its operations after setbacks involving dissatisfied clients and lost accounts. 
 Vigilante, supported by Burnett's copious resources, is creating advertising campaigns, promotional events and other marketing programs aimed at a fledgling niche known as urban consumers: younger trend-setters who have turned aspects of their distinctive culture from rap music to Tommy Hilfiger apparel into mainstream mainstays.
"Urban culture is consumers of like mind-set, like attitude, whose race, gender or socio-economic background are not defining factors," said Marc Stephenson Strachan, executive vice president and chief marketing and operations officer at Vigilante.
"It's not a black or white thing," he added. "It's an opportunity."
Mr. Strachan, 38, described the audience as people "who believe you don't necessarily have to follow traditional trends and tracks, who want to get their piece of the pie without waiting for it, who want to find and make brands for themselves."
His partner, Danny Robinson, who is executive vice president and creative director at Vigilante, estimated that there is "a core group of 15 million people who live the urban culture life style and influence everyone else." Including the influenced, he numbered the market at 35 million to 40 million.
Mr. Robinson, 37, demonstrated his point by raising his hands in the air, palms up, a gesture that he said originated in the urban market, among basketball fans. The gesture, he said, meaning "Push it up, raise the roof, make some noise," is now expanding to the general population.
While urban marketing is becoming more popular among big advertisers, there has been carping about the formation of Vigilante and another specialized agency, Spike DDB, a joint venture of the director Spike Lee and the DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. The critics complain that urban marketing is merely a recasting of what has long been known as ethnic marketing, particularly aimed at black consumers.
"The hurdle is the word 'urban,' " Mr. Strachan said, being perceived as a signal "that it's going to be for African-Americans, the inner city."
"This is different,' he added, because "we're not going after a specific target."
Mr. Strachan and Mr. Robinson had worked separately before joining forces a year ago on a project for Burnett, which hired them to develop urban marketing ideas for an account, Reebok International Ltd., that Burnett later resigned.
"Burnett flew some people to New York and we spent three weeks together," Mr. Robinson recalled. "Then Rick Fizdale said, 'Let's figure out a way to do this for real.' "
His reference was to Richard B. Fizdale, the chairman and chief executive of Burnett, who said of Mr. Robinson and Mr. Strachan: "They put together what to this day was the best and most interesting presentation I've been part of."
Their ideas included a Reebok retail outlet that would be "less a store than a community center," Mr. Fizdale said, and a Reebok-sponsored basketball league. After that, he added, "I decided I wanted an ongoing relationship with them." An agreement was reached last summer, and Vigilante was formally announced in December.
As for assertions that agencies like Vigilante are intended to siphon business from or compete against ethnic agencies, Mr. Fizdale said: "This is not an ethnic advertising agency. This is an advertising agency that hopes to seize a target that's multiracial, as white or Hispanic or Asian-American as it is black."
Vigilante's work so far includes a project for the "Vibe" syndicated television series and ads for the Johnnie Walker Black brand of Scotch whisky sold by the Schieffelin & Somerset unit of Diageo P.L.C.
The general market campaign for that brand, created by Burnett, presents it as a reward, using the theme "Welcome to civilization." The Vigilante ads, by contrast, present it as "a trophy," Mr. Robinson said, "to let everyone know you've made it, which this market still needs to show." That is apparent in the theme of those ads: "Step up. Your drink is waiting."
The goal of the Burnett and Vigilante executives is to spin off Vigilante as an autonomous unit by the end of the year, with Burnett as a part-owner.
"And if we're as successful as we think we should be in year five," Mr. Strachan said, "after that there'll be a Vigilante in Japan, in Europe, on the African continent."
Vigilante is one of several ambitious, unconventional efforts by top Burnett executives that are meant to alert potential clients -- as well as rival agencies -- that they will do whatever is necessary to improve and update their competitive position.
"We saw that this Midwestern, traditional, conservative, corn-flake agency was now willing to change," Mr. Strachan said.
Still, Mr. Robinson said, "Marc and I would read about a lost account" at Burnett "and we'd say, 'Did we pick the right agency?' "
"But anything like this would be a gamble," he added, "and we were looking for a calculated risk with potential upside. This just felt right -- the right chemistry between us, the right chemistry with Burnett."
There is also some carping that agencies like Vigilante and Spike DDB are ploys, half-hearted attempts by hidebound agencies to portray themselves as trendy.
"Our first reaction was, 'What do these guys in the Midwest want with us?' " Mr. Strachan acknowledged. "But we're here today because it's not a front. It's not a way for Leo to get P.R. spin. It's real because the opportunity is real. The dollars are there; the support is there; the resources are there."
Mr. Fizdale, not surprisingly, also took issue with the charges that Vigilante is old wine in chic new bottles.
"It's not a desire to be hip," he said, "but a desire to connect clients with an understanding of an aspect of the market superior to ours."

LENGTH: 881 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Fed is trapped between expectations and reality.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
LOW unemployment, rapid economic growth, the lowest rate of inflation in decades: what more could a Federal Reserve chairman want?
Nothing, if the views of a respectful Congress, an enthusiastic financial industry and a worshipful press are to be taken at face value. In fact Alan Greenspan is in a bind, trapped between the public's expectation of perpetual economic bliss and evidence that even the Goldilocks Economy is not immune to the ailments of inflation and recession. 
 By some readings of current events, the Fed deliberately set the stage for a tighter monetary policy later this year by leaking cautionary words from the still-secret minutes of the March 31 meeting of its policy-making committee. But it's probably going to take more than a few well-placed leaks to generate a soft landing in an economy that has grown accustomed to hearing only good news. "They should have raised interest rates a year ago," said William Dudley, chief United States economist for Goldman, Sachs. "Now it may be too late."
By conventional measures, the American economy is overheating. Economic growth has exceeded 4 percent for more than a year -- roughly 1.5 percent more than Laurence H. Meyer, a Clinton appointee to the Federal Reserve, argues is sustainable in light of the modest growth of the labor force and the trend in productivity. Wages grew about a half percentage point faster than labor productivity, a figure consistent with the view that at 4.7 percent unemployment is close to a percentage point below the "noninflationary" rate.
How does that square with the latest figures showing low inflation? Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, attributes it to the serendipity of "a series of little price shocks" that have permitted businesses to hold down prices in the teeth of accelerating labor costs and still have plenty left as profits. Oil prices have been falling, health insurance premiums have risen less rapidly than the general price level and the strong dollar has reduced the cost of imports. So unless conventional explanations of "cost push" inflation are wrong, wage pressures will continue to build, adding half a percentage point to inflation for every year unemployment remains a percentage point below the noninflationary rate.
Can we be certain that the noninflationary unemployment rate is really somewhere in the mid-5 percent range? No, but William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale University, notes that "the wage increases of the past year are entirely consistent" with the standard model -- which probably explains why the President's Council of Economic Advisers and the Congressional Budget Office have stuck by their independent estimates of 5.4 percent and 5.8 percent, respectively.
Then why hasn't the Fed already made a pre-emptive strike on inflation? Mr. Dudley of Goldman, Sachs recites a laundry list of reasons: the risk of sucking capital away from Asia, the hope that productivity growth will continue to accelerate and offset accelerating wages, and the worry that an interest rate increase would come just as the American economy was beginning to cool on its own.
But it is safe to say that two other concerns dominate Fed thinking. For starters, the fruits of the long economic boom of the 1990's have been entirely captured by college graduates, business owners and stock market investors. Now that wages are finally beginning to rise at the middle and low ends of the scale, steps to choke off growth won't be greeted with enthusiasm on Main Street. "It would look like the Fed was crushing the workers in order to save the capitalists," allowed Mr. Dudley.
Probably more important, interest rate changes have become problematic in the face of what The Economist magazine labeled "America's bubble economy." A modest rate increase might lead to an equally modest correction in the stock market. But it is also possible that it would help cause a sharp drop in stock, bond and housing prices, which in turn could result in recession. "It is hard to explain why the Dow went from 6,000 to 9,000," noted Robert Solow, an economist at M.I.T. -- and it is thus equally hard to predict how efforts to let the economy down gently would affect markets.
Barring fresh evidence that the economy is cooling on its own, the Fed will doubtless act sometime this year. Does it really matter when?
Certainly the predominant view is that delay will compound both the pain of taming inflation and the risk of overshooting. But Mr. Solow is not especially worried. "The evidence suggests that inflation is reversible," he said, adding that a modest acceleration in prices from the current, very low level could be halted without a recession and with only a modest increase in unemployment. Virtually everyone acknowledges, though, that the impact on stock and bond prices in the current speculative environment is not easy to predict.
Mr. Nordhaus of Yale suggests the sensitivity of markets is partly the Fed's fault. Before the 1980's, he notes, the norm was small, frequent changes in interest rates. But in an era when interest rate changes are few and far between, the markets not unexpectedly assume that small changes presage larger ones. "When the Fed moves, people become hysterical," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Samsung in Talks to Sell Units and Consolidate

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, May 7

 BODY:
The Samsung Group, one of South Korea's biggest industrial conglomerates, said on Wednesday that it was in talks to sell some of its units to General Electric and Hewlett-Packard as part of a move to raise $13 billion to repay debt and reduce the sprawling organization to five main businesses.
Hewlett-Packard, the world's second-largest computer company, confirmed that it had discussions since February to buy all or part of Samsung's 45 percent in HP Korea, a 14-year-old joint venture that sells computers and printers and makes power-supply devices. Samsung and G.E. have a medical-equipment joint venture in South Korea. G.E. officials here and in the United States declined to comment. 
 The huge Korean conglomerates, known as chaebol, have come under increased pressure from the Government and investors to raise fresh capital and reduce their towering debt burdens by focusing on fewer businesses. Economists have warned that without such steps, South Korea's recovery from economic and financial crisis could be seriously impaired.
Samsung's negotiations, if they result in the sale of units, could become a model for other Korean companies.
It plans to reduce the number of businesses it specializes in to five -- electronics, finance, services, and two other unspecified industries -- and will sell new shares in many of its companies, said Cho Chang Won, a spokesman. "We expect tangible results in the first half of this year," Mr. Cho said of the G.E. and Hewlett-Packard talks.
The company plans to repay $21 billion of debt in the next five years and will seek to raise money through foreign investment, he added.
Talks with Samsung are in an advanced stage, a Hewlett-Packard spokesman, Brad Whitworth, said, declining to comment on when a final decision might be made. Mr. Whitworth said HP Korea was profitable, though sales in Korean won and American dollars had fallen as the won's value tumbled and the South Korean economy slumped over the last six months.
Analysts have said that G.E. plans to invest as much as $40 billion in Asia over the next four years. Its medical-equipment venture with Samsung was formed in 1984 and has about 250 employees. It makes ultrasound and CAT scan equipment sold worldwide.
Samsung also said that its units would make their finances more transparent, partly by halting the common practice of guaranteeing each other's debts. In arranging a $57 billion bailout for South Korea in December, the International Monetary Fund insisted that South Korean companies adopt internationally accepted accounting rules and make their finances more comprehensible to investors.
While these steps, if carried out, would go a long way toward meeting the demands of the Government, the I.M.F. and international investors, in one key area Samsung's plans fell far short of what analysts say is required.
The company said it had no plan to spin off its fledgling auto division, which is proving a heavy drain on its finances. Instead, Samsung said it would form a strategic alliance with foreign investors and join in the Government's push to overhaul the overcrowded auto industry. Car sales in South Korea have plunged as much as 60 percent this year as the economy contracts.
Samsung's announcement is the latest response to criticism from President Kim Dae Jung that corporate debt and inefficiency helped cause the Korean debt crisis.
Samsung Group sales totaled $64 billion last year. Its businesses range from computer chips, ships and automobiles to insurance, entertainment and kitchenware.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Rising Budget Surplus Spurs Changes in Treasury Note Sales

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The growing Federal budget surplus -- which has been increasing faster than expected -- pushed the United States Treasury today to eliminate one benchmark note and to alter the issuing of another. They were the first major changes in Treasury auctions since the sale of 30-year bonds was cut back in 1993.
The two moves, analysts said, will give the Treasury more flexibility in adjusting its borrowing needs as the outlook for the Government surplus changes. Just yesterday, the Clinton Administration said the surplus for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30 could reach $40 billion. 
 The Treasury also said that the change was the kind of move that should help keep the American bond market attractive as Europe created the world's only other large bond market when the single currency -- the euro -- goes into effect next year.
"What we did today will help benefit our bond market," Gary Gensler, the Assistant Treasury Secretary for financial markets, said in an interview. "Markets want concentrated, large bond issues."
The Treasury also said that it would sell a smaller than expected $22 billion of three-year and 10-year notes at next week's quarterly auction, another reflection of the Government's declining borrowing needs as it prepared for its first budget surplus since 1969.
Investors responded positively to the news, ending a two-day slide in bond prices. The decline in Government borrowing is being met by continuing strong demand, forcing prices lower and pushing interest rates lower. The price of the 30-year bond rose 22/32, to 102 22/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 5.93 percent, from 5.98 percent Tuesday. Two- , three- and five-year Treasury notes also rallied.
In its two main auction changes, the Treasury decided to eliminate the three-year note, which has been auctioned quarterly. Its last auction will be next week. Mr. Gensler said that "the market was telling us this was the least needed security," given that there are also a two-year and a five-year note.
The second move was to shift the current monthly auction of five-year notes to a quarterly sale and increase the size of each issue. The last monthly sale will be in June and the first quarterly auction of five-year notes will be in August.
These changes will also allow the Treasury to stop cutting back on its issuing of three-month and six-month Treasury bills. This is the main way it has adjusted to the Government's declining borrowing needs over the last two years. The market for privately held Treasury bills has fallen $130 billion, or 22 percent, over the last two years.
Bond traders had been expressing concern about the declining size of the Treasury bill market and whether it would affect the ease of trading and prices. "The Treasury has made a trade-off between auction frequency and liquidity," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. "There will be fewer auctions but larger auctions."
Mr. Gensler also said that the move to increase the sale of Treasury bills would help keep the Government from changing the average maturity of its portfolio, something it wants to remain relatively constant so that it is not appearing to change its bet on the longer-term direction of interest rates. As one of its changes in 1993, the Treasury shifted to more short-term borrowing.

HEADLINE: Compaq Said To Plan Cuts In Digital Jobs

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Compaq Computer Corporation will cut 15,000 jobs, or 28 percent, of the Digital Equipment Corporation's work force after the expected merger of the companies is completed later this year, an executive at one of the computer makers said yesterday.
The cuts, which have been expected since Compaq agreed in January to buy Digital for $9.6 billion in cash and stock, will cost between $1.5 billion and $2 billion, according to a document filed yesterday by Digital with the Securities and Exchange Commission. If completed, the merger would be the largest in the history of the computer industry. 
 Despite estimating the cost of the layoffs, neither company would confirm the elimination of 15,000 jobs. Even so, the executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "It's a real solid number."
The expected cuts, which would have been a devastating blow as recently as five years ago, aroused little concern in Massachusetts, where Digital has its headquarters. A high-tech boom in the state has lowered unemployment to 3.7 percent from levels of 10 percent seven years ago.
"If ever there was a time to be looking for a job in Massachusetts, this is it," David Tibbetts, the state's director of economic development, said in an interview yesterday. "Many high-tech companies are salivating for those workers."
Compaq, based in Houston, is the world's largest maker of personal computers and is aiming to transform itself into a supplier of a full range of computers, from PC's to the most powerful systems that corporations use to run their businesses. It is buying Digital, a onetime leading-edge computer maker that stumbled badly in the PC era, primarily to acquire its services arm and direct sales force.
Dan Kaferle, a Digital spokesman, said that the services division, which employs about 25,000 of Digital's 53,500 employees, as well as some other divisions would continue to be based in Massachusetts after the merger. But he and Rebecca Nahas, a Compaq spokeswoman, declined to say where the anticipated cuts would be made until after the deal was closed.
Certainly, Compaq will have little need for most of Digital's headquarters staff after the merger is completed. But Wall Street analysts disagreed over where other cuts would be made.
Stephen C. Dube, an analyst at Wasserstein Perella in New York, said that Compaq would probably eliminate almost all of Digital's computer manufacturing, many of its administrative offices in Europe and some of its research and development while retaining its services employees and it sales force of 5,000.
But Gary Helmig, an analyst at Soundview Financial Group in Stamford, Conn., said that Compaq might eliminate some sales and services jobs and shutter some of Digital's weaker business, like its line of computer work stations, as well.
He said that Compaq had talked about cutting Digital's expenses by 50 percent, adding, "You don't do that without doing major surgery."
One employee who is likely to lose his job is Robert B. Palmer, Digital's chairman and chief executive. Yesterday's filing said that Mr. Palmer would receive $6.45 million in severance pay. He also holds more than a million Digital stock options that would vest immediately after the takeover was completed, netting him an estimated $12 or $13 million.
The analysts greeted the news of the cuts as a sign that the merger was moving forward on schedule despite recent setbacks at Compaq, which saw its earnings plunge 96 percent in the first quarter because of an inventory glut. Compaq has said that the acquisition of Digital will add to its earnings in the second half of this year, which means that it must cut Digital's expenses quickly.
Compaq is offering $30 in cash and 0.945 share of Compaq stock for each Digital share. Yesterday, Compaq stock closed at $31.25, up 69 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. Digital shares also rose 69 cents, closing at $58.69.
The deal must still be approved by two-thirds of Digital's shareholders and the Federal Trade Commission, which has asked both companies to provide additional information about the transaction.
"We have no reason to believe that the F.T.C. will not let this go forward," Mr. Kaferle said.
Digital shareholders are scheduled to vote at an extraordinary meeting on June 11. Compaq and Digital executives expressed confidence yesterday that the deal would be completed by the end of June.
Mr. Tibbetts, the Massachusetts development director, said that the job losses at Digital would be countered by one of its rivals, Sun Microsystems, which is building a campus for 4,000 workers outside Boston in the town of Burlington. Other companies in telecommunications and computer storage as well as Internet start-ups are also actively recruiting, he added, part of the high-tech revival that has turned the state's economy around in recent years.

HEADLINE: SHAPING A GLOBAL GIANT: THE CORPORATE CULTURES -- Two Auto Makers With Long Histories Attempt a Trans-Atlantic Marriage;
A Slimmer Daimler-Benz's Big Gamble

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 6

 BODY:
Long before he orchestrated the stunning takeover of the Chrysler Corporation, Jurgen Schrempp had been setting the stage by overhauling his own company from top to bottom.
In the three years since Mr. Schrempp became chairman of Daimler-Benz, he has lopped off more than a dozen companies and reversed the disastrous diversification effort of his predecessor, Edzard Reuter. Mr. Schrempp has reorganized the company, eliminating more than a thousand midlevel managers and forcing those who remained to focus relentlessly on profit performance. 
 The results have been impressive. After logging a $3.2 billion loss in 1995, mostly as a result of writing off its investment in the Fokker aircraft company, Daimler-Benz's sales climbed 19 percent last year, to $68 billion, and operating profits soared 79 percent, to about $2.5 billion.
Mr. Schrempp is now about to take his biggest gamble ever. Having slimmed down Daimler-Benz by bailing out of businesses from airplanes to insurance, the combative 53-year-old chairman if bulking up again with one of the biggest takeovers in history.
He is also embarking on a huge exercise in cross-cultural management. As Germany's biggest industrial conglomerate, Daimler-Benz's history date's back to the late 19th century and includes a sordid period as a major component of the Nazi war machine during World War II.
In the decades of Germany's "economic miracle" immediately after the war, Daimler-Benz grew rapidly into a major manufacturer of expensive, high-quality cars. As Germany's prosperity soared, so did that of Daimler-Benz.
Things became unglued in the early 1990's, when Mr. Reuter embarked on a sweeping program to expand into new industries. Convinced that the company should become a wide-ranging "technology" enterprise, Mr. Reuter expanded into aerospace and aircraft, data processing and even insurance. Most experts now say the strategy was grievously flawed, but the problems were compounded by recession in the United States and a soaring value of the German mark, which made exports difficult.
Though Mr. Schrempp had been part of Mr. Reuter's regime, he quickly began to carry out a counterrevolution after he took over in early 1995. Daimler-Benz shed more than 40,000 workers in less than two years as it sold or simply shut down marginal business. By late 1996, Mr. Schrempp had refocused the company on automobiles and trucks, which account for about 70 percent of Daimler-Benz's sales.
The transformation has not always been pretty. Last year, Mr. Schrempp reorganized the company structure and did away with the separate Mercedes board. In effect, the move gutted the power of the highly respected Mercedes chief executive, Helmut Werner, who adamantly fought the changes but lost and ultimately quit.
Under the proposed new merger, Mr. Schrempp will at least nominally be sharing power with Chrysler's chairman, Robert J. Eaton. But Mr. Eaton's position as co-chairman of the new Daimler-Chrysler conglomerate is expected to be a transitional post -- certainly if Mr. Schrempp has his way.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Slides by 92.92 as Uncertainty Surrounds Trading

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market fell sharply again yesterday, continuing a recent volatile trading pattern that reflects the uncertainty of the outlook after a rally that has pushed the market to repeated new highs this year.
In the last 11 trading days, the Dow Jones industrial average has plunged 267 points in four trading days, shot up 275 points to a new high in five, and fallen 138 points in two, including yesterday's 92.92-point, or 1 percent, decline to 9,054.65. 
 Nearly 60 points of the decline yesterday came at the end of the day, after Alice Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, said on CNBC that she "sees cause for concern about the values in the stock market."
Although she added, "That doesn't necessarily mean it's a bubble," such a comment from an official at her level at a time of uncertainty can make investors jittery.
"When the market is overbought and a cautionary comment comes out, the market can tumble," said Richard McCabe, the chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch.
The uncertainty for investors is being created by the outlook for both earnings and economic growth. First-quarter earnings have been relatively weak. Although forecasters expect them to rebound, investors will have to wait to see if that will happen.
In addition, although many forecasters are expecting economic growth to slow down, there are no firm signs of that yet, and the expected drag from Asia has not shown up as quickly as expected.
The current stronger-than-expected growth has lead to a reported shift at the Federal Reserve to a bias toward raising interest rates. Forecasters are not betting that the Fed will act soon -- its next policy meeting is May 19 -- but the threat led to the big selloff on April 27 and it is still overhanging the market.
Also, the riots in Indonesia are shifting some attention back to Asia, with investors realizing that the recovery from last year's currency devaluations is still a long way off.
"The market has run very hard without much support from lower interest rates or stronger earnings," said Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities.
If interest rates fall further, he said, that could help. But he does not expect that to happen because the economy is not yet slowing down as forecast. And if earnings improve, that could help.
But he does not expect a real bounce-back until next year, in part because of the drag from Asia. "I don't think it's a long-term earnings problem, but we have a few weak quarters ahead of us," he said.
This view has lead him to cut his asset allocation for equities by 10 percentage points, to 60 percent. He put half of this into bonds, raising that portion to 35 percent, and the rest into cash, raising its share to 15 percent. "We are in for a pause, but not an end to the bull market," he said.
The market was led down yesterday by American Express, off 2 15/16, to 99 1/2 Walt Disney Company, off 2 1/2 to 124 3/16; Pfizer, down 2 15/16, to 108 13/16, and Microsoft, off 1 3/8, to 86 3/8. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 10.58 points, to 1,104.92, while the Nasdaq index dropped 8.23 points, to 1,856.68.

HEADLINE: Growth of Budget Surplus Outstrips Plans for How to Spend It

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The nation's fiscal condition continues to improve at a startling pace, so much so that Washington is having trouble keeping up.
After saying less than two weeks ago that it saw no reason to increase its estimate that the Federal budget surplus would be around $18 billion this year, the Congressional Budget Office reversed itself late Tuesday and told lawmakers that a surge in tax receipts in late April meant the Government would run in the black by $43 billion to $63 billion this year. 
 The White House also quietly increased its informal estimate of the surplus to around $40 billion, about twice what it had been projecting. The new forecasts moved Congress and the White House into a range that private analysts had been predicting for months and suggested that the nation would enjoy substantial surpluses as long as the economy remained healthy and the stock market high.
Much of the late surge in tax receipts appeared to come from capital gains reaped by investors in the booming financial markets. The new calculations were the latest in a long string in which budget analysts have been surprised by the strength in revenues. The Congressional Budget Office in particular came under attack today from Republicans for once again having to revise an overly pessimistic projection.
The good news only served to highlight the deep divisions among Republicans about how to approach the new era of fiscal plenty. Many want bigger tax cuts. Others are loath to risk a confrontation with Democrats over President Clinton's demand that any surpluses be left untouched until the nation settles on how to fix the Social Security system. Some want to use the money to pay for legislation like the recently passed highway and mass transit bill.
So deep are the divisions that the House has still not taken up a budget plan, and any measure that does make it through the House is likely to be very different from the budget resolution passed last month by the Senate. Republicans concede that they might not even try to reconcile the House and Senate budget blueprints and instead may have to leave the tough decisions to the spending bills that both chambers must pass to keep the Government running.
"As long as we were in deficit, we were unified in pursuing the goal of a balanced budget," one Republican staff member said. "Now that that's been achieved, folks have different thoughts about what we should do next. Trying to build a consensus among those differing views is a difficult process, and that's what you're witnessing."
The size of this year's surplus has no direct effect on the debate over next year's budget. It simply means that the Treasury Department can pay off a small slice of the nation's $5.5 trillion debt. Moreover, the budget is only balanced when taking into account the proceeds of the tax levied to finance Social Security. If that money was not included, the Government would run a deficit this year of around $50 billion.
A bigger surplus this year, though, suggests a bigger surplus in coming years. The budget office says it now expects a surplus next year of $30 billion or more, at least $20 billion higher than it had been projecting.
As the estimates have grown, so have demands to allocate any leftover money to a host of uses. While Democrats have acceded with little objection to Mr. Clinton's demand to deal with Social Security before dipping into the surplus, Republicans are chafing under that restriction.
Representative Bill Archer, the tax-cutting Texas Republican who is heads the Ways and Means Committee, said that since Mr. Clinton had signed a $2.9 billion emergency bill to fund the American military operation in Bosnia without finding offsetting spending cuts, he had broken his own pledge not to touch the surplus.
"By funding the Bosnia mission out of the surplus, you have demonstrated that your Social Security pledge can be altered when it conflicts with other important priorities," Mr. Archer said on Tuesday in a letter to Mr. Clinton. "Mr. President, if it's good policy to use the surplus for a mission that helps the people of Bosnia, why would you oppose using a portion of the surplus to help the taxpayers of America?"
Representative John R. Kasich of Ohio, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, has been pressing for deep spending cuts, including measures that harken back to the Republican revolutionary spirit of 1995, like eliminating the Commerce and Energy Departments.
Mr. Kasich had already run into considerable opposition from his fellow Republicans, who think such deep cuts are politically unpalatable. Republicans said the growing surplus would only make it harder for Mr. Kasich to win support for his approach.

HEADLINE: Fed Report Indicates Growth Free of Inflation

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's latest reading on the economy points to inflation-free growth as some manufacturers contend with weaker demand from Asia for electronics and other products.
"Economic growth generally continued to be strong in March and April," according to the Fed's latest regional economic outlook, which was released today. "Expansion was occurring in nearly all districts," except those served by the Federal Reserve banks of Dallas and Minneapolis. 
 In other economic news, the Commerce Department said today that factory orders rose moderately in March as demand for industrial equipment and electronic devices like laptop computers helped offset plummeting aircraft orders. New orders for manufactured goods rose three-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $336.23 billion. Orders fell a revised seven-tenths of a percent in February, slightly less than the previously reported drop of nine-tenths of a percent.
The Fed report said there was no inflation. "Competitive pressures were holding prices in check for most goods," the Fed said, though the Fed banks in Dallas and San Francisco reported increases in the costs of some services.
"It looks like we're going to keep on keeping on with more positive signals on growth and inflation," said Raymond Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis.
The report, which is based on information from the Fed's 12 district banks, is published eight times each year. The latest edition was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and will help guide the discussion on interest rates at the May 19 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee.
The latest Fed report, commonly called the beige book, was based on information collected before April 27. It said shortages of workers persisted as the economy grew. "Labor markets continued to be tight," the Fed said, adding that "there was some evidence of increased wage pressures in service industries and for computer and technical professionals."
On other topics, the Fed said "consumer spending was generally robust," as prices for goods "are nearly steady." Manufacturing grew and real estate markets were generally strong, the report said. However, manufacturers of electronics, chemicals and industrial machinery reported weaker export demand stemming from the economic turmoil in Asia while makers of metal products reported competition from cheaper imports.

San Francisco -- The economy grew at a strong pace during March and April. The effects of Asian economic turmoil were moderately evident in several sectors.

HEADLINE: Astronomers Detect Immense Explosion 2d Only to Big Bang

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE 

 BODY:
Astronomers have detected a titanic explosion in the outer reaches of the cosmos -- one so violent and bright that for about 40 seconds it apparently outshone all the rest of the universe. Except for the Big Bang that is generally believed to have created the universe, no other cosmic explosion of such magnitude has ever been discovered.
The observations that led to this finding caught theorists completely off guard, Dr. John N. Bahcall of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., said yesterday. 
 Science has no models that would produce an explanation for so stupendous an outpouring of energy. And so either new observations of similar explosions will lower the estimated energy output, or theorists will be forced to seek some explanation.
"I'm a very troubled theorist," Dr. Stanford E. Woosley of the University of California at Santa Cruz said of the explosion, which occurred 12 billion years ago. "We're really struggling to find a theoretical basis for this."
The results of an investigation by many scientific institutions in the United States, Europe and Asia were announced at a news conference held yesterday in Washington by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and are being published in papers today by the journal Nature.
The event that brought on these frantic international studies was detected five months ago. On Dec. 14, at 6:34 P.M., Eastern standard time, an exquisitely sensitive orbiting gamma-ray observatory called BeppoSAX, which was built by an Italian-Dutch collaboration of astronomers and launched two years ago, signaled to its operators that it had recorded something interesting. For about 40 seconds, the satellite measured a sharp pulse of gamma rays. More important, it pinpointed the position of the rays' source in the sky.
The pulse was also detected by the United States' Compton Gamma Ray Observatory satellite. As measured by the American satellite, the burst's gamma-ray brightness appeared fairly typical of gamma-ray bursts in general. But what astronomers did not realize at that point was that the event had occurred almost incredibly far away, and must therefore have been immensely powerful to look so bright from Earth.
Thousands of gamma-ray "bursters," as such events are called, have been detected since the 1960's, but they remain mysterious, because each one disappears in seconds or minutes and has not been known to recur for further study. Except for the Dec. 14 burster, none of their distances from Earth have ever been determined.
But this burster, designated GRB971214, gave astronomers some of the clues they had long sought.
Right after the gamma-ray burst was detected, dozens of scientific institutions in many parts of the world raced to look for any traces it might have left. Gamma rays are the most energetic of all forms of electromagnetic radiation, but as an object emitting them cools, it radiates waves of lower energy: X-rays, ultraviolet radiation, visible light, infrared rays and, at the lowest range of the energy spectrum, radio.
Since BeppoSAX was launched in 1996, its unmatched ability to detect the exact location of a fleeting gamma-ray burst has allowed scientists to look for a burst's lingering afterglow, which can take the form of X-rays, visible light and other types of radiation.
Twelve hours after the December burst, Dr. John R. Thorstensen of Dartmouth College, using a 94-inch-diameter telescope at the Kitt Peak Observatory in Arizona, found a visible afterglow.
This visible light persisted for about two weeks, and then something even more interesting turned up at the same spot in the sky: scientists found a faint galaxy.
Astronomers realized that this galaxy was probably the host of the gamma-ray explosion and that its distance from Earth must therefore be the same as that of the burster. Many large telescopes were brought to bear on the galaxy, and the Keck II in Hawaii, one of the two largest ever built, hit pay dirt. A team of American, Italian and Indian astronomers led by Dr. Shrinivas R. Kulkarni and S. George Djorgovski, both of the California Institute of Technology, managed to measure the distance to the burster.
Dr. Kulkarni said yesterday that the distant galaxy that spawned the burster appeared to be creating a myriad of new stars, and that the burst might in some way be associated with this process.
Three reports by separate collaborations studying GRB971214 are being published today in Nature. In one, Dr. Kulkarni's team describes how it used the giant Keck instrument to gather enough light from the burster's host galaxy (dubbed "K") to analyze its spectrum. This was no easy task; the apparent brightness of the galaxy is only about the same as that of a 100-watt light bulb viewed from one million miles away.
The astronomers found that lines marking the presence of hydrogen in the spectrum of light coming from the galaxy had been vastly shifted from their usual spectral positions toward the red end of the spectrum.
The Keck measurement revealed that Galaxy K is receding from Earth at enormous speed. This speed, as Edwin Hubble showed, can be used to calculate the distance of any receding celestial object; the greater its speed of recession from Earth, the greater its distance.
The "red shift" of light from the galaxy that apparently spawned the gamma-ray burster was measured as 3.418. From that, the Caltech group calculated that the explosion occurred about 12 billion years ago, when the universe was about 15 percent of its present age. This showed that the distance to the galaxy from Earth was a staggering 12 billion light-years.
From this distance measurement, combined with the measurement of the gamma-ray intensity observed by the Compton Gamma Ray Observatory, it became possible to calculate that the energy released by the blast was about 3 times 1053 ergs, an amount several hundred times greater than the energy released by the explosion of a supernova. Supernova explosions, produced by certain types of dying stars, are the most violent blasts astronomers knew until now. Put another way, the energy released during the 40-second gamma-ray burst detected on Dec. 14 was about equal to the amount of energy that Earth's entire galaxy radiates over a period of several centuries.
Astrophysicists cautioned that in one unlikely situation, their estimate of the punch packed by GRB971214 might be too high: if the object released all or most of its energy along a narrow beam aimed right at Earth, then estimates of the total energy, released in all directions, would be excessive.
Even so, said Dr. Jules P. Halpern of Columbia University, leader of one of the teams studying the burster, its energy must be enormous.
What could account for the monster explosion?
"Most of the theoretical models proposed to explain these bursts cannot explain this much energy," Dr. Kulkarni said. And, he said, while some recent hypotheses involving rotating black holes might explain it, "this is such an extreme phenomenon that it is possible that we are dealing with something completely unanticipated and even more exotic."
One possibility favored by some theorists is that a superdense neutron star might have been ripped apart as it spiraled in toward a neighboring black hole, and that the disk of debris it formed around the black hole created a gamma-ray burst just before disappearing into the black hole.
Another member of Dr. Kulkarni's team, Dr. Alexei V. Filippenko, an astrophysicist at the University of California at Berkeley, suggested that the burst could have been caused by the violent merger of two black holes.
A question that might one day affect the survival of life on Earth is the distribution of potential gamma-ray bursters throughout the universe. If most of them are at enormous distances from Earth, they will pose no significant threat. But indications are that they are randomly distributed, and that some must therefore be relatively close to Earth.
In the February issue of Sky & Telescope magazine, two gamma-ray specialists, Dr. Peter J. T. Leonard and Dr. Jerry T. Bonnell, described gamma-ray bursters as potential killers. They quoted two astrophysicists at the Israel Institute of Technology, Dr. Nir Shaviv and Dr. Arnon Dar, as having calculated that if a burster occurred within 3,000 light-years of Earth, the flood of high-energy gamma rays bombarding Earth's atmosphere would spawn a cascade of cosmic-ray particles.
"Gamma-ray bursters are definitely a potential threat to life on Earth," Dr. Filippenko said. "But happily, we don't see a statistical likelihood of one going off near us for many millions of years."
