HEADLINE: A Pentagon Report Now Belittles the Menace Posed by Cuba

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
This just in from the Pentagon: Cuba is not, after all, much of a threat to national security.
The Pentagon's intelligence report, like all matters Cuban, ignited controversy on Capitol Hill. Even before its release, Speaker Newt Gingrich protested to the Pentagon that Fidel Castro remained "a dangerous and unstable tyrant." 
 In the report, the Pentagon concludes that the collapse of the Soviet bloc in 1991 gravely eroded the size and power of Cuba's military, leaving it barely able to support itself, let alone attack its neighbors.
The nation, once a flash point for nuclear war between the United States and the Soviet Union, now poses "a negligible threat to the U.S. or surrounding countries," said an unclassified version of the report released today.
The Pentagon's analysis, ordered by Congress last year, was no surprise, given Cuba's economic implosion after the end of Soviet-era subsidies. But it still provoked anger among Cuba's critics in Congress, who accused the Clinton Administration of softening its stand toward President Fidel Castro.
Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Cuban-born Republican from Florida, said the Pentagon had "blatantly minimized" what he called "asymmetric threats" posed by Mr. Castro's Government, including its support for drug traffickers.
In March, after Pope John Paul II's visit to Cuba, President Clinton announced an easing of some American restrictions on aid, allowing Cuban-Americans to send money directly to relatives in Cuba and loosening regulations on providing humanitarian supplies. Asked at a news conference today whether he would consider additional gestures, Mr. Clinton said Cuba's rulers had not yet shown "whether they really wish to have a rapprochement."
He added that the Helms-Burton Act, which tightened sanctions on Cuba in 1996, restrained him from more humanitarian gestures, but that he could never "accept some of the anti-democratic and, frankly, clearly anti-human-rights policies of the Government."
When drafts of the Pentagon's views first circulated this spring, they raised such an outcry that the report's release was delayed while Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen oversaw its completion. A senior defense official said Mr. Cohen did not alter the report's conclusions. But in a letter to Senator Strom Thurmond, a South Carolina Republican who is chairman of the Armed Services Committee, he addressed concerns raised by critics, citing Cuba's "continued dictatorship" and noting its failure to apologize for shooting down two unarmed planes piloted by Cuban-Americans in 1996.
The report said Cuba's army could no longer mount "effective operations" since most of its equipment is in storage. It said the navy could not operate in force outside of territorial waters, while the air force, with fewer than two dozen Soviet-era MIG jets still able to fly, could not even defend Cuban airspace against a large attack. In fact, the report said, the military "must now grow its own food and raise money to pay for some of its own expenses."
The report also offered what may be the most understated reason that Cuba's military has never posed much of a threat to its big neighbor to the north: "The Cubans almost certainly calculate that any attack on U.S. territory or forces would draw a swift, forceful U.S. reaction."

HEADLINE: Lawmakers End Their Session By Increasing State Spending

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, May 6

 BODY:
After three years of moderate fiscal austerity, the State Legislature today wrapped up its fourth session under Gov. John G. Rowland after enacting a series of budget revisions that will lead Connecticut to surpass its spending cap for the first time since it became law in 1991.
But Mr. Rowland, a Republican, and top legislators from both parties declared the Legislature's work a success today, noting that it included another year of tax cuts, as well as more spending on education and job training for the poor. 
 "Never in my memory have Democrats and Republicans from all over Connecticut worked so well together for the people of this state," Mr. Rowland wrote in his end-of-session speech, citing the "spending restraint of the last four years" and tax cuts of almost $1.5 billion.
And Mr. Rowland singled out the retiring three-term Democratic Speaker of the House, Thomas D. Ritter. "The remarkable bipartisanship of the last six years is due almost entirely to your leadership as speaker," Mr. Rowland wrote.
The increased spending is not necessarily cause for alarm: the growth rate is smaller than in almost every year in the two decades before Mr. Rowland took office in 1995. Still, the sudden spurt in payments is a step away from the more frugal line that Mr. Rowland had once vowed to toe, and it has raised questions among a handful of lawmakers and fiscal watchdog groups about whether he and the Legislature have lost their fiscal way.
The concerns of these budgetary monitors have been compounded over the last few days as the Legislature, with the Governor's blessing, has approved plans to borrow hundreds of millions of dollars for major urban development projects, school construction measures and the purchasing of open space.
With the state government already having one of the nation's highest per-capita debts, critics worry that the state is burdening future generations with loan payments and additional expenditures. To make matters worse, they charge, tax cuts that are to be phased in over the next four years could leave the state with even less revenue to cover these costs, creating a projected deficit of $500 million in 2000.
"Remember what happens if the economy goes south," said State Representative Carl J. Schiessl, the Democratic co-chairman of the Legislature's tax policy committee, as he took the unusual step of voting against the tax plan that was enacted Saturday. "The choice is between short-term political benefits and long-term stability."
But the state is projected to have a surplus of at least $460 million this year, the largest surplus ever, and one-third of that amount is being set aside in a rainy-day fund for any future deficits. The Office of Fiscal Analysis, a nonpartisan legislative agency, estimates spending increases of 4.5 percent this year and 6.1 percent next year, which are higher than in Mr. Rowland's first two years but are lower than the double-digit growth rates the state racked up in the 1980's.
And although the latest spending package caused the state to exceed the mandated cap -- Mr. Rowland and the Legislature had to approve the overrun -- that may have more to do with the law's quirkiness than with indiscriminate spending.
The Legislature, for instance, approved returning $115 million of the surplus to taxpayers in July in a rebate, and that money is counted as part of the spending that puts the state over the cap.
"This is not a time for wailing and gnashing of teeth," said Michael Meotti, president of the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a nonpartisan research group. The state had legitimate reasons for forgoing the spending cap, he added, though he noted that he was concerned about the growth of spending.
Connecticut has a two-year budget cycle, and the biennial budget that was passed last year set aside $10.5 billion for the second fiscal year, starting July 1. The budget that the Legislature finished today has spending going up by as much as $800 million that next fiscal year, to about $11.3 billion, according to the Office of Fiscal Analysis.
Mr. Schiessl noted that the state had depended on tremendous growth in income-tax revenues -- which account for almost one-third of state revenues -- because of the boom on Wall Street. That trend may not continue, he said.
Mr. Ritter said today that he was concerned about projections of a deficit, but said that the state had added millions to its budget reserve fund. Pointing to the surplus, he added, "I believe the year we're in had a similar estimate for a deficit."

HEADLINE: Stadiums Are Proposed, but Public Isn't Always Disposed to Pay Price

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Seventy-five years ago, Jacob Ruppert and Tillinghast L. Huston built Yankee Stadium for $2.5 million, without debates over where to locate the stadium, how much money the city would chip in or how many luxury suites were needed to maximize their cash flow. It was their money, no arguments.
Today, it is almost impossible to find a city where there isn't fierce, even ugly, debate. From New York to Pittsburgh to Milwaukee to Seattle, governments and taxpayers have been faced with the question of how much to pay for building new stadiums or arenas -- or risk teams fleeing to other cities. At the same time, economists continue to cast doubt on the monetary benefits cities reap from new playing fields. 
 Such a debate has erupted in New York between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who wants to use at least $600 million in city business taxes to help finance stadiums for the Yankees and Mets, and City Council President Peter F. Vallone, who wants a November referendum to let the voters decide.
Mr. Giuliani, who sarcastically dismissed Mr. Vallone's call for a referendum, said he was prepared to invoke little-used powers under the City Charter to block a vote in November. If the experience of other cities is any guide, the Mayor may have good reason to want to avoid such a vote.
Although referendums have passed in some cities over the last few years, voters in others have rejected measures to use tax money to build new arenas and made their political displeasure known.
On Tuesday, for example, voters in two North Carolina counties roundly defeated a plan to raise money from taxes on food and baseball tickets to finance a stadium to lure the Minnesota Twins to the region. The rejection of numerous plans by the Minnesota Legislature to publicly finance a new stadium led to the team's owner, the banker Carl Pohlad, to tentatively agree to sell the club to a businessman in Hickory, N.C.
Last November in Pittsburgh, voters in an 11-county area overwhelmingly rejected a half-cent sales tax increase intended to bankroll new stadiums for the Pirates and Steelers, the expansion of a downtown convention center and other projects.
The previous May, in Columbus, Ohio, voters defeated a half-cent sales tax increase that would have financed the construction of a hockey arena and a soccer stadium. And in San Francisco, voters have repeatedly rejected using tax dollars to finance a new stadium for the Giants.
But if those cities are examples of voter dissatisfaction -- and sometimes disdain for using public funds to help out wealthy team owners -- they also provide lessons for government officials on coming up with other, more creative tactics.
When Pittsburgh voters turned down the sales-tax increase, politicians went to work on alternative financing. Now a hodgepodge of proposals called "Plan B" has developed, including using a portion of an existing county sales tax, a ticket surcharge, a tax on visiting athletes, and hefty contributions from the teams.
"The referendum vote was against a new tax," said Bob Cranmer, an Allegheny County commissioner who is pushing Plan B, as long as he can force the Steelers and Pirates to chip in more than they have promised. "But a lot of people want the new stadiums. They just didn't want a tax."
Pittsburgh is not alone. While the 1990's have seen a surge in the construction of sports stadiums and arenas, they are being financed with a smaller percentage of public dollars.
David Swindell, an assistant professor of urban studies at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, estimates that local governments have paid an average of about 55 percent of the cost of sports facilities in the 1990's, compared with nearly 100 percent during the 1970's.
But even as governments are paying a smaller percentage to build them, stadiums and arenas are costing substantially more than ever before.
"In the '70's, the payments by teams to the cities were big enough for the cities to break even on their investments," Mr. Swindell said. But with governments offering teams financial incentives to relocate, and signing leases that let the teams keep almost all revenues from the stadiums and arenas, "virtually no payments go back to the governments," he said.
In Columbus, officials eventually found private financing for their arena, with Nationwide Insurance and Dispatch Printing agreeing to pay the entire $125 million.
With a $306 million price tag for a Giants stadium, San Francisco had to be more inventive. Officials there raised funds by selling the naming rights to Pacific Bell, and also raised money from advertising, deposits for high-priced seats, concession rights and bank loans.
As with most projects dubbed "private," governments have made financial contributions through improvements in roads, sewers and other infrastructure. San Francisco is investing about $15 million in such improvements.
But when cities, states and counties have gone beyond financing infrastructure improvements to paying part or all of the cost of a stadium or arena, they have used a variety of sources: admission taxes, hotel and motel taxes, car rental taxes, cigarette and alcohol taxes, direct contributions from their treasuries, and revenues from sports lotteries. Other financing tools include special districts that collect taxes from businesses in a stadium's vicinity, and sale-tax funds dedicated soley to stadium construction.
And there have been successful referendums, including ones in Seattle, Tampa Bay, Cincinnati and Cleveland.
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Giuliani will prove successful in his own approach -- using the commercial rent tax, which he had pledged to abolish -- to help provide money for stadiums for the Yankees and the Mets. But the political and public debate is sure to grow more intense in the coming months, with the Mets having recently unveiled a $500 million plan for a new ball park and the Mayor pushing a West Side stadium for the Yankees at a cost of $1 billion.
But the political cost of advocating government financing for a new stadium can be steep. In Wisconsin, the thorny debate cost one lawmaker, State Senator George Petak, his job.
In an April 1995 referendum, voters sent to a thumping defeat a plan to use a lottery to finance a stadium for the Milwaukee Brewers -- and entreaties to move the team were coming from Charlotte, N.C.
In October 1995, state legislators faced a vote on a plan for a 0.1 percent sales tax increase for the five counties in the proposed stadium's vicinity. Mr. Petak, who supported the plan, nevertheless sought to exclude his district's county, Racine, because he felt it was outside the general Milwaukee area. In the first two votes on the package, Mr. Petak voted no and the legislation failed, 16 to 15. It went to a third vote.
"The question I faced was, do we approve a five-county tax and keep baseball, or say no and not keep baseball?" he said. "So I changed my vote." The legislation passed, 16 to 15, to the delight of Gov. Tommy Thompson and Bud Selig, the Brewers' owner, who subsequently raised $90 million in private money for Miller Park.
Eight months later, the furor over Mr. Petak's vote had not subsided, and he faced a recall election in June 1996. His Democratic opponent labeled the stadium bill "the Republican rape of Racine." Mr. Petak lost by about 1,300 votes, the first lawmaker in Wisconsin history to to be removed by recall, providing the Democrats with a one-vote majority in the State Senate.
"The stadium was the most contentious issue I faced," Mr. Petak said, "and it became part of the Democrats' focus on controlling the Senate."

HEADLINE: SHAPING A GLOBAL GIANT: THE INDUSTRY;
Risking Labor Trouble and Clash Of Cultures, 2 Makers Opt for Size

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 6

 BODY:
A quarter of a century ago, most auto makers were convinced that the only way to thrive was to imitate a then-wealthy General Motors and become as big as possible, producing cars of every size and shape and selling them in every market around the globe.
After many years in disrepute, the same theory is back in fashion now and is fully reflected in the planned merger of Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corporation. 
 The deal would turn two medium-sized auto makers with limited vehicle lineups into a single, nearly global manufacturer selling everything from economy cars to luxury sedans to sport utility vehicles and mini-vans.
The short-term advantages of the merger are clear, and sent both companies' stocks up today. Daimler's automotive unit, Mercedes-Benz, will no longer be so dependent on European sales and on the luxury-car market, which is vulnerable to tumbles in stock prices. Chrysler will no longer earn almost all its profit from sales in the United States of a few models of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and mini-vans.
But several obstacles remain to any long-term success from a merger, auto executives said. One lies in avoiding the ponderous decision-making that has plagued G.M., partly because of its enormous size.
Another danger comes from combining two giant corporations with very different business cultures.
And a third pitfall may lurk in the auto makers' sometimes contentious labor relations.
Just as many airlines now see their futures in mergers and joint marketing agreements that span continents, a combination of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler will put new pressure on smaller auto makers around the world. Small producers must now choose either to form their own alliances or risk being trapped in their home markets with a limited lineup of models.
While mergers used to be the refuge of the weak in the auto industry, the decision by Chrysler to renounce its independence despite strong sales and near-record profit shows that all but the world's largest auto makers no longer want to stand on their own.
"All of the smaller players from Chrysler on down have to be more worried now about what comes next," a top Detroit auto executive said today. "The weaker players have to begin wondering how they survive."
Oddly enough, one of the strongest critics of very large auto producers is Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's vice chairman. Mr. Lutz said in an interview in January that when he was an executive vice president of BMW in the early 1970's, he was often asked whether the company would soon be forced to merge because it produced fewer than a million cars a year and seemed to have few economies of scale.
"Here's BMW 25 years later, still gloriously independent," Mr. Lutz noted.
He added that the most efficient manufacturers produced 300,000 to three million vehicles a year. Then he stopped and quickly revised the upper limit for efficient production to five million a year. Since Chrysler made nearly 2.9 million vehicles last year, an upper limit of three million would rule out any mergers. Daimler produced 1.1 million cars and trucks last year.
The son of a Swiss banker and fluent in German, Mr. Lutz may soon prove important in dealing with cultural differences between Mercedes-Benz and Chrysler. Mercedes is known for conservative automobiles with meticulous attention to quality. Chrysler has a reputation for producing many of the most eye-catching vehicles on the road, like the Dodge Viper sports car and the Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle.
But its vehicles also dominate the bottom rungs of the annual auto-reliability ratings by Consumer Reports magazine.
Merging European and American auto makers is not a new idea, and the result last time was a disaster that Chrysler executives know particularly well. In 1981, Renault of France took control of the American Motors Corporation, which made Jeeps and Eagle cars. Years of struggle followed between Detroit and Paris over who would make the decisions, as Renault insisted that American Motors try to sell French-designed cars that often did not meet American quality standards.
Squabbles among executives ended up dooming the Renault merger, said Gerald Meyers, who was the chairman and chief executive of American Motors until 1982, when he resigned.
"On paper, it was a marriage made in heaven," he said, but in practice, "the cultures couldn't get together, and that was the reason it foundered."
Renault ended up selling American Motors in 1987 to Chrysler, which promptly turned Jeeps into one of the world's most valuable brands. The last senior French executive at Chrysler from that era, Francois Castaing, was passed over for the company's presidency a year ago and left his position as an executive vice president to become a consultant to Chrysler.
Mr. Meyers said that while Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, has some international experience from having run G.M.'s European operations, Mr. Lutz would be the key to preventing the Daimler and Chrysler merger from running into the problems that Renault and American Motors encountered.
Mr. Lutz is known for his passion for car design, like many German auto executives and unlike most top Detroit auto executives, who commonly rise to the top through their companies' financial operations. He is famous in Detroit for ridiculing financial executives, and contended in an interview last year that "loving the product does not mean fiscal irresponsibility and you're going to splurge on your hobby."
One question, though, is how long Mr. Lutz will remain at Chrysler. He is 66 and stepped down last year from the positions of president and chief operating officer, although he continues to play an influential role in the design of new vehicles. Mr. Lutz had been expected to retire at the end of this year from his post as vice chairman, when his current contract will expire, but hinted in the January interview that he would be willing to stay longer if really needed.
"Would I work to the age of 85 until some cleaning woman finds me slumped over the desk? Probably," he said, adding that he still thought Chrysler should force older executives to retire. Like other Chrysler executives, Mr. Lutz declined to be interviewed today.
Another long-term problem for the two companies may lie in labor relations. Jurgen Schrempp, Daimler's chairman and chief executive, has restored his company's profitability partly through a series of showdowns with German labor unions, although the unions continue to be represented on Daimler's board. When Mercedes decided in the early 1990's to begin producing sport utility vehicles in the United States, it chose to build a nonunion factory in Tuscaloosa, Ala.
All of Chrysler's factories in the United States are represented by the United Automobile Workers union, which has had no success until now in organizing foreign auto makers' factories in the South. Chrysler endured a 29-day strike here a year ago that temporarily crippled profits.
U.A.W. leaders said today that they were withholding judgment on the proposed merger until they had more details. But people close to the union predicted that it would seek the right to represent the Tuscaloosa workers, and said that the union was nervous that in the next recession, Daimler might lay off Chrysler workers in the United States before Mercedes workers in Germany.

HEADLINE: As Hills Fill Hollows, Some West Virginia Residents Are Fighting King Coal

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: BLAIR, W. Va.

 BODY:
Sylvia Weekley's family has lived here, in Pigeon Roost hollow, for so many decades that the 84-year-old matriarch no longer recalls precisely when her ancestors first arrived.
Like other hollows tucked into the folds of southern West Virginia's mountains, Pigeon Roost is a lush and woody haven that appears much as it did centuries ago. A whispering creek, six feet wide in some places, passes close to Mrs. Weekley's front door. Her son, daughter-in-law and a grandson live nearby. 
 It is a place largely untouched by time and technology. Until now.
For all its rustic charm, Pigeon Roost is about to be obliterated.
The hollow lies at the foot of two mountains whose tops will be blasted away by Arch Coal Inc., a mining company in search of the valuable low-sulfur coal that is abundant throughout the region and is sold all over the world as a major source of electricity. When the work begins, the hollow and the surrounding terrain will become become part of a 3,100-acre strip mine, the largest in the state's history.
In strip mining, mammoth machines remove coal from veins near the surface by stripping away the land and vegetation. In mountaintop strip mining, the remaining rock and earth are usually dumped down the mountain, burying hollows and streams.
Strip mining is hardly new to West Virginia and other coal-producing states. It was a hot environmental issue in the 1970's, when mining companies began using it as an alternative to underground mining, which is costlier and more dangerous. Because of the moonlike terrain it left behind, strip mining become so controversial that it led to Federal regulations intended to protect the land and waterways.
Mountaintop removal, a form of strip mining, is not new either. Over the last decade it has become favored by many mining companies as the most efficient strip mining, allowing them to remove coal faster and with fewer workers than in any other process because the coal generally lies close to the surface at higher elevations.
Recently, however, the debate over strip mining, which receded through the early 1990's, has been reinvigorated by a measure signed into law in April by Gov. Cecil H. Underwood, a Republican who is a former coal company executive. The law would allow companies to dump even more of the stripped earth into the hollows and waterways below the mining sites before they would have to compensate the state for the damage.
Companies say they need the law to lower costs. West Virginia has a stake, too. Coal production has always been a major source of employment and tax revenue in a state with few comparable options.
But the law has frightened residents of Pigeon Roost and places like it and has renewed bitter complaints that strip mining is an environmental disaster, destroying scenic vistas and a small-town way of life. They say the law is another in a long line of concessions to coal companies at the expense of the environment.
 
Fighting for Life 'We Hold So Dear'
Anger over Arch's pending operations in Blair, where mining has already driven out many families, led to a recent hearing where local residents and environmentalists expressed opposition to the magnitude of the operation.
"This is our culture, life in these small hollows," Patricia Bragg, a resident of Pigeon Creek, said in an interview. Pigeon Creek is in Mingo County, the state's leading coal-producing county.
"We know that the quality of life we hold so dear is weighed against progress of the country," Ms. Bragg added. "But we're paying for that progress. People raise millions to save whales and walruses and birds, but the state doesn't lift a hand to save the most precious thing in the world, a person's way of life."
The law has also touched off a dispute between state and Federal officials who disagree over whether West Virginia is doing an adequate job of protecting the environment. One local group has already notified the state's chief environmental officer that it intends to sue, contending that the state has violated the Federal Surface Mining Control and Reclamation Act of 1977. The law sets standards for granting permits, inspecting mines and reclaiming land damaged by the mining process.
The new state law increases to 480 acres from 250 the number of acres of valley waterways, like the creek running along Pigeon Roost hollow, that mining companies can bury before they have to compensate the state. Under the old regulation, the companies paid the state $200,000 for each acre of stream buried above 250 acres. Under the new law, they pay up to $225,000 per acre of stream buried after 480 acres.
Although residents have focused on this latest development, it is mountaintop strip mining itself that is at the core of the dispute. In mountaintop operations, workers use explosives to blast away rock so that giant machines can scoop out the coal. The process can take months.
It is only then that the companies, under requirements of the 1977 Federal act, begin their reclamation projects. Typically, tons of debris are placed at the head of the hollows, then contoured and seeded to approximate land and streams that were obliterated, and ponds are built to replace the creeks.
Over the last three decades, mining companies have reclaimed millions of acres. But critics maintain that too many sites are left unfinished and that ecological systems fed by waterways, now buried under debris, are changed forever.
 
Technological Gains Accelerate Change
With recent technological advances and 20-story machines that cost as much as $100 million, mountaintop mining has accelerated, enabling companies to produce record amounts of coal in West Virginia, far more than was possible through other forms of strip mining.
Mountaintop mining now accounts for nearly a third of the coal produced in the state, a 50 percent increase in 10 years. It is a major reason that coal remains far cheaper than gas or oil as a source of energy.
In 1987 surface mining accounted for 29.7 million tons of coal produced in West Virginia, just 21.6 percent of the total mined. By 1996, the last year for which statistics are available, the total had reached 54.9 million tons, or 31.6 percent of the state's total production.
Most of the largest coal companies operating in West Virginia supported passage of the new law. Industry executives, as well as elected officials who voted for it, contend that it levels the competitive playing field with neighboring Kentucky, where compensation starts at 480 acres.
Proponents also insist that the law will have little if any adverse effect on West Virginia's environment.
"I do not think you will see any degradation of the environment in West Virginia," said William B. Raney, president of the West Virginia Coal Association, a trade group "If you do, I'll be the first in line to call attention to it."
Mr. Raney and other industry officials also say increasing sales of coal help stabilize the economy of a relatively poor state where the coal industry accounts for 16 percent of the state's revenue in a $2.5 billion budget this year.
 
A Federal Warning And One From Citizens
Those arguments wear thin on Federal officials who believe the state acted hastily in approving the new legislation. In a letter that had urged Governor Underwood to veto the measure, W. Michael McCabe, a regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency, protested several items, including the compensation change. Not that the old regulations were particularly expensive for the companies. According to E.P.A. records of mining applications from 1991 to 1997 in West Virginia, 65 mining sites that affected more than 250 acres of valley waterways brought the state 24 projects and 41 "monetary commitments" of about $7 million.
Mr. McCabe warned the Governor that if the measure passed, "we would regretfully have little choice but to increase our reviews" of all mountaintop mining applications, delays that industry officials assert are unwarranted and expensive.
After Mr. Underwood signed the bill, he criticized Mr. McCabe, for "making threats."
The residents' planned suit against the state cites many of same issues the E.P.A. raised, but more broadly. Challenging the consequences of mountaintop mining, the plaintiffs told John E. Caffrey, director of the state Division of Environmental Protection, they were concerned about the "loss and degradation" of state waters" from mining.
"There is no science on this," said Joseph Lovett, a lawyer in Charleston who is representing the group. "Nobody really knows the effects of filling valley streams. Before, the state had an informal policy. I think the policy was illegal, and now they have put it into law."
Robert S. Kiss, Speaker of the West Virginia House of Representatives, who was a leading proponent of the new law, said that if the new acreage limit proved detrimental to the state he "would not be adverse to revisiting the issue."
At the same time, Mr. McCabe of the E.P.A. said several Federal agencies have begun talking about a comprehensive study of the potential consequences of valley fills.
 
A Community Left With Only Its Dead
But people like Larry Gibson, a retired auto worker whose family settled in Kayford more than 150 years ago, do not need studies to confirm what they see.
At one time, he said, 30,000 people lived in Kayford, about 20 miles from Blair. Now the only permanent residents are the 100 or so members of Mr. Gibson's family who are buried at the top of Kayford Mountain. Mining on nearby peaks, which once were taller than Kayford Mountain, forced the remaining residents to leave, Mr. Gibson said. He and his relatives resisted selling the cemetery and adjacent land, on which they have built a small park.
"It's emotional for me, walking around here," he said, moving about headstones that had been broken by flying rocks from the blasting. "My target is to slow or stop the devastation coal is doing to this state. It used to be a showcase around here."
Dynamite explosions that cause flying rocks as well as cracks in walls and ceilings far from the blast site are a constant problem for people living nearby. They have caused many residents to accept buyouts from the coal companies, who offer $100,000 and more for some homes. While the price may seem generous, many residents say it barely compensates for the cost of moving to new communities, finding new jobs and buying other homes.
But the difficult choice of enduring months of noise, dust and rocks or abandoning towns where relatives have lived for generations is beyond reasonable for many residents of southern West Virginia.
 
Toughing It Out Despite Everything
"The bottom line, whether they offer you a fair price or not, is why do I have to move?" said Ms. Bragg, a plaintiff in the proposed lawsuit. "As an American, I can choose where I want to live. If I choose to live in a hollow, call me a hick or a hillbilly, but that's where I want to live."
For the Weekleys it is no longer an issue. Unlike dozens of their neighbors, they have refused all offers from Arch. Even in the face of thunderous blasting and a reconstructed valley that could come within 300 feet of where they live, they have vowed to stick it out.
James Weekley Jr., Sylvia Weekley's 57-year-old son, walked up the creek to a point several hundred yards away, where the replacement pond is planned. Along the way he spotted "crawdads and other varmints" in the creek.
He looked around a place he knows well. "I'm not leaving," he said. "This is my home, and they are destroying what God created. I'm beginning to know how the Indians felt, and I've told the coal companies that the only way they'll push me out is with a bulldozer. I'm too old to change my life style."

SECTION: Section A; Page 17; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 546 words

HEADLINE: House Approves Cheaper Loans to Help Students and Bankers

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 6

 BODY:
The House tonight overwhelmingly passed an education bill that would make loans cheaper for millions of students but would soften the blow for banks through a new Federal subsidy.
In a late night vote of 414 to 4, Democrats joined Republicans to approve the higher education reauthorization bill, putting the House on a collision course with the Clinton Administration over student loans. The Administration objects to the loan provision, arguing that banks would profit excessively at the expense of other education programs. 
 Today's resounding vote may make it more difficult for the White House to oppose the legislation. The Senate, which has been working with the House on the reauthorization bill, is expected to take the measure up next week.
"If banks don't make a profit, they will go into lending something else," said Representative Howard P. McKeon, Republican of California, who brokered the compromise bill and said it would give students the lowest interest rate in 17 years. "Banks are cold. I would rather make sure we protect students."
Unlike interest rates on mortgages and car loans, which are set competitively by banks, the rate on college loans is fixed by Congress and is scheduled to be readjusted July 1. The current rate is 8.23 percent.
In a bipartisan compromise that seeks to strike a balance between the concerns of students and banks, the House bill would create two separate interest rates for the loans, one for students, 7.43 percent, and a slightly higher one for banks, 7.93 percent. The Federal government would make up the difference.
Late last night, the House also roundly rejected an amendment to end affirmative action programs in public universities.
The battle between the Clinton Administration and the House over loan interest rates comes at a time when college tuition is skyrocketing and a greater number of students are relying on loans. Loans account for 60 percent of Federal student aid, compared with 40 percent in 1980. About 5 million students benefit from the loan programs, a higher number than for any other Federal programs, except Medicare and Social Security.
For months, commercial banks had threatened to abandon the student loan business, saying it would not have been profitable enough for them to continue making loans under the lower rate.
The administration argues that the banks should lower their rate to 7.43 percent without the proposed subsidy, which ranges in cost from $1 billion to $3.8 billion over five years.
Education Secretary Richard W. Riley said in a letter to Speaker Newt Gingrich that the House bill would create excessive profits.
The Federal government's direct student loan operation handles about 35 percent of the total number of loans, and administration officials say they would be ready with a back-up plan if banks decide pull out.
The problem, said Terry Hartle, a spokesman for the American Council on Education, a trade group representing 18,000 universities and colleges, is that nobody knows if it is the government or the banking industry that is exaggerating. "Because the government doesn't have a market-based way to determine what the interest rate should be, there is no way to tell," he said. "Congress has to guess at the prices."

Daimler-Benz of Germany Plans to Acquire Chrysler
Daimler-Benz A.G., the German giant that makes Mercedes-Benz, will acquire Chrysler, Detroit's No. 3 auto maker, in an estimated $36 billion transaction expected to be announced as early as this morning.
It would be the biggest industrial takeover ever, as well as the biggest foreign purchase of an American company. Page A1. 

Two auto makers with limited vehicle lineups would be turned into a single, nearly global manufacturer selling everything from economy cars to luxury sedans to sport utility vehicles and mini-vans. A1.
 
Chrysler's corporate history personifies a hardscrabble American struggle for success. Jurgen Schrempp, having overhauled Daimler from top to bottom, shedding many companies and people, is now building it back up. D4.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2125 words

HEADLINE: SHAPING A GLOBAL GIANT: THE OVERVIEW;
DAIMLER-BENZ WILL ACQUIRE CHRYSLER IN $36 BILLION DEAL THAT WILL RESHAPE INDUSTRY

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS and LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
Daimler-Benz A.G., the German industrial giant that makes Mercedes-Benz automobiles, will acquire the Chrysler Corporation in an estimated $36 billion merger expected to be announced as early as this morning.
The deal would be the biggest industrial takeover in history and the biggest acquisition of any American company by a foreign buyer. It would reshape the United States automobile industry by uniting America's third-largest car maker with Germany's renowned producer of luxury cars and heavy-duty trucks. 
 The merged company -- which would combine one of America's greatest industrial comeback stories with a stodgy but tough German industrial icon -- carries significant risks. Other big automotive mergers have not worked well, and the partners in this proposed marriage differ starkly in culture and product.
Nonetheless, the combination would still create a formidable competitor on both sides of the Atlantic. The companies' combined auto sales, ranging from the $11,000 Plymouth Neons to the $40,000 Jeep Grand Cherokees to the $135,000 Mercedes 12-cylinder CL600 coupes, totaled $131 billion last year.
Terms of the deal, a stock swap that values Chrysler at about $36 billion, are expected to be announced as early as this morning in London, considered a neutral ground between Chrysler's headquarters in suburban Detroit and Daimler-Benz's home in Stuttgart. The deal is a windfall for Chrysler shareholders, whose stock rose nearly 18 percent yesterday on reports of merger talks with Daimler-Benz. Page D1.
Both Chrysler's board and Daimler-Benz's management board met separately yesterday and approved the terms, a person close to the talks said. Daimler-Benz's supervisory board, the second in its two-board structure, is expected to approve the deal over the next few days.
While the two companies are likely to pitch the combination to investors as a merger of equals, Daimler-Benz is expected to be the dominant partner in the future. The new company, which would be called DaimlerChrysler, would be incorporated in Germany with headquarters in Michigan and Stuttgart, and Daimler-Benz's shareholders would own a majority of the shares. It would be jointly run for a number of years by Jurgen Schrempp, the chief executive of Daimler-Benz, and Robert J. Eaton, Chrysler's chief executive, and it is thought Mr. Schrempp could take control after their joint term.
The end of Chrysler as an independent auto maker would mark a stunning turn of events for a company that lurched from one crisis to another in the 1970's, culminating in near collapse, a Government rescue and re-emergence as an agile, low-cost producer and design leader that invented the mini-van.
For Daimler-Benz, known for decades as a ponderous, slow-moving and intensely conservative corporation, the Chrysler marriage promises immediate access to the North American mass market for automobiles without diluting the carefully cultivated upscale image of its Mercedes-Benz brand. It would also give the German company production capacity outside Germany, where worker wages and benefits are among the highest in the world. It further offers Daimler-Benz an opportunity to learn from Chrysler's envied process of making decisions quickly and bringing new vehicles to market promptly -- attributes that have become more important as competition in the industry has escalated. DaimlerChrysler would rank as No. 5 among world auto makers behind General Motors, Ford, Toyota and Volkswagen.
News of negotiations over a merger, first reported yesterday by The Wall Street Journal, electrified financial markets. Chrysler shares surged $7.375, or 17.8 percent, to $48.8125; Daimler-Benz's American depository receipts rose $6.50, or 6.4 percent, to $108.5625. Anticipation of other mergers pushed up shares of Europe's other big car companies, including Volkswagen, Fiat, Renault and Peugeot.
The proposed deal stunned industry analysts and automobile executives, and not simply because of its size. Except for the fact that both companies make cars, they could not be more different. Chrysler, based in Auburn Hills, Mich., is fundamentally middle class and Midwestern. About 70 percent of its sales come from Jeeps, vans and pickup trucks. It has a negligible European presence.
Daimler-Benz, by contrast, is elite and European. Most Mercedes passenger cars range from $30,000 to more than $100,000, and most of its sales are in Europe. Though sales by Mercedes in the United States soared 65 percent last year, it commands less than 1 percent of the American market.
Rumors of a Chrysler merger have been circulating for a long time, but because the company lacks the resources to compete on a global scale, few people expected a merger with Daimler-Benz.
"We wise industry pundits, who are always keeping lists of possible mergers, would have probably put it at the bottom of our B-list," said John Lawson, an automobile industry analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in London.
Unlike many other industrial mergers, analysts said, Chrysler and Daimler-Benz are not likely to benefit from quick cost reductions by eliminating extra factories and laying off thousands of workers. That is because Daimler and Chrysler have such fundamentally different businesses that they barely compete.
But at least theoretically, analysts said, the merger could make good strategic sense over the longer term. By joining Chrysler, Mercedes would obtain a huge position almost overnight in the United States -- the world's biggest market. Chrysler has an enormous network of dealerships in the United States and an insider's feel for how to design and sell vehicles in that market. It is also unlikely to face any antitrust objections from United States or European regulators.
The merger is expected to be what is known as a pooling of interests in which Chrysler and Daimler-Benz shareholders will exchange their shares for shares of DaimlerChrysler. Daimler-Benz shareholders would receive one share of the new company for each Daimler-Benz share. Chrysler shareholders would get about 0.55 share in the new company for each Chrysler share, but that ratio was expected to be adjusted later.
Mr. Eaton and Mr. Schrempp met mostly in New York and London, and once in Switzerland, over the last few months to discuss the merger, a person close to the talks said. While the two companies have held merger discussions before, it was not until the two ran into each other at an auto show several months ago that discussions resumed. The two were in New York as recently as Monday working out the details as well as running through a dress rehearsal of the news conference.
Under Mr. Schrempp, Mercedes has expanded its line of passenger vehicles in directions that were once unthinkable -- sport utility vehicles, snappy new convertibles and even the A-Class subcompact. But company officials have long acknowledged that it would be too dangerous to head too far in the direction of middle-class sedans under the Mercedes name.
Mr. Schrempp, for example, has emphasized that the quirky two-seater "Swatchmobile," which is to be introduced in the next year, is not and will not be a "Mercedes." Indeed, Daimler executives have flirted with the idea of starting a new brand.
The deal is also unusual in that it unites two companies that are both enjoying big profits and big growth. After nearly going bankrupt in the early 1980's, Chrysler now earns more profit on every car than any other company in the industry. Daimler-Benz, which lost billions of dollars in a disastrous effort to diversify into fields like aircraft and insurance, has now refocused on its core automotive business and is enjoying spectacular growth.
But both companies lack important building blocks to become truly global. Neither has a meaningful position in Latin America or Asia, where the biggest demand is for small and modestly priced cars.
Chrysler was forced to sell its overseas subsidiaries in the late 1970's as a condition of receiving Federal assistance and has lagged behind Ford and General Motors in capitalizing on the surge in demand in countries like Brazil and Argentina. Chrysler is building a Jeep plant in Argentina but continues to play catch-up.
Meanwhile, Daimler-Benz's dependence on high-priced cars produced in comparatively low volumes -- only 726,000 automobiles last year, compared with 2.3 million by Chrysler -- has meant that it could not achieve the economies of scale that come with more mass-market products.
Given the complementary strengths of each company, analysts and industry executives said the proposed merger could solve some of those problems.
"It would have to be viewed as a very good strategy, though in a 5-to- 10-year view," said Martin Ziegenbalg, an automobile industry analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson in London. "It will create a true global player that will be more balanced in terms of geography and in terms of product line."
Indeed, some industry experts said the biggest barrier to such a match in previous years had been the incompatibility between strong-willed executives. "These two have been obviously marriage prospects for at least 10 years, but it was totally impossible because of the personalities," said Gerald Meyers, the former chairman and chief executive of the American Motors Corporation, which Chrysler acquired from the French car manufacturer Renault in 1987. Specifically, Mr. Meyers said, a merger involving Lee A. Iacocca, the former Chrysler chairman, would have been unworkable.
That does not mean it will be easy. The cultural differences between one of Detroit's Big Three and Germany's biggest industrial corporation will almost certainly be huge. And the experience of trans-Atlantic automobile mergers is not entirely convincing.
Perhaps the clearest demonstrable success story is General Motors, which took over Germany's Adam Opel A.G. decades ago. Despite its ups and downs, Opel is one of Europe's biggest automobile producers and has generally thrived.
But other cases are not so reassuring. The Ford Motor Company bought Jaguar and Aston Martin and sank huge sums of money to renovate their factories and car lines. But Ford's European operations are still struggling to make money in Europe. G.M. bought 50 percent of Saab of Sweden, but the company has yet to be a big source of profits.
The biggest failure in uniting an American and European company was the French company Renault's acquisition of the American Motors Corporation in 1978. Renault invested more than $1 billion in American Motors, which once made Ramblers but was best known for its Jeeps, only to see the company's sales plunge by more than half in the mid-1980's. Renault finally sold the company to Chrysler for $741 million in 1987, and it has achieved huge success as the base for Chrysler's thriving business in sport utility vehicles.
In Daimler-Benz, Chrysler would be getting a strong partner with a very aggressive management. Mr. Schrempp, who is 53, has put Daimler through a radical and often painful overhaul since he took over as chairman in 1995. Daimler shed more than 40,000 employees in less than two years, refocused on its core automotive business and began expanding into new areas like sport utility vehicles.
Daimler's sales and profits have both soared, and its American sales have jumped 65 percent in the last year thanks largely to its hugely popular new M-Class sport utility vehicle, which is being build in Tuscaloosa, Ala. Daimler's stock price has more than tripled in the last three years and has climbed 40 percent since the start of this year.
All of that has put Mr. Schrempp in a powerful position to make a big move. With Daimler's stock at all-time highs, the envisioned exchange of stock allows Mr. Schrempp to take a huge step onto the global stage without having to borrow heavily or bankrupt his treasury.
What is unclear is how long Mr. Eaton, 58, will stick around after his joint term ends. According to Chrysler's most recent proxy statement, Mr. Eaton and Gary Valade, Chrysler's chief financial officer, are not eligible for early retirement unless there is "the event of a change of control" in the company's management. That would include an acquisition or merger, a person close to the talks said. In fact, a harbinger of how well Mr. Eaton and Mr. Schrempp will ultimately get along could be the site of the news conference to announce the deal. It is thought they picked London because neither chief executive wanted to be upstaged on the other's home turf. "Merger of equals is the term that has to be used to make this palatable," a person close to the talks said. "You have to have a crystal ball to see how this will work out."

HEADLINE: Battle of Conservatives In Nebraska's Primary

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: LINCOLN, Neb.

 BODY:
From the stockyards and railroads of Omaha to the cattle-roaming flat lands of western Nebraska, this state has grown far more conservative in the 100 years since its native son William Jennings Bryan ran for President as a radical populist.
While Bryan attacked the wealthy in his "cross of gold" speech, it is now more often welfare recipients who are portrayed as the culprits in advertisements for the Republican candidates for governor as they head into the May 12 primary here. 
 The front-runner in the Republican contest, which is expected to yield the strong favorite in the general election, is Representative Jon Christensen, one of the most conservative voices in Congress, a man who recently became engaged to a former Miss America, and soon after disclosed that she was a virgin.
The other Republican candidates are John Breslow, the State Auditor who has poured more than $2 million of his own money into political advertisements, most of them intent on showing he is just as conservative as Mr. Christensen; and Mike Johanns, the Mayor of Lincoln, and a moderate.
In the view of most political experts, the race is expected to be between Mr. Christensen and Mr. Breslow.
"Between those two, it seems to be a competition of who can position themselves farther to the right on taxes, on standing pro-business, and being anti-gay and lesbian," said Loree Bykerk, a political science professor at the University of Nebraska.
Mr. Breslow has said that, as governor, he would veto any measure passed by the Nebraska Legislature allowing marriages between homosexuals. "As if that would ever come across his desk," Ms. Bykerk said, noting that the Nebraska Legislature is scarcely on the brink of pushing ahead for gay rights.
But Mr. Christensen has gone a step further, saying he would never hire a homosexual in his administration.
"I would not -- if I knew someone was a homosexual -- I would not knowingly appoint somebody to a position of leadership," he said in a recent debate. "Because I believe it is important that any person model who I am as a person. They model my ideology, my belief system, my conservative values, my belief as a family man."
On the Democratic side, Bill Hoppner, a lawyer and former aide to Senator Bob Kerrey who ran a previous campaign for governor, faces James McFarland, a lawyer and former professional football player -- and, more important, a star for the University of Nebraska in the late 1980's.
Mr. McFarland, who spent one term in the state's unicameral legislature, has some blemishes in his past. He disclosed several years ago that he had struck his wife and son on two occasions in 1985, and that they had sought help at a shelter for battered women. He later divorced and remarried.
The current Governor, Ben Nelson, a Democrat, cannot run for re-election under the state's term-limits law.
A state that is overwhelmingly white and lacking any strong labor union presence, Nebraska has been one of the most Republican states in Presidential elections for at least a generation. Still, it elects plenty of Democrats to state-wide office. In fact, both of the state's senators were Democrats until 1996, when Jim Exon retired, and a Republican, Chuck Hagel, won the seat. This year, the Republicans are expected to win the governor's race, because their candidates have greater name recognition and the Democratic field is considered relatively weak.
As is the case in most of the rest of the country in this election year, Nebraska is enjoying relative prosperity. The farm economy is much stronger than in the 1980's, when foreclosures were common. Omaha, the state's largest city, is booming, with the construction of high-priced housing in the neighborhoods that stretch west of Boys Town.
Nebraska is the home of Conagra, a huge farm products company, and of Warren Buffett, the investor who is considered the richest American after Bill Gates of the Microsoft Corporation.
Perhaps the most contentious issue in Nebraska's general election this year is the increasing number of large hog farms, where the swine are crowded in enclosed quarters, a practice known as confinement.
The odors from confinement hog farming can be noxious, and people who live in small towns near the farms complain about being unable to step outside when the wind blows in a certain direction. Moreover, advocates for smaller farms say the factory-like hog operations threaten to run family farms out of business.
The three Republicans in the governor's race have strongly defended the big hog operations, often by attacking environmentalists as extremists.
"Once they go after the hog producer, the next thing they are going to do is go after the cattle producer," Mr. Christensen said. "Then it is just going to be a slippery slope before they come after us all."
Mr. Johanns has ridiculed environmental rules in Lincoln that protect "carp and bullheads and the mosquitoes flying by."
And Mr. Breslow has argued that the state needs more big hog operations, not fewer. "I think Nebraska has to give a message all around the country that we are here and we want good businesses," he said, "and I believe these are good businesses."
On the Democratic side, Mr. McFarland has called for a moratorium on large-scale hog operations. Mr. Hoppner has said he prefers a strict environmental approach, making sure that big hog farms do not foul the countryside and small towns.
Mr. Christensen, a relative newcomer to state politics, has risen quickly: In 1994 he defeated a Democratic Congressman, Peter Hoagland, to represent the district that includes Omaha and its suburbs. In that campaign, Mr. Christensen, a fundamentalist Christian, relied heavily on support from evangelical churches.
When he divorced during that first campaign -- a potential political liability among religious conservatives -- his wife signed an affidavit attesting to her unfaithfulness, and took the blame for the divorce. Now that Mr. Christensen has publicly lauded his fiancee, Tara Dawn Holland, for "saving herself for marriage," some Nebraskans say Mr. Christensen, 35, should keep some things to himself.
"A man announcing that his betrothed is a virgin sounds backwoods," wrote Rainbow Rowell, a columnist for the Omaha World-Herald. "Example: Yep, she's a virgin with a fine set of teeth, and I got 23 chickens for taking her off Pa's hands."

 BODY:
NEWMAN-Lenore. Died quietly at home on May 6 in her apartment in New York City. Family and friends join together in sorrow at the departure of this caring, loving person who carried her professional social work training as a way of life. She retired from Roosevelt-St. Luke's Hospital as supervising medical social worker. Her surviving family include her nieces Sharon and Marla, her nephew Bernard, her grandnephews Frank and Jeremy, & her sister-in-law Janis Newman. Levi, 91 Central Park West (96th Street), Monday 6-8 P.M., and Tuesday 4-8 P.M. Interment will be at the Riverside Cemetery, Rochelle Park, New Jersey.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
As an Etcher, Whistler Did More Than Scratch the Surface

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
If James McNeill Whistler (1834-1903) did not single-handedly revive the art of etching from its post-Rembrandt doldrums, he had much to do with repopularizing it. Convinced that prints could be as vital as paintings, he became a master of the medium, and there have been collectors so hooked on his etchings and lithographs that they scarcely acknowledge his talent at the easel.
The scope of Whistler's innovative printmaking is evident in the show of 50 etchings and 31 lithographs at the National Academy Museum, parts of his acclaimed sets of views of France, London, Venice and Amsterdam. The show is drawn from the well-rounded collection of Whistler's prints at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh, and it makes clear the technical and artistic accomplishments of Whistler the etcher. 
 Whistler was born in Lowell, Mass., but later became a Londoner by choice. He had always been interested in printmaking, experimenting with etching and lithography in his youth. Expelled from West Point for poor grades in chemistry, then dismissed from a job with the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey for erratic attendance, he went to Paris at age 21 to study painting. He arrived at a time when the tide had turned again to etching as a fine-art medium, and he took it up eagerly, while pursuing his painting studies.
In fact, in the 1850's, his talents as an etcher were more apparent than his prowess as a painter. After a walking tour of northern France, Luxembourg and the Rhineland with a friend in 1858, he produced "Twelve Etchings From Nature," later called "The French Set." The prints were full of details that reflected the powerful trend of realism championed by Gustave Courbet (1819-77).
Only a few are in this show, but they reveal a strong grasp of the etching technique as a medium of light and shadow. Whistler's awareness of Rembrandt and other 17th-century Dutch masters is evident in a striking work from the series, "The Kitchen," a gloomy interior illuminated by a window set in a deep alcove. A lone woman stands at the window, back to the viewer, poignantly silhouetted by the light. In Whistler's time, it was the most popular print of the group.
Yet he apparently considered his first important contribution to etching the group of prints known as the "Thames Set," produced in London, where he settled in 1858. The bustling life on the river was a symbol to him of the city's vitality. And the Dickensian mix of sailors and longshoremen, ships, docks, bars and crumbling warehouses lent itself to his realistic approach. His skill at drawing and use of the etching needle allowed him to shift at will from tight, meticulous rendering to a flowing freedom of line.
In "Black Lion Wharf" (1859), for example, an extraordinarily detailed row of hodgepodge structures stands on the riverbank, while the Thames rolls before it, clogged with more loosely sketched boats and rivermen. One idle sailor sits in the foreground, his arm resting on the gunwale of a boat.
Despite the massing of details, light fills this and other early Thames views, like the 1860 print "Rotherhithe" (a grungy neighborhood east of the Tower of London) that combines riverscape with portraiture. In it, two men relax on a dock in the close foreground; immediately behind them loom a wall and a maze of masts and rigging. The flat picture space was possibly derived from Whistler's study of Japanese prints. In scenes like these, he often allowed the emptiness of the sky to be reflected in a corresponding patch of water, enhancing the light while providing a calm foil for the action on the river.
In his later years, Whistler turned from realism to a more impressionistic style, preferring low-key colors and the murky atmosphere of fog. From Japanese prints, he had begun to view paintings more as "arrangements" or harmonies than as factual reports. In the early 1870's, he started his long series of nocturnes, which he defined as "arrangements of line, form and color," divested of "any outside sort of interest." He carried out the idea in prints as well as paintings, making his first strong venture into lithography in 1878.
In "Nocturne: The River at Battersea," a small watercolorlike lithotint on blue paper of that year, a lone fisherman or clam digger appears in the foreground of a hazy expanse of water with a blurred but decorative silhouette of buildings on the far bank of the Thames. Whistler was moving toward the impressionistic style that came to full fruition in his wonderful Venetian series.
He went to Venice late in 1879 to carry out a commission from the Fine Art Society of London for 12 etched views of the city. His trip, which came at a time of financial struggle, was a triumph; the dozen prints he produced for the society, usually known as the "First Venice Set," and others that were published later under different auspices established him as a great 19th-century master in the field.
His was not the tourist's Venice. He drew palaces, hidden courtyards, out-of-the-way canals, boats, bridges and people, often working directly on an etching plate he carried with a fine needle or a dentist's tool. And he adopted a new style that seemed tailored to the Venetian environment and character.
With great economy of line, he captured the city's bright atmosphere and the delicate traceries of its distinctive architecture. In "Palaces" (1879-80), his biggest Venetian print, he depicted in lavish detail two palaces along the Grand Canal, next to but not including the most famous Venetian palace of all, the Ca d'Oro. The fine details of windows and doors, the ripples of sunlight on the water, the lineup of dark gondolas, are all achieved with a lightness of touch that seems to capture the very essence of this odd but magical place. Whistler wanted the same tonal effects in his prints as in his paintings, and to get them, he wiped excess ink from the plate with muslin, then manipulated the remaining thin film with his hand to give the effect of light or water. The beautiful results of this procedure are particularly evident in his scenes of bridges and boats on the water, like "Nocturne" (1879-80), an idyll in brown ink that some consider his most important print.
Depicting a wide expanse of lagoon and sky at dusk, with the ghost of a two-masted boat at right center and the hazy outline of the Piazza San Marco in the distance, the print is notable for its exquisite tonal variations, which Whistler achieved by careful manipulation of ink on the plate. Paying close attention to the quality of these etchings, printed in the 1880's, he went over each impression himself, using his wiping technique to evoke different moods and even times of day in the same print.
Whistler produced the last of his great etching cycles in Amsterdam, where he spent the fall of 1889. The difference in technique between the works done here and those of his Venice period is marked. The Amsterdam prints are more linear than tonal, as in "Balcony," a tenement scene with clothes on a wash line. Its effects are produced by detailed drawing rather than the gradations of tone Whistler used in many of his Venice views. He said the Amsterdam set, few impressions of which were printed, was his best; but time has judged differently.
In any case, this show is a fine introduction to Whistler's brilliant printmaking strategies, and a great pleasure to see.
"Whistler: Impressions of an American Abroad -- Etchings and Lithographs from the Carnegie Museum of Art" remains at the National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, through June 26.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: MARKET PLACE;
For the best of all possible markets, higher earnings coinciding with lower economic growth.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
WITH the first-quarter earnings season winding down, investors need two things to help them reaffirm a positive outlook: a rebound in earnings from the anemic pace of the first quarter and a slowdown in the rapid pace of economic growth in the first three months of the year.
Those may seem like conflicting goals. But a slowdown may be the best near-term course for stock market investors. 
 According to First Call, a firm that monitors earnings estimates and performance, profits grew by about 3 percent in the first quarter, the smallest increase since the fourth quarter of 1991.
But analysts are forecasting an 8 percent jump this quarter and an even sharper rise in the second half of the year. This expected rebound, many analysts have said, is the reason the market rose to new highs recently in spite of last quarter's weak earnings.
But a slowdown in overall economic growth, from 4.2 percent in the first quarter to the 2 percent range, is not the best way to bolster corporate earnings. A slowdown requires companies to make or sell fewer products as demand declines. Revenue growth would also decline.
Still, investors may hope for a slowdown as the only way to keep the Federal Reserve from interrupting their party by raising short-term interest rates. Even the threat of such a move, which came in a report in The Wall Street Journal on April 27, sent the stock market reeling. And the threat is still overhanging the market, contributing to the volatile performance of stocks in the last two and a half weeks.
While there are some signs of slowing in American industry and exports, consumer spending is strong, propelled by low interest rates, mortgage refinancing, inexpensive fuel prices and a stock market that has risen 13 percent this year. Both car and retail sales were stronger than expected as the second quarter began.
A rapid pace of growth would certainly force Fed policy makers to raise interest rates to try to cool off the economy before inflation began to rebound.
Any such increase would be followed by questions about the next one. There would be a debate over whether the Fed would just nudge rates higher or be more aggressive. The resulting surge in interest rates on bonds would make a stock market that is, at best, just at full value look pricey and vulnerable to a fall.
But weak earnings, as long as they are not far out of line with profit expectations, do not seem as negative.
The reason lies in the billions of dollars pouring in each month to stock mutual funds. This flow of money seems to reflect less worry about earnings than an investor rush to get into stocks before they move much higher. Aggressive jawboning by corporations about lower profit forecasts has seen to it that investors get mostly positive surprises when the quarterly figures finally come out.
And American corporations have proved that they can increase earnings by cutting costs, even if sales are sluggish.
"In this expansion, because we have reaped all the efficiencies of running corporations better, earnings have vastly outstripped the economy," said Richard Berner, chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "There is no ironclad rule that earnings and the economy have to move in lockstep."
But, Mr. Berner said, this means that investors are counting more on earnings from cost-cutting or cost containment than about the growth of sales. Those savings, which bolstered earnings so much in recent years, may be dwindling.
Heidi Kunz, chief financial officer of ITT Industries, acknowledges both the opportunities for savings and the difficulties. "When we look at our business," she said, "we think there are significant cost-reducing opportunities. However, "the question is how much of that you have to share with your customer base" by cutting prices.
All these options should be on the mind of investors as statistics for the second quarter start coming out and the market soothsayers try to divine what the economy is doing and, if it slowing, is it slowing enough.
The first real glimpse into the second quarter comes today, with the Labor Department's employment report for April. The consensus among analysts is an increase of 265,000 jobs and a decline in the unemployment rate to 4.6 percent from 4.7 percent.
Those are not the kinds of numbers that would convince the Federal Reserve that the economy is slowing down. But coming after a surprising job decline of 36,000 in March, such figures might not be too disturbing. Weaker job creation, however, would make traders happier, as they seem to grasp anything that looks like good news these days.

HEADLINE: A Tale of Torture From an Indonesian Dissident

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Pius Lustrilanang, a student activist, says he was kidnapped at gunpoint on Feb. 4 at a bus stop in Indonesia's capital, blindfolded, driven outside the city and placed in a cell, naked.
Before the first electric shock, he says, he heard one interrogator say: "Here there is no law. There is no human rights. All you have to do is answer our questions. Some people leave here alive. Some don't. They are never found." 
 His questioners were military men who went about their work methodically and patiently, Mr. Lustrilanang said. "They tortured me to get information, not merely for pleasure," he said in an interview, his first since he fled Indonesia 11 days ago. "They wanted to know the constellation of the opposition, the alliances between different leaders."
They threatened him with death, he said, and warned him that if he wanted to live after his release, he should stay silent forever.
Mr. Lustrilanang was one of about 50 Indonesians who have disappeared in the past three months, apparently into the hands of the Indonesian security forces, according to the nation's leading legal aid organization.
The Indonesia Government acknowledges that there have been disappearances among the political opposition; some Indonesian officials have suggested that they are the work of vigilantes or criminals. But opponents of the Government have suffered death, torture and jail for their beliefs at the hands of the government, the State Department says.
Mr. Lustrilanang, who is 30 years old and leader of a prominent student group opposed to President Suharto, was held for two months and then released after international pressure on the Government. He arrived in the United States on Wednesday night, and testified today at a Congressional hearing.
As Indonesia endures the worst political and economic crisis in the 32-year reign of President Suharto, the Clinton Administration is straining to separate questions of political freedom and human rights from economic support. On Monday the Administration expressed support for resuming financial aid to Indonesia through the International Monetary Fund, while simultaneously voicing concern about the kidnapping of dissidents.
Mr. Lustrilanang said today that the issues are inextricable. "Any aid to the Suharto regime should be stopped because it only props up his dictatorship," he said. If aid continues, "there should be conditions: political reforms, human rights."
The I.M.F. says it cannot insist on human rights in exchange for financial assistance, but the Administration has failed so far to convince Congress to provide $18 billion in additional financing for the Fund.
In Indonesia today, Gen. Wiranto, the chief of the armed forces, proposed that the military set up a commission to study political reform. But Mr. Lustrilanang said he placed little faith in generals as instruments of change. He believes it was Indonesian soldiers who kidnapped him, held him in a jail on a military base with about 10 other political prisoners and punctuated their questions with prods from an electrified baton.
"This weakened Government has become more vicious and brutal toward voices of dissent," he said today in testimony at a Congressional hearing convened by Representative Christopher H. Smith, a New Jersey Republican. "Often, the perpetrators of those violations are publicly known. In most cases, they are members of the security forces."
Mr. Smith, chairman of the House Subcommittee on International Operations and Human Rights, criticized the Administration for providing military training to Indonesia security forces, including units accused of human rights violations.
American special-operations soldiers have conducted 41 training exercises with the Indonesia military over the past five years, including courses in psychological operations and urban combat, at a cost of more than $3.5 million, according to Pentagon officials.
"The first rule should be that the United States does not give any kind of military assistance whatever to governments that murder their own people," Mr. Smith said.
The White House spokesman. Michael D. McCurry, said today that the United States "would continue to call on the Government of Indonesia to respect the individual human rights of those who are voicing legitimate dissent."
At the hearing today, another Indonesian human rights worker testified under a pseudonym and behind a veil.
"I am an Indonesian from a middle-class background who is scared about telling you my honest opinion," she said, explaining her request for anonymity. "We are a people who are terrified of expressing our opinions and terrified of getting involved in politics of any kind.
"We are not citizens of a state. We are subjects of a modern, militarized sultanate."
In an interview before the hearing, Mr. Smith compared President Suharto to the late African dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, who amassed a personal fortune worth billions while his nation, Zaire, now Congo, went begging. And the congressman scathingly criticized the Administration and the I.M.F. for sending $1 billion to Indonesia this week.
"Suharto is the Mobutu of Asia," he said, "a dictator, and he and his family have been made filthy rich at the expense of his countrymen. He uses torture, and meanwhile the West goes begging him to take their money for stability's sake."
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today that for Indonesia, "the best protection against a political breakdown is the restoration of financial stability."
But Mr. Lustrilanang said in the interview that the Suharto Government was already breaking down, and that only the military was keeping it from falling.
"The military will have to support Suharto or support the will of the people," he said. "Maybe there will be a transition government that will conduct just and fair elections." In either case, by bullets or ballots, change would come, he said.
And, he added with a smile, his own captors had given him some hope of that change: "They asked me, 'What is the goal of your political activities?' I said, 'I want to see Suharto step down.' They said, 'Be patient. Just wait two or three years more.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Pius Lustrilanang, in Washington yesterday before his testimony. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times); Anti-Government demonstrations in Indonesia grow more volatile. Students at Jayabaya University, in the capital, battled with the riot police yesterday after demanding that President Suharto step down. (Reuters)
