HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Bridgeport Project Wins State Approval

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
The Connecticut General Assembly this week approved a $200 million plan to turn the depressed Steel Point area of Bridgeport into an entertainment and retail complex called Harbor Place.
The state funds supplement $700 million raised by the developer, the Conroy Development Company of Greenwich, Conn., which had been selected by the state and the city. 
 Alexius C. Conroy, the company president, said the 52-acre project would be bigger than the Harborplace in Baltimore. "We going to have about 1.5 million square feet of retail and entertainment," he said.
Under the plan approved late Wednesday night in the waning hours of the Legislature's session, Bridgeport would receive $120 million in special bonds, called tax incremental financing, for the project, which also includes a hotel, commercial space and a ferry operation. The bonds will be paid off though tax revenue generated by Harbor Place.
That city is expected to receive an additional $20 million in other state bond money and may borrow up to $60 million for the project, which is expected to cost about $1 billion.
Mr. Conroy said that construction on the project could start as soon as next summer; the next several months will be spent acquiring land.
Part of the land is owned by the United Illuminating Company, an electric utility, which tore down an old power plant on the site several years ago. Several small businesses and homes also exist on the peninsula, which juts into Long Island Sound.
The state money is coming from a $460 million budget surplus and is part of an emphasis by Gov. John G. Rowland to redevelop Bridgeport and the state's two other large cities, New Haven and Hartford.
 NICK RAVO

HEADLINE: Underreporting Found On Male Teen-Ager Sex

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Male teen-agers engage in risky behavior associated with H.I.V. infection more than previously thought, and they are also much more willing to report such behavior if the survey is administered by computer, rather than on paper, a new study suggests.
The research appears to call into question much of the data that has been gathered on sensitive subjects like drug use and sexual habits, and to confirm what researchers have long assumed to be under-reporting in such areas. The more socially stigmatized the behavior, the greater the disparity in the results between the two reporting methods. 
 The results of the study, to be published today in the journal Science, have significant implications both for public health and the understanding of how people relate to computers. The authors said the findings were striking and unexpected, because paper questionnaires were believed to address adequately the privacy issues that are known to inhibit honest responses in face-to-face or phone interviews.
"We had the analysis done and re-done, but this is real," said Charles F. Turner, director of the program in health and behavior measurement at the Research Triangle Institute in Washington and co-author of the study. "It means everything you thought about the risks adolescents face is an underestimate, if you're deriving your perceptions from past surveys."
Among the 1,600 male respondents ages 15 to 19 surveyed nationally, those who listened to questions on earphones and viewed them on a computer screen were almost four times as likely as the paper and pencil group to report some type of male-male sex (5.5 percent vs. 1.5 percent); 14 times as likely to report sex with an intravenous drug user (2.8 percent vs. 0.2 percent); and 5.5 times as likely to report that they were "always" or "often" drunk or high when they had heterosexual sex (10.8 percent vs. 2.2 percent).
The study, financed by the National Institutes of Health, did not test whether the teen-agers might be exaggerating in their computer-assisted responses. But the authors and other social scientists said the results were consistent with what is generally believed to be more accurate levels of the reported behavior than has shown up in previous data.
For instance, male adults interviewed at a time of their life when they would have less incentive to distort the truth typically report the same level of male-male sex activity during their adolescence as those responding by computer in the survey.
"We know people have a tendency to report more socially desirable or normative behaviors," said David S. Metzger, director of the opiate and AIDS research division at the University of Pennsylvania Center for the Studies of Addiction. "We know that for kids in their adolescence, their drug use is at such an early stage that their primary concern is keeping it hidden. I think this moves us a lot closer to the truth."
Other health researchers who have been experimenting with computer technology said the method yields similar results with different groups of respondents. For example, drug users going to syringe exchange programs in several cities were found to be significantly more forthright about their drug use when the questions were administered by a computer, said Don C. Des Jarlais, director of research at the Chemical Dependency Institute of Beth-Israel Medical Center in New York.
"This provides us with better information which should allow us to do better treatment," Dr. Des Jarlais said.
Joe Gfroerer, director of the division of population surveys at the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Association, which administers a major national health survey, said the agency planned to switch to computerized questioning by 2001.
Mr. Turner and his co-authors, Leighton Ku, Susan M. Rogers, Laura Lindberg, Joseph H. Pleck and Freya L. Sonenstein attributed the respondents' willingness to be more forthcoming on the computer to a greater perception of privacy.
The gap in the survey results remained after controlling for such variables as race and school performance. Indeed, the gap between those who reported on paper and those who gave their answers to the computer was even greater among the male teen-agers who performed well in school, leading the researchers to speculate that they had a better image to maintain, and hence more reason to hide the truth.
Experts who have studied human interactions with computers said the results were consistent with studies that have shown a decrease in inhibition when a computer mediates human communication. Sherry Turkle, a psychologist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, describes a common perception of the computer as a "safe space."
"It's a mind but it's not a mind," Dr. Turkle said. Further, she said, "We know our computers are networked, but we still experience them as a blank screen for our own self-reflection."
Although it is an expensive method, computer-administered questioning has been praised by some who have used it as helping to eliminate literacy problems among respondents who might not be able to read or write out their answers. In the study of male teen-agers, respondents heard the pre-recorded questions through headphones.
Some hailed the survey by Dr. Turner and his collaborators as a welcome effort to use digital technology to enhance the quality of the information -- even as it raises concerns about previous methodologies.
"Our understanding of the world is shaped more than any other time in history by the data," said David E. Bloom, an economics professor at Harvard University, whose commentary on Dr. Turner's study will also appear in Science. "But to the extent that the data are weak or misleading, it raises grave questions about the quality of the decisions we're making. To me this particular study is consistent with the view that the data are quite bad, especially with regard to sensitive matters, which is often what we're most interested in."

HEADLINE: SHAPING A GLOBAL GIANT: THE UNIONS;
Labor Officials See Little to Fear in a Combination

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Labor unions often cringe at mergers because such combinations frequently portend large-scale layoffs. But the giant unions representing auto workers in the United States and Germany see little to fear in Daimler-Benz A.G.'s acquisition of the Chrysler Corporation.
The reason: There is little overlap in the production of the two companies, and as a result, union officials see little prospect of consolidation and layoffs. 
 Indeed, some union leaders predicted that a combination would bring more opportunities than worries. For instance, officials with the United Automobile Workers predicted that the acquisition would open the door to the union's organizing workers at a new Mercedes plant just outside Tuscaloosa, Ala., a plant with 1,500 workers that has until now fought unionization.
And labor experts also said the deal could result in strong cross-Atlantic ties between the U.A.W. and I. G. Metall, the powerful union representing German auto workers -- perhaps creating a more formal alliance between a European union and an American one than has ever existed before.
At a news conference yesterday in Detroit, Stephen P. Yokich, president of the U.A.W, sounded anything but worried. "I don't believe it weakens us -- not at all," Mr. Yokich said. "We really don't see any layoffs and the company didn't see any when we spoke to them."
Even if the two unions have some major objections to the merger, some labor union officials acknowledged that such objections were unlikely to result in walkouts anytime soon because the two unions have pending contracts with Chrysler and Daimler.
In an interview with a German radio station, Walter Riester, vice president of I. G. Metall, which represents about 160,000 auto workers at Daimler-Benz, said his first reaction was to check whether the merger endangered production or jobs in Germany.
"To begin with, there is convincing proof that this is not the case," Mr. Riester said. "The range of products at Chrysler and Daimler and Mercedes-Benz is very, very different and both operate in different markets."
Philippe Houchois, an automobile analyst with Standard & Poor's/DRI in London, agreed. "The official line is there will not be any job losses or redundancies," he said. "It's a believable line because there is no product overlap."
An outgrowth of the Chrysler-Daimler deal could be the formation of the strongest cross-Atlantic alliance ever between two unions, several labor analysts said. Officials from the U.A.W. and I. G. Metall already compare notes and discuss strategies about coming problems, but as a result of the merger, that cooperation is expected to increase vastly.
"This merger is good for business and good for labor," said Lowell Turner, a professor of comparative labor relations at Cornell University. "It will also be a good stimulus for growing international collaboration among unions as they struggle to counterbalance the enormous power of capital in the global economy."
Several analysts predicted that the deal, by having the unions looking over each other's shoulders, could prompt the U.A.W. to begin demanding some of the goodies received by their German counterparts. "Americans haven't really paid attention that the Germans get six weeks' vacation because they see Germany as a different universe," Professor Turner said. "But when they get pulled more closely together because of a merger like this, it's likely to affect bargaining demands."
For example, Mr. Yokich said yesterday that it would be good if American unions could win the same rights that German unions have. German law gives unions half the seats on the supervisory board of many companies and requires many corporations to have works councils, which are groups of union officials who can block some of management's moves, like layoffs, but not others, such as installing new technologies.
Indeed, several labor experts suggested that since under German law, I. G. Metall has half the seats on Daimler's supervisory board that could make life easier for the United Automobile Workers in future negotiations or in future corporate decisions on plant closings. For example, if Daimler-Chrysler had a showdown with the U.A.W. over wages in American negotiations, Metall might be able to pressure Daimler, both on the supervisory board and on the factory floor, to give their American co-workers a better deal.
But Karl E. Ludvigsen, chairman of Ludvigsen Associates, an automobile consulting firm in London, said he doubted the merger would strengthen either union's hand. "After all the international mergers I've seen, none of the labor unions have really moved the need in being able to go to the headquarter country to try to get a better deal,"he said. "There's much talk among the unions trying to use their leverage across international boundaries, but they haven't succeeded."
Diane C. Swonk, an economist with the First Chicago NBD Corporation, said that as result of the merger, the United Automobile Workers would be more likely to select Chrysler as its strike target in next year's round of bargaining. The union might conclude it could get a better deal from a German-owned Chrysler, she said.
"This," she said, "makes them a target because the union will think there's a tendency that Daimler will roll over and play dead with the U.A.W. more than Chrysler would have."

HEADLINE: AT&T to Offer New Nationwide Cut-Rate Wireless Service

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Flexing its financial, technological and marketing muscle, the AT&T Corporation moved yesterday to shake up the wireless telephone industry with a new service that offers calls from almost anywhere in the United States to anywhere in the nation for flat rates of as little as 11 cents a minute.
The company also said it had short-term exclusive rights to distribute a new wireless phone by Nokia of Finland that can be left on for more than a week at a time -- much longer than most wireless phones. 
 Some elements of AT&T's new plan -- like the elimination of additional long-distance fees -- failed to break new ground in the telecommunications industry. But by eliminating special "roaming" charges for using its phones on other companies' networks, AT&T appeared to take the marketing lead in the growing field of wireless communications.
"This is exactly the sort of thing that someone in this country needed to say to make wireless a service you use rather than a service you avoid," said David Cooperstein, an analyst at Forrester Research, a technology consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "They should have done it two years ago. But now that they've done it, it's great."
The new plan seemed to be partly a response to the wave of new competitors that have come after AT&T's wireless customers since the Federal Communications Commission began new auctions of the wireless spectrum a few years ago.
AT&T is the largest provider of wireless service in the nation, with more than 8 million subscribers. But while AT&T added 195,000 users in the first quarter, Sprint PCS grew by 227,000 and Nextel Communications Inc. added 371,000.
Dan Hesse, president of AT&T's wireless unit, said in an interview that next week the company would begin putting on its first television advertisements aimed at promoting a specific wireless plan. Mr. Hesse refused to say how much AT&T would spend on the campaign but said it would also include print and radio.
AT&T may have to move quickly because it has exclusive rights to the high-end version of the new Nokia phone for only 90 days. AT&T said it would offer a new battery for the phone this summer that lasts for up to 13 days at a time.
AT&T announced three versions of the new monthly plan, ranging from 600 minutes of air time for $89.99, or 15 cents a minute, to 1,400 minutes of air time for $149.99, or 10.7 cents a minute.
By contrast, AT&T's One Rate plan for normal residential long-distance service charges 15 cents a minute.
Mr. Hesse said the wireless rates would apply 24 hours a day for calls to anywhere in the United States and from areas covering about 97 percent of the population.
Andrew Sukawaty, chief executive of Sprint PCS, a joint venture of Sprint, Tele-Communications Inc., Cox Communications and Comcast, pointed out that his company already offered a plan that eliminated additional long-distance charges. "What they're trying to play as a ground-breaking thing in the industry is window dressing," he said.
Sprint offers a plan for 1,000 minutes of air time and no additional long-distance charges for about $110, or 11 cents a minute. But so far Sprint PCS's network covers less than half of the United States population, and Sprint PCS normally charges 69 cents a minute for calls from networks owned by other companies.
Thomas J. Lee, a telecommunications analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, said AT&T's new plan was aimed not at Sprint PCS but at Nextel, which had mainly aimed at heavy callers as potential customers.
"The real loser here is Nextel," he said. "Nextel's national footprint, which they've always touted with no roaming charges, doesn't look so attactive because Nextel only offers service in half the country and AT&T is offering service almost everywhere."
But other Wall Street analysts questioned whether what was good for consumers was necessarily healthy for the company.
"It's an unnecessary price cut," said John Bensche, a wireless communications analyst at Lehman Brothers. "I think AT&T is going to leave a lot of money on the table. The first-order impact is that they lower the prices they charge their own customers."

HEADLINE: New Policy Center Seeks to Steer the Debate on Climate Change

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
With millions of dollars from a charitable foundation known for its environmentalism and with endorsements from some of the nation's biggest corporations, a former State Department official who helped negotiate the climate-change treaty is mounting a new campaign for action to head off global warming.
Eileen Claussen, who as Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for environmental affairs helped develop the climate protocol approved at an international conference last December in Kyoto, Japan, said today that she would run a policy center that would seek to lend "a credible voice" to the debate on global warming. 
 Pew Charitable Trusts gave Ms. Claussen a $5 million annual grant for the project. Already, treaty opponents financed by industry and treaty supporters from the environmental movement are spending millions of dollars each year in a debate over climate change that is sometimes fraught with exaggeration and even outright distortion of the science and economics of the issue.
"It's a big grant, it's a big bet and it's a big problem," said Rebecca Rimel, Pew's president. "There is probably no bigger issue facing the country and the globe, and the time to act is now, because the longer we procrastinate, the bigger the problem grows."
Besides the Pew financing, about half of which will be spent on advertising, Ms. Claussen won endorsements from a group of large companies with annual revenues in the hundreds of billions of dollars. Their support is meant to signal divisions within big business over the effect of climate-control measures that opponents say could wreck the economy by forcing deep cuts in the use of fossil fuels.
Next week, the new Pew Center on Climate Change will publish an advertisement festooned with the corporate logos of its supporting companies, which include the aerospace giants Boeing and Lockheed-Martin, the Japanese auto maker Toyota, the appliance manufacturers Maytag and Whirlpool, the diversified conglomerates United Technologies and 3M, and several big energy companies: British Petroleum, Sun Oil, American Electric Power, U.S. Generating Company and Enron.
The companies are not contributing financially to the new center, but they are promising to seek ways to reduce their own emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide and to invest in new, more efficient products and technologies.
The advertisement says that these companies "accept the views of most scientists that enough is known about the science and environmental impacts of climate change for us to take actions to address its consequences."
A major tenet of some industry groups fighting the Kyoto treaty is that too little scientific evidence has been accumulated to justify the treaty's call for deep reductions in emissions of gases that trap the sun's heat like in a greenhouse. Automobile and energy companies have been among the treaty's biggest opponents.
Ms. Claussen's group does not explicitly endorse the Kyoto pact, but sees it as "a first step." It has called for more work to put into effect the emissions trading schemes and participation by developing countries that the treaty's negotiators plan to work out later this year. The Clinton Administration has said there must be progress on these issues before it agrees to sign the treaty.

HEADLINE: Retail, 1990's Wallflower, Finally Dances

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
American retailers reported their best monthly sales gains in four years yesterday, capping one of the healthiest quarters of retail sales in almost a decade. Sales in retail stores open at least a year rose 10.2 percent in April, according to the Goldman Sachs Retail Composite Index.
"The numbers are so good, we can't even fit them on our spreadsheet page," said Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers. 
 Indeed, for the industry's first quarter of 1998 -- from Feb. 1 to April 30 -- same-store sales, or sales in stores open a year, rose 6.5 percent. That was far above any other quarter in the last 10 years with the exception of the first quarter of 1994, when sales rose 7.9 percent.
By some gauges, the strongest gains were in the mid-Atlantic region, and the weakest area was the Far West.
As economic indicators go, the retail industry is like the last student picked for the gym class dodge-ball team -- sulking on the sidelines, unable to demonstrate prowess. During almost all of the nation's latest economic boom, the retail segment has been left behind, churning out mediocre sales, inconsistent earnings and disappointing Christmas seasons.
Paradoxically, nearly every other piece of economic data in recent years has pointed to consumers willing to spend. Unemployment has been at its lowest in a quarter century, and inflation has remained almost nonexistent. The stock market has been buoyant and consumers have been buying new homes and autos and traveling. In the last quarter alone, the economy grew at a 4.2 percent annual rate.
Despite all this blithesome news, spending in general retail stores has mostly lagged behind, with many stores reporting same-store sales losses many months of the year. While the 1997 Christmas season was fairly good, most sales were rung up after the actual holiday.
But retailers turned a corner this spring, helped by a combination of the failure of several stores over the last two years, tighter inventory management among retail companies and shoppers who decided that it was time to restock their closets. And the turn of events bodes well for retail company earnings for the first quarter.
"If you look at 1996," said Richard N. Baum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, "retail sales were up 3 percent. In 1997, we crept up to 4 percent. But now, we are up 6 percent, year to date. People feel good about going out and spending money."
Though analysts said sales were consistent around the nation, some areas showed more strength than others.
"The New York region is up above the national average," Mr. Feiner said. "Our index showed sales up 11 percent over last, and I would say New York is about 2 percent higher than that because the upscale stores are doing fantastically well."
Telecheck Services, which monitors check writing, said that the mid-Atlantic region was the strongest, with sales measured by check writing up 4.5 percent, as against an average rise of 3.1 percent.
"The weakest region was the Far West," said William Ford, senior economic adviser to Telecheck. "Sales there only rose 2.1 percent, which could have been an El Nino effect."
Over all, all types of merchandise sold well last month, from bathing suits to house plants to patio furniture to Fendi bags, with the cheapest and the most expensive stores faring the best, as has been the trend for several quarters.
"Warm weather sent people out shopping for apparel, and things were by and large sold at full price," Mr. Feiner said. "Given trends in inflation and interest rates, we do not believe the consumer is spent out."
What retailers seem to be learning is that shoppers hit the stores when they get the urge, not because a holiday is on the horizon or because a store is having a "one day" sale. As a result, retailers have tried to keep their shelves filled with enough but not too much, and to accept that one month may be better than the last for no apparent reason.
"There is something about spring," said Perry Buroker, who lives in Bennington, Vt., and is director of annual giving in the development office at Bennington College. She and her husband just loaded up on garden items, a golf putter, sneakers, clothes and a fence for their backyard. "I'm tired of being inside," Ms. Buroker said. "We have been buying a lot of things."
What seemed a fad two years ago appears now to be a retail reality -- shoppers in all income groups are drawn to discount stores. As such, the cheapest and the fanciest ends of the mall tend to perform well together.
Wal-Mart Stores, for example, had sales gains of 13.2 percent last month, and Target Stores, a unit of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, said sales rose 10.5 percent. Value City, which sells clothing at a discount, reported a sales growth of 19 percent last month, and Dollar General, another discount store group, said sales increased 20.2 percent.
On the high end of the market, Saks Fifth Avenue said its sales rose 17.7 percent, and Neiman Marcus, a Harcourt General unit, reported gains of 10.7 percent.
"The consumer is feeling confident and coming in to spend all that hard-earned money," said Brian E. Kendrick, chief operating officer of Saks. "The baby boomer's propensity to spend is on luxury goods."
Retailers showing the best results are those that have tapped into consumer desires, such as the need for constantly changing merchandise, and have managed to stay disciplined with business issues, like inventory management.
Gap Inc., for example, had a stellar month, reporting sales gains of 29 percent, with strong numbers in all its divisions, which include Old Navy and Banana Republic.
"The absolute dollar level of our increases is pretty meaningful," said Warren R. Hashagen, the Gap's chief financial officer. "The weather was better this year, but all that does is give you an opportunity. We have much-improved merchandise. We have heightened attention to customer service. We have better in-stock. And we have increased marketing and advertising. It isn't just one thing."
Economists say general merchandise retailers are simply enjoying the fruits of a good economy the way they should have been all along. "The consumer spending data has been very strong," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "My view is that it will continue but not as strong."
All the good news does not necessarily mean that it is time to invest in retail stocks.
"All the signs showed that you were going to see blowout numbers" in sales figures, said Dan Meader, executive vice president of Tara Capital Partners, a Dallas-based hedge fund that specializes in retail. "The retail index has outperformed the S.& P. for almost a year, and today reminds us all that retailing stocks can get ahead of themselves. Many of them are fully valued. There are not too many rabbits to be pulled out of the hat."

HEADLINE: Productivity Grows at Slowest Pace Since '96

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
Worker productivity grew at the slowest pace in more than a year in the first quarter, the Labor Department reported today, reflecting a surge in hours employees spent on the job and acute shortages of job applicants.
Productivity -- a measure of the time and effort of providing goods and services -- rose at an annualized rate of two-tenths of a percent. Analysts had expected a rise of six-tenths of a percent. In the fourth quarter, productivity rose at a revised annualized rate of 1.4 percent, down from the initial estimate of 1.6 percent. 
 The productivity data are closely followed because growth in productivity has helped suppress inflation in the growing economy. If productivity slowed for a prolonged period, economists said, that would cause concern at the Federal Reserve. There has been increased speculation in recent days that Fed policy makers may raise interest rates at their meeting on May 19 to head off inflation.
The increase in productivity was the weakest since the third quarter of 1996, when worker output per hour declined at an annualized rate of seven-tenths of a percent. For all of last year, productivity grew 1.7 percent; in 1996, the increase was 1.9 percent.
In further evidence of a tight labor market, the Labor Department reported today that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits unexpectedly declined by 11,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 308,000. On Friday, the Government is expected to report the economy added 264,000 jobs in April after a loss of 36,000 jobs in March led by the construction industry. Many economists expect that the unemployment rate dropped back to a quarter-century low of 4.6 percent, from 4.7 percent in March.
In other signs the economy could grow faster than the Fed would prefer, the Commerce Department said wholesale inventories and sales both increased in March.
But Fed data on consumer borrowing for March showed the weakest increase in four months, a sign that people are not borrowing excessively for their purchases. Borrowing rose by $1 billion for the month, far less than the expectations of $4.1 billion.
Borrowing rose $1 billion, to $1.242 trillion, after rising a revised $6.1 trillion during February. Previously, the Fed said borrowing increased $7 billion in February. Before today's report, analysts had expected an increase of $4.1 billion for March.
Wall Street analysts watch the Fed's consumer-credit statistics because they help them gauge consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Created Its Own Problems, Justice Dept. Says

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
In a strongly worded court brief filed today, the Justice Department argued that the Microsoft Corporation had known for months that its legal problems with the Government might delay the release of its Windows 98 operating system, due to be released next week. But Microsoft deliberately waited until the last minute to ask a court for protection, Government lawyers charged, so the company could make "a self-generated claim of hardship."
In other words, the Government argued, Microsoft is complaining about a problem of its own making. 
 Windows 98 is scheduled to be shipped to manufacturers next week and is supposed to be available in retail stores on June 25.
On Wednesday, Microsoft asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia to stay parts of a preliminary injunction that could be used by the Government to block the release of Windows 98. The injunction bars Microsoft from forcing manufacturers to install the company's World Wide Web browser, Internet Explorer, as a condition of licensing its current operating system, Windows 95.
In Windows 98, Internet Explorer is even more closely integrated into the operating system, making it more difficult for manufacturers to ship computers without Microsoft's browser -- and thus more difficult for Microsoft to comply with the injunction if the court applies it to the new operating system.
Microsoft argued this evening that the Justice Department's argument had "no legal basis."
"We've been working with the Justice Department for six weeks, trying to reach a mutual resolution to this problem," a spokesman, Mark Murray, said. "When it became clear early this week that Justice was not willing to reach a mutual resolution, we immediately sought resolution from the appeals court."
In its court brief, Microsoft argued that the Justice Department never raised the issue of Windows 98 in filings to the court before today and so has no standing to do so now.
With today's filing, the Justice Department attached a partial transcript of a deposition in which Paul Meritz, the Microsoft vice president in charge of the Windows group, acknowledged that the company had recognized this problem months ago.
"Yeah, we did think about it" in December or January, he said. "But our decision has to be to go ahead and, given the nature of the Windows 98 product, to deliver that product."
The dueling court briefs are only one part of a growing legal and public relations battle that has grown in recent weeks to involve computer industry executives and two United States Senators as both the Justice Department and a group of state attorneys general rush to decide whether to file a broad new antitrust suit against Microsoft in time to block the release of Windows 98.
Microsoft has been pressing a multifaceted campaign to block any new suit. On Wednesday evening, William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, spent two hours trying to persuade Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of antitrust issues, that Microsoft had both a right and a responsibility to incorporate new products in its operating system.
Both Microsoft and Justice Department officials said the meeting had done little to narrow the disagreements between the two sides.
Earlier that same day in New York, Mr. Gates presided at a Microsoft-sponsored "rally" featuring testimonials by 50 or so leaders of businesses in or related to the computer industry about the importance of a timely release of Windows 98.
But the event seemed to steel the opposition of some government officials.
Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, one of 13 states preparing to sue Microsoft, said he and the other Attorneys General "have an obligation to see through the rhetoric" and "the well-orchestrated lobbying and public relations campaign."
The Massachusetts Attorney General, Scott Harshbarger, another member of the group, added, "Self-serving spin will not deter antitrust enforcers from protecting consumers who want more economic choices in a competitive marketplace."
And Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee, suggested that many of the business leaders who appeared with Mr. Gates in New York had been coerced.
"I have been told that some of these executives in fact hope to see the Justice Department pursue a further case against Microsoft but have chosen to join Mr. Gates on the stage today because they feel that they have little choice but do so in order not to jeopardize their relationship with the industry's most powerful and important player," Senator Hatch said in a statement issued on Wednesday. He made the same argument in a letter to Mr. Gates.
Microsoft wrote back, disputing Mr. Hatch's assertions, and adding that it "would not refuse to help other companies in the personal computer industry in opposing Government action that they also regard as misguided."
Senator Slade Gorton, a Washington Republican and a staunch defender of Microsoft, stepped into the debate. In an angry letter to his fellow Republican, Senator Gorton told Senator Hatch that he was "astounded by your letter to Microsoft" and suggested that Mr. Hatch did not fully understand the issues.
In response, Mr. Hatch prepared a six-page explanation of his views. Senator Gorton then delivered a statement on the Senate floor denouncing Mr. Hatch and his tactics. That, in turn, unleashed a new round of letters and statements.
And with the Justice Department's decision about a new antitrust suit against Microsoft still a few days away, both Senators' offices said they thought the angry rhetoric was likely to escalate.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Using Grit and Glitz to Bring Aid to Schools

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
SHE'S relentless," the author James McBride said yesterday about Lisa Belzberg, the woman who installed him as principal for the day at Public School 118 in Queens, and who was eight months pregnant when she asked him to do it. "We had lunch at some tony restaurant near her office, and a lot of these East Side fat cats were coming up, shaking her hand, saying, 'Hi Lisa.' I thought it was interesting that these really arrogant folks would bow to a pregnant woman. And I just assumed that she had a very powerful personality, and that there was no point in resisting. And she was also really nice to my son."
Lisa Belzberg is the president of Public Education Needs Civic Involvement in Learning, or Pencil, the group that runs Principal for a Day, the highly regarded and often criticized program that puts role models in New York City public schools for one day each year. The idea came from Ramon C. Cortines, the former Schools Chancellor, but four years ago Ms. Belzberg stopped producing the "Charlie Rose Show," offered to take over the program, and then made it her own. Yesterday she had principals in almost all of New York City's 1,100 public schools. 
 As usual, a lot of the principals were rich or famous, like the actress Stephanie Seymour, the lawyer Joseph H. Flom and the designer Norma Kamali. As usual, Ms. Belzberg defended the program, saying that it was not intended to make people who have a lot of money feel good about themselves because they spent a few hours in the public schools.
"We have a certain glitz," she said. "Obviously, it gets us the publicity we want. But we don't put money people in and ask for checks at the end of the day. We ask for involvement." She ticked off some success stories: New York publishers now give 1.3 million books to the schools each year. VH1 television has donated $1 million worth of musical instruments. And Ms. Kamali created a student-run T-shirt company.
Last year, Ms. Belzberg was in agony when she watched Donald J. Trump offer sneakers to students at Public School 70 in the Bronx, prompting an astute 11-year-old to ask why Mr. Trump was handing out shoes when he could afford scholarships. This year, Mr. Trump was not in the program.
"Did he follow through on his sneakers?" Ms. Belzberg said. "He did. Did he do much else? No."
Ms. Belzberg, 35, is a direct and personable insomniac who grew up in one of Canada's financial dynasties, then married into another one. Her father is Samuel Belzberg, the corporate raider whose runs at American companies in the 1980's sometimes blew up in spectacular losses. Her husband is Matthew Bronfman, 38, of the Seagram family.
Ms. Belzberg was eight and a half months pregnant with their second child when she married him last December, after his divorce in June. They live in a century-old town house just off Fifth Avenue. There is a Picasso in the living room, a Matisse in the bedroom and white-uniformed servants on all six floors.
DO you want to take the elevator or the stairs?" Ms. Belzberg asked Wednesday morning. The spiral staircase looked fine. On the way up was Tess, Ms. Belzberg's infant daughter, and in the library were waiting bowls of fruit. A servant brought scrambled eggs with smoked salmon. "I'm sensitive about seeming like a rich dilettante," Ms. Belzberg said, gesturing with some humor to the surrounding splendors. "Can't imagine why."
Ms. Belzberg graduated from Barnard College, has a master's degree from the London School of Economics, and once worked for the political consultant David Garth ("I was his slave"). Although she seems at ease with the way she lives, she pointed out yesterday that her money is really her father's and her husband's.
"It's not mine, is it?" she said, sitting on the steps outside P.S. 118 in the Hollis section of Queens. "It's just not mine. You never feel like you have done it for yourself." Someday, she said, "I'd like to make enough money myself never to have to ask anybody for money. Wouldn't that be great?"
Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew offered Ms. Belzberg a job, but Ms. Belzberg turned him down, saying she liked the freedom of running Pencil from outside, especially since she has small children. (Her other daughter is 2.)
Will she send her own children to public schools? "I'm an Orthodox Jew," she said simply, saying she keeps kosher and observes the Sabbath with her husband, who was raised in what she calls a "traditional" Jewish home. "My kids will go to Jewish schools."
Ms. Belzberg's husband has never worked for Seagram -- he creates small companies -- but is an heir to the fortune and has been reading the articles describing his brother, Edgar Bronfman Jr., as being over his head with his investments in Hollywood. "Look, he's taking a big hit," Ms. Belzberg said of her brother-in-law. "I think he's obviously really smart. We really believe in his leadership. I don't understand Hollywood. When people say, 'Don't you think that was a stupid decision?' I say, 'I have absolutely no idea.' "
Yesterday, Mr. McBride, the author of "The Color of Water," spent part of his day at P.S. 118 -- his alma mater -- playing the saxophone for students. "This might mean nothing," he said, "or it might make a difference in a kid's life." With Ms. Belzberg, he said, "it wasn't something I was going to get out of doing."

HEADLINE: Critics Fear Role of Politics in CUNY Plan

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
As the battle lines formed Wednesday over the fate of remedial education at the City University of New York, it was becoming increasingly clear that the larger issues at stake were CUNY's tradition of open access and political control at a college system that has educated generations of New Yorkers.
This week, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, long critical of CUNY for admitting too many students unprepared for college work, agreed on a plan to bar such students from the 11 four-year colleges. They are pressing their trustees, most of whom they appointed, to adopt their policy later this month, arguing that it will restore the quality and reputation of the university. 
 Yesterday, on CUNY's campuses and off, the actions by the Governor and Mayor generated alarm.
Many said the limits would exclude students who most need education -- the poor and immigrants from Asia, Latin America and Eastern Europe -- from an institution that has historically served as a path into the middle class.
"This is the destruction of CUNY as it has been and what it hopes to be," said Julius C. C. Edelstein, a former senior vice chancellor at the City University who helped develop its open admissions policy in the late 1960's. "For all of its shortcomings, City University is the social engine of the city, and the attempt to convert it into Swarthmore or Harvard is ridiculous and is not what people of New York need."
Equally fervent was reaction to the unusually direct intervention by the state and city's top political figures in university admissions -- usually a province of the governing board of trustees. Trustees said they were told the plan itself was drafted not by the board or the administration but by aides to the Mayor and Governor.
"Whether I agree or disagree about the particular issue of remediation, I am concerned about the whole issue of governance," said Ann Marcus, dean of the School of Education at New York University. "The idea that you get that kind of policy making from the board and from policy makers undermines the idea of the university. I don't know how you run a university like that."
But as higher education has become more politicized, CUNY and other public universities, especially California's, have become key to fundamental political debates.
"What we have is a pendulum that began to change direction with the call for national education standards, and now it's hitting the colleges," said Saul Cohen, a member of the New York State Board of Regents and a former president of Queens College at CUNY. "California has been on the front edge, and we have CUNY."
Bradford J. Race Jr., chief of staff to Governor Pataki, says that the involvement is not only appropriate but necessary.
"A significant amount of taxpayer resources go to the university," he said. "It is certainly appropriate that systemwide policies be decided after appropriate consultation with the Mayor and the Governor and other elected officials, including legislators. This is all about the quality of education CUNY is providing, and there is enough objective evidence we've seen in terms of graduation rates that suggest that the system is failing at least a significant number of students."
The involvement of Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani in a fundamental shift in university standards, while unusual, does have precedents at CUNY, said Henrik N. Dullea, vice president for university relations at Cornell University who served as assistant secretary for education and art under Gov. Hugh L. Carey.
In 1970, CUNY decided to adopt its open admissions policy, which, responding to minority demands, guaranteed a spot in the university system to any New York City high school graduate. And again in 1976, during New York City's budget crisis, when the state agreed to pick up most of the city's share of paying for CUNY's four-year colleges, political leaders intervened.
"That kind of involvement is unusual, in that it is not a day-to-day occurrence," Mr. Dullea said. "But when very large issues of structure arise, they were involved."
Despite such assurances, many faculty and students and others feel that CUNY's mission to take in students who have earned a high school degree or its equivalent is being attacked by political officials who are less concerned about education than about cutting spending and privatizing some of the functions of the university.
"It's scary; it's frightening," said Arthur Levine, president of Columbia Teachers College. "This is a political solution; it does not make sense educationally. This could do grave damage to students who are working their way through high school now. Some of them won't have the skill levels they say will be necessary to get into CUNY's colleges.
"The fact is that we need to do something about remedial education, which is expanding all over the country. But this is not the way to do it. The only people it holds accountable are the students."
Some students yesterday said the plan being offered by the Mayor and Governor singled CUNY students out unfairly because many of them are poor or members of minority groups.
"There are remedial courses in private colleges as well, but we're under attack because we're public," said Gisseeleen He, a 26-year-old architecture major at City College and a Manhattan resident. "This is very much about economic status."
Whether the Mayor and the Governor will manage to marshal enough of their trustees to vote for the plan at the end of May remains to be seen. Their appointees constitute the majority of the 17-member board. But some of them are known to oppose their plans. But Herman Badillo, a vice chairman of the board who introduced their plan, said, "I think we have the votes."
By Mr. Badillo's count, which is similar to that of some other trustees, the Mayor is likely to hold at least four of his five appointees, and the Governor is likely to carry four votes for certain and probably more. Nine votes are needed for passage.
In the meantime, many faculty, students, city and state legislators and others are looking for ways to try to fight the proposals.
Last night, the Committee for Public Higher Education, an umbrella group of about 50 city organizations, assembled for the first time in more than five years, to plot strategy. In an invitation letter signed by five organizers, including Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian and a longtime CUNY professor, the group said, "If we are to continue to educate the children of 'the whole people,' we must create a groundswell of support for CUNY."

HEADLINE: Democrats Fault Pataki on Education and the Economy

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Speaking almost in unison, four of the Democratic candidates seeking to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki assailed his economic and education policies last night, belittling his first-term tax cuts as a waste of money and attacking him for vetoing spending that would have gone to rebuilding public schools.
In a debate televised statewide from Rochester, the Democratic candidates disputed Mr. Pataki's upbeat depiction of the state he has led for three years, portraying New York instead as plagued by high unemployment and failing schools, and being run by a Republican unconcerned with those problems. 
 "Today in New York, there is no economic plan," James L. Larocca, a former State Transportation Commissioner, said in remarks that neatly summed up the Democratic case. "There is no plans to make plans. The Governor does not have an economic development strategy."
Richard A. Kahan, a former chairman of the State Urban Development Corporation, said Mr. Pataki had spent his first three years "trying to cut taxes -- but the wrong ones, the ones that don't help the people who need them, the small businesses."
Mr. Larocca and Mr. Kahan, along with Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross and District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn, appeared for an hour at the first major event of what has so far been a strikingly low-profile Democratic gubernatorial contest. The forum, in which the candidates responded to questions from a panel of citizens and reporters, was broadcast across the state.
It included all but one of the Democrats seeking to challenge Mr. Pataki: Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the New York City Council. Mr. Vallone's aides said he had skipped the event because he had a previous commitment to preside over a New York City budget hearing in Queens.
As is typical in early debates, the candidates avoided any effort to distinguish themselves from one another. Other than Mr. Hynes, who repeatedly attacked what he described as Mr. Pataki's lax ethics and work habits, the candidates turned their attacks only on Mr. Pataki's policies.
All four candidates said they disagreed with Mr. Pataki's push to cut the personal income tax, describing it as a waste of money that could have otherwise gone to education or programs that might promote economic development in the state. "I think it's the worst tax that we could have cut -- and it's gotten the least results," Mr. Kahan said.
Ms. McCaughey Ross said the tax-cut program had done nothing to help the state's economy. "Ask any of the New Yorkers who have been laid off whether the reduction in the personal income tax worked," she said. Mr. Hynes described it as "another example of the hypocrisy that marks the Pataki administration."
Mr. Hynes said: "You just filed your state income tax. I'm sure you didn't see any great reduction, because you're not one of the top 10 percent in this state."
Similarly, the candidates said that Mr. Pataki had wasted money by giving tax breaks to large corporations without insuring that the companies expand their state operations in the state.
"The only economic development strategy this government has had is to give tax breaks to the wealthiest New Yorkers and the biggest companies," Mr. Larocca said. He advocated legislation that would force companies that had received tax breaks to repay the state if they reneged on a pledge to create jobs.
All four candidates urged a variety of additional spending on schools, day care and job training. Mr. Hynes, for example, called for more spending on remedial education, while Ms. McCaughey Ross again advocated universal pre-kindergarten programs as a way of insuring better classroom performance in later years. When it came to financing the spending, Mr. Kahan urged taking the money from the state's huge prison budget.
"We have 60,000 drug abusers in prison," Mr. Kahan said. If we put our efforts into reducing the prison population and we would save billions of dollars."
The candidates also attacked Mr. Pataki for vetoing $500 million in school construction, as part of $1.6 billion in vetoes of legislative spending he announced last week.

HEADLINE: Slight Increase in Rents Proposed

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
In a hearing marked by little of the chaos and ear-splitting acrimony of years past, the Rent Guidelines Board recommended last night that landlords in New York City be able to charge slightly more for rent-stabilized apartments and lofts beginning in October.
If the recommendation is approved by the board in a final vote next month, tenants in the city's 900,000 rent stabilized apartments who renew their leases for one year will be charged 2 percent more and those who renew for two years will be charged 4 percent more. A $1,000 rent, for example, would increase to $1,020 under a one-year lease, meaning that the tenant would pay $240 more for the year. 
 The proposed increases are identical to those adopted by the board last year and come amid similar economic circumstances for owners: an annual survey released recently by the rent board found that the average cost of maintaining apartment buildings rose by only a tenth of a percent over the last year, thanks mostly to a drop in fuel oil prices.
Landlords generally applauded the proposal. But they also contended that the survey always underestimates the cost of running the city's aging buildings.
"It is, of course, a political decision. It doesn't do the job or make anyone really happy, but it doesn't make the bulk of the electorate unhappy."said Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, a trade association of 2,500 building owners.
The 30 or so tenants who attended the meeting hissed softly when the proposal was approved by a vote of 6 to 2. "At a time when their own numbers show that landlords' costs are not going up, why give them an increase?" asked Michael McKee, policy director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition.

HEADLINE: Stock Exchange On Wall Street Offered a Home In New Jersey

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

 BODY:
The New York Stock Exchange said last night that it had abandoned plans to expand its historic headquarters in lower Manhattan and that it had received an offer from New Jersey officials to build a $1 billion trading floor for the exchange in Jersey City.
Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the exchange, said remaining on Wall Street, where it has been since the Civil War, appeared to be "no longer viable" and that his first choice now would be a previously announced proposal to relocate to Battery Park City. 
 But he said that four New Jersey economic development officials met with him on Tuesday and "very energetically and enthusiastically put on the table" a set of initiatives that could prove "very economically rewarding."
"Our goal is to relocate in Manhattan," Mr. Grasso said. "At the same time, it is very important to recognize that we are a global business, and we have to position ourselves to capitalize on the growth that lies ahead."
Pete McDonough, chief spokesman for Governor Christine Todd Whitman, declined to comment on whether New Jersey was offering the stock exchange tax breaks and other incentives.
"It is our policy not to confirm or deny whether we are in negotiations with any business," Mr. McDonough said.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani dismissed the exchange's announcement as a negotiating ploy, saying that he had an ironclad guarantee from Mr. Grasso that the exchange would stay in the city.
"The New York Stock Exchange will remain the New York Stock Exchange," Mr. Giuliani said on his monthly call-in program on WCBS-AM. "It will not be the New Jersey Stock Exchange. Everybody has negotiating positions and everything else. But I can remember the day that Richard Grasso sat in my office, shook my hand and said, 'We will never, ever move out of New York.' "
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Gov. George E. Pataki, would not comment beyond saying, "It is the New York Stock Exchange and we are confident that it will continue to be the New York Stock Exchange."
Senior Whitman administration officials emphasized that New Jersey had not broken a no-poaching agreement reached with Mr. Giuliani in 1994 to help end the economic border war between the states.
Shortly after she was first elected, Governor Whitman pledged that New Jersey would not seek New York companies to move to New Jersey, and New York promised that it would not approach New Jersey companies to move to New York.
But Mrs. Whitman has repeatedly said that New Jersey would negotiate with chief executives from New York companies who contacted her administration about moving to the state. That seems to be the case with another New York institution, the New York Yankees, which Mrs. Whitman said she had not pursued; but she said she was willing to talk to the team about moving to New Jersey.
Stocks have been traded in lower Manhattan since 1792, when brokers and merchants agreed to trade securities on commission. With the bulls running and its quarters cramped, the exchange has demanded tax breaks and other incentives to help it expand. The possibility of a move to Battery Park City, disclosed by exchange officials last month, was a first step in ratcheting up the pressure.
Last night, Mr. Grasso said, "The first two words of our name are 'New York,' and the Mayor has been terrific."
He said the exchange wanted to build a pair of 50,000-square-foot trading floors. He said the plans for Battery Park City called for a complex of 1.2 million to 1.3 million square feet at a cost "north of $1 billion."
He said the plans for expanding across from the current headquarters involved a nine-story trading complex, including the two trading floors, at a cost of $700 million to $900 million. "That seems to be no longer viable," he said. The reasons he cited were the difficulty in acquiring the sites and opposition from neighborhood and preservationist groups.
Mr. Grasso said the New Jersey officials did not make a detailed offer, but they said the state would in essence finance construction of a similar complex in Jersey City.
The various financial markets may be as synonymous with New York as the theaters of Broadway, but their threats to decamp have kept Mr. Giuliani's aides busy ever since he took office in 1994. That year, the New York Mercantile Exchange flirted with a move to Jersey City, but was granted $184 million in subsidies to build in Battery Park City.
In 1995, city and state officials persuaded the board of the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange to cancel plans to move to New Jersey. At that time, remarks by the Mayor indicated that windfalls were to be had by exchanges that demanded them.
"It's important for New York City, within the balance of the things that we can negotiate, to retain these exchanges," he said.

Auto Giants Detail Deal, But Challenges Remain
Officials of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler made their $39 billion wedding official. They plan to form a global auto giant making luxury Mercedes-Benz cars as well as Cherokee Jeeps and Voyager mini-vans.
 
 But as executives of both companies shared their visions of a global automotive powerhouse, a range of challenges and uncertainties ahead became clear, both for the merged company and the rest of the automotive industry. Page A1.
 
Employees of Chrysler were stunned by news of the acquisition and expressed some fear for their jobs. But they also were upbeat about the prospects for the combined company. D5.

How to Define Best of All Markets

HEADLINE: In Free Markets, Just Who Is Free?;
The Other Unemployed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The assertion that the Phillips curve does not explain current economic conditions (Week in Review, May 3) begs the question of why the model once meshed with the data and now fails. What changed is that unemployment figures no longer measure the unused labor supply. Downsized workers doing temporary jobs are tallied as "employed." Fifty-somethings face coerced retirement. Able workers idled too long by hiring biases like age are not counted as employable. Politicians insist these cases are anecdotal and non-quantifiable. Then they take credit for the low unemployment figures.
 
W.J. GOEBEL
Madison, Wis., May 4, 1998

HEADLINE: In Free Markets, Just Who Is Free?;
Fed's Outdated Model

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In your May 2 Business Day article on the markets, an economist states the common belief that a slowing of the economy is needed to dissuade the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates. The Federal Reserve has fostered the belief that our economy is driven by a demand-led business expansion with potential for an inflation upsurge. In reality, we are in an unprecedented technological revolution that is producing price stability and sustained rapid economic growth. 
 The Federal Reserve needs to construct an up-to-date model of the economy to test its policy concerns without throwing the real economy off track.
 
LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., May 2, 1998
 
The writer, an economist, was assistant vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
