SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3899 words

HEADLINE: SHAPING A GLOBAL GIANT: THE MULTINATIONALS;
Some Cross-Border Deals May Be Star-Crossed

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
They seem so smart and easy.
Certainly the acquisition by Daimler-Benz A.G. of the Chrysler Corporation makes cross-border mergers appear that way. But for all the excitement about that deal, such mergers -- in which a company in one country acquires a company in another -- never come without headaches, often big enough to swamp the benefits. 
 Even when the purchaser is welcomed with open arms, success is elusive. Last December, Merrill Lynch acquired 50 branch offices in Japan of Yamaichi Securities, which had failed, and the 2,000 brokers in those offices cheered their rescue from unemployment. But Merrill today is deep into the difficult process of retraining the brokers to American standards. That means, among other things, that when a favored client loses money, the broker can no longer give company funds to the client to cover the loss -- a not uncommon Japanese practice.
"It has only recently become acceptable to grow globally through acquisitions," said Stephen Blum, a partner at KPMG Peat Marwick, which acts as a consultant in many such deals. "Until two or three years ago, cross-border mergers were thought of as too risky."
Such deals completed last year totaled $320.5 billion, or more than double their value of $132.3 billion in 1994, according to the Security Data Company. United Nations data suggest that cross-border mergers have become the biggest single method of integrating the world's economies. Economists warn, however, that international investment data are too imprecise to draw firm conclusions.
The United States is one of the few countries that do have precise data. The Commerce Department reports that for 1995, the latest year available, foreign acquisitions of American companies represented $47.2 billion of the nearly $75 billion invested by foreign companies in plants and equipment here.
Still, given their druthers, corporations everywhere in the world seem to prefer mergers with companies of their own nationality, and within their own borders. Such mergers completed last year came to nearly $1 trillion, Security Data reported.
Nothing seems to draw companies into cross-border deals more than the prospect of gaining a big foothold, overnight, in another market. Departing from its usual practice of opening stores one at a time in countries like Argentina, Brazil and China, Wal-Mart last year acquired a 21-store supermarket chain in Germany from Wertkauf G.m.b.H. The chain has $1.4 billion in annual sales.
The Wertkauf stores, offering merchandise as well as food, are similar to Wal-Mart's format, but acclimating the company's 4,900 employees to Wal-Mart's ways could take more than a year, said Dale Ingram, a Wal-Mart spokesman.
"We are about to open those stores at 7 A.M. instead of 9, and see how the customers, and the employees, respond," Mr. Ingram said. Closing time, by law, is 8 P.M.
The Bridgestone Corporation of Japan sought to jump-start tire sales in the United States with the purchase of Firestone in 1988. But what the new owner got, said Richard Thomas, a community relations manager for Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., were old factories with outdated equipment and employees who would not accept a 12-hour-a-day schedule, spread over three or four days a week, that it considered essential.
"Each day we were losing money, and the changes came slowly," Mr. Thomas said. Only after years of losses did Bridgestone/Firestone finally win acceptance of that work schedule and begin to make a profit in the United States. In the interim, the company and its workers had to endure a two-year strike that at one point prompted President Clinton to publicly rebuke Bridgestone/Firestone's Japanese managers.
"You take the good with the bad and work your way through it," Mr. Thomas said. "There is no alternative in most cross-border mergers."
Personality clashes can play big roles in such mergers, sometimes even killing them. That stopped a deal that would have created the world's largest pharmaceutical company, through a combination of Britain's SmithKline Beecham and the American Home Products Corporation, based in Madison, N.J. The talks collapsed in February, after Jan Leschly, 57, SmithKline's chief executive, insisted on becoming chairman of the merged company, a job that John R. Stafford, 60, American's chairman, also wanted.
Sweden's Volvo and France's Renault had planned to merge in 1993, creating a giant auto and truck manufacturing company, but frictions killed that deal, too -- friction between top management and among directors and investors.
Differing national views of how to run a business did in what would have been the biggest trans-Atlantic merger in history prior to this week's agreement between Daimler-Benz and Chrysler.
In that doomed deal, British Telecom planned to acquire MCI Communications for $24 billion. MCI welcomed the merger. But the deal, announced in 1996, fell apart in 1997 over differing concepts of risk. British Telecom's shareholders objected to MCI's announcement that its incursion into local telephone service would result in an unplanned loss of hundreds of millions of dollars.
That reaction surprised Bert C. Roberts Jr., MCI's chairman. Whatever their qualms, American shareholders cannot deter MCI management "from a major strategic direction," he said, adding, "That's unheard of."
Other mergers, logically conceived, go through, only to fall on hard times. Hoping to sell more television sets in the United States by acquiring a popular brand name, LG Electronics Inc. of South Korea purchased a majority stake in Zenith in 1995, even though Zenith was unprofitable. The South Koreans expressed the hope that their low-cost manufacturing practices would turn Zenith around. But last month Zenith, still unprofitable, said it might seek bankruptcy protection soon.
Breaking into the American entertainment industry seemed essential to Matsushita Electric Industrial and Sony when those two Japanese giants purchased MCA and Columbia Pictures, respectively, in the late 1980's.
Both sought entertainment "software" to run on their VCR's and other electronic hardware.
But both went on to have a terrible time trying to fathom Hollywood management practices. Matsushita finally gave up, selling MCA in 1995 to the Seagram Company. After losing billions of dollars, Sony appears to have solved its management problem.
And then there is the more common form of culture shock, the kind that can bring an abrupt halt to a traditional way of doing business.
That happened at Brooks Brothers, the upscale men's haberdashery chain, after it was acquired in the late 1980's by Britain's Marks & Spencer, a high-volume mass-market operation. Once-elegant stores soon shrank in size and became more crowded. And buying a suit increasingly meant receiving the coat or pants by mail order, and then returning to the store for alterations.
Perhaps that would have happened at Brooks even without the cross-border merger, said Jay Meltzer, director of Johnson Redbook Service, a retail operation.
"Many old-timers want service and a little ambiance when they shop," he said, "and modern retailers can't afford to do that."
Republicans are skeptical of this tone of apoliticism. They think Rubin uses it as a dodge for playing highly political games. Many are still nursing sores from the end of 1995 when he crushed their attempt to coerce Clinton to sign their budget by threatening default on the national debt. Rubin portrayed himself as appalled by this gambit, describing the threat that America would fail to meet its obligations as "unthinkable," and eventually winning an abject surrender.
In fact, Rubin is canny about politics. It is factored into his expected-value calculations as it has been since he was evaluating antitrust threats to mergers. He treats politics as a consideration in policy-making, but not as an overriding one. As friends note, he is truly chagrined when political considerations overwhelm sound decisions. One recent example was Rubin's objection to sweeping reform of the Internal Revenue Service, on which he eventually had to yield ground. Another, on which he has not yet surrendered, is his obstinate stance against a tax cut cast as an end to the "marriage penalty." Rubin even feels this way even about politics in other countries. Talking to him about Japan, you sense his dismay that the country's leaders are unwilling to take the risks necessary to reverse their country's economic decline -- the sorts of risks he thinks the Clinton Administration took with its economic strategy and then with Mexico.
By the time the Asian crisis hit last year, Rubin had already been thinking about potential problems in the region for some time. He raised concerns about the "frothiness" in Asian markets as early as April 1997. Capital was pouring in and he wondered whether foreign investors were discounting the "risk premium." But no one, Rubin included, was prepared for the consequences when Thailand, as Tim Geithner puts it, "fell of the cliff."
This time, Rubin had less discretion. After Mexico, Senator Alfonse D'Amato added an amendment to an appropriations bill that put conditions on Treasury's lending money without Congressional approval. Rubin could have gone to Congress. But he and Summers and Greenspan discussed it at one of their weekly breakfasts and agreed that it wasn't a good idea to commit American capital. While the danger of an Asian contagion was real, there was a risk of accentuating the "moral hazard," by saving investors from the consequences of their choices.
Rubin's response to any international crisis begins from a kind of Treasury Department corollary of the Powell Doctrine: If the U.S. cannot act decisively, we should not put our resources and credibility on the line. As Summers puts it, Rubin's consistent approach to the crisis has been "that there is something worse than Country X going down, which is Country X going down and taking our credibility and $10 billion of our money with it."
Those around Rubin point admiringly to the way he arrives at such a decision. He begins by gathering all the information he can, toting reams of reports and articles around in a pair of giveaway vinyl briefcases he picked up at a Finance Ministers' meeting in Japan a few years ago. He often reaches down several levels in the bureaucracy to find the person most knowledgeable about the problem at hand, which Treasury officials say his predecessor, Lloyd Bentsen, never did. Being nonhierarchical is something Rubin learned at Goldman, where senior partners trust junior ones to manage their money. He loves to ask questions and embodies the adage, which he sometimes repeats, that you learn more from listening than from talking.
"What so many people have a tendency to do is to lock into a scenario," Summers says. "What Rubin will say, at times to the frustration of others, is that some questions don't have answers -- which is to say that just because a problem is terrible, we don't have to act. It may not be the right time."
When an I.M.F. support program failed to take hold in Thailand, the upside
value of involvement and the risks of not intervening increased. In September, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines began to suffer currency and market declines. Rubin and his team worried that markets for U.S. exports would turn into cut-rate exporters of goods to the U.S., harming the economy and setting back the consensus in favor of free trade. They also feared a contagion beyond Asia. "You had Brazil close enough to the edge that they could have gone, and that would have created a greater risk that Mexico and Argentina would have gone," Geithner says. "And Russia, and everybody else."
Why if Indonesia catches a cold, do Brazil and Russia start sneezing? For one thing, there are financial relationships among emerging markets. Korean and Brazilian banks own Russian Treasury bonds, and in October began to unload them to raise cash. But the larger danger is psychological. Capital that rushes in can rush out just as quickly, a phenomenon Rubin remembers well from his days at Goldman, when the flows were a fraction of what they are today. Panic is a self-fulfilling prophecy, because capital flight fuels the insolvency it fears. Once the dominoes start falling, the only way to stop them is to change the psychology.
The seriousness of the problem was brought home in a series of meetings held in the office of White House Chief of Staff Erskine Bowles in October. Among those in attendance were the Secretaries of State and Defense. Concerns about South Korea were acute. If Korea failed, officials feared a spread to Brazil, one of the countries that held Korean debt, and a linchpin of the South American economy. Ultimately, they were worried about the potential for "a 1930's scenario" -- a worldwide depression accompanied by massive political instability. A consensus emerged that the U.S. could not stand by as disaster developed.
Ordinarily, the Departments of Treasury and State would fight to control policy at such a moment. But in part because Rubin, unlike many of his predecessors, does not aspire to be Secretary of State, State is not threatened by his encroachments on foreign policy. Another diplomatic advantage Rubin has brought to the situation is his unprecedented cordiality with the Fed chairman. Previous Administrations have tried to "jawbone" the Fed, nudging it to act or not act on interest rates; Rubin, though, has laid down the law from the first days in the Administration: no trifling with the Fed. This has muted the traditional rivalry between the Fed and Treasury bureaucracies.
Greenspan and Rubin and their deputies were all involved in hammering out the basic approach to the Asia crisis. It was developed on a flight to Hong Kong for the World Bank's annual meeting in September. By the time the plane landed, there was a strategy: the U.S. should lead the rescue, through the I.M.F. where possible, by providing conditional support. This approach, which was presented to Asian officials at a subsequent meeting in the Philippines, became known as "the Manila framework."
But the surveillance program put in place in Manila was a mixed blessing. In exchange for I.M.F. aid, the Koreans had to divulge information about their foreign-currency reserves. By mid-November, it was clear Korea was at risk of default. Treasury officials spent the days before Thanksgiving formulating a new financing package. The discussions continued through Thanksgiving Day in a marathon conference call composed of officials from Treasury, State and the N.S.C. (Around 6 in the evening, Rubin, Geithner, Summers and the others on the call decided to take a break and spend an hour with their families.)
The plan they eventually formulated was to support $57 billion in loans from the I.M.F., conditioned on the closure of insolvent banks and the shutting down of bankrupt chaebols, Korea's vertically integrated conglomerates. As Rubin recalled two months later on a flight to London, his view was that delay was crucial. "Buying time in these situations is very important, he said. Even if the effort in one or more of these countries was unsuccessful, if you could buy enough time, you greatly increase the likelihood that creditors and investors will distinguish among countries, and you greatly reduce the likelihood of contagion."
Near midnight on Thanksgiving night, Rubin, at his weekend house in Pound Ridge, N.Y., was on the phone with Clinton at Camp David, prepping him for calls to be put through to President Kim Young Sam in Seoul and Hashimoto in Tokyo. There was a delay in the call to Hashimoto, and Clinton was working a crossword puzzle, and asking Rubin for clues. Rubin, who does not do puzzles, passed a question to his son Jamie. "Who's so dumb they don't know that one?" Jamie asked.
"Actually," said Rubin, "it's the President."
The Thanksgiving fix didn't take. In the middle of a campaign, the Government of Kim Young Sam was unable to inspire confidence in its reforms. On the evening of Dec. 18, the day of the Korean election, Rubin convened a small dinner at the Jefferson. Foreign currency reserves in South Korea's banks were down to $9 billion, with a "drain rate" of $1 billion a day. In other words, the country would be in default by the end of the year. And for Korea to fail could be cataclysmic. Unlike Thailand and Malaysia, whose currencies had melted down months before, Korea had a vast economy in its own right -- the 11th-largest in the world, and 5th-largest among America's trading partners. "It was very, very dark," recalls Summers. "Money was pouring out of Korea. What could we do?"
There appeared to be only two choices, neither promising. The first was to let Korea fail and "try to save the rest of the world," as one of those who was at the three-hour dinner puts it. The other was to speed up loan payments from the I.M.F. and make available the so-called second line of defense -- $10 billion from the U.S. and other countries erected under the Manila framework as a final firebreak.
Summers and David Lipton, the Under Secretary of Treasury for international affairs, made the case for deploying the second line of defense. Geithner was the skeptic of the group, arguing for using I.M.F. money first and not committing American capital until there was more confidence it would improve the odds of success. Summers, whose intellect often has a cutting edge, ridiculed this incremental escalation as the "Vietnam" option. The debate was interrupted by the near-constant ringing of cell phones, and calls to the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, who was at the White House working out the wording for Clinton's congratulatory call to the new South Korean President, Kim Dae Jung.
When Rubin finally spoke, he emphasized the limits of America's influence. He wasn't persuaded that sending more money would be a decisive enough step to restore the confidence of international creditors and investors, who had poured capital into Korea as if it were a fixed fight, and were now fleeing as if it had become radioactive. At the end of the dinner, after one of his regular measured indulgences -- four scoops of cassis sorbet -- Rubin postponed the decision.
In this instance, his preference for optionality made the difference. In a conference call two days later, Summers, Geithner and Edwin Truman, a Fed official who works closely with them, came up with a third, more daring plan. The U.S. could try to "lever" the forbearance of the banks that held the bulk of the Korean debt. If international creditors would agree to extend their loans, U.S. officials would arrange to move forward the I.M.F. money, and make available a portion of their second line of defense if needed.
Discussion of this scheme continued as Under Secretary Lipton was dispatched to Seoul to impress the new President, Kim, with the need for financial reform and as Rubin left for a vacation in Virgin Gorda, in the British Virgin Islands, where he goes bonefishing. It was shaping up as another ruined holiday. "I brought my rods, but I didn't get to go fishing at all," he says. Instead he spent his vacation on the phone.
The situation was immensely delicate because Treasury officials felt they could not be in the position of forcing private banks to change the terms of market loans they had made. "It had to be voluntary," Rubin says. "Because if it was involuntary, then the fear was that they would all say, Well, we're doing this here, we've got to pull back from every other place, and you could set off the very contagion you were afraid of." Three days of back-to-back international conference calls culminated in a four-hour conversation with William J. McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The plan was for McDonough to talk to the main American creditors while his central-bank counterparts in London, Frankfurt, Tokyo and Paris held synchronized conversations with bankers in their countries.
The orchestration had to be perfect, and it was. Banks in all five countries agreed to reschedule their Korean debt in the hope of eventually getting repaid in full. President Kim responded positively to the stringent conditions attached to American help, telling Lipton he intended to press ahead with reform, even if it meant layoffs and social unrest. The announcement of the second Korean rescue plan on Christmas Eve
created a pivot in the crisis. By New Year's Day, the Korean stock market and the won had stabilized. Other emerging markets calmed as well. And for the next six months at least, the worst fears about a panic overtaking the world economy subsided.
The situation eased enough that in January, Rubin paused to consider the crisis as a whole. At a speech at Georgetown he tried to assess it. "Foreign investors injected an extraordinary amount of capital into these flawed systems without due weighting of the risks involved," he said. In other words, investors hadn't included a risk premium in their analysis. "I would not give one nickel to help any creditor or investor," he continued, bubbling with contempt for such sloppy thinking. "Unfortunately, there was no way to restore growth and stability without sheltering some investors."
It is possible that the I.M.F. alone could have kept Korea from default. Or that Korea would have defaulted, but not spread contagion. Or that the panic might have spread, but been perversely beneficial to the U.S. -- slowing G.D.P. growth a few tenths of a percentage point and further calming inflation fears, and easing the economy into another "soft landing." Whatever its negative effects, a Korean default would certainly have cured the "moral hazard" problem Rubin discussed -- that by bailing out investors, you encourage them to pour hot money into new speculative bubbles.
In other words, there is no way of knowing if the fact that the Asian economic crisis has not yet ended the long boom in the United States is the result of the Treasury Secretary's extraordinary skill, or sheer luck. If the crisis subsides, Rubin may yet have a chance to try to expand programs like Head Start and Pell grants, and advance the cause of some new ones he has in mind, like individual investment accounts -- I.R.A.'s for poor people. But Rubin understands better than anyone that despite his best efforts, what began with a devaluation in Thailand may yet bring the boom to an unceremonious close.
"We're dealing with issues now the world has never dealt with before," he says. "We're dealing with a multiple of countries in trouble at the same time, where the investors and creditors are not just a limited number of banks, but a vast array of individuals and institutions. That combination has never existed, so by definition you're dealing with much more difficult judgments, and much less clarity as to the probabilities of things.
"Luck or skill?" he muses. "We'll never know." On this note, conversation drifts back to Gus Levy and the banter he and Rubin used to swap on the Goldman trading floor. "Gus used to say that it's better to be lucky than to be smart," Rubin says. "And I used to say to Gus, it seemed indispensable to be lucky, but it wasn't so bad to be smart either, if you could arrange both."

An article in Business Day on May 8 about the difficulties involved in border-crossing mergers referred incorrectly to the relationship between Merrill Lynch & Company and Yamaichi Securities of Japan. HEADLINE: Of the Turmoil In Indonesia And Its Roots

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
When jetloads of pinstriped Western bankers descended on Indonesia last year to demand that President Suharto salvage his battered economy by shutting down the business monopolies held by his children, one of America's most influential anthropologists was not surprised that he balked.
Prof. Clifford Geertz said that in the tradition-laden culture of the central Indonesian island of Java -- home to more than half the population of that vast archipelago nation, and President Suharto's birthplace -- parents dote on their children in ways that other societies would consider indulgent, even excessive. 
 "Javanese children are spoiled," said Mr. Geertz of the Institute for Advanced Study, whose books include "The Social History of an Indonesian Town" and "The Religion of Java." "In Java, there is a tremendous amount of protection from the father. If he doesn't do that, then he would be no good as a father."
Of course, excessive fatherly love is not the sole reason for Mr. Suharto's refusal to break up a multibillion-dollar business empire controlled by his six rapacious children. The President, who has ruled Indonesia with an iron fist for more than 30 years and has been accused of using murder and torture to quash dissent, has never responded well to international criticism.
Yet while bankers, economists and diplomats have spent much of the last year trying to make sense of Indonesia's turmoil, scrutinizing everything from its financial institutions to its byzantine political structure, many have failed to look closely at the often misunderstood culture of Indonesia in trying to find a way to resolve the crisis peacefully.
An Indonesian specialist who is considered by many of his peers to be the leading anthropologist of his generation, Mr. Geertz said he worried that the International Monetary Fund and the other Western institutions were so misreading Javanese culture that they could turn a desperate situation in that nation of 210 million people into a dangerous one.
The collapse of the Indonesian currency, which has lost more than two-thirds of its value over the last year, and the corresponding rise in the price of basic commodities like rice and cooking oil have set off street riots in Jakarta and on dozens of colleges campuses.
Several people were killed in clashes with the Government's security forces this week and thousands were injured in rioting yesterday. Many of the demonstrators have demanded the ouster of Mr. Suharto, who has no history of tolerating dissent and is thought ready to use even more violence to stem the protests.
"I think they don't understand," Mr. Geertz said of those in the I.M.F.. "I don't think that someone who has been trained as a financial whiz can go to Indonesia and immediately grasp the situation. I've worked on it for years, and I wouldn't claim to grasp the situation."
Mr. Geertz said that when Mr. Suharto rebuffed the International Monetary Fund last year and refused to close down many of his children's business operations -- they control everything from toll roads to communications satellites -- he was able to draw on centuries of Javanese tradition. Even if that threatened the collapse of an economy that had once been his proudest achievement.
From the windows of his spacious office at the institute, Mr. Geertz (rhymes with "hurts") stares out over an especially leafy corner of the institute's campus -- a grove of sun-dappled trees sways in a gentle spring breeze -- and insists that he can only guess at the extent of the chaos half a world away on the muggy streets of Jakarta, the steamy, smog-shrouded Indonesian capital.
But from what this 71-year-old anthropologist has read and seen from a distance about Indonesia's economic collapse and the reaction of the public to the turmoil, it all seems very familiar, and very Javanese.
"It's not a matter of everybody in Java is exactly the same or that they all have some sort of Javanism in them that essentially determines what they do," he said, seated with his back to a collection of toothy Javanese tribal masks gathered on his travels. "But the way things are going on in that country, at least from afar, it does not seem unfamiliar to me." Mr. Geertz began his career in the 1950's with field studies on village life in Java.
His first bit of advice to Western bankers and economists is one often given to first-time visitors to Indonesia: avoid confrontation with the Javanese, who are trained from infancy to avoid direct personal encounters that might force a display of anger or other emotion, even within their own families.
Among the Javanese, it is unimaginable rudeness to point out another's mistakes. The language reinforces this heightened sense of civility, with elders and leaders addressed in a "higher," more formal style of Javanese.
"There is this pattern of politeness," he said. "The whole thing is to dampen your feelings, to remain detached and calm and quiet. The Javanese usually don't express emotion.
"I've lived in both Indonesia and Morocco, and the difference is that if a Moroccan doesn't like you, you know it in about two minutes. In Indonesia, it would take two years for you to figure that the guy you've been living next to hates you and has hated you since the first day he saw you. And you may never know."
So when the I.M.F. and the Clinton Administration dispatched high-ranking delegations of bankers and economists to demand that Mr. Suharto comply with terms of the Western rescue plan, Mr. Geertz says, they created the impression among Indonesians that the West was eager to humiliate the only national leader most Indonesians have ever known.
The image was captured most starkly at a news conference in Jakarta in January, when television cameras whirled as Michel Camdessus, the managing director of the I.M.F., stood sternly over Mr. Suharto with his arms folded as the Indonesian leader signed an interim rescue agreement.
The image of the fund's appearing to dictate the bailout terms to Mr. Suharto shocked many Indonesians and brought a political backlash against the fund, emboldening the Government to ignore many of the conditions placed on the $43 billion aid program.
If the I.M.F. had been more subtle in its dealings with the Indonesian leader, "they might have gotten what they wanted from the start," Mr. Geertz said, adding: "But I guess you don't expect that from economists."
Mr. Geertz said that in the midst of the worst crisis of his rule, Mr. Suharto was playing a difficult hand reasonably well: "It's unwise to underestimate the man."
Mr. Suharto's strategy in dealing with the economic crisis has become increasingly clear, and alarming to his friends in the West. For decades, he accepted the counsel of American-trained economists who urged him to open his markets and rely on low-technology industries like garment-making. "He did everything they wanted him to," Mr. Geertz said. But now, Mr. Suharto has decided to abandon much of their counsel.
He has instead adopted the rhetoric of fierce nationalism and has appointed a new vice president who is anathema to most Western economists because of his unconventional and occasionally bizarre economic theories. He has placed his eldest daughter in the Cabinet as minister of social welfare and has not dampened speculation that he intends to create a Suharto dynasty by naming her his successor.
"Suharto is suddenly a radical nationalist," Mr. Geertz said. "I think radical nationalism is a deep strain in Javanese lives, and he's trying to tap it."
Mr. Geertz said he was struck by the comparisons that could now be made between Mr. Suharto and his charismatic predecessor, President Sukarno, whose fiery nationalistic oratory helped win Indonesia its independence in 1949 and kept him in power for almost 15 years, even if his economic mismanagement almost bankrupted the country.
"It's eerie," the anthropologist said. "It's like a re-enactment. This really looks like the last days of Sukarno, if not the very last, somewhere near the end."
Mr. Geertz is careful to insist that he does not predict that Indonesia will experience the sort of violence that swept the nation when Mr. Suharto came to power in 1965, "the year of living dangerously," in the words of Mr. Sukarno, when more than half a million people were killed in an anti-Communist pogrom.
But he said he did see troubling similarities between the chaos of the mid-1960's and that of today. And if there is violence, it could come without warning, given the seeming opaqueness of the Javanese. "With the Javanese, you don't see the violence coming until it happens," Mr. Geertz said. "Once this politeness and deference and controlled demeanor collapse, then all hell breaks loose."

HEADLINE: U.N. Lifts Travel Ban on Iraqis Without Objection From U.S.

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 8

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration offered no objections in the Security Council today when a travel ban on Iraqi officials was ended, but the United States and Russia are still at an impasse over when and how to respond to a report last month that in effect declared Iraq free of nuclear weapons.
The travel ban had never actually been imposed, and American officials said the step was not significant. But the Administration fought hard and long last fall to win Security Council backing for the measure, which would have restricted international travel for top Iraqis responsible for a lack of cooperation with the arms inspectors of the United Nations Special Commission. 
 Only after Iraq blocked investigations entirely by ordering American inspectors out of the country was the United States able, in November, to get the ban approved, at least in principle. But a list of those to whom it would apply was apparently never drawn up. Then the crisis over arms inspections this year intervened.
Next week the Security Council is expected to debate the larger issue of how to respond to the nuclear report, submitted by the International Atomic Energy Agency. Russia has argued that Iraq should be moved immediately to a system of more routine long-term monitoring from the current regular and often more intrusive inspections and destruction of prohibited equipment. The United States wants to put off any change in Iraq's status until October, when the next major sanctions review takes place.
Iraqis have begun to criticize Russia and France for not being more successful at starting the process of easing sanctions now that cooperation with inspectors has improved. Iraq owes Russia billions of dollars, which Moscow would like to recoup from the proceeds of resumed Iraqi oil sales.
European and Asian diplomats describe the Americans as absolutely inflexible on the issue of the nuclear report. Some envoys fear that without at least small rewards, Iraq will revert to obstructive behavior.
Today's automatic lifting of the travel ban followed a letter to the Council from Richard Butler, executive chairman of the Special Commission. Sergey Lavrov, the Russian representative, had requested a report on recent Iraqi compliance from Mr. Butler.
Mr. Butler said in his letter that Iraq had been providing full access to his inspectors since Feb. 23, when Secretary General Kofi Annan signed an agreement with the Iraqi leadership, and that Baghdad was entitled to a rescinding of the threat of travel restrictions.
Iraq remains under a total economic embargo until Mr. Butler has declared it free of biological and chemical weapons and long-range missile systems.
An American group of more than 90 people arrived in Iraq from Jordan and Syria on Thursday to protest American backing of the sanctions by delivering about $4 million in medical aid to Baghdad. The delegation is led by Ramsey Clark, a former Attorney General in the Johnson Administration, and Thomas J. Gumbleton, a retired Roman Catholic bishop from Detroit.
The Americans, calling themselves the Iraq Sanctions Challenge, said in a statement on Tuesday before leaving New York that "the U.S.-U.N. sanctions are a violation of international law."
"Their intent is the destruction of the a whole population," said the statement. Advocates of the protest say the American-backed sanctions have killed 1.5 million Iraqis since the Persian Gulf war in 1991.
An article in the current Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists questions this and other figures, including some from the United Nations, which are considered by a number of experts to be too high and too reliant on information provided by Baghdad. The authors of the article, George A. Lopez and David Cortright, say "estimates of more than a million deaths are almost certainly exaggerated."
"The numbers are still horrifying, though -- perhaps in the range of 200,000 deaths of all ages," they wrote. "This is an appalling tragedy."

HEADLINE: Get Tough With Japan (Phase 2)

BYLINE: By Daniel K. Tarullo; Daniel K. Tarullo, senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations, recently resigned as assistant to the President for international economic policy.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan was armed with charts and graphs when he visited the White House last year. He intended to rebut American fears that an increase in Japan's consumption tax, loaded onto an already fragile economy, would crush any chance for growth.
The unusual step of handing out economic analyses in such a meeting symbolized the denial and delay that have dug the Japanese economy into a deep hole. 
 Just last month, Mr. Hashimoto finally offered a package of temporary tax cuts and public spending to stimulate the economy, and he has begun a campaign at home and abroad to sell the program. But these belated stimulus measures alone will not produce sustained growth. Japan's problems are much more complex. Absent permanent financial reform and deregulation of its domestic markets, Japan will remain a drag on Asia and the world economy.
That point should be impressed on Japan at the annual meeting of leaders of the Group of Seven industrialized nations next weekend in Birmingham, England.
Having participated in these summit meetings over the past several years, I worry that the generally collegial atmosphere will tempt officials of the United States and other countries to give their embattled Japanese counterparts a pat on the back for the stimulus package, without pushing hard enough for further action.
This would be a mistake. The Japanese public is not satisfied. Japanese markets are not satisfied. Japan's economic partners should not be satisfied either.
Given how much Japan has to lose from inaction, outside prompting should be unnecessary. After all, growth has been negligible for much of the 1990's. Unemployment is at a 40-year high. And Japan's downturn has hurt other Asian countries, which depend on Japan to import their products and invest in their economies. As a result, Japan has ceded some regional prestige to China, which by maintaining the value of its currency helped stabilize the Asian crisis.
Unfortunately, Japan is hemmed in by its own politics. When he first came to power in 1996 Mr. Hashimoto tried to break the old mold of a weak prime minister caught in party politics and overpowered by government bureaucracy. But he has lost momentum and is boxed in by the old system.
Other countries cannot be expected to stand by as their own interests are endangered. After all, in the 1980's, Japan, Germany and other nations readily criticized the United States for the risks its large budget deficits posed to the global economy. Uncomfortable as foreign criticism may be for the Japanese, it is essential to press them not only to stimulate their economy, but also to clean up their shaky financial system and to truly deregulate their economy.
The United States has been warning Japan for a year and a half of the risks it poses to the world economy. Asian and European countries have joined the chorus. Yet Japan has taken only the first step toward righting itself.
Patience has its virtues, but so too does firmness, particularly with a country that, unlike its Asian neighbors, has the resources to solve its own problems. Now is not the time to stand down.

HEADLINE: Rome Journal;
Agony Lingers, 20 Years After the Moro Killing

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, May 8

 BODY:
On May 9, 1978, the bullet-riddled body of a former Prime Minister, Aldo Moro, was found in the trunk of a car in central Rome, 55 days after he was kidnapped by members of the Red Brigades. Twenty years later, the anniversary is being marked with an orgy of national brooding.
"It has been 20 years, and still the deeper truth has not come out," said Marco Baliani, 47, an actor-playwright whose one-man show about the Moro case is to be shown live on Italy's second largest state network on Saturday night. "How can we found a new republic if we cannot tell the truth to ourselves?" 
 Like the Kennedy assassination in the United States, the killing of so powerful a political figure remains an obsession for Italians, who view it both as a national trauma that marked the end of innocence for an entire postwar generation, and as a dark conspiracy that remains veiled.
After hundreds of books, a parliamentary investigation that has dragged on for 10 years, five completed trials and a sixth that is about to begin, Italians are so bitterly consumed with the missing pieces that even on the 20th anniversary they overlook a larger irony that was unimaginable only five years ago.
Giulio Andreotti, 79, the wily, powerful politician who was Prime Minister seven times, including the period of the Moro crisis, is currently on trial in Perugia on charges that he conspired to order the killing of a journalist investigating, among other things, an alleged cover-up of the Moro case. Mr. Andreotti's refusal to negotiate with his colleague's captors is one of the more examined mysteries in the case.
All of the 23 Red Brigades terrorists who were convicted of collusion in Moro's slaying, and that of his five bodyguards, have either completed their sentences, or are in lenient home-arrest or work-release programs. Mario Moretti, 52, the most senior Red Brigades leader, who admits he was the one to shoot Moro, commutes four days a week from his Milan prison cell to a computer programming job that pays $850 a month.
And Italian society, so torn in the hate-filled 1970's that the Andreotti Government imposed special laws to combat terrorism and social unrest, is now serenely united on at least one point: The full story behind the crime has not yet been told.
The only prominent dissenters are Mr. Andreotti and his closest aides, some former Red Brigades terrorists who still resist the notion that they were unwittingly manipulated by sinister right-wing forces, and an American scholar, Richard Drake, who wrote a 1995 book that concluded that there was no conspiracy. Mr. Drake's book was widely disparaged in Italy.
The morning of his abduction on March 16, Aldo Moro, the leader of the Christian Democratic Party, was on his way to Parliament to usher in the first Italian Government to be actively supported by the Communist Party -- the so-called historic compromise that he had arranged.
Mr. Andreotti refused to make concessions to the terrorists to save Moro. The Italian police and secret services were unable to rescue him, and their stunning display of incompetence was quickly interpreted as deliberate. To this day, most Italians believe that Moro died because the powers-that-were had reasons not to keep him alive.
"On this anniversary I live the need to in some way understand what really happened," said Alberto Franceschini, 50, who, as one of the founders of the Red Brigades, should know. Arrested in 1974, he got out of prison in 1992 and now works at a foundation that distributes European grants to Italian unemployment programs.
Mr. Franceschini said that his comrades had definitely killed Moro, but that they might not have acted alone.
"I don't know whose hands were behind the scenes, Andreotti's or Nixon's," he said. "But I know we were part of a much larger game."
As shown in its fascination with the killings at the Vatican this week, Italy has always been deeply attached to conspiracy theories. For the last 55 days, Italian radio, television, newspapers and magazines have overflowed with interviews, documentaries and debates about the Moro case. News footage of Moro's body in the car trunk has been replayed over and over like the Zapruder film of Dallas.
At least a dozen books about the Moro case and its mysteries have been published this month. It is not quite "Boogie Nights" nostalgia; young people throughout Europe in the 1970's were more preoccupied with dissent than disco. Rather, it is one generation's morbid fascination with its own tumultuous history.
And one reason for the media storm is that the generation of baby boomers who two decades ago wore Palestinian scarves, threw firebombs and at least for a while sided with the Red Brigades are now middle-aged network executives and publishers who shape public opinion.
"I didn't want to do another journalistic chronicle of the case," Mr. Baliani explained. "I wanted to tell the story thorough my own personal experience -- and that of so many people like me."
A counterculture actor at the time, he begins his tale by describing his feelings of "euphoria" over the news of Moro's kidnapping, and traces the bitter disenchantment and horror he felt at his death.
His televised tribute to the case on Saturday is viewed as so momentous that for the first time, the Italian Ministry of Culture permitted filming in one of Rome's most ancient ruins, the Forum of Augustus. The setting was irresistible.
"We wanted to make the connection to classical tragedy," Mr. Baliani said. "The death of Moro is the classic drama of our age -- tragic, yet squalid."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Actor-writer Marco Baliani, who is broadcasting a theater piece on the Moro case on television tonight, says "the deeper truth" of the case has still not come out. (Claudio Martinez for The New York Times); Below, the body of the former Prime Minister, discovered on May 9, 1978, in a car parked on a downtown Rome street. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Market Gains on Jobs Data In Spite of a Mixed Outlook

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market rose yesterday, but market analysts were uncertain about what data in the April employment report touched off the rally.
The new jobs data may have comforted investors by allaying fears of an imminent interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve. Or the report may have touched off a rally only because there were not too many unpleasant surprises and the market had, after all, fallen sharply in the previous three days. 
 The steady growth reflected in the jobs report could normally be positive for stocks because growth translates into sales and profits. But Fed policy makers have indicated recently that they are leaning toward a rate increase unless the economy slows enough to dampen their concerns about inflation.
Unfortunately, several analysts said, the jobs data did not provide clear answers about the outlook for growth and inflation and, therefore, the outlook for Fed policy.
The surprising decline in the unemployment rate, to 4.3 percent, must be adding to Fed worries about rising wage pressures. And the increase of 262,000 in new jobs, while matching Wall Street forecasts, is not yet indicating that the economy is slowing to a pace that would ease the central bank's inflation fear.
At the same time, the job numbers showed the third consecutive monthly decline in manufacturing jobs, which some analysts took as a sign that the economic turmoil in Asia was beginning to have an effect as American exports decline. Some 16,000 manufacturing jobs have been lost since January, ending a string of rapid growth since September.
"The data continue to make life hard," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. He is forecasting an economic slowdown that will be enough to keep the Fed from raising interest rates. The manufacturing data, falling exports and the huge increase last quarter in company inventories make him think the drag from Asia is coming.
At the same time, he has been confounded by a much stronger than expected run-up in consumer spending, which has kept the economy moving ahead briskly into the second quarter.
Robert V. DiClemente, the chief United States economist with Salomon Smith Barney, is also noting the manufacturing slowdown and said that "we are not at the flash point yet" of a Fed rate increase. Fed policy makers next meet on May 19.
But he is worried that the strength of consumer spending may persist, which would be enough to force the Fed to act later in the year. And he is watching the rise in hourly earnings, which were up 4.4 percent for the year through April, and the recent slowdown in earnings. The fall in earnings can indicate that wage increases are eating into profits rather then reflecting increased productivity. This would worry the Fed.
"Since price inflation has been minimal and domestic profit margins firm, productivity appears to have accelerated sufficiently last year to damp increases in unit labor costs," Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said in January. "How long that pattern can continue is still an unresolved issue."
The bond market did help stocks yesterday by holding relatively steady for most of the day in the face of the surprisingly steep drop in the unemployment rate. The other important figures, the number of jobs added to payrolls and a 4-cent increase in hourly earnings, were in line with expectations.
"The fact that the bond did not blow through 6 percent helped," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore.
But bond prices dipped in the afternoon, which appeared to set off some stock selling. The price of the 30-year bond fell 10/32, to 10 23/32, as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.97 percent from 5.95 percent. A week ago, the yield was at 5.93 percent.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up as much as 119 points, finished at 9,055.15, up 78.47 points, or almost nine-tenths of 1 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index did better than the Dow, rising 13 points, or 1.2 percent, to 1,108.14. It was as high as 1,111.42. The Nasdaq index did even better, jumping 1.6 percent, or 29.23 points, to 1,864.37.
Drug, computer system and health care stocks drove the S.& P. 500 higher. The Dow was led by I.B.M., up 2 7/8, to 120; Merck & Company, up 2 7/8, to 117 7/8, and American Express, up 21/16, to 101 11/16. The Nasdaq moved higher on a sharp rebound by Microsoft, up 2 3/8, to 85 3/4, although the Justice Department indicated again yesterday that it might file an antitrust suit that could halt the distribution of Windows 98.

HEADLINE: Some on Wall St. See Buffett's Hand in Bond Sales

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Is Warren E. Buffett selling part or all of his huge position in zero-coupon Treasury bonds? That is the question bond traders across Wall Street are asking, as huge sell orders pour in on the same long-term Treasury issues that Mr. Buffett owns.
It is Mr. Buffett's policy not to comment on any trades he may be making. And one trader reports that Mr. Buffett's people say they are not selling any of the roughly $20 billion in zero-coupon bonds purchased last year by Berkshire Hathaway Inc., Mr. Buffett's investment company. But such a response would be typical for any large investor interested in keeping his strategies under wrap. 
 Zero-coupon bonds are obligations of the United States Treasury that pay no interest but are bought at a deep discount to their value at maturity, or so-called face value. The bonds inch up in price as they get closer to maturity. But their prices also move much more rapidly than interest-bearing bonds when interest rates change.
Bond traders are speculating that Mr. Buffett may be selling because of the size of the trades and the particular issues involved. In the last couple of weeks, some $5 billion face value of the 2020 and 2021 maturities that Mr. Buffett owns have been sold, an enormous amount to be concentrated in just a couple of issues.
In an attempt to keep the trades quiet, perhaps, bond traders say the sell orders are going to only one Wall Street firm, Credit Suisse First Boston. Spreading the trades to firms up and down the Street would draw attention.
If Mr. Buffett is getting out of bonds, he is not alone. Bond traders have seen waves of selling in recent days as pension funds, insurance companies and money managers fret about a possible rate increase by the Federal Reserve Board.
David Greenlaw, an economist at Morgan Stanley, said that although the Fed is holding steady at the moment, the longer-run picture looks bearish for bonds.
Yesterday's report of a historically low unemployment rate in April and Thursday's report on productivity and unit labor costs both indicate that wage pressures are building in the United States.
Employment costs are an inflation signal that Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, watches closely.
In the first quarter productivity rose only two-tenths of 1 percent, versus 1.4 percent in the last quarter of 1997. Unit labor costs rose 3.8 percent.
Mr. Buffett certainly has enormous profits in his zero-coupon trade.
Since the beginning of the year, long-term bonds have risen in price around 50 basis points, or one-half of one percentage point.
If Mr. Buffett has sold one-quarter of his position in the last three weeks, as one bond trader suspects, then his profits for the last few months could exceed $100 million. Not a bad trade for a man who until recently was famously bond averse.

HEADLINE: U.S. Dispatches Its Balkans Mediator With a Warning to the Serbs

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Fearful that fighting along Yugoslavia's southern border is about to erupt into a full-scale war, the Clinton Administration has sent the architect of the Bosnian peace agreement to warn President Slobodan Milosevic of the consequences of the recent violence.
Administration officials said that the American Balkans mediator, Richard C. Holbrooke, and President Clinton's special representative to the Balkans, Robert S. Gelbard, will travel to Belgrade this weekend. They will press Mr. Milosevic to end the fighting in Kosovo, the southern province of Serbia, which along with Montenegro forms what remains of Yugoslavia. 
 "Holbrooke and Gelbard will go in with a stiff warning that the United States regards the situation in Kosovo as dangerous not just to Yugoslavia but to all of its neighbors," said an Administration official involved in American policy in the Balkans who insisted on anonymity. "If Milosevic wants to end Yugoslavia's isolation, he'd better be listening."
It is not clear whether any warning to Belgrade will be enough to prevent the situation in Kosovo from spinning out of control and drawing Albania and other nations in the region into the fighting.
In recent weeks President Milosevic has sent troops and paramilitary forces into Kosovo to put down protests by the province's ethnic Albanian majority, which is seeking greater autonomy -- if not independence -- from the Serb-dominated Government of Yugoslavia. Scores of ethnic Albanians have been killed in the clashes, which have raged along Kosovo's southern border with Albania.
Administration officials said the decision to send Mr. Holbrooke, a former Assistant Secretary of State for European Affairs and the central negotiator of the 1995 Dayton agreement that ended the civil war in Bosnia, was meant to suggest to Mr. Milosevic that the situation is dire.
"Nobody delivers a threat like Holbrooke, and I mean that as a compliment," a State Department official said.
Last week the United States and five of its allies imposed new economic sanctions on Yugoslavia to protest against its handling of the crisis in Kosovo, and they threatened further action if the Yugoslavs did not agree to negotiate with the province's ethnic Albanian leaders.

Charges Lifted for 14 Bosnian Serbs
 THE HAGUE, May 8 (Reuters) -- The United Nations war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia said today that it had withdrawn charges against 14 Bosnian Serbs.
It said the charges stemmed from offenses at the Serb-run Keraterm and Omarska prison camps in northwestern Bosnia. The chief prosecutor, Louise Arbour of Canada, said the tribunal acted in order to focus its efforts on more senior officials and those responsible for exceptionally brutal offenses.

HEADLINE: Credit Suisse First Boston Settles Suit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 8

 BODY:
Credit Suisse First Boston agreed today to pay $52.5 million to Orange County, becoming the first securities company to settle litigation stemming from the California county's 1994 bankruptcy.
The settlement could serve as a model for other firms to settle as well, although one lawyer said today that he did not believe there were any other substantive settlement talks under way. 
 In a settlement announced last month, the law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Greene & MacRae, which served as the county's bond counsel, agreed to pay $45 million to the county and an additional $10.2 million to a county community college district.
Orange County, which is just south of Los Angeles, sued nearly 20 securities firms, plus the LeBoeuf law firm, its accounting firm and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit-rating agency, seeking more than $2 billion in damages. The county contended that they were responsible for risky investments that resulted in losses of more than $1.6 billion, leading to the largest municipal bankruptcy in the nation's history.
The main target of the litigation is Merrill Lynch & Company, which was most heavily involved with the county's finances. Credit Suisse First Boston sold only about 4 percent of the securities that led to the county's losses. But the firm played a prominent role in other types of transactions.
Jim Mercer, a lawyer for the county, called today's agreement "a significant settlement from a defendant that's not one of our primary defendants." Mr. Mercer, who is with the Los Angeles law firm of Hennigan, Mercer & Bennett, added, "Up until now, there has been a united front" among the brokerage firms.
Jan Mittermeier, the chief executive of Orange County, said she was pleased with the settlement. "It's good to see those who are culpable admitting their responsibility," she said in a statement. "This is a positive indicator for future litigation results."
Credit Suisse First Boston did not admit responsibility but rather maintained today that it acted "professionally and responsibly" in its relations with Orange County. "But, given the magnitude of the county's losses and the fact that litigation is unpredictable and distracting for any firm, this settlement is the right course of action," Allen Wheat, chief executive, said in a statement. "This chapter is now closed."
Credit Suisse First Boston, which is owned by the Credit Suisse Group of Switzerland, was also the first company sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with the Orange County bankruptcy. In January, the company and two former employees agreed to pay $870,000 to settle Federal charges that the company had not properly informed investors of the risks associated with a county bond offering it underwrote.
Credit Suisse First Boston might seem an unusual choice for a settlement because the lawsuit against it was toward the back of the queue and so far from a court date that it was virtually dormant. But the county approached the company a few weeks ago, apparently because the two had had discussions in the past that indicated Credit Suisse First Boston might be amenable to a settlement, according to attorneys. The company decided to settle to remove its potential exposure to huge amounts of damages. The settlement is subject to court review.
But if today's agreement serves as a benchmark for other settlements, it could mean the county would go a long way toward collecting its $2 billion in damages.
The trial against the main defendant, Merrill Lynch, is scheduled to start on Sept. 15. In a separate legal proceeding, Merrill agreed last year to pay the county $30 million to stave off possible criminal charges. The company has also acknowledged it is being investigated by the S.E.C.
The money collected by the Orange County Litigation Fund, which now totals $126.5 million, will be distributed to school districts and other government entities that contributed to Orange County's investment pool, which made the risky investments.
Orange County's treasurer and assistant treasurer of that time were sentenced to prison terms. The county, which emerged from bankruptcy in 1996, has not yet recouped its losses from the failed investments. But the area is thriving economically, with very low unemployment and a growing high-technology industry.

HEADLINE: Making Battery Park A Place to Linger

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
It is a fort that never saw battle, an immigrant way station that came and went before Ellis Island, and New York City's most heavily trafficked park, given over almost entirely to visitors from out of town.
Once known simply as the Battery, it is ground zero in New York history: the city began there. But nearly four centuries later, it is known to most residents only as the place to stand in line for ferryboats to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island. 
 Now, in a tenacious effort to restore Battery Park as a monument and public space used as something besides a congested transfer point, a private group is trying to renovate and redesign the 23 acres of greenery, statuary and wind-swept harbor vistas at the southern tip of Manhattan.
The project, to be announced today by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, would provide the next installment in a series of major initiatives to create and improve parks along Manhattan's Hudson River shoreline, from the Battery to 72d Street. The renovation is being planned a year after Battery Park City, the park's neighbor to the north, completed a 10-year landscaping and construction project that has resulted in 24 acres of lawns, waterfront esplanades, playgrounds and performance spaces.
"These projects reflect a primeval feeling we all share, that where there is water there should be park," said Henry J. Stern, the city's Parks Commissioner. "They also reflect the realization that first-rate parks need a substantially greater level of support than the city can provide on its own."
Despite the encouragement of the Mayor and his aides, and an injection so far of more than $6 million in city funds, the Battery Park project is not expected to receive nearly enough government support to cover its final price, estimated at $40 million. Patterned after such privately financed initiatives as the restoration of Bryant Park by its surrounding property owners, and the improvements to Central Park by the Central Park Conservancy, the project can succeed only with a huge infusion of corporate and philanthropic contributions, which have so far not materialized.
Less than a quarter of the money needed has been raised, but the Conservancy for Historic Battery Park, so named to distinguish itself from the newer expanse of park space in Battery Park City, is taking a step-by-step approach, hoping that contributions will flow and its work can be completed over a five-year schedule.
The first increment, completed last month, is a newly rebuilt riverfront esplanade, intended to resemble the walkway it joins at the southern border of Battery Park City. Other plans include new landscaping for the entire park, which would create a broad, unbroken expanse of lawn similar to the one in Bryant Park.
The park's 23 statues would be rearranged, with all but three lined up at the perimeter, along Battery Place and State Street, creating something called the Walk of Explorers and Defenders. Ultimately, in the most ambitious part of the project, the park's historically rich central fixture, Castle Clinton, would be rebuilt.
Transformation is nothing new for Castle Clinton, which was built as a fort for the War of 1812, was converted in later stages to a concert hall and an aquarium, was nearly destroyed by Robert Moses in 1941, and now is mainly used as an oversize ticket booth for ferries.
Although plans for the structure are in the early stages, officials of the conservancy said it would probably be enlarged by one or two floors, and a roof would be added to what is now a round stone fortress, open to the elements. Although such construction would radically alter the appearance of the old fort, conservancy officials said it would be restored to something closer to its earlier incarnation as a theater and cultural center. New Yorkers once came in droves to attend performances there staged by P. T. Barnum, including the American debut of Jenny Lind, the renowned "Swedish Nightingale," in 1850.
"This would be a restoration of former use, not of architecture," said Warrie Price, president of the conservancy. "We want to revitalize the castle's soul, and make it a destination point for New Yorkers."
Such grand designs may provide a test of private sector generosity, even at a time when huge gains on Wall Street and an ebullient city economy are fattening the coffers of philanthropic groups.
Unlike the Central Park Conservancy, with its projects supported by wealthy residents of Fifth Avenue and Central Park West, the conservancy working on Battery Park cannot lean heavily on the largess of its neighbors. And unlike Bryant Park, which was a notorious symbol of urban blight before its renovation in the late 1980's, Battery Park presents less civic urgency. It is less blighted than worn at the edges.
"The constituency for Battery Park has to be different," said William Rudin, a member of the Rudin real estate family, which owns five large commercial buildings in lower Manhattan, and has contributed more than $200,000, the largest private gift, to the Conservancy for Historic Battery Park.
Mr. Rudin said his family, spurred in part by its financial interests in lower Manhattan, had a more personal motive -- his great-grandparents, Louis and Rachel Rudin, who emigrated from Russia in the late 1880's, were among the 5 million immigrants processed through a receiving center at Castle Clinton in the almost 40 years before Ellis Island opened in 1892.
Now, four million people visit Battery Park each year, most of them to board ferries to the Federal landmarks on Ellis Island and Liberty Island. "I think it is almost embarrassing for the nation that they have to go through a place that needs a lot of work," Mr. Rudin said.
Even if the $40 million needed for the project can be raised, it remains unclear how much of it the city, state or Federal governments will contribute. Ms. Price said she expected the government to cover more than half the costs, but such support would only be granted if the city's private sector pitches in first with far more money that has already been raised.
"Private participation has got to drive the project," she said. "It has become very clear that Battery Park is important to the people of New York City."
One source of government support could be Congress, where Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, long an advocate of improving public access to the New York Harbor, is pressing for the Battery Park project to be included as a recipient in this year's Transportation funding bill. The project would qualify because the ferries to Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty would continue to take on passengers in the park.
In the meantime, officials of the newly formed conservancy said they would seize upon today's announcement by Mr. Giuliani to kick off a series of public events in the park that are designed to lure more New York City residents as visitors, and to drum up financial support.
The first event, a fund-raiser on June 1, is planned as an elegant waterfront dinner in the park, with seats priced at $400, $600, or $1,000. A series called New York Centennial Summer in the Battery, commemorating the 100th anniversary of the incorporation of the city's five boroughs, will include free lunch-time concerts in the park on Tuesdays and Thursdays, from June 16 to August 20.
On June 20, the conservancy will sponsor a benefit concert in the park by the folk rock singer Ani DiFranco. Tickets are $26.
In keeping with her group's step-by-step approach, Ms. Price said the immediate objective was to raise enough money -- $6 million -- to complete the next phase of the five-year project: the rebuilding of a corridor of green space, known as the Upper Promenade, above the park's esplanade.
She said the group is determined to have that work begun by the fall, and completed by July 4, 2000, when huge crowds are expected for fireworks over the Statue of Liberty.
"It simply must be done," she said. "How can we be the host of the eyes of the world without getting this job done?"

HEADLINE: Lettuce Is Available, But Costing More Green

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
As a rule, Mary Keselowsky of Oakhurst, N.J., serves salad to her husband and three children at dinner. But when the price of romaine lettuce recently climbed to $1.99 a head, double what Ms. Keselowsky usually pays for it, she refused to add it to her shopping cart.
Then, a few days later, finding no adequate substitute, she relented. 
 "My kids don't eat spinach," she said.
The heavy rains attributed to El Nino that have battered California in recent months have caused a lettuce scarcity throughout the nation, driving up the price of romaine and red- and green-leaf greens to as much as $4 a head and often forcing consumers to settle for inferior quality.
Stores from Los Angeles to New York have posted signs placing blame for the high price of lettuce and some other produce on weather conditions, and some consumers are either combing their neighborhoods in search of bargain lettuce or mixing cheaper substitutes like watercress into the salad bowl.
Others say salad prepared with lettuce is such a mainstay of their diet that they have no choice but to keep loading the costly and sometimes unsightly heads into their carts.
"Lettuce happens to be one of the healthiest foods," Elizabeth Rynkowsky said the other day as she shopped with her sister, Fannie, at a Food Emporium on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, where romaine was priced at $2.99 a head. "That's where they've got us," Fannie Rynkowsky added.
With romaine in short supply, some restaurants chains, like Sizzler, have tinkered with the composition of the salad bar by increasing the proportion of the more abundant iceberg lettuce while eliminating the pricier varieties. Other chains, like Wendy's and Ruby Tuesday, have stopped serving Caesar salads.
"We took Caesar salad off the menu about a week ago," said Rebecca Lusk, a spokeswoman for Wendy's, which has 4,500 restaurants around the country. "It was a supply issue. There wasn't enough quality product to supply the system."
But customers at fancier restaurants known for their Caesar salad will not have to do without it.
In recent weeks, Brian Searle, who buys produce for the "21" Club in Manhattan, has paid as much as $60 for a 24-head case of romaine lettuce. That is about four times the typical price, he said, and enough to prompt the restaurant to stop serving that variety at private parties unless it is specifically requested.
But a $13 Caesar salad is still being offered to the restaurant's customers. "If there's a blip on the lettuce screen, we're not going to change all the menus," said Jeffrey Sacchet, the manager of operations.
Nor are customers at Musso & Franks on Hollywood Boulevard in Los Angeles getting short-changed on their $11 Caesar salads, said John Garcia, the kitchen manager. "We're not going to cheat the customers," he said.
The spike in lettuce prices was caused by unusually heavy rains, which disrupted the lettuce-planting schedule in California, the source of most of the nation's supply, said Gary Lucier, an agricultural economist for the economic research service at the United States Department of Agriculture.
"Planting is a continual process," Mr. Lucier said. "If you interrupt that process, you pay for it."
Although prices appear to have peaked last week, and to have declined somewhat since, Mr. Lucier said shoppers could expect more fluctuation until about the second week in June. Prices will dip further between now and June, when the crop planted during the dry spells that punctuated the storms reaches the market, he said.
"What we're expecting is a roller coaster over the next month," Mr. Lucier said, "where prices go down and then go back up."
Some customers are astonished when they see the high prices.
"I've had people come up to me, point to the prices and say we've got to be kidding," said Kevin Krankall, produce clerk at Super Stop & Shop in Stratford, Conn.
Officials at several supermarket chains said they expected romaine prices to drop in a week or so as the New Jersey harvest goes to market. And although the rise in lettuce prices has been felt nationwide, the impact has been less pronounced in places where iceberg lettuce commands more respect.
Customers of the Kroger Company, which has 1,392 food stores in 26 states, mainly in the Midwest and the South, have been reacting calmly to the shortage of romaine and red-leaf lettuce, said a spokesman, Paul Bernish. "Keep in mind," he said, "that those varieties of lettuces represent only a fraction of what we sell in iceberg lettuce."
